HEADLINE: House Rejects a Proposal to Shift Military Money to Social Programs

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The House today decisively rejected a Democratic budget plan that would have shifted more than $6 billion in military savings to social programs next year by breaking the 1990 budget agreement between Congress and the White House.
The defeat had been expected by the Democratic leadership, which had delayed floor action on the bill for three weeks in a futile attempt to attract support from conservative and moderate Democrats. 
 But the margin of the defeat was wider than expected, underscoring the weakening of the leaders, who have come under heavy criticism for their handling of the scandals surrounding the House bank and the House post office. The plan was rejected by a vote of 238 to 187, with 76 Democrats joining 162 Republicans in opposing it. .
 
Paying Off the Deficit
 The debate that preceded the vote was highly partisan. Republicans said fiscal responsibility demanded that any savings from military cutbacks be applied to reducing the size of the Federal deficit, as the 1990 budget agreement provided. But Democrats who backed the proposal contended that they represented the interests of working-class and middle-class people trying to survive the recession.
"We must decide whether we stay on a cold-war footing or recognize that defense savings can be invested here at home for the first time in a half-century," said Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee.
The House action today followed the March 6 passage of the $1.26 trillion Democratic budget for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1. That budget resolution would cut Pentagon spending by $15 billion more than the $10 billion that the White House has proposed, and it offered two alternatives for $9 billion of the savings.
Under one of those alternatives, 70 percent of that money would have been reallocated to education, housing and other social programs. With that proposal defeated today, all the savings would now go toward deficit reduction.
The Senate has yet to pass a budget bill.

HEADLINE: Sanctions on Libya Likely To Fuel Qaddafi's Chaos

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 31

 BODY:
The United Nations sanctions imposed on Libya today appear likely to worsen the indecision and disorganization that are already hallmarks of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's 23-year rule.
But even though the stepped-up pressure may embolden competing factions within the Libyan Government in pursuing their divergent agendas, it is unclear whether the sanctions will bring about the kind of internal collision that the West appears to hope for as a prelude to the fall of Colonel Qaddafi. 
 Arab diplomats pointed out that Colonel Qaddafi has long proven adept at exploiting the seemingly chaotic divisions beneath him in the Libyan leadership.
"There are now pressures in Libya to change policies, but the larger truth is that Qaddafi holds all the strings, playing one group against the other," said Mansour Kikhia, a former Libyan Foreign Minister and now a member of the Libyan opposition living in exile here. "If there is one thing Qaddafi truly believes, it is that if you plant more confusion you defer problems."
 
Competing Tribal Clans
 The diplomatic negotiations of recent weeks, in which Libya sought a way out of the crisis brought on by the West's demand that it hand over two agents accused of the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, have already illustrated Libya's rising internal struggle, in which competing clans of tribal allies and army officers are vying to dominate Government policies.
The most powerful of the clans is a group led by Maj. Abusallam Jalloud, who is widely viewed as the Government's second-ranking official after Colonel Qaddafi. Major Jalloud -- thought to be Colonel Qaddafi's closest friend until just a few years ago, when the two apparently began to differ on policy -- has supported Islamic fundamentalists in Algeria at the same time Colonel Qaddafi urged their suppression.
A few days ago, even as Libyan Ambassadors were saying that they were willing to cooperate with the United Nations, Major Jalloud said Libya would burn its oilfields rather than yield to Western pressure.
Major Jalloud's influence rests on about 25,000 youthful armed members of so-called revolutionary committees, many of whom hail from the major's Al Majarhah tribe. His claim on power is considerable enough for Colonel Qaddafi to tolerate his public dissent.
 
Tolerable Hardships
 Another group ascendent in Libya politics is closely allied with neighboring Egypt and led by Ahmad Kaddafeddem, the Egyptian-born cousin of colonel Qaddafi. A third faction is led by the Colonel's brother-in-law, Addallah Senousi, who is one of his closest aides.
Mr. Kaddafeddema, man in his early 40's, is "general coordinator" of Egyptian-Libyan relations and until recently strongly advocated drawing closer to Cairo as a way to benefit from Egypt's close relationship with the United States and the West. Mr. Senousi also advocates closer ties with the West, but away from the tutelage of Egypt.
Libya has endured economic sanctions imposed by the United States and Britain for some time. Today's action by the United Nations widens the burden on Libya to include a ban on flights to or from the country, on bans on arms and aircraft sales, and a significant reduction in the number of Libyan diplomats in United Nations member countries. Those represent a tolerable increase in hardships for Libya, in the view of several Arab diplomats.
What really frightens Libyans is the prospect of a far more comprehensive international ban on trade with Libya, resembling the one observed now by the United States alone. If European countries, particularly Italy and Germany, were to stop the import of Libyan crude oil, such a ban would hurt the Libyan economy deeply.
Equally alarming to Tripoli is the prospect of seeing the country's considerable assets in Western Europe frozen or seized, much as Iraq's are. Those assets include oil refineries, a group of gasoline stations as well as a recently acquired share in a British hotel chain.
But Italy and Germany rely heavily on Libyan oil, partly because of the short shipping distance across the Mediterranean and partly because light Libyan crude is considered of high quality for refining. It would be more difficult for Italy and Germany to replace the one million barrels of oil a day they import from Libya than it would for Libya to find new customers.
Over the last few months, Libya has moved several billion dollars in deposits from Western Europe to banks in the Middle East and Asia. That may have protected the money, but it will severely hamper Libya's foreign transactions. Libya's awkward attempt today to block foreigners from leaving the country, which Arab diplomats say will certainly be rescinded, will frighten many of those who are still willing to travel to Libya to run its oil industry for high wages.
And the fear of a coup has led the Libyan leader to strip large segments of the Libyan armed forces of their weapons.
 
Crisis Might Aid Qaddafi
 "There is only one word I can use to describe the situation inside Libya today," said a senior Palestine Liberation Organization official in Tunis who has recently returned from Tripoli. "Panic."
Although there is little if any affection for Colonel Qaddafi within the Arab world and among Libya's population, the crisis may play to his favor at this delicate moment in the Middle East.
"We are opposed to the regime but not to our own country," Mr. Kikhia said. "We worry about sanctions or military actions that can only hurt the Libyan people. The issue in Libya is that people in this case think the West is out to get Libya, not Muammar Qaddafi and his clique."

HEADLINE: 'Free' Macedonia Faces Hostile World

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SKOPJE, Macedonia

 BODY:
In the tumult that has destroyed Yugoslavia, Macedonia has defied its bitter history of conflict by remaining at peace.
For 1,400 years, the Slavic people who live here in one of the most jealously eyed stretches of territory in the Balkans have had a host of distant conquerors. A strategic crossroads on the land routes that connect the Adriatic to the Black Sea, and Europe to the Middle East, Macedonia was a dominion of the Serbs, of the Ottoman Turks, and of the Nazis in World War II, among others, before it became a republic of Communist Yugoslavia in 1944. 
 Now, without the warfare that has killed as many as 10,000 people elsewhere in Yugoslavia, Macedonia stands on the brink of independence, as one of four republics that have voted to secede. Each day, trucks make the 310-mile journey from the Macedonian capital, Skopje, to Belgrade, the Yugoslav and Serbian capital, withdrawing men and equipment from the 40,000-member Yugoslav Army garrison.
 
Not Without Regret
 In many new nations, it would be a time for flags and anthems. But here, the mood is subdued, as though many of Macedonia's 2.3 million people feel that independence is coming at too high a price, and in a way that could yet generate problems more burdensome than half a century of Communism. At best, many of the government leaders responsible for establishing the new state appear to be going about their tasks reluctantly, with one eye on what the republic has lost.
"In the past, when I heard people talking about independence, I used to say, 'Quiet, quiet, we are not much bigger than a suburb of London or New York," said Jane Miljovski, a 44-year-old economics professor, who is also Minister for Privatization.
Ljubomir Frckovski, the Interior Minister, a constitutional law professor who is 34 years old, said, "We all feel some regrets."
So far, even the first steps toward creating a new country have been frustrated by the opposition of Macedonia's neighbors. On every side -- in Serbia, the core republic of what is left of Yugoslavia, in Albania, in Bulgaria and in Greece -- hostile forces are challenging Macedonia's right to independence directly or obliquely. The challenges come in ways that have reminded some pessimists in Skopje of the prelude to World War I, when the weakening grip of the Ottoman Turks made Macedonia the chief battleground in two Balkan wars.
 
A Challenge From Greece
 Bulgaria is one of four countries that have recognized Macedonia so far, but nationalists there, as in Albania and Serbia, have raised an argument traditionally wielded by rival claimants to Macedonian territory. They maintain that its peoples are not properly a distinct nation but belong, by language and culture, to one or another, or perhaps all three, of the neighboring Slavic states.
But the most direct challenge has come from Greece, which has said that it will never accept a new country on its northern border as long as it insists on calling itself Macedonia, which is also the name of the northernmost province of Greece. A Greek blockade has delayed or halted cargoes of food, oil, medicine and other imports bound for Skopje. Serbia, resentful at Macedonia's refusal to take part in a truncated Yugoslav federation, has imposed its own food blockade.
In Skopje, the atmosphere is rife with rumors of conspiracy and maneuver, much as it was a century ago, when nationalists mounted their first serious challenges to 500 years of Turkish rule. While the government has committed itself to creating a parliamentary democracy, including broader cultural and linguistic rights for 650,000 ethnic Albanians, more militant groups have pressed for narrower policies that opponents fear could turn into a settling of old scores, against pro-Yugoslav Serbs, Albanian nationalists, and former Communists.
Over cups of thick Turkish coffee that are a legacy of Ottoman rule, stubble-bearded men with high-buttoned, tieless shirts debate late into the night, and spend days writing polemics for an array of new newspapers and journals. Some fear that the manuevering will turn violent, as it did in the 1890's and early 1900's.
"It would take only one incident, and you could have a war between Bulgaria, Greece, Serbia and Albania, as happened twice in this century," said Saso Ordanoski, the 27-year-old assistant editor of Puls, a Skopje newsweekly. "Our only hope lies in creating an equilibrium, and for that we need independence and international recognition."
Since declaring independence in November, the Skopje government has remained in a diplomatic void. Through its membership in the European Community, Greece has so far prevented any of the leading European nations from recognizing Macedonia's independence.
The United States, which delayed recognizing the independence of any of the former Yugoslav republics as long as there was a chance of Yugoslavia's being rebuilt, said recently that it would relent in the case of Croatia and Slovenia, but that recognition of Macedonia would be "coordinated" with the European countries, implying that it must first settle its problems with Greece.
It is not only politicians in Skopje who seem ambivalent. In the city's old Turkish quarter, many of the cobblers, tinsmiths and jewelers who work in the wood-latticed storefronts of the old bazaar still display large framed photographs of Marshal Tito, the Communist leader whose death in 1980 began the unraveling of the Yugoslav federation.
 
No Choice, Leaders Say
 The Skopje leaders say the decision of the other Yugoslav republics to break away left them with no choice but to follow suit, but to have any chance of making their independence stand they will somehow have to assuage the grievances of Greece. To many Greeks, the only territory that has the right to the name Macedonia is the northern tier of Greece itself, from which the most fabled of all Macedonians, Alexander the Great and his father, Philip of Macedon, hailed.
Publicly, Greece has shown no sign of relenting, but a Greek diplomat in Belgrade said a compromise might be worked out if the Skopje government agreed to something it has so far refused, a change of its territory's name to the Slavic Republic of Macedonia, to distinguish it from the Greek province, which is inhabited predominantly by ethnic Greeks.
The diplomat suggested that a little knee-bending by Skopje might also help. "This pseudo little republic must stop irritating us," he said.

HEADLINE: It Was Libya, U.S. Insists. Syria? Iran? Probably Not.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
United States investigators insist that the evidence in the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 points so far to Libya, and only Libya.
But they acknowledge that a telling string of coincidence and circumstance continues to suggest that Iran and perhaps Syria may have played central roles. And they strongly deny that Iran or Syria have been excluded from their inquiry for political or diplomatic reasons.
 
The Detonator
 Libya was first tied to the Pan Am bombing in 1990, when investigators in Scotland found a fragment of the detonator that triggered the plastic explosive that destroyed the Pan Am 747 jet, killing 270. That fragment was identical to 10 detonators that had been seized from Libyan agents in Senegal in early 1988, 10 months before the Pan Am bombing. 
 When two senior Libyan intelligence officials were indicted for the bombing last November, the Justice Department also disclosed that it had obtained a diary showing that one agent had stolen luggage tags from Air Malta, enabling them to place the suitcase on a Malta flight that connected with Flight 103 in Frankfurt, Germany.
Those findings have convinced investigators that Libyans carried out the deed with the approval of their leader, Col. Moammar el-Qaddafi. One theory is that Colonel Qaddafi sought revenge for American air strikes against Tripoli and Benghazi in 1986.
Investigators concede, however, that they cannot rule out the participation of their original suspects -- Iran and Syria. For there is ample evidence that Iran sought to bomb an American passenger jet in the fall of 1988, and that Syrian terrorists were at work on a bomb plot similar to the one now linked to Libya.
 
The Other Suspects
 Iran was a prime suspect because it had an obvious motive: revenge for the accidental downing of an Iranian passenger jet carrying 290 persons in July 1988 by a United States Navy warship.
Investigators first concluded that Iran had contracted that summer with a Syria-based terrorist group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, to pay $10 million for a series of bombings.
That autumn, three months before the bombing, a West German cell of the Popular Front group constructed five plastic bombs that were concealed in radios, stereo equipment and other devices. But the plot was broken up by West German police in October and many members were jailed.
Investigators do not exclude the possibility that Iran then turned to Libya, but they say that they have no firm evidence.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Poll;
Clinton Dogged By Voter Doubt, Poll of U.S. Says

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
With only one Democratic opponent remaining on the field, Gov. Bill Clinton has gained the support of a bare majority of Democrats nationwide and his campaign continues to confront a cloud of doubts and reservations, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
In a month of fierce campaigning that knocked three of his opponents out of the race for the nomination, Mr. Clinton's support jumped to 51 percent from 28 percent among Democratic primary voters, the national poll found. But half said they worried that "allegations about Bill Clinton's character" could cost him the election this November. 
 Republicans have worries of their own. President Bush's approval rating remains stuck at 41 percent and fewer than one adult in five approves of his economic stewardship. Moreover, enthusiasm seems strained even among his Republican supporters, with only a third categorizing themselves as "strongly favorable" toward the President.
 
Hungry for Options
 The poll, a national survey that is not predictive of the primary in New York, showed an electorate that after months of campaigning remained uneasy with all of their Presidential candidates and hungry for more options. Most people said that Mr. Bush, Mr. Clinton and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California had not offered clear visions of what they hoped to accomplish over the next four years.
Sixty-seven percent of the Democratic primary voters said they would like to see someone else enter the race for the nomination, up from 52 percent who felt that way in late February. And when offered a trial heat that included H. Ross Perot, the Texas businessman who is considering entering the race, 44 percent of all registered voters chose Mr. Bush, 31 percent chose Mr. Clinton and 16 percent Mr. Perot. Mr. Perot drew slightly more support away from Mr. Clinton than from Mr. Bush.
The survey, conducted by telephone with 1,638 adults, reflects the unsettled state of the Democratic race as it heads into next Tuesday's primaries in New York, Wisconsin and Kansas. Still, the poll measures national trends, and its findings are not directly transferrable to the upcoming contests in those three states. The poll, conducted Thursday though Sunday, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Clinton has clearly broken from the pack in the public's mind since his sweep of Southern primaries on March 10, followed by his big victories in Michigan and Illinois that drove former Senator Paul E. Tsongas from the race. Mr. Clinton is now the choice of 51 percent of the Democratic primary voters, compared to 30 percent who preferred Mr. Brown.
But even as favorable opinion about Mr. Clinton grew in his party, so did the unfavorable: 33 percent of the Democratic primary voters nationally said they viewed him positively, while 28 percent held negative views.
Among all registered voters, only 24 percent said they viewed the Arkansas Governor favorably, while 41 said they held negative views, a worrisome ratio for any politician. The view of Mr. Bush is evenly divided: 42 percent favorable, 41 percent unfavorable.
Mr. Clinton is considered to be more caring than Mr. Bush "about the needs and problems" of average people, the poll found. But Mr. Clinton has clearly suffered from the months of controversy over accusations that he manipulated his draft status, had extramarital affairs and was involved in a conflict of interest because of his wife's partnership in a law firm that does business with the State of Arkansas.
Only 26 percent of registered voters said they thought Mr. Clinton had more honesty and integrity than most people in public life, while 54 percent said he did not. These are the kind of attitudes that trouble many political professionals in the Democratic Party, although Mr. Clinton asserts it is the inevitable result of months of bad press, and can be turned around.
When offered a head-to-head match with Mr. Bush, 49 percent of registered voters chose Mr. Bush and 40 percent chose Mr. Clinton, about the same result as last month.
While Mr. Clinton is clearly worried about the outcome in New York, this poll shows him with a substantial edge over Mr. Brown among Democrats nationwide. The former California Governor, despite his new status as the sole Clinton alternative, still has more critics than friends in his own party. Twenty-one percent of the Democrats expressed favorable opinions of Mr. Brown, while 27 percent expressed unfavorable.
More than half of the Democrats also felt that Mr. Brown spent his time "attacking" Mr. Clinton rather than "explaining" what he would do as President. But the poll suggested that Mr. Brown was seen as a useful vehicle for protest -- not unlike the way Patrick J. Buchanan was viewed among Republicans in other polls.
For example, 64 percent of the Democratic primary voters agreed that "Jerry Brown is saying some things that Bill Clinton needs to hear." And 67 percent of those voters said they agreed with Mr. Brown that the political system was corrupt.
Mr. Brown's pet proposal, replacing the progressive income tax system with a 13 percent flat tax, drew a mixed response. Six out of 10 adults nationwide said they thought the present system was unfair, but only 26 percent said they thought Mr. Brown's solution would be more equitable. Thirty-three percent said they though it would be less fair. Forty-nine percent said they thought Mr. Brown's system would most benefit the rich.
People also offered mixed views about the effect of Mr. Clinton's character issues. Only 11 percent of the Democratic primary voters said such accusations would make them choose someone else. But a much greater group said they worried about the effect of this political baggage on other people.
And there was also evidence of a backlash: 59 percent of Democratic primary voters said too much time and attention had been spent on accusations about Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Bush got some unwelcome news in this poll: 43 percent of the registered voters said they trusted Congress to best deal with domestic problems, compared to 38 percent who most trusted the Bush Administration.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers Measure of Approval to Romania

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Romania, the former Communist country most regarded with suspicion by the United States, is receiving a measure of approval from Washington for recent steps it has taken toward a more democratic government.
"Progress has occurred in Romania," said an Administration official who specializes in Balkan affairs. "The situation is by no means perfect, but they have made progress." 
 On the strength of such an assessment, the Bush Administration announced earlier this month that it is prepared to sign a new trade agreement with Romania and to accord Bucharest "most favored nation" treatment, the normal tariff advantages extended to the United States' best trading partners.
Romania received those benefits from 1975 to 1988, when they were renounced by President Nicolae Ceausescu in defiance of United States demands that he improve Bucharest's human rights record. The preferences had fostered $1 billion in trade annually in the 1980's.
After the overthrow and execution of Mr. Ceausescu in December 1989, the group that seized power in Bucharest, the National Salvation Front, included a number of prominent former Communists. Front candidates won overwhelming endorsement in national elections in May 1990 that were marred by intimidation of other parties. Subsequent clashes in which opponents of the National Salvation Front were beaten and jailed drew sharp criticism from the United States.
But local elections in February, according to a State Department spokesman, met "generally accepted international standards." The spokesman went on to commend Prime Minister Theodor Stolojan for his role in guiding Romania "toward a market economy and democratic pluralism."
The local elections, the first free voting on this level since before World War II, gave the opposition Democratic Convention alliance 24 percent of the vote while the National Salvation Front won 33 percent nationwide.
Romania now appears to be set on a path toward greater political diversity and possibly a change of power emerging from national elections, which are tentatively scheduled for June.
Already the Salvation Front, whose ranks are filled with former Communists, has split into factions. One is headed by President Ion Iliescu, the other by former Prime Minister Petre Roman, who was ousted last fall after a miners' strike. At the Front's recent convention, Mr. Roman was named chairman while Mr. Iliescu, who had sought to be the party's candidate for president, was rebuffed.
Administration officials said that they were still concerned about the Government monopoly on television broadcasting, the absence of parliamentary control over the intelligence service and abuses of human rights.
The officials acknowledged that there were now enough independent newspapers in Romania to establish a free press, although there are still shortages of newsprint and insufficient means of distribution.
As for the Romanian Intelligence Service, formed in 1990 after the dreaded Securitate of the Ceausescu regime was abolished, an Administration official said there were "quite credible complaints that they are still involved in political surveillance." The intelligence service reports directly to President Iliescu, although Parliament passed a law in February asserting legislative control over it.
In the area of human rights, the Administration has voiced concerns to the Bucharest Government about expressions of anti-Semitism.
Administration officials said they expected the White House would send the new trade agreement to Congress soon for its approval, but that no legislative action could be expected until after Romania's national elections.
In another mark of acceptance, the Administration has sent John R. Davis, a Foreign Service officer with East European experience, as the new United States Ambassador to Bucharest. In turn, Bucharest is dispatching Aurel Dragos Munteanu, a writer who opposed the Ceausescu regime, as Romania's Ambassador to Washington.

HEADLINE: Security Council Votes to Prohibit Arms Exports and Flights to Libya

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 31

 BODY:
The Security Council voted today to impose a ban on air travel and arms sales against Libya in two weeks and other sanctions unless it surrenders agents implicated in the bombings of a Pan Am flight over Scotland in 1988 and a French airliner over West Africa the next year.
The vote in the 15-nation Council was 10 in favor with five abstentions. Abstaining were China, which as a permanent member of the Council could have vetoed today's decision; Morocco, the Council's only Arab member, and three other third-world countries: India, Cape Verde and Zimbabwe. The five said they favored delaying an ultimatum to Libya to allow more time for a negotiated settlement. 
 Voting in favor were the Council's other four permanent members -- the United States, Britain, France and Russia -- along with Austria, Belgium, Ecuador, Hungary, Japan and Venezuela.
Today's resolution passed by just one vote more than the minimum of nine required for approval -- a show of support smaller than the margins mustered for any of the resolutions dealing with Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis. [Text of resolution, page A12.]
Unlike the sanctions against Iraq, the measures approved today would not affect the export of oil, Libya's main economic resource.
The Council acted despite pleas for a delay from the Arab League, the Organization of Islamic States and the Maghreb Union of North African countries. They warned that the sanctions would risk arousing politically destabilizing passions throughout the Arab world.
 
Demand for Suspects
 But Council members emphasized that under the resolution, Libya still had until April 15 to comply with their demands. The Council has demanded that Libya hand over to the United States or Britain two Libyans accused in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. In addition, it wants Tripoli to turn over four other Libyans to the French authorities investigating the 1989 downing of U.T.A. flight 772 over the Sahara. A total of 440 people from some 30 countries died in the two disasters.
The resolution also would require Libya not only to "commit itself definitively" to renouncing terrorism but also to demonstrate its "renunciation of terrorism" by unspecified "concrete actions."
If Tripoli fails to meet the April 15 deadline, all member countries of the United Nations would be required under the resolution to sever air links with Libya, close Libyan airline offices on their territory, stop servicing Libyan aircraft and halt sales of planes and spare parts to Libya. The sale of arms to Libya would also be banned. And governments would be required to expel many Libyan diplomats and restrict the movement of those allowed to remain.
Wearing black for mourning, relatives of some of the 270 victims of the Pan Am bombing watched from the visitors' gallery as the Council voted.
Bruce Smith, a former Pan Am pilot whose wife, Ingrid, died aboard Flight 103, said he felt the resolution was a "significant milestone."
"It is satisfying on both a personal and professional level," he said. "It's a good step for the aviation industry that something like this is being done to counter international terrorism and I feel we are doing something about formulating the solution."
He was one of 10 former Pan Am employees at the United Nations to "remember the passengers and the crew" of Pan Am 103.
But other relatives said the Council did not go far enough. Some said they would like to see the United Nations "get tough" not only on Libya but Syria and Iran.
"We'd like to see a total economic embargo against Libya -- an oil embargo would be just the beginning of what would be necessary," said William Hochswender, whose nephew, Julian Benello, 25 years old, was on the Pan Am jet.
Hours before the vote, Western diplomats said Libya was preventing some foreigners from leaving the country, raising concerns that they could be held as hostages. Libya denied it was interfering with departures.
The State Department said none of the 500 to 1,000 Americans in the country was encountering such trouble.
 
Land Borders Closed
 The ban on flights to and from Libya means that people who want to leave would have to take boats; there is regular ferry service between Tripoli and Malta.
Late last year the Libyan Government said it was closing its land borders to foreigners wishing to leave the country, though it was not clear whether travelers could still enter Libya by land. Cairo is more than 1,200 miles from Tripoli; Tunis is at least 400 miles away.
The airlines chiefly affected by the air-travel sanctions would be Swissair, Lufthansa, KLM and Alitalia, which fly regularly to and from Libya, as well as Libyan Arab Airlines, the country's national carrier.
The resolution provides for the sanctions to be reviewed by the Council at least every four months. It says that countries suffering economic hardship as a result of them, like neighboring Egypt and Tunisia, which fear Libya might expel their nationals working there, may appeal to the Council for compensation.
 
Campaign Against Terrorism
 The chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said the issue the Council faced was whether "the international community is prepared to back up its own words with actions and demonstrate that it will protect itself against a state that engages in terrorism."
France's representative, Jean-Bernard Merimee, said that by affecting Libya's armaments, aviation and diplomatic personnel, the sanctions would directly hurt three of the instruments it uses to support international terrorism. But he indicated that the Council would relax the air-traffic ban against Tripoli to allow Libyan pilgrims to make the annual pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia.
Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, stressed "the very great importance" London attaches to Libya providing concrete evidence that it has renounced terrorism. Although he did not say what evidence Britain wanted, he listed several Libyan arm shipments intercepted on their way to the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army as well as the fatal shooting of a police officer, Yvonne Fletcher, in 1984 by a gunman inside the Libyan Embassy in London.
The requirement that Libya demonstrate its renunciation of terrorism by "concrete actions" has aroused speculation that the United States, Britain and France might demand names of terrorists trained and armed by Libya as well as details of past terrorist operations it was involved in as a condition for lifting sanctions.
 
Fate of Qaddafi
 Since Libya would presumably be reluctant to provide such information, some diplomats argue that the sanctions are likely to prove more difficult to lift than to impose, and could become bound up with the personal fate of Col. Muammer el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, as those imposed on Iraq are becoming wound up with the fate of President Saddam Hussein.
Libya's representative, Ali Ahmed el-Houderi, as well as the representatives of many of the Arab and Islamic groups that took the floor in Libya's defense today, argued that the dispute over the airline bombings has become a legal one over whether Libya should try those accused of terrorist attacks instead of extraditing them, which it contends it has a right to do.
Since Libya has already asked the International Court of Justice at the Hague to rule on that issue, they said the Security Council should at least delay a decision on sanctions until the Court has given its verdict, although that could take months.
But the United States, France and Britain said the Security Council had a duty to deal with actions threatening peace and security in the world and argued that a country accused of such behavior cannot prevent the Council taking action against it simply by appealing to the World Court.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Urban Problems;
Democratic Foes Harmonize On Need to Give Aid to Cities

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Facing mayors for a dialogue on urban problems, and then each other in a debate on the same topic in the Bronx, the Democratic Presidential contenders expressed broad agreement yesterday that cities needed more help from Washington, which, each said, he would deliver as President.
But each candidate cast the issue in the image of his own campaign, Bill Clinton insisting that urban problems were really American problems and Edmund G. Brown Jr. arguing that cities were just another casualty of politics as usual.
 
Differing on Welfare
 Summoned to a 75-minute exchange at Gracie Mansion, led by Mayor David N. Dinkins and Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, the candidates were peppered with questions on topics like housing and crime by a dozen other mayors from Cincinnati to Puerto Rico. They responded with answers so generally similar that Mayor Dave Karp of San Leandro, Calif., described them afterwards as "the Bobbsey twins." 
 Mr. Clinton's strategists, fearful that they have lost control of the dynamic of the campaign as the primary approaches, are seeking to use these appearances with Mr. Brown to cast him as a candidate whose outrage, appealing to many voters, cloaks dangerous policy ideas. They also hope these appearances will allow them to climb above the uproar of the New York press. [News analysis, page A21.]
Hours after leaving Gracie Mansion, in the debate at Lehman College in the Bronx, the two candidates drew some sharper distinctions on welfare, gun control and other issues.
Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, said he would probably grant New Jersey's application for a waiver from Federal welfare rules that would allow it to refuse making additional payments to women who have children while on welfare. But Mr. Brown, the former Governor of California, said he would not. Mr. Brown said a five-year moratorium on the manufacture of handguns was "Not a bad idea; let's try it," but Mr. Clinton said that was not the answer.
Both candidates made it clear that they would propose substantial changes in the way the Federal Government treats cities if they won the Presidency after 12 years of Republican rule. And their exchanges were staid by the standards of some of their recent skirmishes.
Yesterday, Mr. Brown repeatedly said the answer to the nation's urban ills was a restructuring of what he described as a corrupt political system ruled by the "governing elite." Mr. Clinton ticked off specific programs that he said he would enact to help the cities, like a national health service corps to set up clinics to help the poor.
At both events, Mr. Clinton made a point of saying that Mr. Brown's proposal to discard the tax code and impose a flat 13 percent income tax would be a disaster for New York and other places with high state and local taxes.
Mr. Brown tended to answer the mayors' queries on whether he would support new Government spending programs with quick assents like "Sure," and "Of course," while Mr. Clinton was more measured, reciting laundry lists of specific programs for job training, tax credits and private investments.
 
'I Don't Buy It'
 After the mayors' forum, Mr. Flynn, the president of the United States Conference of Mayors, who has been seeking more discussion of urban problems in the campaign, said the exchange was fruitful. "They understand the agonies and they feel the pain," he said.
But other questioners were nonplussed.
"It can't be as simple as get those guys out and put me in and everyone will have steak and potatoes and two cars in the garage," said Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, one of six black mayors on the panel, who asked the candidates what they would do about growing racial divisions and crime. "I don't buy it. The code word is tax breaks to the middle class, and that won't do it."
The mix of Mr. Clinton's vaguely specific proposals and Mr. Brown's specifically vague exhortations left Mayor Dwight Tillery of Cincinnati undecided and unimpressed.
"What I find is that it's very difficult to get the specificity from these guys," he said. "I don't walk away with the sense that Clinton really understands that American cities are falling. He doesn't seem willing to alienate what he calls the middle class. Maybe he's done his research, and found that city people don't turn out to vote in great numbers. But a great politician would reach out and galvanize people who have dropped out of the political process. Jerry Brown has more fire in the belly. At this point, I don't feel I have much of a choice."
 
Jackson Watches Quietly
 The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who passed up the chance to run for mayor of Washington and for President but remains a powerful presence courted by both candidates, sat on the sidelines as a silent observer yesterday at the forum. But he praised the candidates for forsaking personal attacks and addressing urban needs.
There were disagreements, of course. Mr. Brown said he would redirect 50 percent of the military budget to domestic needs over the next five years, while Mr. Clinton said he would cut it by 36 percent. Mr. Brown expressed unequivocal support for bills pending in Congress that would direct some $15 billion in aid to cities to counter the effects of the recession, while Mr. Clinton said he supported the notion but would have to see how specific appropriations would affect the rest of the Federal budget first.
The candidates' biggest policy difference remains over Mr. Brown's call for scrapping the Federal tax code and replacing it with a 13 percent flat tax on income and what would amount to a 13 percent value added tax on sales. Mr. Clinton said that would be a disaster for high-tax cities like New York by eliminating the deductibility of state and local taxes, a position Mr. Dinkins has previously seconded.
If the candidates seemed to be trying to be all things to all mayors, it may have been at least partly because the profile of their questioners' cities varied from Mr. Dinkins's eight million stories in New York City to Mayor Shawn Hogan's 9,877 souls in Hornell in upstate Steuben County.
Mayor Karp of San Leandro leads a city of 70,000 just south of Oakland in the San Francisco Bay area.
He said afterward: "One thing that caught me is there's a major difference between urban problems and rural problems. But not, it seems, in the eyes of Clinton."
Asked in the debate by Roz Abrams of WABC-TV what he would do to bring industry back to the cities, Mr. Brown hesitated, saying, "That's a pretty big order here."
"But you want to be President," Ms. Abrams responded.
Mr. Brown then said, "It's going to take a kind of commitment that we don't have."

Chart: "The Democratic Candidates' Views on Urban Issues"
 Urban issues took center stage yesterday for the first time in the Presidential campaign, forcing the two leading candidates for the Democratic nomination to present their positions on a variety of issues of concern to cities. From position papers and statements, this is a synopsis of their views.
 
GOV. BILL CLINTON:
 
Employment
Calls for expansion of job training and mentoring programs, tax credits to make entry-level jobs more attractive. Has made a major issue of welfare reform, with able-bodied recipients receiving education and job training and then being required to take jobs, with the government as employer of last resort.
Analysis: He has not taken a position on plans backed by many mayors to provide municipalities with $15 billion or in recession aid.
 
Housing
Would give 10 percent of federally owned housing stock as well as housing on closed military bases to community groups to house the homeless. Would encourage resident ownership of low-income housing, insure adequate funding financing for maintenance of subsidized housing, hold a "housing and homelessness summit" with goal of creating "a new consensus for poverty programs, funding levels, and Federal assistance for innovative housing crisis solutions."
Analysis: Mr. Clinton says it would take years to restore funds for subsidized housing, deemed vital for the cities, to their pre-Reagan Administration levels.
 
Crime and Drugs
 Favors Federal matching grants for cities with "comprehensive crime control plans" that include "a significant increase in the size of the police force," as well as concepts such as like community policing, with a particular emphasis on school safety. Supports death penalty, the use of which he has authorized in Arkansas; the Brady Bill, which requires a five-day waiting period for the purchase of a handgun.
 Analysis: His police proposals would reward many Dinkins Administration initiatives. He last declined to intervene in the use of the death penalty last January against in the case of a man who shot himself in the head after he killed a police officer.
 
AIDS
 Said of AIDS, "It would become part of my obsession as President." Says he favors expanding clinical definition of AIDS in a way that would include more women and intravenous drug users, institution of several programs proposed by two government AIDS panels.
 Analysis: Despite a highly publicized confrontation with an AIDS activist last week, Mr. Clinton would no doubt win overwhelming gay support if nominated.
 
EDMUND G. BROWN Jr.
 
Employment
 Supports a roughly $30 billion package proposed by the U.S. Conference of Mayors that includes direct aid to cities, public works and transportation financing, and low-interest small business loans. Pushes idea of urban enterprise zones in which businesses would be given incentives to invest, and massive energy conservation program through which, he says, large numbers of jobs would be created.
 Analysis: Who pays for this?
 
Housing
 Supports community-based housing initiatives for homeless, but specific ideas unclear. More generally, endorses heavy cuts in defense funding and transfer of funds to domestic programs. "Our crisis is not the dead Soviet empire," he said two days ago in Manhattan. "It's the turbulence, bitterness, despair, and alienation in every city in America."
 Analysis: New York, above all American cities, has coveted Federal housing money and welcomed subsidized housing; the national program, severely cut during the Reagan and Bush Administrations, was born here more than 50 years ago. Mr. Borwn's positions lack precision.
 
Crime and Drugs
 Opposes death penalty and supports Brady Bill. While pointing to numerous tough crime bills he signed as California Governor, which he says led to longer sentences and thousands more imprisoned convicts, he maintains that fundamental answer to crime and drugs is income support and jobs. "You can't have one out of five kids born in poverty and not expect to see drugs sold," he has said. "I put drugs in the larger context."
 Analysis: Larger context is huge and expensive. What's his opinion of community policing and other initiatives that have received great play since he was Governor?
 
AIDS
 Even before the Academy Awards wore the red ribbon of concern over AIDS crisis. Calls for more research and a national health care system that will cover the costs of the ill.
 Analysis: Again, specifics of what he would do are a question, but many AIDS activists believe they can work with him and Clinton alike. (pg. A21)

HEADLINE: I.M.F. ENDORSES RUSSIAN PLAN FOR ECONOMY, CLEARING WAY FOR AID AND FOR MEMBERSHIP

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund said today that it had endorsed Russia's economic reform plan, paving the way for Moscow to receive up to $4 billion in I.M.F. aid over the next year.
I.M.F. officials say Russia could begin receiving loans from the fund as early as May, a move that will place the Russian economy to some extent under the stewardship of the I.M.F. It will still require Moscow to meet certain conditions to qualify for the aid, including stringent targets to control the inflation rate and budget deficit. 
 The decisions bring Moscow to the verge of membership in the I.M.F., a major step toward eventual integration of the Russian economy with the West, continuing a process begun five years ago by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the former Soviet Union.
 
Joining in Late April
 The relationship could lead to future strains between Russia and the I.M.F. as Moscow struggles to stabilize its economy and maintain control over its own affairs and the Fund is likely to link continued assistance on further belt tightening.
I.M.F. officials say they expect Russia and most of the other 14 former Soviet republics to join the fund in late April, with I.M.F. aid to the new members beginning soon afterward. Aid to the other former republics aside from Russia could total about $2.3 billion over the next year.
All together Russia and the other former republics could qualify for as much as $18 billion in I.M.F. aid over the next three years. But this sum is contingent on an increase in international support for the Fund, including a $12 billion contribution from the United States. The White House and Congress have hesitated to push for the money in an election year when foreign aid of any kind is considered unpopular.
 
Aid Package Announcement
 President Bush is expected to announce on Wednesday a large-scale aid package to help Russia and the other republics. Administration officials say the President will urge Congress to authorize about $600 million in technical and humanitarian assistance, an American contribution toward a multibillion dollar international fund to stabilize the ruble and the additional $12 billion contribution to the I.M.F.
So far, Germany is the leading financial contributor to the former Soviet Union, having provided about $35 billion, but much of that is earmarked to help Soviet troops leave what was formerly East Germany. The German contribution represents about half of the Western aid given to the former Soviet Union.
Discussion of American aid to Russia has been muted so far in this year's Presidential election campaign, but the Administration and the Democrats are giving signs that they will soon begin paying more attention to it. The issue was raised earlier this month when former President Richard M. Nixon circulated a memorandum in which he criticized the United States for not seizing the opportunity to offer more help to President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Russia's move toward a market economy has involved removing most price controls, privatizing many small businesses, giving enterprises more freedom and slashing the republic's budget deficit.
As a result of the reforms, many factories have laid off workers, prices for bread and meat have soared, and pensions of the elderly have fallen far behind inflation.
The meeting today was the first between the I.M.F.'s executive board and representatives of the Russian Government. The fund's members praised Russia's reform program, but criticized it for having an inadequate safety net for pensioners and for not reducing its budget deficit and expanding money supply fast enough.
Once Russia joins the I.M.F., fund officials will ask Moscow to refine its reform program further. Then the I.M.F. board will vote once more on the program before releasing money.
I.M.F. executives also called on Russia today to move faster to raise its energy prices to world levels and to reduce trade barriers with other republics of the former Soviet Union.
"These are the alarm bells people are still talking about," said one senior I.M.F. official. "But they're doing a good job. We know it's tough. They can't backtrack. They have to stick with it."
 
Russia Offered a Stake
 In another important decision that was the subject of weeks of debate, the I.M.F. executive board agreed to offer Russia a 3 percent ownership stake in the fund, which is like a cooperative bank in which each member country contributes a share of the capital. This would give Russia a larger quota than China and the largest quota in the fund after the Group of Seven industrial nations and Saudi Arabia.
To join the fund, Russia will be called on to contribute just under $4 billion. Under I.M.F. rules, Russia can contribute about $3.1 billion of this in its own currency and the rest, about $900 million, in hard currency. I.M.F. officials say Russia will borrow or receive as grants most of this $900 million.
I.M.F. officials said they were confident that Russia would accept the membership terms. But they said specific membership quotas still had to be determined for the other 14 former Soviet republics, including Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. I.M.F. officials said all 15 republics would be offered a membership stake totalling about 4.75 percent. This would mean they would be called on to make a $6.3 billion contribution to the fund.
Since countries are allowed to borrow amounts equal to their membership contribution during their first year of membership, the 14 republics other than Russia might be able to borrow up to $2.3 billion from the fund over the next year.
The I.M.F. usually makes loans for what it calls "emergency balance-of-payment support." This means that the money usually goes to finance imports of machinery, fuel or fertilizer needed to increase production.
In return, however, countries that receive I.M.F. loans agree to meet certain economic targets. I.M.F. officials said the agreement with Moscow would include targets on reducing the republic's inflation rate, budget deficit, money supply growth, and balance-of-payments deficit.
If a nation fails to satisfy its targets, then the I.M.F. often will suspends its aid program. Normally, a year's worth of aid is disbursed quarter-by-quarter.
According to fund officials, there is much flexibility in whether they suspend aid. One official said that if world oil prices were to plummet, causing Russia's trade deficit to miss its target, the I.M.F. would not necessarily suspend aid.
I.M.F. officials praised the Russian government for making major progress in all of these areas, but emphasized the importance of restraining the budget deficits and monetary growth in order to prevent hyperinflation.
"The I.M.F. commends the Government of the Russian Federation for launching a bold and comprehensive economic reform program," Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, said today in a statement. "If fully implemented, it will lay the foundation for an economic program that the I.M.F. could support with its financial resources once Russia becomes a member of the institution."
 
Endorsement Not Essential
 I.M.F. officials said that receiving the fund's endorsement of a country's economic program is not essential for that country to become a member, but is essential to receive aid.
"They can join even if they don't have their program endorsed, but it certainly makes everyone feel better about it," said one I.M.F. executive board member who insisted that his name not be used.
In 1990, the United States backed a plan to increase the I.M.F.'s funding by $60 billion, but the Government has not yet approved its $12 billion share in that funding increase. I.M.F. officials say the additional funding is needed to help them finance the huge aid being demanded by the former Soviet republics, Eastern Europe and the nations of the third world.
The I.M.F. estimates that Russia needs $12 billion in balance-of-payments support this year, and another $6 billion to finance a fund to stabilize the ruble.
American official say their $600 million humanitarian and technical assistance will help reduce Russia's balance-of-payments needs. For example, by providing Russia with some medicine as part of its humanitarian aid program, Washington would reduce Russia's need to use hard currerncy to buy medicine.
 
Can Reschedule Debts
 I.M.F. officials said their endorsement of Russia's program was important because Western creditor nations saw that endorsement as a condition for a new rescheduling of Russia more than $60 billion in foreign debt. Russian officials say postponing their interest payments on this debt could save them $3.5 billion a year.
I.M.F. officials said that over the next 10 days the fund's executive board will seek to determine the membership quotas for the 14 other republics. The quotas are usually determined according to a nation's economic output, but fund officials said it would be hard to calculate quotas for the republics because of a lack of solid economic data.
Fund executives said the dispute over what Russia's membership share should be threatened to delay its joining the fund. China, with a 2.5 percent share, was said to be reluctant to concede Russia a larger share, but Russian officials said that as a matter of pride, they deserved at least 3 percent. The Netherlands, for example, has a 2.37 percent share.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
Cuomo's Freudian Slips: Desire, or Just Fatigue?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
Mario Cuomo's Freudian slip has been showing again.
New York's militantly unpresidential Governor addressed a group of Puerto Rican and Hispanic leaders in Albany this week. He began with a few words about his life in politics. 
 "When I got elected Presid -- " he said, before catching himself. "I mean Governor. Sorry," the flushed and embarrassed leader of New York quickly shouted as his audience drowned him in applause.
"That was God saying, 'Mario, it's time to rest,' " Mr. Cuomo quickly added.
Earlier in March, Mr. Cuomo spoke at a breakfast of labor leaders. He described his plans for New York's economic recovery this way: "As I said in my State of the Union speech this year -- " Again he stopped, corrected himself and forged ahead.
On Monday, Mr. Cuomo announced that he would travel to California next week to speak at the state Democratic convention, and the political world once again plunged into the unusual contours of Mr. Cuomo's mind.
Yesterday, however, responding to what he called unfounded speculation that he might be trying to revive the never-quite-dead Mario scenario for a brokered Democratic National Convention, Mr. Cuomo canceled his trip.
 
Expecting Applause, Drawing a Gasp
 Brooklyn and Bill Clinton just don't seem to mix.
The Arkansas Governor passed a rare, heckle-free afternoon there last weekend. But then he got an eerie lesson in the Byzantine complexity of New York politics.
He had just finished entertaining 100 local community leaders at the Prospect Park West home of Representative Charles E. Schumer. Clearly pleased with his reception and the day so far, he mentioned casually that he was on to the next event, an award dinner where the guest of honor would be Mr. Schumer's Congressional colleague, Representative Steven J. Solarz.
The crowd grew silent and then let out a collective gasp.
Mr. Clinton looked puzzled, clearly unaware that despite their political similarities, their Brooklyn and Jewish backgrounds, and their many identical stances, the two Congressmen would have long ago dueled at dawn if elected leaders permitted themselves to express animosity in such a traditional fashion.
 
Wait Till Fall, Say Perot Backers
 H. Ross Perot has the hottest "800" number in the business, truckloads of money and, in the "Year of the Outsider," he is the last legitimate link to Bat Masterson.
But Mr. Perot, who has started to run an independent race for the White House, has never come up against the arcane and antedeluvian intricacies of New York State election law.
To appear on the ballot here in the fall, Mr. Perot will have to accumulate at least 20,000 signatures from registered voters who do not vote in the April 7 primary. He can't start trying until July, and he has to be finished by August.
"What we will have to do is gather every signature we can and then sort it out afterward to find those that are legal," said Thomas Barr, one of New York's most prominent corporate lawyers, who has often represented Mr. Perot.
 
Musical Chairs But No Harmony
 So you thought it was tough assigning seats for the Paris peace talks?
Try a Presidential debate. Bill Clinton's advance men assaulted Gracie Mansion yesterday like a S.W.A.T. team on the trail of Abu Nidal.
The mayoral residence looked like an armed camp, as more than 100 police officers, equipped with a mobile headquarters and satellite-transmission capability, surrounded the mansion where the debate took place.
Initially, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and Mr. Clinton were seated between Mayor David N. Dinkins and his counterpart from Boston, Raymond L. Flynn.
Then the Clinton team went to work. First they took over chairs reserved for the press, writing "Clinton Staff" over the tags that were already attached. Then they turned tothe horseshoe-shaped dais. They did not want Mr. Brown sitting next to their candidate, so they decided to have each candidate flank Mayor Dinkins. Mr. Flynn was moved to Mr. Clinton's left.
"This is like a bar mitzvah," said an exasperated Jackie Friedman of the Mayor's office of special events. Mrs. Friedman, who is married to the former Bronx political boss Stanley Friedman, ought to know. She's been around bar mitzvahs and politics for a long time.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Pleas Amid a Vote by N.H.L. Players As New Strike Deadline Approaches

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
With hockey players voting on a collective bargaining agreement, and a strike scheduled for 3 P.M. today, the leaders of both union and management appealed to the fans and the work force yesterday afternoon in an emotional display of public passion and persuasion.
Sounding like candidates for public office, the president of the league and the executive director of the Players Association held separate news conferences in Toronto that were televised nationally in Canada. 
 The National Hockey League president, John Ziegler, and the Players Association director, Bob Goodenow, also spoke privately yesterday morning and said they planned to do the same last night. Meanwhile, player representatives of the 22 teams oversaw secret balloting on an offer from the owners that has been unanimously rejected by the players' bargaining committee.

 
 
Willing to Keep Talking
 Goodenow said none of the votes would be announced until late this afternoon, but word began to trickle out Tuesday night from at least two teams that the owners' last offer would be turned down by the players. One Canadian-based team rejected the contract by 22-0. A United States-based team turned it down by 19-2. "If the owners thought the union was weakening, they were badly mistaken," said one union activist.
Asked if a strike could be avoided if the players rejected the proposal, Goodenow answered: "I don't think so." Ziegler vowed to do his best to avoid the first leaguewide work stoppage in the N.H.L.'s 75-year history.
"I'll talk right up until the walk," said Ziegler, who added that the owners can't afford to give much more than they have offered.
"There's always room for talks," he said. "There isn't much room economically. You're asking people who back this game to lose substantial personal fortunes. This isn't a bluff. They may have to lock up the shop."
Goodenow, somewhat more subdued in tone, said the union was puzzled when the owners rebuffed a players' counterproposal made early Sunday morning and instead told the players to take or leave an offer the owners had made several hours before. He said the players strongly want changes in the free-agent procedures to increase player mobility and want to keep the estimated $10 million they get each year for allowing their pictures to be used on trading cards. The owners want a share of that money.
"The free-agency issue is really one where the players want some movement," Goodenow said. Of the trading-card issue, he said, "The owners are asking us to negotiate something we already have."
 
Losses Anticipated
 Ziegler restated the league's position that its teams would lose a combined $9 million this season after making $125 million for the previous three seasons. Ziegler blamed increasing salaries for the deficit. Goodenow said the increase in pay was "a massive catchup" to what is a fair wage.
The day of debate became possible on Monday when the union postponed its original strike deadline by 51 hours. Goodenow denied that the delay was a sign of weakness and explained it by saying that the union wanted to give its members all the details of the final management offer.
Yesterday morning, player representatives of the 22 teams began to receive documents and videotaped messages from Goodenow. The leverage in the players' favor is the timing. The regular season ends on Sunday. Players get their paychecks during the regular season and earn only bonus payments in the playoffs. Many owners make much of their profit during the post-season.
 
Practice Rinks Off Limits
 If the strike begins this afternoon, tonight's three games will be canceled and players on the road will travel back to their home cities at the expense of the union. Practice rinks and team equipment will be off limits to players. The teams have finished most of the regular season schedule, with only two or three games remaining.

 The Stanley Cup playoffs are scheduled to begin on April 8, next Wednesday, a four-round tournament of as many as 105 games that could end as late as early June. Thus far, players have announced no plans to picket and owners have announced no plans to use replacement players, although both options have been discussed.
If the strike is short, the games could be made up quickly because the league has scheduled two off days, next Monday and Tuesday. But if the strike drags on for a few days, the league would have problems with booking arenas already committed to basketball and other activities.
The two foes were a study in similarity and contrast. Both Ziegler and Goodenow are lawyers from suburban Detroit. Ziegler, who learned the hockey business in the front office of the Detroit Red Wings, is in his 15th year on the job. Goodenow, a former player agent, is in his first year on his job.
In his presentation, Ziegler used charts and graphs and seemed more forecful. "Are not owners entitled to make a profit?" Ziegler asked. His news conference began two hours before Goodenow's and the timing put the labor leader on the defensive.
Goodenow said Ziegler's remarks were "pretty strong and a blatant attempt" to influence the voting of the players and the opinions of the fans.

 Negotiations of this sort in sports often become tests of wills and personalities between the bargainers. Neither Ziegler nor Goodenow expressed harsh words toward the other. Neither side has requested mediation to replace a previous agreement that expired last Sept. 15. Both Ziegler and Goodenow spoke of cooperation and shared revenues when and if the regular-season schedule expands from 80 to 84 games as both sides have tentatively agreed.
But Ziegler said the spirit of trust could deteriorate if there is a strike. "If you study strike situtions, what you see is that once that trigger is pulled, the parties separate and hunker down and there is hostility," Ziegler said.

 Goodenow said rising salaries were a natural condition of the job market.
"These are smart businessmen," he said of the owners. "Nobody's holding anybody up." He said the players' free-agent proposals represent "modest change" and that he doubted the owners' projection of increasing losses in the near future.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
The Last Days of 'Edge' on PBS

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
If you haven't yet caught "Edge," public television's monthly pop-culture magazine, try doing it tonight at 9 on Channel 13. There's not much time left. A co-production of WNET and the BBC, "Edge" will have only one more show to go, on May 13, and then it's electronic-graveyard time. Life on public television, never easy, seems to be getting almost impossible these days.
Any broadcaster will admit all too readily that television news magazines demand considerable time to develop a personality and an audience. CBS's "60 Minutes" was several years old before it struck top-10 pay dirt. More recently, ABC's "Prime Time Live" was nearly hooted off the air before settling into its current comfortable niche. NBC has just announced a 52-week commitment to its latest magazine effort, "Dateline NBC," starring Jane Pauley. Overnight successes just don't happen in this genre. 
 So, PBS has pulled the "viewers like you" financing rug out from under "Edge" after only eight programs (the decision was made when only six had been broadcast). That's barely enough time to catch your breath, never mind sit back and think about what might work more effectively. "Edge" has its problems, but not of a magnitude requiring nearly instant dismissal.
In the beginning, "Edge" seemed eager to become the electronic equivalent of Vanity Fair magazine. Welcome to the kingdom of celebrity, in which celebrities can be found interviewing other celebrities. Just what does Norman Mailer think of Oliver Stone, anyway? The problem with "Edge," given its monthly format, is that too often it wound up looking as if it had arrived late for the party, getting to supposedly hot subjects just as they had begun to cool off from overexposure. One notable instance involved a labored mini-drama designed to illuminate a new novel by, yes, the ubiquitous Mr. Mailer.
But gradually, even if almost imperceptibly, "Edge" began to show signs of having become more assured, more focused. Robert Krulwich, series host, looks more comfortable with a camera now, forgetting the course in Basic Communications that advised him -- this above all -- to keep moving. Program No. 4 adroitly grouped its essays around the theme of "identities in America" and the ways we reinvent ourselves constantly, using everything from political ads to sports highlights. Not overwhelming, perhaps, but moving in an encouraging direction.
Tonight's mix is just that, a disjointed collection of pieces looking at a broad range of contemporary Americana. Merrill Markoe, the comic writer and performer, considers television dating games, especially "Studs," and dubs them, quite accurately, "humiliation entertainment." What kind of people go on these shows? Actors, unemployed actors, says Ms. Markoe, and on "Studs" they sign waivers absolving the producers if a participant should contract a sexually transmitted disease. Some entertainment, it seems, has no limits.
In another segment, the director Robert Altman discusses his new movie, "The Player," which has Hollywood abuzz with its plot about a studio executive involved in the murder of a screenwriter. Mr. Altman describes it as "a bad movie about making bad films." Unfair to the movie community? The producer David Brown observes that "Hollywood is the only place I know where the reality exceeds the legend."
Also on tap: Studs Terkel recalling his favorite stories; Ryan Weideman, a New York cab driver and photographer, talking about the thousands of pictures he has taken of his passengers over the past 10 years; the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art's provocative "Helter Skelter" exhibition, exploring the underside of the city; and a visit to Elko, Nev., and the eighth annual Cowboy Festival Gathering, with its rancher poets writing about topics like "A Thousand Little Ponies."
All in all, an ambitiously broad lineup of stories, handled skillfully. "Edge" might have evolved into a series of substance, had there been more development time. But that, apparently, is what public television cannot afford these days. A thought: Is time running out on public television itself?

Edge
Produced by WNET and the BBC; Steven Weinstock and Michael Jackson, executive producers. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Problem That Won't Go Away

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Race
How Blacks and Whites Think and Feel About the American Obsession
By Studs Terkel
403 pages. The New Press. $24.95.
By tackling the toughest issue in the United States and the hardest subject of his career, Studs Terkel has written his most challenging book. "Race" is the kind of book that happens along once in a long while -- "The Other America," by Michael Harrington, quickly comes to mind -- and demands: Here's the real testimony, now what are you going to do about it? The question is directed at Presidents and Presidential hopefuls and public servants all down the line; to people in early-education classrooms, in health clinics, in hiring halls and on the job; to neighbors and non-neighbors in the cities and countryside who seldom cross the racial divide in their daily lives. 
 In 1944, Gunnar Myrdal, later a Nobel laureate in economic science, called race "an American dilemma." In 1968, after America's streets erupted in hatred, the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders (which issued the Kerner Report) found that blacks and whites inhabited two different societies, "separate and unequal." The same idea of racial division is analyzed by Prof. Andrew Hacker of Queens College in his thoughtful new book, "Two Nations." Now Mr. Terkel, America's pioneering oral historian, calls race "the American obsession."
Mr. Terkel, whose previous books include storytelling about the Depression ("Hard Times"), how people feel about their jobs ("Working") and World War II ("The Good War"), has always been optimistic about people, even if not about their elected leaders. In his latest work, Chicago's living testament to American literature -- he does for fact what Saul Bellow does for fiction: breaks illusions -- looks backward as well as forward.
He writes that as bad as the riots were in 1968, "there was hope, among whites as well as blacks, that things would get better. Despite the assassination of King, the Great Society was still in full swing. But since the mid-70's, public investments have disappeared and the commitment to civil rights has completely gone." He says that since the Kerner Report the situation has worsened because there is greater acceptance of racism.
In one of the scores of authentic voices in "Race" -- voices that speak for a deliberate range of tolerant, intolerant and indifferent people -- a fireman's wife says that the white middle class is getting a bum rap and ought not to be expected to carry all the burdens of the blacks on its shoulders.
Mr. Terkel writes that the woman was prepared for "someone to calm her condition, to assuage her hurts; someone with simple answers." Then, he observes, along came President Ronald Reagan in 1980 "with anecdotes of welfare queens and Cadillacs. In winning the Presidency, the Gipper reversed the field and made the 80's the decade unashamed." He is even more outspoken about President Bush and his attitude toward blacks: "After all, George Bush, in effect, employed Willie Horton as his campaign manager and was rewarded with the Presidency."
"Race" includes Mamie Mobley, whose 14-year-old son, Emmett Till, was slain in Mississippi in 1955 by white racists who were acquitted by an all-white jury. Mr. Terkel asks her if she harbors bitterness toward the two accused and toward whites in general. A woman sustained by religion, she replies: "I haven't spent one night hating those people. I have not looked at a white person and saw an enemy. I look at people and I see people."
In a conversation that began in North Carolina with C. P. Ellis, who had once been "Exalted Cyclops of the Durham chapter of the Ku Klux Klan," Mr. Terkel relates how the ex-Klansman's attitudes changed after direct contacts with blacks in his union, where they found common ground. Now Mr. Ellis takes it as a compliment when people tell him, "You sound like Martin Luther King."
Between the interviews in the book -- most centered around Chicago as a representative city that serves as a magnet for blacks from all over the country -- there are several "Overviews" by authorities. Douglas Massey, a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago, offers a probing analysis of the racial divide. Professor Massey emphasizes one reason why it has worsened in the last 10 years:
"Black English has drifted farther than ever from standard American English. Increasingly, blacks isolated in ghetto poverty are speaking a different language, with its own own rules of grammar, its own structure, its own choice of words, its own pronunciations. It's not inferior, but if speaking standard English is the minimum requirement for a good job in this country, an increasingly large share of our population is frozen out immediately."
If some of what "Race" reports is familiar, it is no less compelling to hear once again about the two separate and unequal societies. The problems of race have been around at least since the first slave ship landed in Colonial America. Even before slavery was abolished, Alexis de Tocqueville wrote in "Democracy in America" that "the most formidable evil threatening the future of the United States is the presence of the blacks on their soil. From whatever angle one sets out to inquire into the present embarrassments or future dangers facing the United States, one is almost always brought up against this basic fact."
And yet, until there is an affirmative turnaround, there's a historical and moral obligation to keep the subject alive, to try to make Ralph Ellison's fictional "Invisible Man" visible. Studs Terkel does so with reporting style and enormous goodwill through the voices of real people in "Race."
