HEADLINE: Informality Reigns, And Good Manners Get a Bad Name

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
THE pleasure of your company is requested in a new age of informality. Do not bother to R.S.V.P. Do not get done up in black tie. The mood just now is one of casualness in dress, in manners, on all fronts.
This is the time of the artfully unmade bed (rise, take up your downy duvet and toss it); the carry-out dinner; the telephone solicitor who calls at all hours and addresses you by your first name. 
 A date for the movies and Chinese food nowadays does not necessarily mean two distinct activities. Not in the age of informality. And not in New York, where any number of moviegoers are capable of eating Sichuan from a carton while following the action on the screen. The pros use chopsticks.
Q. Is the informality of the 1990's anything like the informality of the 60's?
A. No. Women wore T-shirts and no bras in the 60's. Today it's bras and no shirts.
In keeping with the new informality, affluent urbanites who once drove around town in BMW's have switched to Jeep Cherokees and Ford Explorers. "It feels right now," said Steven Meier, a Manhattan lawyer who travels to meetings in his trusty Explorer dressed in a sports jacket and khakis.
A blue suit with a Giorgio Armani label hangs in his office closet "in case I have to impress a client." But he rarely reaches for it. "In today's economy you don't want to wow 'em with your elegant shoes, your gold ring, your fancy car," Mr. Meier said. "That's not the style anymore."
Along Park Avenue, social couples who once did time on the charity circuit now look upon opulent parties as boring or embarrassing. Let's have some of that new informality, they say. Which may explain the number of informal charity parties on the calendar this season.
Take, for example, the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association's Bingo and Barbecue Benefit in June. The association used to hold black-tie auctions and sales of antiques and artworks. A couple of years ago, it sponsored a benefit sale of watercolors from the collections of Louis XIV, the Empress Josephine, Napoleon and members of the French court.
Let them eat barbecue.
"There is a wish for greater informality in these gatherings," said George Trescher, the marketing consultant who runs most of New York's big charity events. "Particularly if you're trying to mix groups of young and older guests."
Mr. Trescher, who was tieless at the time, said the dress code has been unraveling for years now. But jeans at the theater? The ballet? The opera? "Yes, yes," he said. "What's new is that nobody looks askance at it. It's laissez-faire."
Heads did not turn unduly when Kevin Walz took an aisle seat in the orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera the other night. He was wearing wool pants, no jacket and a plaid shirt unbuttoned at the neck to reveal his undershirt.
"What a bum, huh?" he said, stroking his chin. "I didn't even shave."
Mr. Walz, a furniture designer, was dressed for a rock concert he planned to attend after "The Marriage of Figaro." He said a trend toward piggybacking cultural events might have something to do with the new informality.
"Last month I went to the ballet in jeans for an evening of Stravinsky and then down to the Ritz," he said. "I snuck out five minutes early so I wouldn't miss the Pixies."
To observe the new informality on the move, hang around in an airport terminal. Count the sneakers, the shorts, the sweatsuits, even in business class.
"We were talking about that the other day, coming back from Barbados," said Sisi Cahan of Manhattan, a frequent flier long before they had clubs. "People used to look terrific traveling, and now they look ghastly. I haven't seen anyone attractive in an airport in years."
On a flight from New York to Paris, the etiquette authority Letitia Baldrige found herself seated next to a nearly nude dude from California.
"Bared to the waist, he was," she said. "The flight attendants didn't say one thing. He was a surfer, very suntanned, and I must say he had a great body."
Contributing to the decline in decorum, in Ms. Baldrige's view, is a growing folksiness in the corporate culture. "Companies are telling employees to first-name everyone, to forget about deference to age and rank," she said. "All of a sudden, it's not only the C.E.O., but the clergyman and the schoolteacher who are being called Joe. It's spreading like wildfire."
Ms. Baldrige, who lives in Washington and lectures around the country, went on to say that "down here the diplomats try to hold onto some formality in entertaining, but it's getting worse and worse."
"Some people don't even bother to R.S.V.P.," she said. "Other people accept for seated black-tie dinners and don't show up. Or they show up with small children. 'Oh, I couldn't get a baby sitter -- knew you wouldn't mind.' "
For an academic look at the reasons behind the new informality, put in a call to Michael T. Marsden, a professor of popular culture at Bowling Green State University in Ohio.
A secretary answered the phone, informally. ("This is Sylvia.")
The caller asked for Professor Marsden. ("Hi, this is Mike.")
Professor Marsden cautioned against comparing the informality of the 1960's, which was real and deep and wide, to the informality of the 90's. It could be one of those behavioral blips on the East and West Coasts that never go anywhere.
"In the 60's, wearing blue jeans was identifying with the working-class culture," he said. "In today's world the up-and-coming executive is supposed to aspire to the leisure life. What better way to show this than to wear a sweatsuit? It's costuming."
Nonetheless, Professor Marsden went on, society has thrown off some formal trappings taken on in the 80's. "But not all," he said. "Look at weddings. Formal weddings are on the rise. As for funerals, when people are laid out at wakes, they're generally dressed formally. It's not likely you'll find somebody being buried in their sweatsuit."
In any case, elaborate entertaining is out in New York. No more putting on the dog for company. Caterers who used to gussie up trays of hors d'oeuvres with foie gras medallions say they are making meatloaf, mashed potatoes and beans. "But beans don't have to be beige or boring," said Susan Simon, whose catering company on the Lower East Side has always been known for its stylish and informal food.
And guests like Mr. Walz, the jeans-at-the-ballet man, find the down-home feeling refreshing. "You even see Pyrex on the table now," he said. "People are much more casual about entertaining. They're acknowledging that life is tough in New York. What's important is that we're all together, having dinner. So what if there are a dozen kids underfoot and the centerpiece is daisies?"
When not dining at home, some busy New Yorkers are dining out, informally, while doing something else or waiting to do something else. In coin laundries, in bank lines, in doctors' offices, everywhere there is the crinkle of foil unfolding, the snap of aluminum cans opening.
Subways, always informal, have become more so with commuters breakfasting on bagels and coffee and applying major makeup and nail polish. On the F train the other day, Lucinda McBride blotted her lips with a tissue, smiled and said, "My mother said never put on lipstick in public." She went on to apply eye shadow and mascara as the train rumbled from Brooklyn toward Manhattan.
"This is how I get ready for the office," Ms. McBride said, studying her face in a mirror. "I've got two kids under 6."
That's nothing, according to Phyllis Hall, who works for a trade magazine in Manhattan and commutes on a No. 68 N.J. Transit bus with a man who manages to change from sports clothes to a business suit on the turnpike.
"By the time we come out of the Lincoln Tunnel, he's in full business attire," she said. "He even does cuff links."
Here is the new informality personified. Except for the cuff links. They must go.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Forecasts a Loss of 200,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
In their annual economic forecast released yesterday, officials at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said they expected the region to lose another 200,000 jobs in 1992 before a mild recovery settled in in 1993. That bleak forecast comes on top of the 495,000 jobs that have already been lost in the region over the last two years.
"No major turnaround is expected in the next few months," said Stanley Brezenoff, the Port Authority's executive director.
Of those additional job losses, about half, or 110,000, are expected to come from New York City, said Rosemary Scanlon, the Port Authority's chief economist, with the rest from northern New Jersey, Long Island and the suburbs north of the city. 
 With that prediction, Ms. Scanlon places herself at the pessimistic end of the forecasting spectrum. The New York City Office of the Comptroller has estimated that 100,000 more jobs will be lost in the city in 1992, while the Dinkins administration's latest financial plan assumes that 72,200 jobs will be lost this year.
 
Gloomier Regional OutlooklXx
 The Port Authority report came as the Federal Government's chief forecasting statistic, the index of leading economic indicators, showed a marked improvement, advancing eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. [Page D1.] It was the index's second straight monthly rise, causing widespread belief that some kind of national recovery was in progress. Other economic data published yesterday also suggested that a nationwide recovery was underway.
But the Port Authority's regional survey was gloomier.
Ms. Scanlon bases her regional forecast on the assumption that though some industries will begin to recover in 1992, those gains will be offset by job losses in government, retail sales, local services and manufacturing. Most of the losses will come in the first half of this year, she said.
Among the reasons she cited for her outlook were the slow pace of the national recovery and the fact that employment tends to be what economists call a lagging indicator, with companies waiting until they see sure signs of recovery before they begin to expand their work forces again.
Also contributing to the region's uncertain economic outlook is the spread of the recession overseas. The economic slowdown in continental Europe and Japan is most likely to reduce demand for goods made in the New York area and to depress foreign investment in the region, Ms. Scanlon said. "To some degree our futures will be dependent on that in 1992," Ms. Scanlon said.
On the favorable side, Ms. Scanlon said she expected the rebound on Wall Street to help spur the local recovery. She said investment bankers were once again earning handsome bonuses and brokers were seeing their commissions rise again, and this should begin to translate into stronger housing sales, restaurant revenues and retail sales.
The latest regional forecast is darker than the predictions made by some two years ago, after effects of the 1987 stock market crash had already become apparent. In early 1990 the Regional Plan Association, a Manhattan-based research group, projected that New York City and the 26 surrounding counties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would add about 100,000 jobs a year in the next few decades. That figure was less than half the growth during the 1980's, when two million jobs were added to the region.

HEADLINE: By Slim Margin, Hoboken Rejects Waterfront Plan

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., March 31

 BODY:
After two referendums and weeks of fierce debate, residents here today rejected a waterfront redevelopment plan with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that supporters called a financial boon and opponents described as a monstrosity.
Now the future of the historic waterfront, which docked the world's first steamboat and once teemed with 10,000 jobs, is again an open question. 
 Preliminary results from the City Clerk's office had the plan defeated by 231 votes, 5,547 to 5,316. Officials later said the margin was 341 votes, but said they did not have the total number available. The office said that about 60 percent of Hoboken's 19,145 registered voters cast ballots.
The first plan to go to a referendum, a larger plan to redevelop Hoboken's crumbling waterfront, was defeated in July 1990 by 12 votes.
 
'The Message Is Clear'
 Jubilant members of the Coalition for a Better Waterfront, a citizens group that had proposed an alternative plan, said tonight that the results meant that it was time for the city to listen to the citizens.
"What a great day," said Ron Hine, a leader of the coalition. "The people have spoken twice now and the message is clear." But, he added, "We really want to extend an olive branch now and work for an alternative like the one we proposed."
Under the plan that was defeated today, the city would have leased four parcels of waterfront property, including a 5.5-acre pier next to the PATH transportation terminal, to the Port Authority for 55 years. The authority would have prepared the site and sought a developer to build a 20-story office tower and 9-story hotel on the pier, as well as two residential buildings just west of it.
The opponents offered a plan covering the entire length of the waterfront. They called for a mile-long walkway, 19 blocks of mixed residential and commercial development and more than 20 acres of new parks.
 
Residents Bitterly Divided
 The city's plan had bitterly divided residents of this old Hudson River port city, which has a population of 33,400. Business and civic groups endorsed the plan as a means for new jobs and new revenues to stabilize high property taxes. Opponents said it would give too much of the city's valuable waterfront to the Port Authority, break environmental laws and overwhelm the three- and four-story buildings that give Hoboken a small-town character.
City Councilman Tom Newman, a major spokesman for the plan, said that an opportunity had been missed to help the struggling city. He said it would probably take at least two years for the city to develop a new plan to be put before the voters.
Meanwhile, he said, the Port Authority could go elsewhere with the $100 million it had earmarked for the project. "It's been 10 years, three administrations and two referendums," Mr. Newman said. "How likely is it that the P.A. is going to sit around and wait for Hoboken?"
The Port Authority was to give the city $3.25 million in advance as part of $20 million in lease payments. It also was to build a park and expand the city's Little League field. Once a developer had leased the property, the authority was to have given the city 20 percent of gross revenues for the first 35 years and 60 percent for the remaining 20 years.
Opponents said the deal, which gave the authority first option and rights of first refusal on the rest of the city-owned waterfront as well as a $10.25 million lien, gave too much away.
The authority, which entered a 40-year lease with the Federal Government for the use of the piers in 1952, has been interested in developing them for more than a decade. The city bought the piers in 1984, and legislation that year allowed the agency to develop both commercial and residential properties. But it has since been thwarted in Hoboken by public opposition.

GRAPHIC: Photo: For the second time in less than two years, voters in Hoboken, N.J., have rejected a waterfront redevelopment plan. Mayor Patrick Pasculli, center, a supporter of the plan, expressed dismay as the votes were counted. (Kim Garnick/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Behind the Counter;
Learning Hard Lessons at the Mall

SERIES: Modern Mecca: Second of a series of occasional visits to a regional shopping mall

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn.

 BODY:
Janice V. Matte does not complain, except to mention that if her husband still had his management job, she would probably be at home tending her garden on their two acres in Redding.
Instead, at 54 years old, she is out on J. C. Penney's sales floor at the Danbury Fair Mall from Saturday to Wednesday every week, selling draperies for other people's windows. It is her husband, Larry, who hints at their disappointment since he was caught in the first wave of layoffs at the United Technologies Corporation. 
 "I felt it was wrong she would have to do that," he said. "She had served her time. She had raised her children. I didn't like the idea of her having to work." At Christmas time in 1988, Larry J. Matte received his layoff notice, and Janice Matte went to the mall to get a full-time job for the first time in 30 years and an education in the ways of the working world.
 
Gleaming Storefronts
 At the mall, the recession is the great invisible presence. Even in what the Census Bureau lists as the wealthiest state in the country, there are people, like Janice Matte, whose lives have been changed in big and little ways by hard times. But almost in defiance, the mall's storefronts are always gleaming, its showcases always overflowing, as if any whisper of the reality beyond the glass doors will break the mall's spell.
Handwritten window signs, like those used by city store owners who are too worn down to hire sign painters, are strictly forbidden by the mall's managers. And when a mall business falters, it usually does so in such a dash of discretion that only the most observant shoppers would notice that it had ever existed.
One day this winter, the jewelry chain store on the second level, Bailey, Banks & Biddle, was doing "inventory." The next day, the metal gate was shut for good.
Behind the counters and back in the storerooms, young men and women who would otherwise be on college campuses talk about trying to save enough to get off "the floor" and back to school. In the shoe department at Macy's, a clerk offers the prediction -- mostly a hope -- that the big chain's bankruptcy will not be such a bad thing after all.
And people like Janice Matte, who might otherwise be tending their gardens, describe a life that is different from the one they had imagined.
In a little more than three years at the mall, Mrs. Matte said, she has learned that work days are mostly "just work." Her husband said she has adapted to the fact that, between her income and his earnings from his new job as an employment counselor, they now make just about what he once earned alone. But unexpectedly, the job has also given her a chance to prove that she can succeed in a world that, she said, seemed far away during all the years she spent ferrying her girl and two boys, now in their 20's, to soccer practices and wrestling matches.
As it turns out, she is good at selling draperies. Very good. Better than 7,000 or more J. C. Penney window-covering salespeople at 1,300 Penney stores across the country. Last month, in what has become something of a regular event that is giving her a name around the Danbury store, she made "the list."
Not the best dressed. Or the most eligible. She made Penney's list of top 10 drapery sales people nationwide. Last year, she sold $410,472 worth of window coverings, making her eighth on the list. An average salesperson might sell half that much and earn about $10,000, said her supervisor, Bob Pelletier, the department's merchandising manager. Last year, Mrs. Matte said she made about $30,000.
"I have a place here, and I am confident in what I do," Mrs. Matte said one day sitting at the table in the drapery department where they keep the glossy magazines so people can select window treatments to match their images of themselves.
 
Attentiveness and Expertise
 Some of her customers say her success results from a combination of attentiveness and expertise that is hard to find behind counters anywhere anymore. "She didn't look up at you with eyes opened, chewing gum and say, 'Yeah?' " said Gethin Dalton, a Ridgefield resident who relied on Mrs. Matte to get him through the ordeal of selecting draperies and matching bed linens with his teen-age daughter.
It was not always so comfortable for Mrs. Matte. "At first," she said, "I thought it was a big disaster. When I was out of high school, women weren't into careers. Maybe I wasn't qualified. Or maybe I didn't have the training."
For a while when her children were teen-agers, she worked a few days a week at Emily's Cheese Shop in Bethel. But this was different. This was not just standing around and being pleasant. This was a big company with procedures and paperwork. She had to master the ins and outs of valances and mini-blinds. She had to be able to explain why the Taj Antique Satin was worth the money or how to save with Jeweltex.
At the Danbury Penney's, even the most experienced "floaters," the people whose job is to move from department to department, shy away from the window coverings department because of all the possibilities for mistakes.
Mrs. Matte saw all those possibilities, too. She started to bring her paperwork home to make sure she did it properly, and there were plenty of times, she said, when she would wake up in the middle of the night in a sweat about an order, wondering whether she had measured correctly or filled out the proper forms.
 
Catching a Customer's Eye
 The only way to earn more than $5 an hour in the department is through commissions. So Mrs. Matte had to compete with the other sales clerks, catching customers' eyes as they walked in, looking as if she knew the answers to their questions. At Danbury Fair, and retail businesses everywhere, people say commission-sales stores can be "dog-eat-dog" places filled with "barracudas," dominant salespeople who master the art of elbowing out co-workers.
Mrs. Matte was, she now sees, intimidated by the competition that is sometimes hidden behind the friendly atmosphere and the first names that define retail businesses. At least twice, Mr. Pelletier remembered, she told him she wanted out of the department. "She was insecure," he said, "There's too much information here,' " he remembers her pleading. "I'll never be able the learn this.' "
He thought she could do it. And besides, he recalled recently, she had a look that was right for the department. With her professional skirts and blouses, the bifocals and hair that always looks as though she has just come from the beauty shop, she looked to him, he said, like "someone you, as a customer, would feel comfortable asking about colors or styles."
The big problem for Mrs. Matte was that there was someone else in the department who had the look and already knew how to use it. In those days, Ethel Abdella, also in her 50's, was the drapery heavy-hitter in the Danbury Penney's. She was on the list then.
The two women had been acquaintances through a bowling league in Ridgefield, and it had been Ethel, called "Essy" by friends in the league, who had said Janice should put in an application when she heard Larry Matte was out looking for a job.
 
Some Hard Lessons
 One of the hard lessons Mrs. Matte now says she learned about work in those days was how competitive it can be out on the sales floor. Ms. Abdella, who is now working as a waitress at a Danbury diner, says she did not try to freeze out the newcomer. "I didn't compete for sales," she said. "I didn't have to." But she acknowledges there was not enough room for the two of them in the department. "One of the reasons I left was because of her," she said.
People who know both of them say their styles clashed, with Ms. Abdella more "hard sell" and Mrs. Matte favoring a more subtle style. But fundamentally, some of them said, as Mrs. Matte gained confidence, Ms. Abdella grew increasingly irritable.
"If she liked you, she loved you, and if she didn't, you'd know that too," said Jean Sundlot, a neighbor of the Mattes in Redding who worked for years with Ms. Abdella as a waitress before her days at Penney. "Janice felt that, too," Mrs. Sundlot said. "She'd say, 'I did so well this week, and I think Essy's annoyed.' "
After Ms. Abdella left and Mrs. Matte got the merchandiser's assistant title that had belonged to Ms. Abdella, Mr. Pelletier said things quieted down in the department. The title means that Mrs. Matte is in charge out on the floor, and if she sells the minimum "draw" of $75 for every hour she works, she is entitled to $3 an hour extra, plus a 7 percent commission on sales over $75.
Of course, as Mrs. Matte has learned, work always presents new challenges.
There is a new woman in the department, Ida Lounds, whose sales are climbing fast. Last year she sold $320,000 of window coverings, about $90,000 less than Mrs. Matte, which qualified her for a sort of junior "all stars" list in the Penney region that includes the Danbury store.
 
'Competitive Environment'
 Everyone says Ms. Lounds gets along better with Mrs. Matte than Ms. Abdella did. But it is no secret to anyone that when one gets a sale, the other doesn't. Every time Mrs. Matte gets some special recognition, her boss said, that can be useful. "It's manipulation, a little bit," he admitted. "You mention it to Ida. It causes a healthy competitive environment."
When someone comes in, Ms. Lounds said recently, "You try to get to 'em first."
For Mrs. Matte, the search for sales begins again every Saturday morning. After three years, she said, she is used to the routine. Saturdays have begun to have that grim Monday morning feeling she remembered from when she worked as a clerk before she was married.
When he is home alone, Mr. Matte said, Saturday mornings still feel as though someone has taken something away. "When you are used to having your wife around," he said, "it's not the same thing. But we're coping."
Once she is out on the sales floor, Mrs. Matte said, there is always that next sale to think about. She is proud, she said, that the list shows how far she has come, but the honor brings with it a certain burden.
"Sometimes," she said, "I wish it would go away so the pressure wouldn't be there."
 
The Series So Far
The first article in this series about the Danbury Fair Mall appeared on March 27. It described the mall, in Danbury, Conn., as one of the region's new "town squares," a place that draws people not only to buy, but to stroll and to meet friends, a place where some succeed and others fail.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Opens Plant, Makes a Point

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 31

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation officially opened its Jefferson Avenue North plant today in the heart of this depressed city, bucking the conventional wisdom of the auto industry.
While Japanese auto makers were settling in the rural mid-South during the 1980's, hoping to avoid unions, urban problems and the costs associated with an older work force, Chrysler embraced all of them. It forged ahead with a 1.75-million-square-foot building on the east side of Detroit that will employ up to 2,100 workers when it reaches full production of Jeep Grand Cherokee utility vehicles. The total cost of developing the new car and constructing the assembly plant is $1.2 billion. 
 In return for its against-the-grain decision, local, state and Federal governments agreed to spend about $280 million on improvements and tax abatements.
 
 
Was a Plant Even Needed?
 Some experts and Wall Street analysts have questioned whether the auto maker needed the factory at all, noting that Chrysler has shut down American assembly plants in recent years and may have to close more.
But Chrysler maintains that it will prove its detractors wrong. It views the project partly as fulfillment of a moral obligation to politicians, trade unions and workers for supporting it during its financial crisis and federally backed bailout in the early 1980's. The new plant is situated across the street from the site of its 85-year-old predecessor, which was demolished last year.
Moreover, Chrysler hopes the Jefferson Avenue North plant and its workers will dramatize the domestic character of its new Jeep model.
"We're going to show the world that an American-owned company, smack in the middle of urban America, building an American product with American components -- and, most importantly, using American workers -- can build the best sport-utility vehicle in the world," Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of Chrysler, said at the dedication ceremony.
 
 
Half as Many Workers
 Though American and urban, the new plant will mimic Japanese efficiency in the number of workers it needs to build vehicles. Compared with the old factory, which employed up to 5,000 workers, the new plant needs less than half as many to assemble roughly the same number of cars. Like their Japanese counterparts, Jefferson Avenue workers are organized in self-directed teams that will rely far less on supervision than previous workers had.
Chrysler said Jefferson Avenue workers were trained for more than a million hours, or about 500 hours each, to prepare for their jobs. Chrysler also argues that its work force is more experienced, allowing production to increase at a faster rate.
The average age of workers in the plant is 51 years, and the average seniority is about 26 years. By contrast, the workers' average age at Japanese "transplant" operations in Kentucky and Tennessee is in the 30's, and they are not union members.
 "To the extent that Jefferson Avenue North helps to improve relations between the company and the union it was the right thing to do," said John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company. "Building a new plant in Detroit certainly was not the obvious choice."
 
 
Red, White and Blue
 Chrysler has long urged protectionist measures as a means to reduce the number of Japanese vehicles sold in the United States. Chrysler executives have also criticized the location of Japanese transplants, accusing them of dodging unions and urban black workers by locating "in cornfields."
Lest anyone miss the point, Mr. Iacocca was surrounded on the dais by Owen F. Bieber, head of the United Automobile Workers union; Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People; prominent elected officials, and acres of red, white and blue bunting.
Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit drew lusty cheers from plant workers when he ridiculed -- without referring to the Japanese explicitly -- remarks in which a Japanese politician said American workers were lazy and uneducated.
Early reviews by enthusiast magazines of the Jeep Grand Cherokee utility vehicle compare it favorably with the Ford Motor Company's highly successful Explorer.
With the Grand Cherokee aimed at the Explorer and similar models built by the General Motors Corporation, Chrysler must find customers for its eight-year-old Jeep Cherokee model. Chrysler is lowering the Cherokee's price in an effort to make it more appealing to lower-income buyers. But if the strategy fails, analysts speculate, the auto maker may close its Toledo, Ohio, assembly plant and consolidate production at Jefferson Avenue.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Owen F. Bieber, left, president of the United Automobile Workers, sat with Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, yesterday during the dedication of the new Jefferson North assembly plant in Detroit. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Indicators Up Again, By 0.8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The Government's chief forecasting gauge advanced eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, a second straight rise that left little doubt that economic recovery, although probably not robust, was taking hold.
The increase in the index of leading indicators was broadly based and was accompanied by the first meaningful rise since last spring of a related index that measures current economic activity. 
 "A recovery does seem in place after 18 months of recession and 11 quarters of distinctly subpar economic growth," Allen Sinai of the Boston Company Economic Advisors said in response to the Commerce Department report.
 
Further Recovery Evidence
 Other data published today tended to support this conclusion. the Conference Board's survey of consumer confidence made its biggest gain in a year. [Page D8]. In addition, an index compiled by corporate purchasing managers in Chicago climbed to 51.1 in March from 48 in February. Anything over 50 on the index implies economic expansion.
The advance in the Government's predictive index, although no greater than had been expected, was regarded, nonetheless, as further evidence of the stepped-up economic activity that first showed up in housing and has recently spread to industrial production and retail sales.
"I think the recovery is on the way," Michael J. Boskin, chief economic adviser to President Bush, told a luncheon meeting of the National Economists Club. "I think it's likely the economy will continue to improve."
But Mr. Boskin and many other analysts remained somewhat cautious about the outlook, noting variously that the labor market had yet to show much improvement and that some of the other statistical gains early this year seemed to have reflected unusually mild weather.
"We're moving ahead, grudgingly," said Laurence H. Meyer, head of a St. Louis consulting firm that bears his name. "There are still hurdles. We shouldn't get carried away with one month's very good data."
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, took the occasion of today's figures to release findings of a Harvard University economist, James L. Medoff, that the Senator said showed "bleaker" job prospects than implied by the current unemployment rate of 7.3 percent.
Mr. Bentsen said there were far fewer jobs available to unemployed Americans than in previous comparable periods, with the Conference Board's help-wanted index currently as low as when the jobless rate was 9.6 percent in 1983. In addition, he said, "The study finds that new jobs pay less and offer fewer benefits than at the beginning of the 80's."
The unemployment rate, a figure that tends to keep rising even after recoveries start, is to be published this Friday for March.
The eight-tenths of 1 percent climb in the index of leading indicators followed a revised 1 percent advance for January. That was one-tenth of a point more than initially reported.
For the second straight month, seven of the 11 index components contributed to the increase, but the balance was even greater than in January, when it included a huge jump in stock prices.
The biggest positive factor in February was a lengthening of the average workweek followed by a higher money supply, a rise in building permits, higher prices for sensitive materials, improved consumer expectations, increased factory orders and a rise in the proportion of companies reporting slower deliveries from suppliers.
 
1991 Gains Recalled
 The negative factors were a decline in unfilled orders for durable goods, lower stock prices as gauged by the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, lower contracts and orders for plant and equipment and a slight rise in first-time claims for unemployment benefits.
While analysts said they were encouraged by the two straight monthly gains, they noted that the predictive index posted six straight gains of the same magnitude through July 1991 and that little revival ensued. Most do not expect the economy to stall out again this year, however, in part because of substantially lower interest rates.
There also appears to be greater current business momentum, reflected in a seven-tenths of 1 percent February rise in the index of coincident indicators. This gain, which followed a six-tenths of 1 percent January decline, was the biggest in two years.
Still, many analysts continue to worry about continued high household debt and the likelihood that much of the early-year improvement in retail sales was attributable to post-Christmas price cuts. Some also expect some spring setbacks as the statistical effects of unseasonably warm winter weather wear off.
"There's a little less here than meets the eye," commented Lincoln F. Anderson, an economist for Fidelity Management and Research in Boston. "We'll see some fits and starts."
 
Private Surveys Rise
 Two privately constructed predictive indexes also posted gains for February. The composite index of Safian Investment Research climbed 1.7 percent -- the second straight gain and the biggest in five years -- as 16 of its 23 components advanced. The macroeconomic index compiled by David B. Bostian Jr. of Herzog, Heine, Geduld rose to 126 last month from 106 in January.
"There's no question in my mind that we're headed for 4 percent real growth in gross domestic product this year," said Mr. Bostian, one of the most optimistic of American economists.
Still another Commerce Department gauge, an index of indicators that lag behind current activity, fell five-tenths of 1 percent in February, its 13th straight decline.
But the ratio of the coincident index to the lagging index -- an alternative forecaster -- moved up smartly for the second straight month.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Figuring Out the Russian Consumer

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Though Russia resembles a consumer society about as much as Moscow resembles Muskogee, Western marketers are focusing on demographics, seeking to penetrate the psyche of a country that Winston Churchill called a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma.
D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has published "The Russian Consumer: A New Perspective and a Marketing Approach." The agency, which has offices in Moscow and St. Petersburg, serves Western clients in Russia including Mars Inc., the Procter & Gamble Company and Finnair. 
 At the agency's headquarters in Manhattan yesterday, executives shared the study's insights into how Russians behave as consumers.
For example, a segment of Russians characterized by the study as "Cossacks," for their ambition and nationalism, prefers German cars and English cigarettes, while another segment with a merchant-like mentality prefers American cigarettes and domestic vodka.
Perhaps "might prefer" is a better phrase, given current conditions in Russia that make any exercise in assessing consumer attitudes academic, at best. Brand imagery is of little interest to shoppers who must chase scarce goods at steep prices.
The agency's executives recognize that Russian consumers do not represent a significant market yet, but they say that will not always be the case.
"Within the next two years, it will start turning around," Arnold Selkowitz, the international executive vice president for D. M. B. & B., said of the Russian economy.
But in the boundlessly cheerful world of advertising, it is never too soon to start studying an estimated 200 million people with an eye toward converting them into consumers.
The survey, written by Nigel Clarke, the strategic planning director at D. M. B. & B. Europe in London, and Sergey Koptev, the managing director of D. M. B. & B. Moscow, sorts Russians into five groups, each with its own fanciful appelation, based on psychological and demographic factors.
That is patterned after a familiar, and popular, practice in marketing research known as psychographics. For instance, the Claritas Corporation's Prizm data -- for Potential Rating Index by ZIP Markets -- divides Americans into 40 to 48 lifestyles with colorful names like "Norman Rae-ville" and "Blue Blood Estates."
Members of each of the five Russian groups in D. M. B. & B.'s study differ in their outlook, behavior and openness to Western products.
"Kuptsi," a word that Mr. Clarke said translates loosely as "merchants," in an old-fashioned sense, prefer Russian products in theory, he said, but disdain "shtampovka," stamped-out, mass-produced goods. This group, the largest among the five, admires some Western products, he added, particularly well-engineered German and Scandinavian goods like automobiles and stereo equipment.
The group that Mr. Clarke labeled "Cossacks," while aggressively nationalistic, pursues "the most recherche Western products" as status symbols, he said, from premium cigarette brands like Dunhill to expensive cognacs like Remy Martin.
Such Russians display the Western products they buy "literally and symbolically," he said. In their apartments "you are likely to find empty cans and wrappers stacked up as testimony to consumption," he said, adding, "Empty cans of Pepsi and wrappers from Western confectionery are next to the hi-fi and the Western television."
Another group, "Business Executives," which resembles so-called yuppies in this country, is "Western-conscious, but not Western-dependent," Mr. Clarke said. These entrepreneurs prize functionality as well as imagery, he added, and might be as likely to want to drive a Russian Lada automobile as a Western Mercedes-Benz or Honda.
A crucial point to deciphering an emerging Russian market is that "Russia is not desperate just to be like the West," he asserted.
While "Hungary wants to be similar to Austria," he added, "Russia wants to be a nicer Russia."
In advising marketers to divide Russians into groups in order to conquer them, the study is a blueprint for Western-style segmented, or targeted, marketing, rather than the kind of broad-based, mass marketing one might expect would be more efficacious in a consumer society, like Russia's, in its infancy.
"If you're dealing with a market as different as Russia is," Mr. Clarke explained, "even if you want to go 'broad,' it's best to think: 'Which group would go most for my brand? Where is my natural center of gravity?' "
Those who dote on aphorisms about Russia should be aware that, besides Churchill, Bergen Evans's "Dictionary of Quotations" cites these cautionary words from the Marquis de Custine's "Russia in 1839": "Anyone who has come to understand that country well will find himself content to live anywhere else."
And Churchill himself preceded his famous description with this sentence: "I cannot forecast to you the action of Russia."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading and interest rates were little changed yesterday, as most market participants waited for the start of the second quarter to take new positions.
Reaction was fairly muted to a healthy eight-tenths of a percent rise in the Government's index of leading economic indicators and a survey by the Conference Board showing consumer confidence increased in March. 
 And surveys of purchasing managers in Chicago, Detroit and Milwaukee showed that conditions among Midwest manufacturers improved last month.
"For the most part, the numbers were about in line with what the market expected," said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers. "They suggest the economy is inching and clawing its way forward, but do not portend a particularly robust recovery going forward."
Prices of long-term notes and bonds dipped slightly after the figures were released, and remained below levels a day earlier. But prices of shorter-term notes inched higher.
"You can't read much about the market from what is going on right now," one trader said. "The market is still thin, and with the end of the quarter, a lot of people's hands are tied. Starting Wednesday, we should get a truer read of what is really going on."
Figures on unemployment are due out on Friday.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 1/2, down 5/32 , to yield 7.95 percent, compared with 7.93 percent late Monday.
 
Outstanding Treasury Issues
 Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 27/32 , down 3/32 , to yield 7.52 percent. But prices of the 5 3/4 percent two-year notes rose by 1/32 , to 10010/32 , to yield 5.58 percent.
Interest rates fell on short-term Treasury bills.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 4.03 percent, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.15 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Province of Nova Scotia offered $300 million worth of 30-year noncallable debentures through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 8 3/4 percent securities were priced at $98.30, to yield 8.913 percent, 94 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A negotiated sale of $300 million worth of securities from the Metropolitan District of Columbia Aiport Authority highlighted activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
The issue consists of serial bonds with yields ranging from 5.10 percent on securities maturing in 1995 to 6.70 percent on bonds maturing in 2007.
A term bond maturing in 2019 was priced to yield 6.82 percent.
Lehman Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities, which are subject to alternative minimum tax provisions, are insured by MBIA Inc.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
Municipal bond traders also reported little movement in prices of widely quoted issues in the secondary market for tax-exempt securities.

HEADLINE: Bank Fund, C.D. Yields Still Mixed

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and short-term certificates of deposit continued to show a mixed pattern for the week ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
"Doubt is forming as to whether we have seen the end of a three-year downslide in interest rates," Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday. "On the one hand, there have been upticks in the leading economic indicators as well as in consumer confidence. On the other, economists are urging the Federal Reserve to ease rates further. 
 "The pressure is on," he added, "to head off a repeat of the situation last spring when some indicators turned upward but the economic recovery predicted for June did not materialize. Hence, we are at a very critical point in terms of where rates will be two or three months down the road."
New York-area commercial banks offered an average yield of 3.38 percent, off 2 basis points from the previous week, on their money market accounts. Among the savings institutions in this area, money market accounts averaged 3.90 percent, down 6 basis points from the previous week. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Among the banks in the New York-area showing the largest changes in yields, the Emigrant Savings Bank cut its money market account by 50 basis points and its three-month certificates of deposit by 10 basis points. The largest change in the yield on a six-month certificate was made by the Republic National Bank, which dropped its yield by 26 basis points.
The Monitor said the average yields at 20 large banks outside the New York-area had remained unchanged at 3.57 percent, while the yields on six-month certificates had averaged 3.92 percent, up a a basis point, an indication of the mixed movement in yields.
By comparison, at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, the average rates were 4.08 percent and 4.19 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Consumers Gain Back Some Confidence

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumers turned markedly more optimistic in March. The Conference Board said yesterday that its consumer confidence index jumped to 54, from 47.3 in February, its biggest gain in a year.
The rebound in the closely watched Conference Board measure matches a sharp rise, reported two weeks ago, in the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for the first half of the month. Nonetheless, the new polling results cheered stock investors early in the day, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average more than 20 points before other factors prompted prices to slip back. 
 After the United States victory in the Persian Gulf, in March 1991, the Conference Board index shot up 21.7 points, to 81.1, only to languish and finally collapse again last fall as the nascent recovery failed to generate lots of new jobs or prevent another round of layoffs.
The entire gain in the Conference Board poll this month, which reaches 5,000 households with a mail questionnaire, was attributed to brightening expectations about economic conditions six months from now.
 
Worry on Jobs
 By contrast, consumers' assessment of current conditions remains fairly downbeat, largely out of concern that the job market is firming only slowly. Almost half of consumers reported that jobs are "hard to get" and less than 5 percent said they were plentiful.
 As it turns out, a surge in hope in advance of an improvement in job prospects is pretty typical at the start of a recovery.
"It's an almost classic configuration," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Sector. "The substantial improvement in the consumers' expectations is encouraging." Expectations surged while consumers' attitudes about their current circumstances failed to budge for several months at the start of the 1980 recovery and the 1983 recovery, for example.
Nonetheless, Mr. Linden warned against reading too much into one month's results. "While the latest message from the public is better than it has been since last October," he said, "it must be assessed with considerable caution. A single month's figure is still too fragile to be a convincing sign of recovery."
 To underscore that caution, Mr. Linden pointed to somewhat softer buying plans. Just 5.9 percent of respondents, compared with 7 percent in February, say they are planning to buy a new car. Home-buying fever has cooled, too, with 3.3 percent of consumers, down from 4.2 percent in February, saying that they intend to buy a house in the next six months.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed, With No Lift From Good Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in moderate trading yesterday, with analysts saying the latest batch of economic data was not enough to propel it to new highs.
The dollar's soft performance came despite a round of positive news on the United States economy. The Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators, a key measure of the economy's performance, rose eight-tenths of a percent in February. 
 Later, the Conference Board, a New York-based business research group, reported that its survey of consumer sentiment increased sharply. The group's consumer confidence index rose to 54 in March, up from 47.3 in February.
Robert Ryan, senior trader at the Bank of New York, said the reports were not enough, however, to jolt the dollar out of its narrow trading pattern.
"The market is looking for a catalyst here and we haven't seen it," he said.
Traders generally believe that market participants actively bought dollars several weeks ago in anticipation of healthy economic reports that would increase the currency's value. But Mr. Ryan said the investors apparently got too far ahead in their trading positions.
Earl Johnson, vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said, "It's kind of a situation where the market recognizes the recovery is under way, but it needs some sign that it will get stronger before the dollar will go up."
The dollar rose yesterday against the Japanese yen in New York, trading in the face of market rumors that the Japanese central bank may cut the discount rate.
At closing in New York, the dollar was quoted at 133.85 yen, up from 132.75 late Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.12 yen, to a closing 133.05 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 133.20 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7365, from $1.7320 late Monday. At closing in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.7355, less expensive than Monday's closing of $1.7375.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6450 German marks, up from 1.6445; 1.4995 Swiss francs, down from 1.5000; 5.5760 French francs, down from 5.5775; 1,240.25 Italian lire, down from 1,241.50, and 1.18925 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19105.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Great Search: A Perfect Tax

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ARE Americans ready for another sweeping overhaul of taxes -- something, perhaps, like Jerry Brown's flat tax? The answer may not matter much to candidate Brown, who needs recognition as a champion of change far more than he needs a practical plan for cutting the Gordian tax knot. Indeed, Mr. Brown's campaign staff has conceded as much: "The nuts and bolts" of the flat tax, said a Brown campaign spokesman, "are still to be determined."
But the answer matters a lot to economists who thirst for a tax fix that is both simple and politically palatable, yet able to collect enormous sums without grinding down the poor or hopelessly distorting incentives to work, save and invest. For Mr. Brown's tax bears at least a fleeting resemblance to their Holy Grail -- what specialists call a "direct consumption" tax. 
 The not-so-plain old income tax, the one Washington struggled mightily to reform in 1986, does have virtues. It can be made as progressive as one dares, and it is certainly a proven revenue raiser. But the tax is inherently complicated to calculate and administer because income is inherently difficult to define. Moreover, progressive income taxes are likely to distort incentives by putting a fat wedge between what successful people earn and what they keep. Most damning, the tax seems a lightning rod for discontent, perhaps because it is so easily riddled with exceptions and preferences.
Sales taxes, particularly European-style "value added" taxes collected at each stage of production rather than at the point of sale, attract less enmity. Indeed, some conservatives despise the V.A.T. precisely because it is invisible -- and thus an easy ticket to bigger government. But a uniform-rate V.A.T. has one giant drawback in almost everyone's view: It is bound to be regressive because the rich spend less of their income.
Western Europe has fixed this problem by exempting food and shelter, and by charging higher rates on luxuries. But the fixes made a shambles of rational pricing, undermining the free market principle that, say, a car costing nine times as much to build as a refrigerator should cost consumers nine times as much.
Taxes on gasoline -- better still, taxes on the carbon content of fuels -- have been known to set economists' pulses racing. They are a snap to collect, generate oodles of cash and, contrary to the popular impression, are progressive.
Carbon taxes may even serve the cause of economic efficiency by forcing consumers to reckon with the damage caused by traffic congestion, local air pollution and greenhouse warming. But they are political non-starters in the land of the free(way), pure poison at the American ballot box.
Contrast any of the above to the clever direct consumption taxes devised in the mid-1980's by Robert Hall and Alvin Rabushka of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University and by David Bradford of Princeton.
Direct consumption taxes have two complementary components: a levy on business revenues that resembles a value-added tax, and a single bracket payroll tax that together amount to a progressive levy on consumption.
The business tax is a flat percentage of business receipts after subtracting the cost of all purchased inputs, including labor and new capital equipment. Thus, it is really just a tax on the return to management skills and to capital already in place when the tax is first imposed. Since the cost of new assets would be deducted from taxable business receipts, the tax should not deter new investment.
If the flat tax rate on wages is set equal to the rate on business receipts, the combination would amount to a uniform value-added tax that exempted only the return to new capital. For the economy as a whole, after all, wages and business receipts, less the value of investment, equal total consumption. But here is the beauty part: by breaking out the wage component and taxing it separately, it is possible to make the combined tax progressive without distorting consumer prices.
Mr. Hall and Mr. Rabushka would give each family a basic exemption, and then tax wages exceeding the exemption at the flat rate. They calculated that a 19 percent rate, combined with a $16,000 family exemption, would generate the same amount of revenue as the current Federal income tax.
A direct consumption tax would be easier to collect and would demand far less paperwork than the current system. The broad base, combined with the low marginal rate, would minimize economic distortions. The wage allowance would exempt the working poor. And the exemption of investment would stimulate growth. But would it sell?
Jerry Brown's lookalike flat tax plus V.A.T. suggest that Mr. Brown thinks it would. And however one judges his other qualifications for office, it is hard to deny that the former governor of California has a better eye than most for what voters will buy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The index of leading indicators rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, a second straight rise that left little doubt that the economy was in recovery. [Page D1.] 
 Consumers turned markedly more optimistic in March, the Conference Board said. [D8.]
Farm prices rose seven-tenths of a percent in March. [D8.]
The House Banking Committee introduced a modest bill for the savings rescue after it was unable to persuade the full House to support a larger bill. [D2.]
Wall Street earned record fees in the first quarter, as corporations rushed to sell stocks and bonds. [D7.]
Many of the nation's accounting and law firms are growing alarmed that the insurance safety net that protects them from disaster is in danger of giving way. [D8.]
 
Companies
Olympia & York failed to get a syndicate of banks to agree to extend by one year a $450 million loan. [D1.]
Sprint Communications said it would limit liability of big corporate customers for huge bills rung up by thieves. [D4.]
Sears said that it would eliminate 2,000 jobs by early next year and that Edward A. Brennan, its chief executive, had declined to be considered for an annual performance bonus. [D4.]
Digital Equipment acquired 800 Software Inc., a personal- computer software distributor in Berkeley, Calif. [D4.]
Chrysler opened its Jefferson Avenue North plant in the heart of depressed Detroit, bucking the industry's trend. [D5.]
Pinelands stock fell in reaction to a deal linking its New York TV station with a Disney-owned station in Los Angeles. [D19.]
 
International
The Bank of Japan lowered a key lending rate by three-quarters of a point, and the Government announced a package to stimulate the economy. [D1.]
Canada will end discrimination against imports of foreign beer over the next three years. [D1.]
Negotiations broke down on a 36-nation agreement to limit Government subsidies to steel companies, but the Bush Administration said it would allow American curbs to expire. [D6.]
The International Monetary Fund endorsed Russia's economic reform plan, paving the way for a $4 billion loan. [A1.]
 
Business Technology
Michelin recently introduced a tire that drivers have been dreaming about: one that lasts 80,000 miles. [D9.]
 
Markets
Stocks closed flat after early gains. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.23. [D10.]
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading and interest rates were little changed. [D17.]
Platinum futures prices moved up sharply, helping gold and silver. [D18.] The dollar was mixed. [D18.]

HEADLINE: High Salaries for Public Health

 BODY:
New York City lacks a president for its beleaguered public hospital system and New York State lacks a health commissioner. One big reason is reluctance to pay the high salaries needed to attract top candidates. That's dangerously penny-wise and pound-foolish.
A city commission appointed to find a replacement for Dr. J. Emilio Carrillo, who resigned as head of the Health and Hospitals Corporation last fall, says it can't come up with a qualified list. The commission blames low pay -- only $129,000 per year to supervise 16 hospitals. Chief executives of single private hospitals may earn two or three times that much. 
 State legislators, meanwhile, have yet to confirm Dr. Mark Chassin, whom Gov. Mario Cuomo nominated as state health commissioner last summer. The job has been open for more than a year. Dr. Chassin, a former Federal Medicare administrator and a Rand Corporation researcher, agreed to come to Albany only if the state would augment the official $98,399 salary with $61,000 for serving as head of a research institute. Republicans of the State Senate balked at the supplement. State officials now hope to negotiate Dr. Chassin's confirmation as part of the budget package.
New York City officials have in mind some candidates who might serve as hospitals chief if offered additional pay -- say $50,000 a year -- for a part-time teaching appointment. But they are wary of seeming too generous at a time of fiscal meltdown.
That's false economy. The Hospitals Corporation depends heavily on reimbursements from Federal, state and private health insurance funds, and skilled administrators know how to maximize those revenues -- that's one reason private hospitals pay so much to attract them. The right person could save taxpayers tens of millions.
The fiscal crisis makes it all the more imperative to find skilled health administrators; salary supplements are a sensible price to pay.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 467 words

HEADLINE: Borrow More? Yes, to Grow

 BODY:
How's this for spit-in-your-eye logic? Two weeks ago the Congressional Budget Office calculated that the already dismaying Federal deficit would rise this year by an alarming amount. Yet in the face of that, a group of 100 economists, including six Nobel laureates, calls on Congress to borrow billions more.
It may sound screwy, but in fact the call makes compelling economic sense. Yes, the stratospheric deficit needs to be controlled. But there are some things more important than reducing it quickly. What matters is less the size of the deficit than what the borrowed money is used to pay for. That's why the economists call for investing in infrastructure and education. 
 More public investments make sense in the short run, because they would help stimulate the economy out of recession. And they make even more sense in the long run, by raising productivity and growth.
In an open letter to President Bush, Congress and the Federal Reserve Board, the economists call on Congress to pump $50 billion into assistance for state and local governments. The money would be used to better educate workers and to build highways, mass transit, technology centers. The open letter also calls for tax credits to stimulate private investment.
The economists acknowledge that these proposals would raise the deficit. But they make a convincing case for doing so. After all, the main reason for worrying about large deficits is that, by sucking money out of private capital markets, they drive down private investment. But if Congress turns around and uses the borrowed money to pump up private and public investment, the economy comes out ahead.
Besides, the alarming new $400 billion deficit figure is somewhat deceptive. It includes huge transfers for the savings and loan bailout and for interest. These expenditures do little more than swap dollars from one set of taxpayer pockets to another. That affects the distribution of income for particular people but doesn't much affect the overall economy.
All that said, however, Congress has no warrant for turning cavalier about borrowing. The deficit is projected to balloon later in the decade for rock-solid reasons -- like skyrocketing Medicare and Medicaid expenditures.
Unlike bank bailouts and interest payments on the national debt, money spent on health care will represent a real drain on the economy. The trick is to get out of the current recession -- and then tend to the immense deficit with a careful mix of tax hikes and spending cuts targeted to cut consumption rather than investment.
The economists' letter rings with an unassailable logic. Deficit reduction is important, but not at any cost. Short term and long, starving valuable public investment for the sake of lowering the deficit does more harm than good.

HEADLINE: Penny-Pinching Submarine Warfare to Death;
Recipe for Victory

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 24 lead editorial summarily dismisses the importance of the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics and of submarines to our nation's defense.
Rather than your simplistic suggestion to create a supermarket for ships in one, all-purpose production facility, the better approach is to maintain the country's pre-eminent submarine builder and concentrate surface ship work at other shipyards, including Newport News. 
 We were victorious in Operation Desert Storm because we had advanced technology combined with the heroism of our fighting forces. That's the real key to our long-term security, and the Seawolf submarine moves this technology forward.
Finally, it may be easy for you to regard the issue of workers as being of no consequence, but as a member of Congress representing thousands of Electric Boat employees and others dependent on that revenue, I think it is abhorrent that the President would give them their notice of the end of the cold war in the form of a pink slip with no plan for the future. But then what would you expect from a President whose economic advice is to do nothing?
 
JACK REED
Member of Congress, 2d Dist., R.I.
Washington, March 24, 1992

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President, Co-Founder Of Abaxis Resigns Post

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Abaxis Inc., a medical devices company trying to develop a portable blood analyzer to give doctors data in minutes instead of days, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Richard K. Leute, had resigned and been replaced by the company's chairman, Gary H. Stroy.
 Mr. Leute, who helped to found the company, resigned last Friday as an officer and director because of "personal reasons," Mr. Stroy said. Mr. Leute, 54 years old, remains a consultant to the company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif. Mr. Stroy, 49, remains chairman. 
Kenneth E. Rubenstein, 51, previously a consultant in product development to Abaxis and other companies, was also named Abaxis's vice president of development.
 Abaxis was founded in 1989 by Mr. Stroy, Mr. Leute, and Vladimir E. Ostoich, who remains Abaxis's senior vice president of research and development. The name Abaxis is Latin for "away from the axis," referring to the centrifugal force used in many devices to separate elements in blood.
 The company, which has 50 employees but no revenue as yet, has spent about $10 million developing a device that would allow physicians to analyze the blood of patients immediately. Currently, hospitals can only analyze blood economically by batching together a large number of blood samples from patients and have them tested by a huge device the size of an automobile. The process can take hours or even days.
 "Let's say a doctor in the morning wants to discharge a patient, but needs a blood workup," said Mr. Stroy in an interview. "He may have to wait for the results in the evening or even the next morning. That's $1,000 for an extra day's hospital stay."
 Abaxis expects to introduce a commercial device later this year, Mr. Stroy said. He said he did not expect any sharp change in policies because of the management shifts. He said he had participated in the running of Abaxis from its beginning.

HEADLINE: AID TO RUSSIA;
BUSH AND KOHL UNVEIL PLAN FOR 7 NATIONS TO CONTRIBUTE $24 BILLION IN AID FOR RUSSIA

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
The leaders of seven major industrial nations announced a $24 billion, one-year program today to help propel Russia toward democracy, including a contribution from the United States of nearly $4.5 billion.
In announcements in Washington and Bonn, President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl presented the program as a way for the United States and its allies to prevent economic collapse in Russia and stop a new authoritarianism from rising from the rubble of the former Soviet Union. 
 The two leaders stressed that Russia must follow an approved economic reform program to get the aid, and so must any other former Soviet republics that get similar assistance in the future.
 
Billions for Peace, Bush Says
 Mr. Bush also said he was going to ask Congress to authorize him to funnel as much as $15 billion to international lending institutions for interest-bearing loans to the former republics in coming years.
Trying to sell the program to a recession-weary nation, he said he was not asking for new tax dollars this year, and his top aides initially tried to avoid saying precisely how much money the United States was spending. No country other than the United States said today how much it would contribute.
Mr. Bush said Americans stood at a moment as important to 20th century history as the end of the two World Wars, and had the chance to turn political chaos into lasting peace by adding a few billion dollars to the trillions it cost to wage the cold war.
"The stakes are as high for us now as any that we have faced in this century," Mr. Bush said at a White House news conference this morning. "Our adversary for 45 years, the one nation that posed a worldwide threat to freedom and peace, is now seeking to join the community of free nations."
He continued: "If this democratic revolution is defeated, it could plunge us into a world more dangerous in some respects than the dark years of the cold war." [Excerpts, page A11.]
 
One Step Behind, Critics Say
 In Bonn, Mr. Kohl said, "We have agreed to send a decisive signal of political and economic support to President Yeltsin and the forces of reform in Russia" and the other republics. "The offer is also an incentive to successfully implement this brave reform program, especially in Russia."
A senior German Finance Ministry official, Horst Kohler, said at a news conference that American support for the aid program was "late, but welcome."
But Mr. Bush sought to make the case that he had been working for months toward this package, which goes substantially beyond existing United States programs, and he heatedly denied that his announcement was motivated by election politics.
Despite his soaring oratory today, however, Mr. Bush has consistently lagged behind the European allies in responding to the upheaval in Eastern Europe: Just two weeks ago, he dismissed criticism along these lines from former President Richard M. Nixon by saying he could not write a "blank check" for Russia.
 
Response by Clinton
 The timing of his announcement today was clearly intended to create maximum political benefit. The White House delayed a Presidential address on governmental reform to make room in Mr. Bush's schedule for the aid announcement. And he spoke just moments before Gov. Bill Clinton, campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination, delivered a major speech on foreign policy in New York.
Like Democratic leaders in Congress, Mr. Clinton applauded Mr. Bush's announcement. But he renewed criticism of Mr. Bush's hesitancy, first to embrace the opposition forces in the Soviet Union and then to put the full power of the United States and its Treasury behind President Boris N. Yeltsin.
"The President has kept America largely on the sidelines in the democratic revolutions that toppled the Soviet empire and are transforming the face of world politics," Mr. Clinton said. "Time and again, this Administration has sided with stability over democratic change."
The political aspects were also evident in the care that Mr. Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other top officials took to argue that taxpayers would not have to spend more money to finance the aid for the Russians in this election year.
Mr. Bush himself went so far as to refuse to include any specific amounts in his presentation, and Mr. Baker and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady also avoided specifics. But the Treasury said the United States would contribute $4.35 billion, all of it from "existing," "previously authorized" or "already committed" funds.
Of the American share, $1 billion is in loan guarantees that do not involve cash outlays. But the rest came originally from taxes, some of it last year, some in previous decades.
Asked how he would explain the aid to Americans worried about their jobs, their schools, their crumbling cities and their deteriorating roads and bridges, Mr. Bush replied: "Simply make the case that to do nothing would be irresponsible, that the United States must continue to lead and that we have an enormous stake, a personal stake for every American, in the success of these democracies.
"And to risk their failure by doing nothing is very short-sighted, and so that's the case I'm going to make, and I will also be saying, 'We have a lot of blessings in this country, and one of them today is peace.' "
 
Where the Money Is Going
 The $24 billion program represented the first step toward a comprehensive approach to the republics long sought by Russia and some other countries, especially Germany, the current chairman of the Group of Seven industrial nations, which besides the Germans and the Americans includes Britain, Canada, France, Italy and Japan.
The program establishes a $6 billion fund to maintain the value of the ruble while it becomes a convertible currency.
This money gives Governments the ability to intervene in currency markets when the ruble has dropped below a certain value. Central banks or treasury ministries in major world capitals could use that money to buy rubles -- increasing demand for them in world markets and raising the price on free markets. A version of this protection now exists for the Polish zloty, and at times the United States dollar has benefited from a variation on that strategy: When it dropped against the mark or the yen, Germany and Japan bought dollars in an attempt to stabilize the dollar exchange rate.
The program provides $11 billion in aid from members of the group and other wealthy countries, $4.5 billion in loans from international institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and $2.5 billion in deferral of Russian debts.
Except for that $2.5 billion, the money would be provided through the I.M.F., the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The $6 billion stabilization fund will come from a pool collected by the I.M.F. in previous decades for such emergencies; the $4.5 billion will come from other funds controlled by the three organizations.
Apart from the United States participation in the international organizations' loans and the ruble fund, Mr. Bush's proposal relies primarily on expanding existing programs, like loan guarantees for purchases of farm products. In some cases, it simply incorporates current programs like medical shipments and humanitarian food assistance under the new heading of "comprehensive aid."
The American share amounts to $1.5 billion of the money being used for the ruble fund, $850 million of the other loans and about $2 billion of the $11 billion in aid. None of the money Russia owes the United States is covered by the debt-deferral plan.
Administration figures showed that all of the $2 billion in direct aid would come either from existing programs or as guarantees on loans -- money that would not have to be spent unless a loan was not repaid.
Although Congress does not have to act on those programs, its approval is needed for Mr. Bush's request for the $15 billion more in lending authority to help the other republics, as well as his proposals to lift cold-war restrictions on other kinds of credit.
Mr. Bush is also seeking Congressional backing for other proposals in the aid package. These include expansion of programs like the Peace Corps, the Citizens Democracy Corps and other "people to people" groups, promotion of free markets in Eastern Europe to cover the former Soviet Union and use of a $500 million fund to dismantle Soviet nuclear weapons to cover as well the conversion of military industries to civilian use.
 
Nonpartisan but Still Political
 Congressional leaders on both sides of the aisle pledged to set aside partisan politics and move Mr. Bush's proposals to the floor of both houses quickly. The President asked for passage by the end of the month.
Declaring that there is "no higher priority" than this bill, Mr. Baker said, "I'm ready to go up there tomorrow and start fighting for this legislation."
But the Democrats did not abandon their criticism of the President.
Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, told Mr. Bush at a White House meeting with Congressional leaders this morning that the package was very similar to a program for Eastern Europe that he had been pushing for a year without any support from the Administration.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Majority Leader, called the plan a "good start" but "long overdue."
Mr. Gephardt added, "Now the President must use his bully pulpit to rally the American people to his cause, something he has resisted doing on major foreign policy issues throughout his Presidency, to justify the cost of and the need for a comprehensive plan to insure the consolidation of economic and democratic reforms."
