HEADLINE: AID TO RUSSIA;
Buying Time for Yeltsin

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
The $24 billion in aid that President Bush and other leaders have promised Russia is not going to turn it into a prosperous nation overnight. But it does give President Boris N. Yeltsin something Mikhail S. Gorbachev never received: a major vote of confidence on his economic reforms.
For Russia, the aid package may make the crucial difference between unbearable misery and hard, but tolerable times, and this, economists say, could give President Yeltsin the margin of maneuver to push ahead with his tough free-market program. 
 It is no coincidence, Soviet experts say, that President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany unveiled the aid package just five days before Mr. Yeltsin must seek to persuade a hostile Russian Parliament to swallow some more free-market medicine.
 
One Up on Gorbachev
 "This aid gives Yeltsin's economic program a lot of respectability," said Marshall Goldman, associate director of Harvard's Russian Studies Center. "Gorbachev never brought back a package like this."
The $24 billion in assistance includes a $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble, $2.5 in debt rescheduling, $4.5 billion in aid from the International Monetary Fund and other international organizations, and some $11 billion in direct help from Washington and the other industrialized democracies that will include food, medicine, export credits and other aid. President Bush said the United States would provide about one-fifth of the package.
The announcement today by Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl, who is chairman of the Group of Seven industrial democracies this year, was in sharp contrast to the lukewarm embrace that Group of Seven leaders gave Mr. Gorbachev at the Economic Summit in London last July. Mr. Gorbachev implored the industrial nations for extensive aid, but they turned him down, saying his reforms were too half-hearted.
Many Sovietologists said the West's failure to give Mr. Gorbachev billions in aid that he could proudly take back to Moscow was an important factor behind his downfall.
Experts on Russia also say that if economic conditions turn disastrous in the republic of 150 million and if there is a coup that puts a hostile dictator in power, the aid package will enable President Bush and other leaders to say that they did their best to insure the republic's transition to a free-market democracy.
"I think Bush is trying to get out of the whole question of who lost Russia," said Judy Shelton, a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution. "He'll say, 'Look how much money we're providing.' "
 
A Steadier Ruble
 In the view of American officials and many economists, the package should go far to steady one of the key factors causing Russia's economy to teeter -- a currency that has no respect. The multilateral fund being planned to stabilize the ruble aims not only make it easier for the Russians to do day-to-day business, but is intended also to create a solid currency that will help restore faith in the republic's economy.
American officials say that a stabilization fund could begin as soon as this summer and that they hope it will firm up the ruble as successfully as a multilateral fund stabilized the Polish zloty in early 1990. If the fund restores confidence in the ruble, the currency could obtain a limited convertibility later this year. The big hope is that Russian exporters will have the confidence to bring their hard-earned profits back to Russia rather than stash them abroad.
But some economists say the Russian economy is in such a shambles that a stabilization fund may not work and that the currency will not become convertible for at least a year or two.
While Mr. Yeltsin has many supporters, many other Russians are seething about his reforms. It has allowed prices to soar, pensioners complain that they cannot afford basic foods, and widespread layoffs have begun as tight credit squeezes many enterprises.
Although they admit an I.M.F. program will cause pain, American officials say they hope it will revive Russia's economy by slashing budget deficits and helping control inflation.
Once it becomes an I.M.F. member and receives loans from the fund, Russia must agree to meet certain stringent conditions that the I.M.F. recommends to cut its deficit and money supply growth. In this way, Russia will be integrating itself into the world economy while also ceding some economic sovereignty to the West.
Although the package announced today is aimed primarily at Russia, some economists say the other republics are in more desperate need of aid. In their view, Russia might earn lots of hard currency once it raises energy prices to world levels. While this would cause hardship for many Russian citizens by reducing energy consumption at home, it would enable Russia to export far more oil, helping to fill its depleted hard-currency coffers.
But most of the other republics import energy from Russian and could face bitter times if oil prices soar to world levels.
"We may have a situation where the Ukraine, the Baltic republics, the Central Asian republics are in a worse condition because they will be starved of funds," said Jan Vanous, director of Planecon, a Washington-based consulting group. "They don't have as many goods as Russia to export."
Because of its economic and political might and because it is sprinting ahead with reform, Russia has been the first beneficiary of other countries' largesse. Experts on the Commonwealth of Independent States say they hope the Group of Seven will not forget the other republics just because they do not have the nuclear arsenal Russia has. The $24 billion package announced today includes $500 million in agricultural credits to the other republics.
The aid should shore up Mr. Yeltsin's position as he comes under fire for removing price controls and keeping credit tight. The package, along with the I.M.F.'s announcement Tuesday that it backed Mr. Yeltsin's reforms, were certainly designed to strengthen his hand, many Russia experts say.

HEADLINE: Aid to Russia;
Thankful Russia Still Wary Of Daunting Tasks Ahead

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 1

 BODY:
For months, the reigning young economists of Russia have been campaigning for Western economic aid, both to stabilize an economy lurching through one of the greatest transitions of this century and to provide political support for President Boris N. Yeltsin.
In a coordinated fashion today, perhaps timed to help Mr. Yeltsin mute sharp criticism of his economic reforms when the full Russian Parliament convenes on Monday, President Bush and the German Government announced plans for considerable Western aid to Russia and other former Soviet states. 
 The announcement of a multinational $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble and make it freely convertible to Western currencies will be particularly welcome. A convertible ruble is an essential part of a free-market future for Russia, a safety net to help preserve a realistic exchange rate.
 
What Russia Says It Needs
 Yegor T. Gaidar, 35 years old, the Deputy Prime Minister in charge of the reform, has been calling for such help for a long time now. He wrote an op-ed page article that appeared in The Financial Times on March 4, arguing that "if the West wants to help us, now is the time." Then he called for a $5 billion stabilization fund to peg the ruble at about 50 to the dollar; today, with a dollar buying about 110 rubles, he was promised $6 billion.
Mr. Gaidar also asked for support to allow the import of needed commodities in this transitional period, when many Russian factories cannot obtain parts and supplies. Today, according to the German Finance Minister, Horst Kohler, the seven major industrialized nations agreed to finance a balance-of-payments gap of up to $18 billion.
Given the time difference -- Moscow is 9 hours ahead of Washington -- immediate reaction here was muted; official responses are likely to come Thursday.
 
'This Just Came In . . .'
 On the main television news show, at 9 P.M., Mr. Bush's announcement was not among the main headlines. The program began with a report on negotiations over a new treaty between Russia and Czechoslovakia, then several lesser items, then "news just in from the United States" -- the Bush announcement.
The report stressed the need for Congressional approval of the proposed aid, and spoke of the Administration's willingness to remove many of the "more than 260 laws enacted during the cold war that hindered the development of cooperation and business deals."
The 11 P.M. news added a few details and provided some analysis, suggesting that Mr. Bush had been inactive on aid to the former Soviet Union because of criticism during his re-election campaign that he focused too much on foreign policy.
When telephoned by news agencies, some officials were quick to express their appreciation. The chairman of the central bank, Georgi Matyukin, a regular critic of Mr. Yeltsin's program, told Reuters: "This is very substantial. I would be very happy if the United States just fulfilled their plans to assist us in the way declared by Mr. Bush."
Deputy Finance Minister Sergei Ignatyev said, "Western support is very necessary but everything depends on what we are able to do ourselves."
Both said the imprimatur of the West and the International Monetary Fund would change the psychological climate.
Both the balance-of-payments support and the stabilization fund are subject to a further agreement between Russia and the I.M.F. on a detailed economic program, with specific budgetary and financial targets. That program has not yet been agreed to, Russian and American officials said today.
 
The Unanswered Questions
 With Russia now expected to join the I.M.F. at a meeting on April 27, Mr. Bush's announcement is likely to force the negotiations along so that the formal program is ready by then and loans can start to flow as early as May.
But much remains to be done before a ruble-stabilization fund can be established, David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said in Moscow on Sunday. "Before we are in that position, we have to have finance lined up, a full stabilization program must be in place and you must know what kind of currency is going to function," he said.
The Russian reforms, begun with a price liberalization on many commodities on Jan. 2, has proven moderately successful. While prices for food and other goods have risen sharply, necessities remain subsidized and there is more to buy. Predictions of starvation this winter did not come to pass, and more Russians are finding ways to make money through private trading and labor.
 
Moving Forward, Slowly
 But privatization of major state industries has been very slow and private investment minimal, and Mr. Gaidar has had to ease both monetary and fiscal policy to maintain political stability. He also recently announced that liberalization of energy prices, scheduled for April, would not take place until May or June.
Many Western economists have criticized the reforms as too quick and radical, or too slow and piecemeal. Some think the International Monetary Fund itself is too inflexible an instrument, although they recognize that it is the easiest way to obtain multinational support.
But as a Western diplomat said today, "No one has ever tried to transform a socialist command economy of this size into a free-market one, and no one knows how it's supposed to happen, even if they pretend to.
"It's like the old Maine joke: If you wanted to get there, you wouldn't start from here."

HEADLINE: Aid to Russia;
Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on Aid Plan: 'Today We Must Win the Peace'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today on aid commitments to the former Soviet republics:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
 I have a statement that is a little longer than the normal, but let me just say that I have just met with the Congressional leadership to request their bipartisan backing for a new, comprehensive and integrated program to support the struggle of freedom under way in Russia, Ukraine, and the other new states that have replaced the Soviet Union.
 The revolution in these states is a defining moment in history, with profound consequences for America's own national interest. The stakes are as high for us now as any that we have faced in this century, and our adversary for 45 years, the one nation that posed a worldwide threat to freedom and peace, is now seeking to join the community of democratic nations. A victory for democracy and freedom in the former U.S.S.R. creates the possibility of a new world of peace for our children and grandchildren. 
 But if this democratic revolution is defeated, it could plunge us into a world more dangerous in some respects than the dark years of the cold war. America must meet this challenge, joining with those who stood beside us in the battle against imperial Communism: Germany, the United Kingdom, Japan, France, Canada, Italy, and other allies. Together, we won the cold war, and today we must win the peace.
 This effort will require new resources from the industrial democracies, but nothing like the price we would pay if democracy and reform failed in Russia and Ukraine and Belarus and Armenia, and the states of Central Asia. It will require the commitment of a united America strengthened by a consensus that transcends even the heated partisanship of a Presidential election campaign.
 And today I call upon Congress, Republicans and Democrats alike, and the American people, to stand behind this united effort.
 
 
. . .
 To this end, I would like to announce today a plan to support democracy in the states of the former Soviet Union. This is a complex set of issues which took months to sort out, working within the Administration, working with our major allies and with the leaders of the new independent states of the former Soviet Union. A number of things had to come together to make sure we got it right.
 
 
. . .
 After weeks of intensive consultations in the G-7, Chancellor Kohl, currently serving as chairman of the G-7, has announced today G-7 support for an I.M.F. program for Russia. The program that I'm announcing today builds on this progress and includes three major components.
 First, the United States has been working with its Western allies and the international financial institutions on an unprecedented multilateral program to support reform in the newly independent states. The success of this program will depend upon their commitment to reform and their willingness to work with the international community.
 Russia is exhibiting that commitment, and I'm announcing today that the U.S. is prepared to join in a substantial multilateral financial assistance package in support of Russia's reforms. We're working to develop, with our allies and the I.M.F., a $6 billion currency stabilization fund, to help maintain confidence in the Russian ruble.
The U.S. will also join in a multilateral effort to marshal roughly $18 billion in financial support in 1992 to assist Russian efforts to stabilize and restructure their economy. We've been working with the Russian Government for three months to help it develop an economic reform plan to permit the major industrialized countries to provide support.
 We will work to complete action on this approximately $24 billion package by the end of April, and I pledge the full cooperation of the United States in this effort.
 Secondly, the United States will also act to broaden its own capacity to extend assistance to the new states. I am transmitting to Congress a comprehensive bill, the Freedom Support Act, to mobilize the executive branch, the Congress, and indeed, our private sector, around a comprehensive and integrated package of support for the new states.
 Now, this package will authorize a U.S. quota increase of $12 billion for the I.M.F., which is critical to supporting Russia and the other new states. The I.M.F. and World Bank will be the primary source of funding for the major financial assistance needs of the new governments.
 
Congress's Authorization
 The U.S. quota increase for the I.M.F. was specifically assumed in the budget agreement and does not require a budget outlay. The package will support my existing authority to work with the G-7 and the I.M.F. to put together this stabilization program for Russia, and support possible subsequent programs for other states of the former Soviet Union, as they embark on landmark reforms, including up to $3 billion for stabilization funds.
 It would also repeal restrictive cold-war legislation so that American business can compete on an even footing in these new markets. And I'm determined that American business be given the chance to invest in trade with the new states, and to that end, I've also directed that the United States negotiate trade and bilateral investment in tax treaties with these countries just as soon as possible.
 Significant new trade relationships can create jobs right here in this country. The package will broaden the use of $500 million appropriated by Congress last year to encompass not only the safe dismantling and destruction of nuclear weapons, but also, the broader goals of nuclear plant safety, demilitarization, and defense conversion.
 It will also establish a major people-to-people program between the United States and the states of the former Soviet Union to create the type of lasting personal bonds among our peoples, and Russian understanding of democratic institutions so critical to long-term peace . . .
In sending this authorization legislation to Congress, I call upon the Congress to act concurrently to provide the appropriations necessary to make these authorizations a reality.
 Third, in the addition to the $3.75 billion already extended by the U.S. since January 1991, I am announcing today $1.1 billion in new Commodity Credit Corporation credit guarantees for the purchase of American agricultural products. Six hundred million dollars of that will go for U.S. sales to Russia, and an additional $500 million for U.S. sales to Ukraine and other states.
 
 
. . .
 I know there are those who say we should pull back, concentrate our energies, our interest, and our resources on our pressing domestic problems, and they are -- they are very important. But I ask them to think of the consequences here at home of peace in the world. We've got to act now.
 
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Mr. President, you mentioned several figures in your statement. Overall, what's the cost of this to taxpayers? And where is the money going to come from?
A. Well, most of it will come from the I.F.I.'s, from the international financial institutions. About a fifth of the total is assigned to the -- about a fifth of it, 20 percent of it, is our share, and there's not a lot of new money. It's our feeling and the feeling of the partners that we ought to go use these international financial organizations who were set up to do this very job.
 
 
. . .

 
Bush's Timing
 Q. Mr. President, if the risks are so great, the stakes so high, why did you wait until two months into an election year to outline the program and begin to push for it, especially when as you say, there's little new money involved?
A. Because -- we haven't waited. If you listened to what I said earlier, we spelled out a determination to do this in December. We have been working with our allies constructively to bring about agreement on this international financial institution approach. That was hammered out this weekend by Secretary Brady's people overseas. . . .
A lot of work has been going into it, and rather than kind of posturing out there, we wanted to have a sound program that will have strong international support, and that is exactly, thanks to the cooperation of the allies, what we have.
So this isn't any "Johnny come lately" thing and this isn't driven by election-year pressures. It's what's right for the United States and I must say, without committing anybody to anything, that the reception from the joint leadership seemed quite positive. . . . Q. But sir, whether you were posturing or not, have you not waited a while before beginning this sales pitch?
A. I said something about it in January. Jim Baker mentioned it in December. I've been talking about it. The question, though, is not a lot of political rhetoric. The question is getting something done that's positive.
 
. . .

 
Reason for Skepticism
 Q. Sir, the reason there is this skepticism is, back when Pat Buchanan was beating you about the head in New Hampshire, you weren't out there in New Hampshire, going to New Hampshire and saying, we've got to help Boris Yeltsin; we've got to help Kravchuk. You weren't talking about that at all. You weren't preparing American public opinion.
Today, Bill Clinton is out there talking about his plan for Russia and the republics. That's why it looks a little weird.
A. Well, but I've explained to you, John, that there's a great deal of diplomacy. I remember when one of your, one of the people who used to sit proudly in this room, accused me of not being emotional about Germany, about trying to get a reunited Germany when the wall came down.
I said -- what I was saying to myself, much less interested in emotion, much more interested in getting something positively done. Use the power of the Presidency of the United States to see if you can't have that be accomplished in a very peaceful way.
 
 
. . .

 
Persuading the Public
 Q. Our recent poll shows that 55 percent of the public thinks that foreign aid in fact should be cut, and another 40 percent thinks that it shouldn't be increased at all. How are you going to persuade the public that this in fact is worthwhile when they look around and see roads deteriorating and schools in trouble?
A. Simply make the case that to do nothing would be irresponsible -- that the United States must continue to lead, and that we have an enormous stake, personal stake, for every American in the success of these democracies. And to risk their failure by doing nothing is very shortsighted.And so that is the case I'm going to make.
And I will also be saying, we have a lot of blessings in this country, and one of them today is peace. Your kids and mine don't go to sleep at night as worried about nuclear weapons as some of the preceding generations here. And I want to be sure that I can certify to the American people I've done everything I can as President to see that that continues, that democracies are strengthened, that freedom is on the march, and continues to stay on the march.
And this approach we're taking is the way to do what we can to guarantee that.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Policies Under Clinton Are a Boon to Industry

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
Under Gov. Bill Clinton, Arkansas has grown to be a business-friendly state. The Governor entices corporations with tax breaks, low wages and a warm, cooperative attitude. All this has helped add jobs, increase income tax revenue and provide much of the money spent on efforts to improve public schools.
But in some cases industry has used state government concessions while eliminating jobs. 
 The International Paper Company is one believer in Mr. Clinton's Arkansas. In 1985, at the Governor's urging, the state created a special investment tax credit act at the company's request. Both the state government and the company said the act led to thousands of construction jobs; the company said it helped save at least 1,000 jobs at one International Paper mill and increased jobs at another mill -- to 1,401 jobs today from 1,058 in 1985.
 
Modernization Pays Off
 Charlie Ventress Jr. of Moscow, Ark., is being paid $18.56 an hour to coat magazine paper manufactured at the company's modernized complex in Pine Bluff. The plant was modernized as a direct result of the 1985 act, which gives manufacturers a tax credit for new investments.
"I'm glad that Arkansas got the plant," he said. "Before they put the plant in, I got a demotion and a lot of people were laid off. It made me feel secure about making a living for my family."
Mr. Ventress is just one of several thousand people in Arkansas who benefited from Governor Clinton's industrial policies, which have brought a job creation rate that is far higher than the national average, especially in the state's large industries like poultry processing and paper.
But Howard Goggans, a retired plant controller for the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, another large paper company in Arkansas that also took advantage of the investment credits, considers them corporate welfare subsidies. Unlike nearby states, Mr. Goggans says, Arkansas loosely structures and enforces the tax credits, enabling companies not only to pay less in taxes, but also to eliminate jobs.
When his own company asked for state approval of a multimillion-dollar tax credit several years ago, Mr. Goggans said, "it was rubber-stamped; no one ever looked at whether we did what we said we would do." In the end, he said, the investment was for "modernization that actually lost jobs."
A spokeswoman for Georgia Pacific acknowledged that the tax credits had led to a decrease in the number of jobs, from 146 employees to 123 at one Arkansas mill modernized under the act. But she also said the opposite had been true at another mill.
The investment credit law does not require companies to create jobs to be eligible for the benefit. Mr. Goggans, who was a member of Mr. Clinton's tax reform commission, said he had tried unsuccessfully to persuade the Governor to change that.
To attract business, Arkansas, with Mr. Clinton's support, introduced the investment tax credit and other special tax breaks, like exemptions from sales taxes for a wide range of business activities. In part, Arkansas has had to do this to compete with other states that are also aggressively competing for jobs. As a result of the tax breaks, overall job growth in Arkansas in the last decade has been robust. But there is a price, which Mr. Clinton has said he is willing to pay.
 
Growth of Sales Taxes
 State data show that business tax preferences, especially sales tax exemptions, cost the state at least $400 million a year -- almost 20 percent of the state's total revenue. As an apparent result of that and some other factors, in the last decade Arkansas has had to rely increasingly on sales taxes to balance its budget.
Sales and personal income taxes have grown more than twice as fast as corporate tax revenue. The shift is regressive because sales taxes most affect those least able to pay: lower- and middle-income taxpayers. And Arkansas has more than its share of those.
The state's average tax rate is the 42d lowest in the nation. But Citizens for Tax Justice, a public interest group in Washington, says those taxes hit poor families harder than wealthy families by a ratio of 1.7 to 1. That ratio, which has worsened in the years Mr. Clinton has been Governor, is about equal to the national average, as shown in the group's study.
Rodney Burrell, a 25-year-old father of two who earns about $10,000 a year, says the state's tax policy hits people like him the hardest.
Mr. Burrell was trying to buy a used car in North Little Rock recently, hoping to find one that cost less than $2,000 so he could avoid a new sales tax that has been imposed on used car purchases costing more than that. Last year, as part of a tax package intended to raise teachers' salaries, the state raised the general sales tax from 4 percent to 4.5 percent and broadened it to apply to used car sales.
 
Regressive New Taxes
 "I'm looking for something so I don't have to pay the tax," Mr. Burrell said, adding that the tax "hurts the people who can't afford it the most."
Those new taxes are regressive. But any evaluaton of Mr. Clinton's record must take into account a clear impediment he faces as Governor: Under the Arkansas Constitution, any increase in the income tax must be approved by three-fourths of the Arkansas Legislature. That leaves the state government little choice but to raise other taxes.
Improving education has been a high priority for Mr. Clinton. Those are the chief reasons he has added or raised a variety of taxes since taking office, including taxes on cigarettes, insurance premiums and gasoline. But a clear side effect has been to reinforce a longstanding distortion in the distribution of wealth.
Donald R. Market, director of the Arkansas Business and Economic Review at the University of Arkansas, likes to describe the state as "sort of like a developing nation." He noted its persistently higher-than-average unemployment rate and cited figures showing that 75 percent of the state's households earn less than $35,000, compared to 61 percent of households nationwide.
 
The Dominance of Industry
 But he, like many other people in the state, does not blame Mr. Clinton for failing to turn this around. "I don't know if a Bill Clinton or any other governor can turn a poor state into a rich one," he said.
Still, Brownie Ledbetter, president of the Arkansas Fairness Council, a coalition of consumer and labor groups, says industry has such political and economic dominance in the state that it is no wonder the gap between the state's rich and poor remains.
"We've been dominated by corporate folks, politically and economically, since we've been a territory," she said. "We don't have much of a middle class left."
The leaders of the poultry, paper, trucking, energy and financial services industries, among others, have been highly influential members of the state's political establishment for many years. But rather than discussing that, state officials prefer to talk about the job growth rate.
"We had a 3 percent growth rate last year, ranking fifth in the nation, and we were ranked eighth for the year before that," said Joe LaFace, an economist with the Arkansas Department of Finance and Adminstration.
 
Lower Cost of Living
 Mr. LaFace says the figures showing the state's low per capita income are misleading because they are not adjusted for its lower cost of living.
Mr. Market agreed; he estimated that the income gap between Arkansas and other states would be "narrowed but not eliminated" after taking that into account.
Mr. LaFace says the 200,000-plus jobs added over the last decade include a higher than normal concentration of manufacturing positions, particularly in food processing, one of the state's biggest industries.
The most frequent source of wealth for the state's richest citizens, according to a recent cover story in the monthly magazine Arkansas Times, is the poultry industry. The Tyson family has grown rich from that.
John Tyson, vice chairman of Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest poultry-processing company, said his company added 15,000 workers in the last 12 years, from 6,000 in 1980 to 21,000 today.
 
Business Tax Breaks
 The company and its officials have long been financial backers of Mr. Clinton, and have allowed him to use the company airplane numerous times at no charge, public records show.
State officials say the poultry and feed industry has thrived because of sales tax exemptions, investment credits and extremely low severance taxes on natural gas.
Still, three years ago a tax reform commission appointed by the Governor recommended eliminating some of the business tax breaks, including the 1985 investment credit. The commission said there was too little accountability and not enough assurance that the tax credits were actually used in ways that created jobs.
Enterprise zone tax credit regulations were eventually tightened, restricting eligibility. But the Clinton administration did not eliminate any corporate tax preferences.
 
Legislative Impediment
 Mr. Clinton has argued that eliminating the preferences would do more harm than good. And Timothy J. Leathers, the state's revenue commissioner, says the Governor has been unable to raise other taxes, such as a severance tax on natural gas, because the Legislature would not agree.
Officials in the Governor's office also say they have been unable to get the state's voters to approve any change in the constitutional requirement for a three-quarters majority in the Legislature for an income tax increase.
Others, like Ms. Ledbetter and Mr. Goggans, contend that Mr. Clinton has not tried hard enough to overcome that requirement.
Ms. Ledbetter describes herself as a longtime supporter of Mr. Clinton, but she said he "hasn't been willing to use his political capital" for that, though "other governors have done that, have been willing to take it on."

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Chief Rejects Push for Change

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, today rejected initiatives by both intelligence committees in Congress to legislate a wholesale reorganization of the United States spy system.
Unveiling the Bush Administration's modest plan to reorganize the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister intelligence agencies, Mr. Gates told a joint hearing of the Senate and House intelligence committees, "Our changes should be evolutionary, conforming to the reality of an unstable, unpredictable, dangerously overarmed and still transforming world." 
 He added that based on the recommendations of 14 study groups he created soon after becoming the nation's top intelligence officer last November, the Bush Administration preferred to initiate its own changes.
Except for a request from Congress for new authority to shift money among intelligence priorities, he said: "The Administration believes legislation is unnecessary. Indeed, in a fast-changing world I believe legislation would be unwise."
 
Warns Against Cuts
 Mr. Gates also told the lawmakers to resist the impulse to slash the intelligence budget, estimated at $30 billion a year. "As our military capability shrinks, we had best be cautious about too quickly weakening our early warning capability -- our intelligence capability," Mr. Gates said.
The chairmen of the two panels, Senator David L. Boren and Representative Dave McCurdy, both Oklahoma Democrats who had proposed similar reorganization bills, expressed disappointment that the Administration did not go further in its own efforts to streamline and reduce the size of its intelligence apparatus. Mr. Boren asked Mr. Gates to "keep an open mind" on the possibility of putting some structural changes into law.
The most obvious shortcoming of the Administration plan, they said, was its failure to create a new national agency to streamline the collection and communication of satellite photographs.
Last June, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf complained to Congress about the quality and timeliness of the intelligence given his forces during the Persian Gulf war, noting as one example, that field commanders were unable to get reconnaissance photographs of potential Iraqi military targets that were less than a day old. A C.I.A. study group strongly recommended creating a new agency and wanted to model it on the National Security Agency, which is responsible for eavesdropping around the world.
In his testimony, Mr. Gates admitted that "one of the most difficult areas for us to address was that of imagery," adding that there were "a lot of bureaucratic difficulties trying to wire that thing together given the existence of a lot of other institutions."
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was adamantly opposed, because the Defense Mapping Agency, which makes maps and currently reports to him, would become part of the new agency, Administration officials said. The new agency would not report to General Powell, the officials said.
 
Cheeney Expresses Doubts
 Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney also expressed serious reservations about any such reorganization, and officials in the C.I.A. were concerned about losing control over the National Photographic Interpretation Center, which analyzes satellite photographs, these Administration officials said.
Mr. McCurdy said, "This is the one recommendation that steps on the most toes," as well as involves the most money, "and therefore, you're going to have the most opposition to it."
Mr. Gates also said that the nation's espionage apparatus would move away from its preoccupation with the former Soviet Union and would focus more resources on other global issues.
The percentage of the total budget devoted to the new Commonwealth of Independent States would be 34 percent in the next budget while 50 percent had been devoted to the Soviet Union. Only 15 percent of the C.I.A.'s budget would be spent on analysis and operations in the former Soviet Union, he said.
The decision was made as a result of National Security Review 29, which was written by Mr. Gates while he was deputy national security adviser at the request of Mr. Bush. It envisioned a reshaping of the nation's intelligence priorities through the year 2005 to include a greater focus on issues that have not previously been central to insuring national security.
 
Four Concerns Mentioned
 Although Mr. Gates declined to discuss the details of the review in open session, he identified these as the main concerns: political and economic developments in the Commonwealth of Independent States, including proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and control of nuclear weapons; the spread of nuclear, chemical, biological weapons and ballistic missiles worldwide; narcotics and terrorism; financial and trade issues and technological developments that could adversely affect the Untied States, and new issues like threats to the environment, natural resources and health.
He said, for example, that the safety of foreign nuclear reactors and health problems from nuclear waste were identified as areas of concern.
Mr. Gates also announced a number of structural changes in the intelligence community, which he said Mr. Bush had accepted.
The National Intelligence Council, for example, a sort of academic council that is supposed to bring together the opinions of intelligence agencies throughout the Government, will be broken off from the C.I.A., moved into a new headquarters away from the agency and given more independence.

From left were Mr. Gates, Senators David L. Boren and Frank Murkowski and Representative Dave McCurdy. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Broad Market Is Lower; But the Dow Gains 13.86

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday in volatile trading, with blue chips posting gains but the broader market lower.
Bolstered by rising bond prices and bargain hunting toward the close, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 13.86 points, to 3,249.33, after trading lower most of the session. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a moderate 186.4 million shares, compared with 182.7 million on Tuesday. In the broader market, declining issues led gainers, 1,027 to 666, on the Big Board.
The market suffered at the opening from sharp selloffs in London and Tokyo. Traders said investors were also worried about United States non-farm payroll figures due to be released tomorrow, and first-quarter corporate earnings that will be reported over the next few weeks.
 
Encouraging Signs
 But in an encouraging sign, the National Association of Purchasing Management index rose to 54.1 percent in March from a previous 52.4 percent, which was higher than economists forecast.
 Stocks also drew strength from the bond market, where the 30-year Treasury bond in the secondary market gained 21/32 point to close at 1016/32 . The yield fell to 7.89 percent, from 7.95 percent Tuesday.
 Analysts said investors would continue to look to Japan, where the Nikkei average closed below 19,000 for the first time since January 1987, plunging 764.16 points, or 3.95 percent, to 18,581.79 yesterday. It fell again in very volatile trading today.
Dick Stein, vice president at MKI Securities, said if Tokyo shares firmed, the Dow could rally as much as 30 or 40 points.
 "We need a rally over there and we may get it," said Ron Doran, director of institutional trading at C. L. King & Associates. "That could pop us up, no question about it."
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks gained 0.54 point, to 404.23. The American Stock Exchange index fell 1.89, to 393.15.
 The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.17, to 223.42. The Nasdaq over-the-counter index fell 1.
 
 
Centocor and Grace Retreat
 Among active shares, Centocor dropped 1 1/2, to 27 5/8. A Prudential Securities analyst, Joseph Edelman, removed it from the position of "single best idea" in the biotechnology stock group.
 W. R. Grace shed 3 1/4, to 37 1/2. The company said first-quarter earnings were likely to decline.
 Traders attributed losses among some bank shares to worries about Olympia & York's financial predicament. The big property developer is scrambling to meet impending debt obligations.
 Citicorp lost 1/2, to 16. Chemical Banking dropped 1/8, to 23 5/8. Chase Manhattan eased 5/8, to 23 1/4.
 Bristol-Myers Squibb edged up 1 3/8, to 77 5/8, in active trading. A Kidder, Peabody analyst, Jerry Brimeyer, repeated a buy rating following a sharp decline in the share price Tuesday on concerns about first-quarter results.
 A retailer, 50-Off Stores, fell 2 3/8, to 22 1/8, on what analysts and the company said were less than expected annual results of 63 cents a share, compared with 33 cents a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Gain; Taxable Funds Hold Steady

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on the money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed in the last week.
Tax-exempt money fund yields moved up smartly in the week ended Monday because of a combination of factors, including the increase of supply and the absence of an increase in demand. To attract investors, issuers sometimes push up yields. 
 The seven-day compounded average yield for tax-exempt funds rose 27 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.04 percent, with the simple yield up 26 basis points, to 2.99 percent. In the same period, the 30-day compounded yield rose 12 basis points, to 2.72 percent, and the simple yield gained 11 basis points, to 2.68 percent.
Donoghue's said the average number of days left to maturity of securities being held in portfolios was unchanged at 51 days. Managers reached out to the longer maturities to try to pull in the higher yields because they did not expect interest rates to move higher soon.
According to Donoghue's, the total assets of tax-exempt funds for the week were down a sizable $1.2 billion, to $96.3 billion. In the previous week, assets declined $760 million.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded average yield was 4.22 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket was 4.40 percent.
For the week ended Tuesday, among taxable funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Fidelity Spartan Municipal Money Market Fund was the best performer for the second consecutive week. The fund had a return of 3.95 percent, up from 3.62 percent the previous week.
The assets of taxable funds fell $16.2 billion, Donoghue's said. It was a record outflow, but analysts noted that the size of this category had grown steadily and was in proportion to the total of $481.9 billion.
Most of the outflow was attributed to institutions, which pulled $12.4 billion from the funds, leaving their total assets at $146 billion. Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, said the institutions, which had entered the money funds in a big way when interest rates began dropping, were swinging out to the more attractive yields in other short-term investments, like Treasury bills, because money-fund yields were essentially flat.
 
Yields Unchanged
 The average seven-day compounded taxable average yield was unchanged at 3.80 percent, with the simple yield also unchanged at 3.73 percent. The compounded and simple 30-day yields were also unchanged, at 3.80 percent and 3.73 percent, repsectively.
The taxable fund with the best return was the Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, at 4.54 percent. The fund's distributor is the Olde Distribution Corporation of Detroit.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.63 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor. Its national index was down 2 basis points from the previous week.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
Aides Seek Right Song For Clinton

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
Having dealt with sex and drugs, the Clinton campaign must now overcome the most impossible hurdle of all: rock and roll.
"We just can't find a theme song," said Gary Ginsberg, who is in charge of the Arkansas Governor's advance team. "We have tried everything from R.E.M. to John Philip Sousa. You could not imagine how much energy, imagination and debate has been devoted to this issue." 
 For a while the Blues Brothers caught on with the heavily Chicago-based staff. But, as many people know, John Belushi was the lead singer and he died of a drug overdose.
"That was the end of that idea," said Mr. Ginsberg. "Every song has one lyric that may offend one person. Or an artist may have had a drug conviction 10 years ago."
"I Feel Good," by James Brown seemed to work well for the Governor. But Mr. Brown was recently released from a Federal prison. Forget that one. In Chicago the campaign gave "Taking it to the Streets" by the Doobie Brothers a tryout, and the song won a quick following. At least until the staff started paying attention to the lyrics, which contain a brief, questionable reference to Jesus. Bye-bye Doobie Brothers.
"Its preposterous," said Mr. Ginsberg, who has taken to buying compact discs as he travels the country.
 
Beyond the Citadel Of Blandness
 Attentive voters are already used to the way Mr. Clinton constantly speaks in three-part plans and five-point programs. But many are only beginning to focus on former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California who, when he slips into Moonbeam Mode, can turn the most linguistically hardened head to mush.
On Tuesday Mr. Brown was asked by Mayor Douglas Palmer of Trenton what he would do to invest more money in the nation's cities. This was his reply:
"I hope to get myself elected on a platform that operates as a battering ram to break down that citadel of blindness and complacency that continues year after year to go along with a kind of almost genocide of a whole generation of youth."
Later, he was asked to clarify his position on the tax system:
"The tax code is like a wet blanket and a ball and chain on the economy," he replied.
Enough said.
 
Clinton Leaves Donahue Speechless
 Mr. Clinton visited the Phil Donahue show yesterday, a program that often explores the inner meaning of marital infidelity and drug use, among many other issues.
The Arkansas Governor believes he has said enough those subjects and was hoping to talk about a few others. Wrong program.
"We're going to sit here a long time in silence, Phil," Mr. Clinton said as Mr. Donahue pressed for more details on previously reported accusations that he had a long affair with a cabaret singer. "I'm not going to answer any more of these questions. I've answered them until I'm blue in the face. You are responsible for the cynicism in this country."
Phil looked wounded.
"I think there is, perhaps, a responsibility to speak directly to the fact that hanging over your front-running candidacy is a potential deal breaker in the fall when you run against George Bush," he said.
Mr. Clinton told him he was "debasing our politics."
After what seemed like 17 hours, a member of the audience was finally allowed to speak. It may not be representative, but here is what she said:
"I really think, given the pathetic state of most of the United States at this point I can't believe you spent half an hour of air time attacking this man's character," the woman said. "I'm not even a Bill Clinton supporter, but I think this is ridiculous.'
 
Scratch Out The Other Fellow
 When Mr. Brown visited the editorial office of New York Newsday yesterday he was surrounded by people seeking autographs. Somebody handed him a newspaper with a picture of himself, Mr. Clinton and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson on the front page.
Other politicians might have just signed the paper. But Mr. Brown took a pen and proceeded to scratch Mr. Clinton's face out of the photo.
Then he signed his name, patted the the muff on a nearby sound boom, and cheerfully handed the paper back to the astonished autograph-seeker.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Foreign Policy;
Turning His Sights Overseas, Clinton Sees a Problem at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton accused President Bush yesterday of failing to articulate clear goals for American foreign policy after the cold war and outlined his own program for assisting Russia's transition to democracy.
In his second major foreign policy address of the campaign, Mr. Clinton tried to attack Mr. Bush on what has been regarded as his greatest strength: foreign policy. Speaking at a Manhattan hotel five days before the New York primary, the Democratic candidate cited several specific areas where he disagreed with Mr. Bush -- from what he called his failure to get a handle on relations with Japan, his slow response to events in Russia and his reluctance to use trade sanctions against China. 
 But Mr. Clinton also leveled a broader critique, saying the President had failed to provide a compelling vision to justify American engagement abroad after the cold war.
Addressing the Foreign Policy Association, a nonpartisan group that sponsors discussions on foreign affairs, Mr. Clinton argued that because of President Bush's inability "to offer a compelling rationale for America's continued engagement in the world, the Administration has invited a new birth of isolationism on the left and the right."
 
'Alliance for Democracy'
 Calling the Bush foreign policy essentially "reactive, rudderless and erratic," Mr. Clinton declared that America "deserves better than activism without vision, prudence without purpose and tactics without strategy."
Speaking at the New York Hilton, Mr. Clinton detailed his own vision, in which he argued that the United States can lead "a global alliance for democracy as united and steadfast as the global alliance that defeated Communism."
He said that as first steps Washington must seize the opportunity to buttress free markets in former Communist lands, develop a national strategy to more effectively compete in the global economy -- on the grounds that America cannot be influential abroad "if we are weak at home" -- and make better use of the United Nations to stabilize and prevent regional conflicts.
President Bush chose almost the exact hour of Mr. Clinton's speech to present his own latest ideas on how to support free-market reforms in Russia, underscoring the problems that any Democratic candidate is going to have in making foreign policy an issue in the campaign.
 
Similar Ideas on Russia
 From the beginning of the Bush Administration the Democrats have often felt frustrated in the foreign policy arena, precisely because it seems that every time they propose something -- particularly in the area of arms control and support for former Soviet republics -- the White House eventually adopts a version of it, deflating the Democratic critique.
Mr. Clinton's ideas for shoring up democracy in the former Communist lands tracked closely with those of Mr. Bush. The Democratic candidate called for contributing $1 billion to a $6 billion Western fund to help stabilize the ruble so Russia can better import and export goods, but only after further draconian economic reforms are implemented by the Russians.
He also called for temporarily suspending Russia's servicing of its external debts, $1.2 billion in new American loans to help the former Soviet states import manufacturing materials, food and medicine, and replenishment of the American support for the International Monetary Fund to make it better able to assist the new democracies in Eastern Europe. He also asked for an expansion of person-to-person contacts that would bring American advisers to Russia and thousands of Russians and others to the United States for study.
Mr. Clinton argued that the several billion dollars needed to finance his programs could come from the defense budget and foreign aid savings resulting from the end of the cold war. But he left this vague and provided no breakdown or details to show exactly where the funds would come from.
He framed his general proposals in simple images that the average person might understand. Talking about a stabilization fund he said: "A fund of this kind is like a net for acrobats. By building confidence, it reduces the chance it will ever be used."
Russian aid in general, he said, should be looked at "not as a bailout, but a bridge loan, much as a family gets from the bank when it buys a new house before selling their old house."
Indeed, judging from today's speech by Mr. Clinton, what distinguishes Mr. Clinton's foreign policy from that pursued by Mr. Bush may be less the substance than the strong ability to articulate a rationale.
 
'Flattered' by Bush's Timing
 In many ways, Mr. Clinton gave the speech that Congressional Democrats and former President Richard M. Nixon have been urging President Bush to give for months. The Arkansas Governor gave voice to actions that in many cases the President himself has already done, or is proposing to do, but has struggled to put into words in a way that would be comprehensible and win broad domestic support.
Asked for his reaction to the fact that the President scheduled his announcement for the exact time of Mr. Clinton's long-scheduled speech, Mr. Clinton said: "I am flattered. I wish I could have the same influence on his domestic policy."
Mr. Clinton tried to distinguish his basically centrist foreign policy from the equally centrist approach of Mr. Bush by denouncing some specific Administration actions. But some of his criticism appeared to some listeners as a stretch, particularly his argument that the Administration propped up the Government of Mikhail S. Gorbachev "long after" it was obvious that power had shifted to the republics, or that Mr. Bush was browbeating Israel while "nurturing ties to Syria."
Where Mr. Clinton also tried to distinguish himself from the President was by underscoring his willingness to make the case to the American people about why such an investment in Russia and other republics at this time is in the long-term American interest. He said President Bush, before today, had been afraid to do that because of the unpopularity of foreign aid.
"I know it isn't popular today to call for foreign assistance of any kind," said Mr. Clinton. "It's harder when Americans are hurting, as millions are today. But I believe it is deeply irresponsible to forgo this short-term investment in our long-term security."
"Let me be clear: our nation can afford this," Mr. Clinton added. "This is not an exorbitant price to pay for a chance to create new American markets and anchor a revitalized Russia firmly in the democratic camp."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Loans for Argentina

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund on Tuesday announced a $3.15 billion package of loans to Argentina, which the country hopes to use to stretch its huge commercial debt.
The funds are expected to help Argentina in talks with private banks aimed at rescheduling the country's $31 billion in commercial debt. Argentina's total foreign debt is $62 billion. 
 The I.M.F. package included a $2.95 billion loan that runs through 1994 and $200 million originally pledged under a previous arrangement with the fund. About $900 million will be used as guarantees in Argentina's dealings with banks to reschedule and cut commercial debt.
The Argentine Economy Minister, Domingo Cavallo, said from Tokyo that Japan was willing to help Argentina raise funds for its dealings with the banks. Mr. Cavallo spoke after holding talks with Tsutomu Hata, Japan's Finance Minister.
"They confirmed that there is a good predisposition in Japan to help us raise the enhancements," Mr. Cavallo said.
Argentina wants its commercial creditors to reschedule its debt over 30 years. It has also offered to pay $400 million on past interest. Banks had sought a $1.1 billion payment.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

LAGGING BEHIND ON RECOVERY
Economists are growing increasingly convinced that a national recovery is finally under way, but they caution that residents of the New York region will have to be more patient. A recovery in the region is likely to lag behind that of the rest of the nation by six months or more, many said, with economic growth resuming only in 1993. B7.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
DINKINS PICKS HOSPITALS CHIEF
Mayor Dinkins nominated Dr. Billy E. Jones, the city's Mental Health Commissioner, to be president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation. The announcement came a week after a mayoral search committee said that it could not find a suitable candidate for the post, mainly because applicants said that the current salary of $129,000 was too low. B3.
 
COLOMBO MOB LEADERS ARRESTED
As jurors considered testimony in the murder and racketeering trial of John Gotti, the reputed boss of the Gambino crime family, Federal officials announced that they had arrested two leaders of another crime family, the Colombos. B3.
 
BATTLE OVER THE SCHOOL BUDGET 
 Brushing aside Mayor Dinkins's request to trim $100 million from next year's school budget, Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez called for a 7.8 percent increase in spending for items ranging from school repairs to better security. B3.

REGION
 
RATE INCREASE FOR BLUE CROSS
New York State's insurance superintendent is poised to announce a steep increase in health insurance costs for more than 1.5 million subscribers to Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which covers the New York City, Hudson Valley and Albany areas. Some people's premiums could go up by as much as 21 percent. A1.

HEADLINE: Welfare and Medicaid Bills Likely to Keep Soaring

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 1

 BODY:
Although the new state budget will wring unprecedented savings from New York's Medicaid and welfare programs, even the budget's architects do not believe it will arrest the explosive growth in spending on social services in the near future.
And unless the economy makes a remarkable rebound in New York, the continued growth in spending on social services for the poor and elderly may open large deficits in the budget this year and in subsequent years. 
 State leaders have pointed to their ability to agree on $1.1 billion worth of changes in Medicaid and welfare as one of the signal achievements of this year's budget negotiations. But the patchwork package produced by the Assembly Democrats and Senate Republicans is, as has often been the case in recession-era Albany, a compromise driven more by the need to generate cash quickly than by any consensus on a policy to control long-term spending growth.
"We cut growth this year, but only in a superficial way," said one legislative aide who is an expert on Medicaid issues.
Even with the $1.1 billion in savings, the state's spending on Medicaid and welfare is projected to grow from $6.1 billion last year to $6.5 billion this year. The state's welfare caseload grew from a monthly average of 1.3 million in 1990 to 1.5 million last December; the Medicaid caseload grew from a monthly average of 2.4 million in 1990 to 2.6 million in November.
 
No Driving Vision
 Because there is no guiding ideological or political imperative behind Albany's welfare reform movement, the budget's initiatives stand in contrast to more extreme measures enacted in other states. States from New Jersey to California have pared welfare-grant levels, eliminated welfare programs for the able-bodied poor and have threatened to withhold the welfare grant if recipients fail to search for work or have additional children.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Democrats who hold a majority in the Assembly have blocked similar changes in New York, arguing that such moves would balance the budget on the backs of the poor and could have severe long-term costs, both in human and financial terms.
But rather than making the Medicaid and welfare systems more efficient, many of the measures included in the budget compromise may simply shift the state's costs to health-care providers, patients and local governments.
 
Missing the Mark
 "The majority of the changes do not really cut expenditures," said Cynthia Green, an analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group financed by businesses.
The state plans to raise $229 million, for example, by extending and increasing taxes on the revenues of hospitals and nursing homes that were first imposed late in 1990.
It will save $20 million by requiring Medicaid patients to make payments whenever they receive service. And it will require local governments to begin paying a share of the energy costs that the state currently covers for welfare recipients, amounting to $50 million.
In the five months since the state discovered a $4.8 billion gap in its $30.8 billion budget, state leaders have agreed that much of the deficit would have to be closed with cuts in social services, the fastest growing part of the budget. But they have struggled to achieve a balance in how the cuts should be made.
 
New York City Influence
 The Assembly Democrats want to provide as much protection as possible to Medicaid and welfare recipients, particularly in a recession. Fifty-seven of the 95 Democrats in the Assembly are from New York City, where two-thirds of the state's welfare recipients live.
The Senate Republicans, meanwhile, are determined to protect an already weak health-care industry, including the nursing homes and hospitals that care for many of the state's Medicaid recipients.
Both sides claimed small victories. The Senate Republicans won approval to start a demonstration project in Rockland and Onandaga Counties aimed at deterring welfare fraud by fingerprinting recipients. Many Assembly Democrats objected to the project, because they felt it equated welfare recipients with criminals.
The Assembly Democrats, meanwhile, fended off Republican efforts to cut Home Relief grants and make deep cuts in Medicaid benefits. And they received Republican support for an initiative that would penalize health maintenance organizations that do not meet targets for enrolling Medicaid recipients.
They see the gradual transformation of the state's Medicaid program into a "managed care" system -- which requires recipients to use health maintenance organizations and similar prepaid health programs-- as a temporary check on health-care spending, necessary until a universal health-care system can be developed.
 
'Seasonal Budget Chaos'
 Officials with interest groups representing both the poor and health-care providers agreed that the unusual changes in this year's budget reflects not only New York's bipartisan Legislature, but also its recurring inability to balance its budget.
"It's the price we pay for seasonal budget chaos," said Daniel Sisto, president of the Hospital Association of New York State. "We no sooner get through one of these battles than we get another deficit and it starts all over again. Nobody can think long-term."

HEADLINE: Asked to Cut Back, Fernandez Seeks $517 Million More

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Brushing aside Mayor David N. Dinkins's request to trim $100 million from next year's New York City schools budget, Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday called for a $517 million increase in spending for items ranging from school repairs and security to a longer school day for some students.
The Chancellor's budget request, calling for a 7.8 percent increase, marks the beginning of the annual tug of war over how much will be spent to educate the public schools system's 973,000 students. 
 In unveiling his request for a record $7.185 billion operating budget, Mr. Fernandez conceded that he might not get everything he asked for. But he said, "We feel very comfortable with what we're requesting. We don't feel there's anything frivolous."
 
'Funds Aren't There'
 The Chancellor attributed more than half of the $517 million increase to such mandatory costs as those due to inflation, contract settlements with teachers, and legislative and regulatory requirements. But he said he would use $200 million from the increase for new programs.
Mr. Dinkins's budget director, Philip R. Michael, said yesterday that "the funds aren't there" to provide the board with an extra $517 million. But he said it was "appropriate" for Mr. Fernandez to seek as much assistance as possible from the Mayor.
"If you don't speak up," Mr. Michael said, "your agency's priorities are not going to be able to compete with other agency's priorities."
Among new programs, the Chancellor said he hoped to secure $70 million from the refinancing of city bonds with the Municipal Assistance Corporation for a three-point plan to improve school productivity. That plan, he said, would lengthen the school day for some middle school students, use computers to teach basic skills in elementary schools and help selected young students avoid costly special-education classes.
An additional $81.5 million in the budget would be used for emergency repairs at a handful of school buildings that are in "deplorable" condition, the Chancellor said, with problems like leaky roofs, faulty boilers and broken windows.
The total budget proposal, including pensions and debt service, would be $7.746 billion.
 
Assistance Corporation
 The process of fashioning a budget for the schools this year promises to be particularly heated, in light of the city's continuing fiscal constraints and the school system's rising enrollment. The board anticipates that it will have spent $6.668 billion on operating expenses when the current fiscal year ends June 30.
To help plug the city's budget gaps over the next two years, Mr. Dinkins said last month that he hoped to borrow more than $250 million, with the help of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, through a complex bond refinancing. But the chairman of the assistance corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, has warned against such a move, although he originally suggested it. The assistance corporation also controls $200 million in surpluses, accrued through past refinancings, that the city would like to use.
But even if assistance corporation money were made available to the city, Mr. Michael said yesterday, it is far from certain how much, if any, the schools would get. Mr. Rohatyn's office said yesterday that he was traveling in Europe and could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Michael also said the city would not automatically pay for every expense that the Chancellor listed in the budget under the category of mandatory increases. "That certainly is not the end of the discussion," said Mr. Michael, who added that those costs would be reviewed carefully.
 
'It Wouldn't Be Pleasant'
 In his budget request, Mr. Fernandez did not suggest how he would handle potential budget cuts, despite indications from Mr. Dinkins in January that the schools might have to pare $100 million in the coming fiscal year. Mr. Fernandez said it was "too early" to make such determinations.
"It wouldn't be pleasant," Mr. Fernandez told reporters, "but we'd come up with ways of making cuts."
Mr. Michael said the city has shielded the schools from any potential cuts in state education aid that might emerge from the state budget negotiations.
Included in the Chancellor's proposal are two requests for new money that the city has already agreed to. As part of a $28 million program announced by the Mayor on March 1 to tighten school security at the city's most dangerous high schools, $8 million will be added to the current operating budget. The city has also promised $36 million for school security and conflict resolution under the Safe Streets-Safe City program.
Mr. Fernandez presented his request yesterday to the Board of Education, which will hold a public hearing on April 15 before voting on whether to send it to City Hall.
"It's important for us to talk about what we need and why we need it," said H. Carl McCall, the board president. "That's what this budget does."

HEADLINE: Reasons Assessed for Lag In Metropolitan Recovery

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Economists are growing increasingly convinced that a national recovery is finally under way, but they caution that residents of the New York metropolitan region will have to be more patient. A recovery in the region is likely to lag behind that of the rest of the nation by six months or more, many said, with economic growth resuming only in 1993.
The reasons are many. The recession started in the metropolitan region about a year and a half earlier than elsewhere and has been much more severe, making it a steeper climb back to stability and ultimately to growth. 
 "The mood here is a bit more fragile -- confidence is weaker," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which forecast on Tuesday that the region would lose an additional 200,000 jobs in 1992. That means it will take longer than in other parts of the country for people to feel inclined to part with some of their income, in stores and restaurants or with their real-estate brokers. And until they do, the region's economy is expected to be slower to rebound.
 
Sharp Drop in Demand
 The severity of the local recession has a lot to do with the fact that many of the industries that dominate New York City's economy are in the services sector, like advertising, banking, law, and accounting. After expanding at a breakneck pace in the 1980's, virtually all those industries are facing new competitors from overseas and a sharp drop in demand because so many of their corporate clients have merged or gone out of existence.
These industries are struggling to adapt to the new economic climate at a time when they are burdened with the excessive overheads that they built up during the booming 1980's. The restructuring of many of these industries has contributed heavily to the 495,000 jobs that have been lost in the region in the last two years.
"This is a region that is in the painful and wrenching throes of reinventing itself in all the industries that define what New York is all about," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "We're very far from reaching the end of that road."
The weakness in the region's private sector has been matched by state and local governments, which will further delay a recovery. With residents earning and spending less, income, property and sales-tax revenues have fallen steeply. The reduced size of New York City's budget has led to more job cuts in the public sector and less public spending on hospitals, economic development and infrastructure projects like roads and school construction.
All of that, in turn, detracts from local economic activity. Economists say one reason they are so gloomy about the region's employment prospects this year is the anticipated reduction in the size of the state and city work forces in New York.
 
Strong International Ties
 Until recently, many people viewed the city's strong international ties as a source of economic strength that could offset some of these other weaker areas. The city has served as a major distribution point for traded goods, and in recent years the export of services like investment banking, legal advice and advertising has become increasingly important to the local economy.
But with Europe suffering from high interest rates and the strain of trying to prop up eastern Europe, and with the Japanese financial and real-estate sectors slumping, even that segment of the New York economy seems to be vulnerable.
But while job losses are expected to continue to plague the region, economists say it is also important to look at wage rates.
 
Higher Wage Rates
 Even in its boom years, said Robert V. Nicoletti, senior forecasting economist for the city's Office of Management and Budget, the New York region was never great at generating new jobs. What it has done well, however, is to produce higher average wages. From 1979 to 1990, for example, employment grew less than 9 percent, while average wages, adjusted for inflation, rose by 15 percent.
"If you look at what happened to the city's economy in the 1980's," said Mr. Nicoletti, "two-thirds of the growth was due to rising real wage rates, not rising employment." Nationally during that same period, employment grew by 22 percent while real wages remained virtually flat.
Even last year, when the city lost 194,000 nonagricultural jobs, the average wage rate rose by about 3.5 percent, Mr. Nicoletti said. And he forecasts that the increase will be even greater this year, augmenting last year's gains, and will exceed the national average.
Ms. Scanlon of the Port Authority agreed. "Incomes will grow, but jobs will probably lag this year," she said. "The feeling will be one of recovery, even though the jobs won't show it."

HEADLINE: Port Agency Says Hoboken Owes Refund

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., April 1

 BODY:
A day after Hoboken voters, for the second time in two years, defeated a plan to redevelop the city's crumbling waterfront with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as a partner, the bistate agency says it wants a refund of at least part of the $30 million it has spent on the project over the last decade.
Sounding clearly frustrated, the chairman of the Port Authority, Richard C. Leone, said yesterday: "As far as I'm concerned, there is no project. The people have decided the issue locally. We've invested about $30 million various ways, and I think Hoboken has a financial obligation." 
 But Hoboken officials said they were meeting with a citizens coalition to evaluate its alternative to the defeated plan and quickly propose a new one to the authority. "We're going to move very fast in evaluating what the coalition proposed and keep Port Authority funds in Hoboken," said Mayor Patrick Pasculli.
The defeat of the plan, which would have given Hoboken a $3.25 million advance lease payment from the authority immediately, means that property taxes will definitely go up next year, said Peggy Thomas, the city's director of planning and community development.
"I don't see any other alternative," said Ms. Thomas, who was a leader of the campaign to have the plan approved. "We've lost our industrial base, and we have no tax base. The only thing we can do is turn to our property owners."
Hoboken, with 33,400 residents, has had a surge of gentrification over the last decade, but the rising number of professionals buying condominiums and cooperatives has not offset the losses from dwindling industry, officials say.
The defeated plan called for 1.88 million square feet of development on parcels near the Hoboken transit terminals, including a 20-story office building and 9-story hotel on a 5.5-acre pier and two residential buildings of 21 and 17 stories just inland from the pier. The rest of the city-owned property would be developed with the advice of a citizens group.
Under the plan, the city would lease the 1.88 million square feet to the Port Authority for 55 years; the authority would prepare the site and seek a developer. It would also build a park, expand the city's Little League field and give the city 20 percent of the development's gross revenues for the first 35 years and 60 percent for the remaining 20 years.
Supporters said the plan would mean short-term budget relief, new recreation areas for children and, eventually, 4,500 new jobs and $3 million to $4 million in annual revenues.
But opponents, led by a group called the Coalition for a Better Waterfront, had several objections. They said it would mean a too-tall, environmentally destructive tower in the river that would dwarf Hoboken's three- and four-story brownstones, and maybe even siphon business from the city's vibrant commercial district. They also noted that the promised fiscal relief was no sure thing, since the agreement did not call for any development until the year 2005.
The opponents argued, apparently effectively, that the city was pushing hard for a flawed project because of its short-term budget problems. They said city officials needed the authority's $3.25 million payment to fill a budget gap projected at $13.2 million next year, or one-third of the entire city budget, and did not want to have to repay the Port Authority $7 million it had received as an advance in 1989, before a larger development plan was defeated by 12 votes.
 
Chance for Coalition's Plan
 Hoboken is now liable for the $7 million. Ms. Thomas said the money had been set aside in case of a defeat.
She also added that the Coalition for a Better Waterfront's plan may have a chance. Its proposal, designed by a Manhattan architect, Craig Whitaker, would create parkland along the water's edge, with a milelong esplanade the entire length of Hoboken and 19 blocks of mixed development no more than eight stories high.
While Mr. Leone said that the authority was seeking legal advice to recoup "at least some" of the $30 million it had invested, he added that the agency would be willing to hear "any plan from anyone."
"We're not going away as an agency," he said. "We have many items on our plate."
At least once before, the Port Authority said it would drop all plans for the Hoboken waterfront because of citizens' opposition, but it has repeatly re-entered negotiations.
In 1984, the New York and New Jersey Legislatures passed bills that would let the Port Authority spend $125 million in each state to develop mixed residential and commercial properties on the waterfronts at Hunters Point, Queens, and Hoboken. While the Hoboken project has stalled, the Hunters Point project is moving ahead, with private money already committed, said Mr. Leone.
Although Hoboken officials have said that the Port Authority could take the money elsewhere, Mr. Leone said the legislation made it clear where the $125 million was to be spent. He added, however, that it did not mean the agency had to spend it.
"It could just sit there," he said.
