HEADLINE: Quayle Says Rules Review Saving U.S. $10 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Pressing what has become a chief domestic theme in the election year, the Bush Administration said today that its 90-day review of Federal regulations would produce savings of $10 billion to $20 billion a year.
The White House is now seeking ways to subject permanently to Administration review the thousands of regulations Congress mandates for everything from chemical exposure in the workplace to meat labeling. 
 "This is only the beginning," said Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads President Bush's Council on Competitiveness. "We are the ones who are going to run this operation -- and it's not going to be the Congress."
Briefing reporters in his office, Mr. Quayle said that with about 50 initiatives already announced by the Administration for reducing the cost of regulations, which he estimated at $400 billion a year, the focus had shifted to finding a way to "institutionalize" the review process.
In announcing in his State of the Union Message, President Bush announced a 90-day review of regulations and a moratorium on implementing some new rules.
In addition to confronting Congress, the Vice President's comments were seen as part of an election-year strategy that relies heavily on prompt recovery from the nation's longest postwar recession.
 
More Measures Announced
 "A sluggish economy doesn't need overregulation," Mr. Quayle declared. "A sluggish economy needs less regulation."
Responding to a question about the President's endorsement of various pieces of legislation requiring a host of new rules, Mr. Quayle said the Bush Administration was "probably a little bit lax" about trying to review new regulations during its first 18 months, assuming that the regulatory "beast" had been killed by the Reagan Administration.
At the same time, Government officials announced today another flurry of measures related to the review process. Included in a package identified as reforms in financial services was final adoption of a rule allowing federally chartered thrift institutions to open branches in any state or territory.
The rule was immediately denounced by the Independent Bankers Association of America, which said the Administration had pre-empted state and Congressional authority and that its action could result in the loss of thousands of jobs.
Also announced was the adoption of uniform antitrust enforcement policy by the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission, which share responsibility for approving corporate mergers and acquisitions. The White House said the new policy would give business "greater certainty" about applicable standards.
 
Breakdown on Savings
 Aides to the Vice President, with some apparent reluctance, provided a breakdown on how the administration had calculated its estimate of $10 billion to $20 billion in savings.
The biggest part, $2.4 billion a year, would come from a Presidential order implementing a court decision that union members are not obliged to pay dues for union expenses for things other than collective bargaining.
The estimate also included $1 billion to $3 billion by adding a rule that encourages the use of more natural gas, which would mean cleaner air and cheaper energy, more than $1 billion from the accelerated approval of new drugs, and as much as $8.3 billion in rules enforced by the Environmental Protection Agency, including those covering toxic waste cleanup and air pollution.
Overall, Mr. Quayle promised a regulatory policy based on the initial presumption that any new rule is unnecessary. "They ain't seen nothing yet," the Vice President said.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Lifts a Ministerial Load Off an Economist's Shoulders

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 2

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin freed his chief economic adviser, Yegor T. Gaidar, of his duties as Minister of Finance today, but Mr. Gaidar will remain Deputy Prime Minister charged with overall economic strategy.
Mr. Gaidar and his aides said he had requested the change because Finance Ministry routine was taking too much of his time. He was succeeded as minister by Vasily V. Barchuk, 51 years old, a career official who had been First Deputy Minister of Finance. 
 "Gaidar can now focus his attention on strategic reforms and on coordinating the economic work of the Government," said Aleksei V. Ulyukayev, a senior aide to Mr. Gaidar. The reforms are crucial to a multi-billion-dollar package of foreign aid announced on Wednesday.
The unexpected announcement added to the suspense before next week's session of the Russian Congress of Peoples Deputies and roused some speculation that Mr. Yeltsin might have wanted to give the impression that he was curbing Mr. Gaidar's reach. But Mr. Ulyukayev said Mr. Gaidar remained in overall command of the Finance Ministry.
 
Happy Russians
 Commenting on President Bush's proposed measures to support the economic reforms in Russia, Mr. Ulyukayev said, "It took rather long for the United States Administration to take these decisions, but now we can only welcome them."
The United States Ambassador, Robert S. Strauss, who had been a leading advocate of large-scale aid to the republics, said he had spoken to senior Russian officials "and they are all extremely pleased.
"They are pleased with the package, they are pleased with the Bush-Baker energy that was devoted to it, pleased to learn that it is getting bipartisan support," he said.
"There is concern, a serious concern, that the International Monetary Fund will force some disciplines that will be too harsh for the public taste, and I have spent some time explaining that the I.M.F. may not be the most loved organization in the world, but they are respected for understanding the kind of problems, better than any other institution, that they face out here."
The I.M.F. has called for stringent economic reforms, including letting oil prices rise to free-market levels, as conditions for its assistance.
Whatever its longer-term impact, the announcement of the economic package is certain to benefit Mr. Yeltsin when the Congress, Russia's elected legislature, convenes on Monday.
By all accounts, Mr. Yeltsin's economic program and his style of rule will come under considerable criticism. Already Ruslan Khasbulatov, the ambitious chairman of the Congress, has circulated what amounts to an alternative reform program and has staked out areas of attack.
 
Political Russians
 But Mr. Khasbulatov has denied that he will attack Mr. Yeltsin himself or try to vote out his Government. His main goal is generally viewed as an attempt to assert the powers of the legislature -- and his own powers -- against those of the President and the Government.
The soaring prices and the economic shock that will accompany the end of oil-price controls this spring are the main weapons of the critics. Part of Mr. Yeltsin's problem with the Congress is that the legislature, elected two years ago, is still heavily laced with members of the old nomenklatura, who are instinctively opposed to the reforms under way.
From the other flank, Mr. Yeltsin has to contend with radical members who accuse him of dragging his feet on privatization and of exercising an authoritarian style. Mr. Yeltsin is expected to concentrate on privatization in his opening address on Monday.
Washington's timing in announcing the proposed aid was generally accepted as an attempt to dull the critics' attacks and to make further sacrifices more palatable. The I.M.F. specifically praised Russia's reforms earlier this week when it opened the way to Russian membership.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Opening a new front in the drive to reduce smog, a coalition of New York, New Jersey and the New England states announced an agreement to impose extensive controls on electric generating stations to cut the emission of nitrogen oxides. The states' action was spurred in part by the Federal Clean Air Act amendments of 1990, which call for controls but give few details. [Page A1.] 
 The S.&L. bailout began grinding to a halt after a House vote against continued Federal spending on the industry cleanup. Federally insured deposits are not threatened, and Congress is certain to approve further spending eventually. [D1.]
Orders to U.S. factories rose 0.5 percent in February, the second straight small gain. But first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose for the second week, climbing by 9,000, to 456,000, providing further evidence of a weak recovery. [D1.]
A bill to regulate the cable TV industry bogged down on objections from both Democrats and Republicans, making it likely that the measure will be greatly weakened to pass the House. [D5.]
The Administration said its review of Federal regulations would produce savings of $10 billion to $20 billion a year. [A15.]
 
Companies
A run developed at Metro North State Bank in Kansas City, Mo., spurred in part by depositor fears that bank insurance can no longer be completely trusted. The bank's chairman blamed an "unsubstantiated rumor" that regulators were on the verge of closing the bank. [D1.]
Some victims of stroke and head injury are cared for at home by a private company, Neurocare, of Concord, Calif., which sends a team of therapists to patients' homes daily. The cost, at $5,000 a month, is a fraction of traditional residential programs. [D1.]
A historic changing of the guard at Big Steel -- that is what many say about Thomas J. Usher, president of USX's steel operations, who actually seems to listen to what union leaders have on their minds. [D1.]
Immunex said it was suing Hoechst, with which it developed a drug used in bone marrow transplants, contending that Hoechst provided the drug free to Immunex customers and others. [D3.]
 
International
Olympia & York put off for a week a meeting at which it had promised to open its books to 100 creditor banks to renegotiate its debt. The session, originally scheduled for Monday, will be held on April 13, the company said. [D3.]
 
Markets
Stock prices fell, partly because of computer-driven sell programs, as many investors stayed on the sidelines ahead of the report on March employment. The Dow fell 15.21, to 3,234.12. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading. [D12.]
The dollar fell against most currencies in response to the increase in unemployment benefits claims. [D13.]
Orange juice futures prices sagged after a Government report said Brazil had a much larger share of the newly liberalized Japanese orange juice market than the U.S. had. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
For stock mutual funds, the first quarter was a perplexing combination. The money poured in from investors, but the profits from investing all that money were decidedly mixed. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
What distinguishes the present slump from earlier postwar dips are the structural drags, especially the huge public and private debts and the inflated asset values built in the 1980's. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
When celebrity endorsers become embarrassments, it poses problems for those who use stars to sell products. Now advertisers and agencies are devising strategies to minimize such problems. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: House Democrats Push for Permanent Jobless Pay

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders today demanded a permanent expansion of unemployment benefits and other relief measures, and they pressed President Bush to go along by linking them to proposals to aid Russia's depressed economy.
The steps, proposed by Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the third-ranking House Democrat, and indirectly supported by the majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, are intended to entangle Russian aid and unemployment in election-year politics. 
 They are also intended to renew confidence among Democratic members who are disgruntled about the way in which House leaders have been dealing with the House bank scandal and in confronting the White House.
Mr. Bonior's effort to link foreign aid to domestic policy is part of an emerging Democratic campaign line promising to meet the needs of Americans before the needs of foreign Governments. It is also intended to underscore the impression that Mr. Bush loses his leadership compass when he returns home from his travels abroad.
 
Jobs Bill in Works
 He said the Democratic leadership is working hard to draft a sweeping jobs bill, which he hopes to have introduced in the next few weeks. He gave no details, but Democratic aides suggested legislation would be introduced to expand public works programs significantly.
Mr. Bonior also announced the Democratic leadership's support for a bill introduced Wednesday by Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, to change the extended unemployment benefits program permanently by expanding eligibility and bolstering the financing of unemployment insurance. Mr. Bonior said Democrats would push to extend unemployment benefits to the 60 percent of the unemployed he contended receive no benefits at all because they have been unemployed for so long or because they have part-time jobs.
Currently, about every three months Congress extends benefits for 13 or 20 more weeks, depending on the unemployment rates of individual states. In early February, Mr. Bush signed an extension of benefits valued at $2.7 billion for two million jobless people after Democratic leaders agreed not to press for a longer extension. Last year he killed similar measures on two separate occasions, arguing that he did not want to increase the deficit.
Emergency benefits averaging $170 a week are given to people who have lost their jobs, cannot find work and have exhausted their 26 weeks of state-financed benefits.
 
Relaxing Eligibility
 Under Mr. Downey's proposal, Federal benefits would be extended, and effective Oct. 1, 1993, they would be permanently expanded by lowering the eligibility standards by which states qualify for Federal unemployment benefits and restricting the rights of states to disqualify applicants for benefits.
Currently, most states qualify for 13 weeks of benefits when the rate of unemployment for the recently employed reaches 5 percent, and is 20 percent higher than for the same period during the previous two years. Under Mr. Downey's program, the qualifications for benefits would be expanded considerably. States would qualify for the same 13 weeks once their overall unemployment rate reached 6 percent and 10 percent higher than the same period in the first or second preceding year.
The proposal would also reduce the Federal unemployment tax rate by more than half for most employees, but it would make up the revenue by reducing itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers by 2 percent for every $2,500 their income exceeded $100,000 for a single person and $150,000 for married couples.
Judy Smith, a White House spokeswoman, strongly suggested that Mr. Bush would veto a permanent extension of benefits, saying, "as a general matter we would not support a bill that would bust the budget or raise taxes."
 
Americans' Foreign Stake
 But she contended, "The American people have a major stake in the success in the developing democracy of the states of the former Soviet Union."
It was not immediately clear whether Mr. Bonior's statement linking the expanded unemployment benefits to aid to Russia represented a trial balloon, or a preliminary announcement by the House leadership.
An aide to Mr. Gephardt said Mr. Bonior was speaking for himself. But the Missouri Democrat later issued a statement implicitly supporting the Bonior position.
"The President must understand the linkage between this country's economic well-being and the success of his foreign policy," Mr. Gephardt said. "Not only must he convince the public that his aid package to the former Soviet Union is in our deep self-interest but he must also assure them he is equally committed to creating jobs and helping the unemployed here at home."

HEADLINE: Dow Off 15.21, to 3,234.12, Ahead of Job Data

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Computer-driven sell programs contributed to a drop in stock prices yesterday, as many investors stayed on the sidelines ahead of the Government's report today on March employment figures.
Many on Wall Street are anxiously awaiting the employment report, which is the first official indication of how the economy did last month. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.21 points to close at 3,234.12. After moving in a narrow range for most the the session, the Dow tumbled more than 35 points in the afternoon, but recovered 15 points before the close of trading.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 185.4 million shares, compared with 186.4 million on Wednesday. Losing issues outpaced gainers 1,109 to 605.
Analysts said that futures-related programmed trading guided the market in recent sessions and that its impact was magnified yesterday as many traders took a wait-and-see attitude about the economy.
They said the market's underlying sentiment remained suspicious about the strength of an economic recovery and concerned about the sharp fall in the Japanese stock market.
"There is a deepening concern in world financial markets that there is a financial crisis brewing in Japan," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues has been plunging all week.
As for the American economy, some analysts said the latest survey of purchasing managers indicated that the employment report would be weaker than expected. A consensus of economic forecasts predicted that non-farm payrolls would show an increase of 45,000 jobs, while the unemployment rate would remain unchanged at 7.3 percent.
"Concern is that the economy is sputtering and we will not get strong enough earnings to validate current prices," Mr. Johnson said.
Analysts said that while the Dow would continue to find support near the 3,200 level, breadth and volume data sketched a gloomy outlook.
"We are beginning to see 40 or more new lows" in a single session, said Gene Jay Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company. "This is the first time we have had that in a long time."
 
Other Indexes Drop
 In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.73 points, to 400.50. The American Stock Exchange index dropped 2.67 points, to 390.48. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks was off 8.27 points, or 1.37 percent, to 593.82.
Among active over-the-counter issues, Immunex plunged 10 1/2, to 31 1/2, after the company said first-quarter sales of its drug Leukine were below expectations because of a giveaway program by Hoechst A.G. Immunex is suing Hoechst, which was its partner in developing the drug.
Other biotechnology companies were also hurt. Amgen fell 2 3/4, to 59 1/2, and Genzyme, lost 2 3/4, to 40 1/4.
The Price Company plummeted 10 3/4, to 35, after the wholesale merchandiser reported disappointing earnings.
CMS Energy topped the most active list on the Big Board, dropping 6, to 15 3/4, after Michigan regulators denied the utility's rate request.
Transco Energy was off 2 1/4, to 9 7/8. It said in a filing it could face a liquidity problem by late summer unless it completed a restructuring.
Polaroid dropped 2 1/2, to 25 5/8. The company said its first-quarter sales would be lower than expected.
Citicorp fell 1/4, to 15 3/4, after its Citibank unit said it had settled litigation against BankAmerica. Meanwhile, BankAmerica lost 1 1/8, to 42.
Paine Webber Group, another financial company, lost 3 3/8, to 20.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index was off 1.91 points, to 221.51. And the Wilshire Associates Equity Index was down 36.115 points, to 3,926.541.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.& T. Video Phone Chip

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J., April 2

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduced new computer chip technology today that will allow people in different cities to see and talk to each other over their personal computers.
The low-priced PC innovation could break a critical cost barrier that analysts say has prevented the video-conferencing business from breaking into the lucrative mass market. 
 The telecommunications company said its new three-chip video coder-decoder, called the AVP-100, could process video signals and sound simultaneously for interactive transmission.
Samples will be available in the fourth quarter, with full production beginning by mid-1993.
A.T.& T. said it would sell the chips in its own products and make them available to other manufacturers. Its computer subsidiary, the NCR Corporation, will also build PC's and automated teller machines with video equipment.
The AVP-100 will allow PC users with digital phone service to communicate by sight and sound for less than $400 in additional equipment costs. Video-conferencing equipment today generally costs $30,000 and up and usually requires a special room.
Steven Sazegari, an analyst for Dataquest Inc., predicted the market would grow rapidly over the next decade. "I think the others will follow," he said.
Analysts noted that Compression Labs Inc. and the Integrated Information Technology Company hope to introduce a personal video system. A similar venture is under way between the Picturetel Corporation in Peabody, Mass., and the Intel Corporation in Santa Clara, Calif.
While A.T.& T. did not project what the actual product would cost once built into a PC, analysts expect it to be less than that of existing equipment.
Analysts also said the announcement marked A.T.& T.'s sixth attempt at a video communications product since 1964. None of them have done well in the market.

HEADLINE: Argentine Sees Falklands' Return But Pledges, 'Never Again War'

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, April 2

 BODY:
Marking the 10th anniversary of Argentina's ill-fated invasion of the Falkland Islands, President Carlos Saul Menem predicted today that his country would recover the archipelago in the South Atlantic "before the year 2000."
But he added that Argentina would gain sovereignty over the islands, which the Argentines call the Malvinas, "by diplomatic channels and methods." 
 "Never again war," President Menem said after leaving a Roman Catholic Mass in Lujan, 40 miles north of Buenos Aires. "We lost a lot more than what we had gained through dialogue, which now, with an open and strong diplomacy, we are recovering."
On April 2, 1982, Argentina's military leader, Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, sent troops into the windy islands some 300 miles east of the southern tip of Argentina and captured the tiny British garrison. Troops then hoisted the Argentine flag over Government House.
 
Underestimating the Reaction
 Though Argentina and Britain had tried for months to negotiate a settlement to the dispute over the islands, which Argentina has claimed for more than 150 years, each side deeply underestimated the other's reaction.
In response to the invasion, Margaret Thatcher, the British Prime Minister at the time, sent thousands of troops 8,000 miles to recapture the islands. Seventy-four days after the invasion, Argentina surrendered. In all, 649 Argentines and 285 Britons died.
"From a strategic point of view, it was a bad decision," President Menem said of the decision to invade.
For Argentines, the marking of this anniversary carries both high emotion and deep ambivalence. Graffiti on walls in downtown Buenos Aires say, "Malvinas, we will return," and street signs erected by the Government proclaim, "The Malvinas are Argentine."
But for the country as a whole, the war was both a deep embarrassment and a huge economic setback, with some here calculating that it cost almost half a billion dollars. For many Argentines, it is a war that should never have been fought.
It also marked the end of the military junta that had ruled Argentina since the mid-1970's. Soon after the surrender, the Government of General Galtieri resigned in disgrace.
 
U.S. Ties Strained
 Argentine relations with the United States were also strained when the Reagan Adminstration decided to support the British war effort.
Mr. Menem restored diplomatic relations with Britain early in 1990. Under an agreement, issues like fishing limits and military flight paths have been worked out, and there have been numerous exchanges of diplomats between the two countries. But Britain has refused to talk about sovereignty.
The Falkland issue is certain to continue. For its part, Britain has made sure it will not be surprised by an attack again. Since the war it has invested as much as $6 billion in building a highly sophisticated air base that can defend the islands.

HEADLINE: As a Caesar Goes, So Goes His Family

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
The conviction yesterday of John Gotti, a Mafia Caesar, virtually assures the decline of the Gambino family as the nation's pre-eminent organized-crime family.
It is also another sign that Mafia families across the nation are on the run, battered by aggressive prosecutors, betrayals and internal strife. "This could be the death knell to organized crime as we know it in the United States," asserted James M. Fox, the assistant director of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
 The Gambino family's empire once extended over New York City's waterfront and the construction, garment and air-freight industries as well as gambling and loan-sharking rackets and it has had a strong presence in New Jersey, Connecticut and southern Florida.
But recent convictions of top Gambino leaders are believed to have significantly weakened the family, even during the five turbulent years that Mr. Gotti ruled it with an arrogant iron fist that was said to engender hostility within the gang and hatred from other organized-crime leaders.
Through court-authorized wiretaps and electronic bugs, law-enforcement authorities say they have frequently heard Mafia members rail against Mr. Gotti for his attempts to encroach on their rackets.
 
An Unwritten Code
 The Mafia's unwritten code calls for a boss to keep his titular rank even in prison. But organized-crime experts believe that Mr. Gotti may try to anoint his son, John Jr., as the new boss. That power play could lead to bloody battles among Gambino factions.
"John Jr. is not well liked or respected by the older guys," said Jules J. Bonavolonta, the former head of the F.B.I.'s organized-crime section in New York.
The husky 28-year-old John Jr. is a physical carbon copy of his father. In 1990, his father promoted him to the rank of capo, or captain, over the heads of many older family members.
Mr. Gotti may have a hard time naming a successor or running the family from prison. His authority had ebbed in the 15 months he has been in jail. Experts say rivals in the family blamed him for their problems, believing that his swashbuckling life style attracted too much attention to the Mafia. At the trial, tapes in which Mr. Gotti was heard belittling other Mafia members further antagonized underworld confederates.
During his imprisonment, Mr. Gotti appointed a 73-year-old capo, James Failla, to be the acting boss. Exactly what power he will retain is unclear.
 
Deadly Internal Wars
 Prosecutions and deadly internal wars in the last decade have virtually eliminated the Bonanno, Colombo and Lucchese families as potent organized-crime battalions in New York.
But for the Genovese family, Mr. Gotti's conviction should be welcome news. The Genovese and Gambino families have been fierce rivals since Mr. Gotti became boss of the Gambino family in December 1985. Many of the Genovese top leaders have avoided indictments and they are in position to become the area's most dominant Mafia group.
The strength of the Gambino family rests with about 400 "made" or inducted members and more than 1,000 associates or people who actively assist the family.
The Genovese family's rackets include interests in the construction and garbage removal industries in New York and New Jersey. It has about 300 members and 1,000 associates. The other families, riddled by convictions and defections of top members, have been reduced to about 100 members each.
 
A Grim Horizon
 For Mr. Gotti's remaining loyalists the horizon is grim. Salvatore Gravano, Mr. Gotti's underboss and right-hand man, defected to become the Government's critical witness at the trial of Mr. Gotti and his co-defendant, Frank Locascio, the family's consiglieri, or counselor.
Federal and state law-enforcement officials say they expect that Mr. Gravano will provide additional evidence that will lead to prosecutions of other Gambino members and inroads into the family's remaining rackets.
After flourishing for 50 years, virtually untroubled by Federal or local authorities, the nation's Mafia families in New Jersey, Philadelphia, Boston, Providence, Kansas City, Cleveland, Detroit and Los Angeles have been largely eliminated by prosecutions in the last decade. But law-enforcement authorities doubt that New York's Mafia families can be eradicated or prevented from engaging in illegal gambling and loan sharking. The New York metropolitan region, with its five large families, and Chicago, where the Mafia is called the Outfit, have been the hardest targets to knock out for the F.B.I. and prosecutors.
In the last decade the Goverment's strategy has been been to seek to eliminate the top echelons of each family and to dismantle the economic foundations of the gangs through civil lawsuits against the mobsters and their corrupt allies in labor unions. The object, the authorities say, is to turn back the clock 70 or 8o years to when the Mafia consisted of unsophisticated street gangs with little political influence or power.
Many officials say Mr. Gotti, through inept leadership and self-incriminating boasts on secret tapes, accelerated his own family's demise.
"In retrospect, his leadership was marked by profound failures," said Ronald Goldstock, the director of the state's Organized Crime Task Force. "His high points were the earlier acquittals and fireworks in Ozone Park on the Fourth of July."

HEADLINE: Lard Havers, 69, Former British Attorney General

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 2

 BODY:
Lord Havers, who as a prosecutor and Attorney General was involved in some of Britain's most controversial trials of the last 20 years, died on Wednesday in London. He was 69 years old.
Lord Havers retired from Government service in 1987 because of ill health after serving only four months as Lord Chancellor, the highest-ranking legal office in England and Wales. As such, he had presided over the House of Lords. 
 He served as Attorney General of Britain for eight years after being named to the post in 1979 by the newly elected Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher. When Mrs. Thatcher appointed him Lord Chancellor in 1987, he was made a baron.
His son Nigel, a British television and film actor, said his father had been working at his private office in London on Wednesday when he became ill. He died later at a hospital. Lord Havers had undergone coronary bypass surgery in 1985 and again in 1987.
Upon hearing of Lord Havers' death, Prime Minister John Major described him as a "a very great law officer."
Robert Michael Oldfield Havers was born on March 10, 1923, the second son of Sir Cecil Havers, a barrister, and Enid Snelling. He attended Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, and served as a lieutenant in the Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve. In 1949 he married Carol Elizabeth Lay.
He became a member of the bar in 1948 and a Queen's Counsel in 1964. He was elected to the House of Commons in 1970, representing Wimbledon, and retained the seat for 17 years, until he was made a Baron.
In 1972, he was named Solicitor General by Prime Minister Edward Heath and received a knighthood.
As Solicitor General and later as Attorney General, Sir Michael Havers prosecuted two of the most famous bombing cases involving the Irish Republican Army. Appeals courts later ruled that defendants in both cases had been wrongfully convicted, in one case for the prosecution's withholding of evidence, and the defendants were released from prison.
The debate over the two cases cast a cloud over a career in which Lord Havers had been celebrated for his skill as a prosecutor.
Sir Michael was the prosecutor at the 1981 Old Bailey trial of Peter Sutcliffe, the serial killer of 13 women who was known as the Yorkshire Ripper. In 1982, in one of his most spectacular courtroom successes, Sir Michael got Hugh Hambledon, a Canadian economist, to confess under cross-examination that he had passed NATO secrets to the Soviet Union.
It was also Sir Michael who decided in 1986 to prosecute Peter Wright, a former British counterespionage agent, on charges of violating the Official Secrets Act by writing a book about his experiences. The book, "Spycatcher," became a best-seller in the United States and Sir Michael's attempts to block its publication in Britain and Australia ultimately failed to the embarrassment of Mrs. Thatcher's Government.
He was also a co-author of several books, including "The Poisoned Life of Mrs. Maybrick," "The Royal Baccarat Scandal" (which was adapted into a play) and "Tragedy in Three Voices."
In 1981, the I.R.A. bombed his home in Wimbledon. Sir Michael and his family were on vacation in Spain at the time and press reports later said he informed his wife of the incident by saying, "Darling, we seem to have had a slight accident at home."
Lord Havers is survived his wife, Lady Carol, and his sons, Nigel and Philip.

HEADLINE: Taipei Journal;
The Horror of 2-28: Taiwan Rips Open the Past

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 30

 BODY:
A jeep pulled up in front of Lin Mao-sheng's house at 11 A.M. one March day and two plainclothes officers summoned him for a meeting with the provincial Governor.
Mr. Lin, the dean of National Taiwan University and the first Taiwanese to earn an American Ph.D., was never seen by his family after that day in 1947. He was one of thousands killed in a massacre that has haunted Taiwan ever since, but that almost no one dared mention in public until a few years ago . 
 Now, as Taiwan gallops toward democracy, the taboo has been lifted. The Government is planning a memorial to honor the victims, and a month ago it published an officially backed report that suggested that 18,000 to 28,000 people may have died in the massacre.
What is almost as astonishing as the cruelty of the massacre itself is that the Government should acknowledge it. The Nationalist Government responsible for the killings is still in power, and for decades it was likely to imprison anyone who raised the issue.
 
An Enormous Departure
 For thousands of years, the writing of history in Chinese societies has usually been a process of molding events to serve a political purpose, with each new emperor commissioning scholars as "spin doctors" to cast the previous reign in just the right light. So it is an enormous departure for the Government to own up to such brutality.
"In 5,000 years of writing history, this is the first time that the Government hasn't interfered in the process," said Marvin C. H. Ho, the president of the Taipei Language Institute and a member of the commission that issued the report.
Lin Tsung-yi, the 71-year-old son of Lin Mao-sheng, the university dean who was executed, complains that the report covers only the immediate aftermath of the uprising in 1947 and neglects the "pure terrorization" of Taiwanese for decades afterward. But he commends the Government for having "the guts to produce a report with fairly objective data."
The massacre is known as 2-28, because the date of the first substantial killing was Feb. 28, 1947. It all started when officials in the Nationalist Government pistol-whipped a 40-year-old widow who was selling contraband cigarettes on the street. An indignant crowd pressed around and an inspector fired, killing one person.
Rioting began almost immediately, directed against the Nationalist Chinese officials from mainland China who had taken control of Taiwan two years earlier. Taiwan had been occupied by Japan from 1895 to 1945, and the newly arrived mainland Chinese were resented for their corruption and economic mismanagement.
 
Uprising Is Crushed
 The protesters gained control of most of the island of Taiwan, also known as Formosa, but army reinforcements arrived from the mainland and crushed the uprising. This account is included in a scholarly book about 2-28 published last year:
"As the Nationalist troops came ashore, they moved out quickly through Keelung streets, shooting and bayoneting men and boys, raping women and looting homes and shops. Some Formosans were seized and stuffed alive into burlap bags found piled up at the sugar warehouse and were then simply tossed into the harbor."
President Lee Teng-hui, a native Taiwanese who was reportedly almost shot during 2-28, announced soon after he took power in 1988 that the Government was prepared to reconsider its approach to 2-28. The centerpiece of the new policy is the new Government-financed report.
"It's very difficult to write such a history," said Lai Tse-han, a history professor who was in charge of drafting the report. "At the beginning, it was very difficult to interview the victims' families. They were very suspicious of anything to do with the Government."
The report helped ease the suspicions, partly because it stated that some of the indirect responsibility for the killings lay with Chiang Kai-shek, the Nationalist leader, who was then based on the mainland. After losing the Chinese civil war to the Communists in 1949, Chiang fled with his troops to Taiwan. Today about 15 percent of Taiwan's population consists of mainland Chinese or their descendants.
 
No Government Interference
 Some Taiwanese wanted more direct criticism of Chiang and of his son, Chiang Ching-kuo, who was President of Taiwan until his death in 1988. But Professor Lai said there was no hard evidence that either of the Chiangs played a direct role in planning the massacre.
Professor Lai, a tweedy scholar with owlish spectacles, said Government officials never interfered with the commission's work. The military and civilian authorities provided secret archives, but Professor Lai suspects that a few things may have been held back, and he was never able to get his hands on a 1947 diary of Chiang Ching-kuo to help assay his role.
Another contentious feature of the report was the estimate that 18,000 to 28,000 people may have been killed. Mr. Ho said he and the majority of commission members did not subscribe to so high a range.
While the Government is now planning a memorial for the victims, and probably an apology and compensation as well, it is not clear whether the gestures will heal the wounds or reopen them. Some Taiwanese believe that tugging on the string of history might unravel the entire historical underpinning of the Government, as happened in the Soviet Union.
Thousands of people were imprisoned and executed for political reasons in the 1950's. At that time, unlike 2-28, Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo were in Taiwan and unmistakably bear direct responsbility. If the authorities acknowledge that the two Chiangs were behind the routine torture and execution of thousands of citizens in the 1950's and 1960's, it might be difficult to explain why their portraits still hang in every classroom on Taiwan.
"A lot of people here don't know about the repression in the 50's and 60's," Professor Lai said. "More people were killed at that time than during 2-28. Police just knocked on the door at midnight, and then the people inside just disappeared."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As democracy continues to bend Taiwan inexorably toward a more open society, a dark chapter in its history has been opened. A massacre in which thousands were killed in 1947 is being brought to light, and a Government-led report has been credited with casting aside many of the shadows. Lai Tse-han, a history professor, directed drafting of the report from his archive-filled office. (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Legislature In New Jersey Cuts Sales Tax

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 2

 BODY:
The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a one-cent rollback in the state sales tax, but Gov. Jim Florio said he wanted to see how the Republicans who control the Legislature would make up the $608 million in lost revenues before he approved or rejected the measure. If he decides to veto it, he faces an almost certain override.
"I'd love to sign a sales tax rollback," said the Governor, a Democrat, "but I need to know whether it is a good deal for New Jersey's citizens." 
 The Governor's definition of a "good deal" is a tax reduction that will not require higher property taxes, college tuition or transit fares or significantly lower state aid to education.
The Senate approved the tax rollback, from 7 to 6 percent, by a vote of 28 to 1. The rollback would take effect July 1.
One Democratic Senator, Raymond J. Zane of Woodbury, voted with the 27 Republicans and the remaining Democrats abstained or were absent.
The measure passed the Assembly last week by an even larger margin, 59 to 5. Two Democrats joined the Republicans and the rest were absent or abstained on the ground that they could not vote on a rollback without knowing what programs or services would be cut to make up the lost revenue.
 
A Buoyant Atmosphere
 The vote in both houses was sufficient to override a veto by the Governor.
The rollback was a Republican pledge since the party won overwhelming control of the Legislature last Nov. 5 on a tidal wave of voter anger over a $2.8 billion tax increase imposed by Governor Florio and the Democratically controlled Legislature in 1990.
With the outcome a foregone conclusion, the Senate debate was essentially a reprise of last week's discussion in the Assembly, and, though pointed, took place in an almost buoyant atmosphere. Both sides wore lapel pins, the Democrats' asking "Who Gets Cut?" and the Republicans' saying "Jobs Now!" referring to their program to revitalize the economy, which includes the tax cut.
On the floor, Democrats argued that they were being asked to vote in the dark and Republicans maintained that they would explain their proposed cuts in early May. The Republicans insisted that their spending reductions would total more than the $608 million needed to replace the revenue that would be lost through the sales tax rollback.
The Republican Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, in fact ruled that debate over the revenue shortfall was not pertinent and that only the rollback itself could be discussed.
"It may be legitimate to ask questions," about revenues, he said, "but it does not have anything to do with the bill, which is to reduce the sales tax. The debate is not over revenues."
Senator Walter Rand of Camden, a Democrat, retorted, "It's a sham and a shame, irresponsible at best, to move this legislation without identifying the cuts. If you think you can hide behind parliamentary camouflage, you are mistaken."
Beyond saying that the necessary cuts will be forthcoming, Republicans have generally said only that the sales-tax reduction itself will spur spending that will generate more sales-tax revenue, an analysis that Governor Florio described as "discredited supply-side voodoo economics."
The tax cut would translate to about $77 over a year for each New Jersey citizen, although some analysts say that the figure would be closer to about $47 for an individual because corporations account for an estimated 40 percent of the spending that generates sales taxes.
 
Renters May Lose Out
 One Republican Senator, Dick LaRossa of Trenton, suggested in floor debate that $330 million of the shortfall could be made up by reducing the amounts returned to taxpayers under the Governor's expanded Homestead Tax Rebate program, which took effect last year.
Governor Florio and the Democrats increased the rebate from a flat $180 for each homeowner to a sliding scale that, on the basis of income and property tax paid, can go as high as $500 and includes renters for the first time.
Mr. LaRossa alluded to the inclusion of renters as a possible source of cuts. "I'm certainly not interested in redistributing tax dollars to people who have never paid a dime in property taxes," he said.
The Senate's approval of the rollback left Governor Florio with four options. He can sign the bill, veto it outright, veto it with conditions or allow it to become law without his signature after 45 days. If he vetoes it, he faces a virtually certain override, since the Republicans control two-thirds majorities in both houses.
Today, he gave no strong indication of his intentions, except to say that no decision is likely until he knows where the cuts will be made, and he may take all of the 45 days he is allowed under the law to make up his mind.
"If we can cut the sales tax by a penny, or two pennies for that matter, we should do it," he said in a written statement issued after the vote. "I will be listening to and consulting with the people of New Jersey during the 45 days I have to study this legislation" to "make sure this would be a good deal."
Elderly people, he said, "have told me it wouldn't be a good deal if it means losing their homes because the scandalous property tax increases of the 1980's return."
He also said he opposed a rollback if it caused substantial tuition increases at state colleges and universities or fare increases because of reduced subsidies to N.J. Transit.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primary;
Far-Removed Feeling in Kansas Race

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOPEKA, Kan., April 1

 BODY:
Here in the middle of the country, the New York Presidential primary campaign is a distant spectacle playing on national television news, but for Kansas voters, what they learn from the video backwash is of particular interest. Next Tuesday they, too, will be voting in a state primary, but their choices will be made without contact with candidates, or even candidates' commercials.
It is a phenomenon that has a lot of Democratic politicians here worried. 
 At the Capitol, with its handsome murals of prairie history, some party leaders say they have a sinking "here we go again" feeling seeing their Presidential candidates self-destruct, and this week some top Democrats began talking up a brokered national convention, in which another candidate might be chosen through negotiation.
"Right now I think the best thing I can do for my state is to plan on going to the convention uncommitted so that in case of a deadlock Kansas might put a candidate over the top on a third or fourth or fifth ballot," said Gov. Joan Finney.
The state party chairman, John Bird, says he is considering recommending votes for uncommitted delegates, which can be done by checking the last line on Tuesday's ballot, "None of those named."
 
Paper Backs Tsongas
 The fidgety political atmosphere here was even reflected on the editorial page of The Wichita Eagle, a southern Kansas newspaper that is influential statewide, which Tuesday endorsed former Senator Paul Tsongas, hoping he would revive his suspended campaign.
"In this wacky political year, anything is possible," the editorial concluded.
For many Democratic office holders and party regulars, remaining uncommitted has been easy because neither Gov. Bill Clinton nor Edmund G. Brown Jr. has broken away from the battle for New York's 244 delegates to campaign personally for the 36 delegates at stake here.
In fact, neither has even mounted enough of a Kansas campaign to attract much local news coverage. They do not have advertisements on television, no polls have been published, and with the exception of a one-day fly-through by Hillary Clinton last week, the candidates do not even have surrogates making news for them here. Tonight Mr. Clinton came as close to campaigning in the state as he is going to when he appeared in live interviews on three Wichita television stations.
 
Interest in Perot
 Without even any signs of a protest against President Bush in the Republican primary, the efforts by volunteers for H. Ross Perot to put the Dallas tycoon on the November ballot in Kansas seem to have generated as much or more local interest as the vote next week.
So the Kansas primary may be a unique experiment in political science, with voters making their decisions almost solely on the basis of national media coverage of a another contest taking place the same day.
"New York politics is not a lot like what we do in Kansas to begin with," said State Representative Gary Blumenthal of Merriam, a Kansas City suburb. "And what people have been exposed to here is television stories about tabloid stories. With all the press attacks and denials and misinformation, our voters think they've got a choice between a flake and a liar, when actually both these guys have a lot to say on the issues."
The sight of such a bruising primary fight at the top of the ticket is especially troubling to Kansas Democrats, who in recent years have struggled to make gains in a largely Republican state. They now have a Democratic governor, a majority in the state House of Representatives and two of the five Congressional seats.
 
Visions of a Free-for-All
 As former state chairman and leader of the party in the west Kansas farm country, Norm Dreiling is exasperated with the national campaign. "We are hellbent to cut each other to death again," he said, "and now you can just see that establishment crowd back East in Washington and New York figuring how they can deny Clinton the nomination. Well, if they broker the convention, they are just going to get the American people even more mad at them."
Others are less concerned about a potential free-for-all. State Representative Anthony Hensley of Topeka, the majority whip, said: "I hear lots of rank-and-file regulars saying that a brokered convention could be better than picking Brown or Clinton. Look, it could be very dramatic. We could get a lot of TV time and really launch a candidate into the general election with some excitement."
Mr. Clinton is widely expected to win the primary in this state, where most Democrats share his centrist views. During her visit last week Mrs. Clinton met labor leaders and helped secure the endorsement of the machinists union in Wichita, the largest labor organization in the state. And, with just three paid staff workers and a few volunteer phone banks, the Arkansas Governor has the largest campaign operation.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Bill on Jobs In Big Economic Package

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 2

 BODY:
Capping a nearly festive day spent showing off their new political muscle, Republicans today pushed through the New Jersey Senate a bill to generate nearly 100,000 new jobs, an idea that Gov. Jim Florio proposed in his State of the State address.
In a legislative session in which bipartisan cooperation has been rare and agreement between Mr. Florio, a Democrat, and the new Republican majority has been almost nonexistent, the bill establishing the Economic Recovery Fund passed, 39 to 0. 
 The legislation was part of a seven-bill package that the Senate approved today, including a bill to roll back the state's sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent.
"Taken together, these bills will create jobs, retain jobs and spur New Jersey's economy," said the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco. The unemployment rate in New Jersey is 7.6 percent, matching the national rate.
Mr. DiFrancesco said the package of bills would produce at least 118,000 jobs, protect the jobs of 500,000 manufacturing workers and pump more than $2 billion into the state economy.
The Senate, where Republicans outnumber Democrats, 27 to 13, also signed off today by a vote of 37 to 0 on Mr. Florio's request to raise the spending cap on the state's Transportation Trust Fund to $565 million, a move that state officials say will create tens of thousands of jobs.
Other bills in the package approved today would extend the expiration date of all state and local government permits and approvals on development projects; exclude chemical, pharmaceutical and other businesses from paying local property taxes on their machinery, apparatus and equipment; limit the liability of secured lenders in cases of hazardous spills, and establish a program to assist banks in becoming more involved in export finance. The measure on hazardous spills would protect, for example, a bank that had foreclosed on a property where a business had been sued because of a spill.
All of the bills passed today except the one cutting the sales tax now go to the Assembly, where easy approval is expected. The Assembly has already approved the tax cut but Mr. Florio has said that before he signs the bill he wants the Republicans to show where they will cut spending to compensate for the loss in revenue.
Under the Economic Recovery Fund bill, the state would use $200 million in revenues from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for projects like an Atlantic City airport and a state performing arts center. Sponsors say the measure will generate $800 million for the state's economy, and Mr. Florio has said that it will lead to the creation of 20,000 construction jobs and 75,000 permanent jobs over the next three years.
The proposal was the cornerstone of the State of the State message Mr. Florio delivered Jan. 14 only hours after the Republicans assumed overwhelming control of both houses of the Legislature.
This is is the first time in 20 years that a New Jersey Governor faces a Legislature in which the rival party commands two-thirds majorities in both houses. But the Republican leaders eagerly supported Mr. Florio's idea and made it a major part of their own economic plan for the state.
 
More Construction Jobs
 The Republicans also supported Mr. Florio's proposal to raise the spending cap on the Transportation Trust Fund, which is supported by gasoline taxes. The Governor has said that raising the limit could create 13,000 construction jobs, and the Department of Transportation says the ripple effect could create 43,000 other jobs.
There is a $365 million annual limit on state spending from the seven-year-old trust fund, and surpluses must go into a reserve. Two years ago, the Legislature, then under Democratic control, increased the spending limit to $565 million a year to pay for transportation projects. Without today's bill, the cap would have reverted to $365 million on July 1, the beginning of the state's fiscal year.
The most controversial bill voted on today was one that would extend the expiration date of all state and local government permits and approvals on development projects.
"Approved permits are expiring or lapsing due to the current inability of many builders to obtain construction financing," said John H. Dorsey, the Senate Majority Leader.
The bill passed, 33 to 1, despite protests from environmental groups and the League of Women Voters, who argued that the legislation would allow developers to circumvent environmental authorities and to build in buffer areas around wetlands.
The legislation to exempt certain businesses from local property taxes on their machinery was sponsored by Mr. DiFrancesco.
He said he had introduced the bill in response to recent decisions in the state tax court allowing municipalities to consider machinery and equipment, including heating or air conditioning systems and elevators, when figuring the property tax base of businesses. The measure was approved, 31 to 5. All five dissenters were Democrats.
The bill would apply to tax cases now before the court as well as future tax assessments. A statement that accompanied the bill said no data had been compiled on its fiscal impact on municipalities.

(Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Race Relations in Arkansas Reflect Gains for Clinton, but Raise Questions

SERIES: Clinton as Governor: 12 Years at Arkansas's Helm -- Fourth of five articles.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 27

 BODY:
Two years ago England, Ark., a town with a recent history of racial tensions, was about to blow again.
A fight in the high school playground between a black student and a white student had escalated to a larger racial confrontation. Black parents kept their children home from school. Whites felt the incident was overblown. The Knights of the Klu Klux Klan began distributing inflammatory leaflets in England, a town of nearly 4,000 people 22 miles southeast of Little Rock. 
 Using a racial epithet, they charged blacks wwith disrupting "law and order," and warned, "If you think you have troubles NOW, wait until the minorities become the MAJORITY."
After that, Gov. Bill Clinton decided to get involved.
He came to town and met privately with an integrated group of residents, urging them to form a biracial committee to work out their problems. His efforts bore fruit. A committee was set up, the two sides started to talk and tensions were defused. To Mr. Clinton's supporters, his performance typified his ability to forge biracial coalitions that work through racial animus.
 
Bridging the Divide
 As he campaigns for President, Mr. Clinton has been able to attract a vast majority of the black vote -- although with a much lower black turnout than in 1984 or 1988 -- by presenting himself as the candidate best able to bridge the nation's racial divide.
He is the Governor of a Southern state that has seen its share of racial violence. Black sharecroppers took part in an angry uprising in 1919, for example, and in 1957 President Dwight D. Eisenhower ordered Federal troops to Little Rock to escort nine black students into newly integrated Central High School. Now, Mr. Clinton asserts, he is "uniquely qualified" to bring blacks and whites together.
His long record as Governor offers support for that assertion, and raises some questions. Most Arkansans agree that under Governor Clinton more blacks and women have been appointed to boards, commissions and departments than under any other chief executive in the state's history. Mr. Clinton has appointed blacks to influential positions as the state's chief financial officer, health commissioner and head of the Department of Social Services, Arkansas' largest state agency.
"I never detected any reluctance on his part to appoint blacks to important positions in state government because of their color," said Mahlon A. Martin, president of the Winthrop Rockefeller Foundation. "If fact, he made an affirmative effort to do so."
Mr. Clinton appointed Mr. Martin as director of the Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration, the state's top fiscal job. He was the first and only black to hold that position.
 
Legal Protection for Blacks
 A close examination, however, shows that by most measures Mr. Clinton's achievements in Arkansas are no better than those of many other governors nationwide. At the same time, the Clinton administration's record in providing legal protection for blacks and in improving their economic conditions comes under frequent criticism.
Arkansas is one of only nine states that has no law banning discrimination in the sale and rental of housing. It is one of only two states -- Alabama is the other -- with no civil rights bill barring racial discrimination in hiring and promotion. A civil rights bill was introduced in the Legislature last year, and Mr. Clinton supported it. But even with his backing, the measure failed.
While the Clinton administration has tried to help the development of black businesses while also trying to lure jobs for everyone, poverty persists among blacks living in the rural counties of the Mississippi Delta in southeastern Arkansas. There, illiteracy and joblessness remain stubbornly high, and at least one county has an infant mortality rate higher than that of French Guiana, Malaysia and Cuba. Even Mr. Clinton's admirers among blacks complain that his administration has yet to materially improve the lives of blacks in the Delta.
"Clinton has appointed a few token Negroes to various boards, and he knows how to go into African-American churches, get in the pulpit and sound like a black Baptist preacher," said Jimmie L. Wilson, a black State Representative from the Delta. But in the final analysis, he added, eastern Arkansas has fared no better under Mr. Clinton than it did under previous governors.
 
Drop in Farm Population
 The Delta's rich loam makes it one of the most fertile agricultural areas in the United States. But mechanization, the development of large-scale farming and the credit crisis of the 1980's have thrown many poor farmers and agricultural workers, both black and white, off the land. In 1950 Arkansas had 215,270 farmers and agricultural workers. By 1980 that number had dropped to 50,616.
In some ways Lake View, Ark., an all-black town near the Mississippi, typifies the Delta's problems. The town was founded in the 1930's as part of the New Deal; the Federal Government settled 96 black families in Lake View, and each was given 40 acres and two mules.
Today, Mayor Leon Phillips said, only five of these families still own their farms, and they are barely hanging on. Most of the black families lost their farms in the last 10 years, the Mayor said.
So how are most of the town's 609 residents making ends meet now?
"Welfare, man, welfare," Mr. Phillips said without hesitation.
In small Delta towns like Holly Grove, many blacks live in crumbling shacks; outside, scrawny chickens dart around abandoned cars rusting in front yards. In Lake View, situated on a narrow, curving lake, there is little more than two miles of paved road, even though the town covers 30 square miles.
 
Most Get Free Lunches
 Mr. Phillips, who is the superintendent of schools as well as the town's mayor, says 96 percent of the 230 students in Lake View's only public school are so poor they are eligible for federally financed free lunches, while another 2 percent qualify for reduced-priced lunches.
Some blacks in Arkansas complain that the Clinton administration's economic development efforts have been focused only on northwestern Arkansas, a section that is predomnantly white. State officials vehemently deny the charge, but they do acknowledge that most of state's economic growth in recent years has been in areas outside the Delta.
But the officials say business owners themselves have chosen northwestern Arkansas for a number of reasons. For one thing, the main campus of the University of Arkansas is in Fayetteville, in the northwestern corner of the state. Moreover, the area has a better educated work force, and the state's largest companies were already situated there. Among them are Tyson Foods Inc, the country's largest poultry processor, and Wal-Mart Stores Inc., one of the nation's largest retailers.
"In the industrial recruitment business, anyone who understands it at all understands that the public sector cannot take companies where they do not want to be," said Dave Harrington, director of the Arkansas Industrial Development Commission. "You take them where they've asked to be taken or to an area that has the criteria that they've asked for."
 
Controversy Over Records
 The issue was raised three years ago when several black legislators charged that a Japanese-owned company, Tokusen USA, was steered to Conway, Ark., a mostly white city 27 miles northwest of Little Rock. The legislators demanded that the development commission make public confidential state records related to the company's decision to move to Arkansas.
Mr. Harrington, a Clinton appointee, said Tokusen was not steered away from black areas, and insisted that the records would show that race played no part in the company's decision to put its plant in Conway. Still, he refused to release the records, arguing that making them public would harm Tokusen's competitive position.
When The Arkansas Gazette sued the state to gain access to the documents, Mr. Clinton persuaded the Legislature to pass a bill tightening the state's freedom of information law, preventing the release of all but the most innocuous portions of the records relating to the Japanese company.
Throughout the dispute, however, it became clear that Arkansas routinely gave businesses that were contemplating a move to the state demographic data that included the racial makeup of cities and counties under consideration. The agency has since stopped providing that data, although Mr. Harrington defends the practice.
"It becomes important to a certain extent," he said in an interview. "When people are looking to the area they want to live in and the types of employees they want, it's important that you give them a personality and a makeup of the community, providing that is not always negative. In some cases it's very positive."
 
Black Jobless Rate
 In his campaign statements, Mr. Clinton says the number of blacks in the state who were unemployed decreased by 34.8 percent from 1983 to 1990. But a Federal agency, the Bureau of Labor Statistics, says the number of blacks nationwide who were jobless fell by 37.6 percent in the same period. Indeed, Arkansas' 17.5 percent unemployment rate for blacks in 1991 was higher than the rate for a number of other Southern states, including Alabama, Louisiana and Mississippi.
As the campaign notes, the Clinton administration has made a concerted effort to create new, black-owned businesses. The Arkansas Industrial Development Commission has made more than $2.3 million in loans to minority enterprises since 1983, and the state has established programs to assist struggling black farmers in the Delta.
In 1983 Mr. Clinton signed an executive order committing the state to purchase 10 percent of its goods and services from black-owned businesses. But the executive order did not carry the force of law, and most agency heads have ignored it. In addition, according to Mr. Martin, the state's former chief fiscal officer, Arkansas had too few black business with the experience and wherewithal to meet the state's demands. As a result, the state bought less than 3 percent of its goods and services from black entrepeneurs.
Last year the Governor pushed a bill through a reluctant Legislature that committed the state to make a good-faith effort to reach its goal of buying 10 percent from black-owned busisnesses. He also established a Minority Business Advisory Council to oversee the law.
And despite the problems, black officials in Arkansas say they believe Mr. Clinton is doing about as well as can be expected, given that he has to contend with a conservative Legislature that often is resistant to change. While these officials say the Governor made a mistake last month by playing golf at a Little Rock country club that has not admitted blacks, they seem willing to forgive him.
"I look at the overall picture, what he has done for blacks and the overwhelming support he has gotten from the black community every time he has run," said William L. Walker, Jr., a black State Representative from Little Rock. "If I didn't know anything about the guy," Mr. Walker added, he would consider the country club episode far more critically.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Behind the Scenes;
Reflections on People, Props and (Oh, Yes) Issues

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

 BODY:
The New York primary happens to fall on the Yankees' opening day. But modern politics is anything but baseball: Just because the candidate shows up doesn't mean the people will come.
In this age of television politics, where the reality on the nightly news is more real than the day-in, day-out of the campaign, nothing, paradoxically, is more important than the crowd. 
 And nothing is more elusive. TV giveth, and TV taketh away.
"People watch television," said John LoCicero, a political consultant who was Mayor Edward I. Koch's behind-the-scenes handler and has volunteered his expertise to Bill Clinton's campaign. "What do they need to go and see the candidates for? You have to work to get a crowd."
 
How to Build a Crowd
 Advance people have a special term for this work: building a crowd.
Time was when the political rally was the emotional and informational medium of the campaign. No more. "The people are just props," said Norman Adler, a political consultant and veteran of 20 Presidential campaigns. "When the candidates go out, they're not really going out for votes. They're going out to be on the news. What you want are a lot of different kinds of props."
At 5:30 A.M. March 26, Bruce Nyman, a Nassau County supervisor from Long Beach, got a call from one of Mr. Clinton's advance people asking him to produce a crowd -- in less than eight hours. "They wanted to do a senior hit," said Mr. Nyman.
Mr. Nyman guaranteed a great crowd of senior citizens. "Then I panicked," he said. All he had were 50 to 75 senior citizens in a lunch program at the Temple Beth-El Synagogue on Long Beach.
By 1:45 P.M., when the candidate and the television cameras showed up, the auditorium was packed with more than 350 enthusiastic senior citizens. Here is how Mr. Nyman did it: "We called Democratic committee people, election inspectors, the presidents of all the organizations," he said. "At 9 A.M. we printed up flyers: 'Governor Clinton coming to Long Beach today. We sent mini-buses to bring more senior citizens from adult homes."
 
Not the Right Message
 One big problem: The senior citizens in the lunch program were supposed to leave by 1 P.M. But someone, no one will say who, arranged for the buses to be delayed until 2:30, long after the candidate had left.
Asked about the mysterious scheduling change, Mr. Nyman said, "That must have been a coincidence."
Mr. Clinton had also had a mysterious scheduling change. His Long Island appearance was supposed to have been at a medical-equipment factory in Bayshore. His staff would say only that they didn't learn until the last minute that the factory "would not have sent the right message." The factory makes, among other things, toilets and crutches.
It's not a matter of just showing up, warned Mr. Adler. Some crowds are politically incorrect.
"You don't want to show up at a factory gate and find it's nonunion," he said. "You don't want to go to a place where people are going to complain a great deal, especially in an organized way. I would be very chary of campaigning in the East Village where there are a lot of anarchists and dissenters."
Even though the political masterminds might think of them as props, the people in the crowd persist in thinking of themselves as voters. John Lundin, who lives in Mount Vernon and is an auditor for the New York Stock Exchange, braved the rain Monday night to attend a Clinton rally at Mount Vernon High School.
"I want to hear what he says for myself," Mr. Lundin said. "On TV, you only get little bites.
 
In Quest of Knowledge
 Last Saturday, another voter, 28-year-old Joe Pigott, an unemployed banker, traveled from the Upper West Side to Union Square to find out about Edmund G. Brown Jr.
He joined what is known in the advance lingo as a "built-in crowd," the throngs who visit the Greenmarket Farmers Market at Union Square on Saturdays. By noon, more than a thousand people were waiting for the candidate.
The former California Governor didn't show up until nearly three hours later. The crowd cheered: "Jerry! Jerry! Jerry!"
"What a crowd," the candidate called out. "It's incredible."
This crowd blocked the customers who were trying to buy the farmers' organic meat, eggs and vegetables, home-made jam and bread, and fresh fish. Joel Patraker, the manager of the market, estimated that the farmers lost about $8,000. "This is so oxymoronic," he said. "Here we have the environmental candidate, and he wipes out the Greenmarket."
 
The Focus Is Off
 Despite the setting, Mr. Brown talked about his flat-tax proposal, not about issues of specific interest to farmers. His team had apparently not known that Union Square is the home of a farmers' market.
"We thought we'd get a lot of public exposure," one volunteer said. "California set it up. They didn't realize there is a significant community event there every Saturday. If they'd known, they would never have done it."
Mr. Pigott was disillusioned. "I didn't learn anything more about Brown by attending that rally than if I'd watched the 11 o'clock news," he said. "The crowd was looking for someone who would actually speak to them, not the cameras. But it was just an egregious photo op."

Bill Clinton yesterday was able to include a statue of Washington as a special attraction. The other props, people, arrived in time to see the candidate. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)
