HEADLINE: The Steel Man With Kid Gloves

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
On a recent trip to the USX Corporation's largest mill, in Gary, Ind., Thomas J. Usher unexpectedly strolled into the offices of the United Steelworkers local to listen to what union leaders might have on their minds about the mill.
A visit by the president of the corporation's vast steel operation to a union office might seem like business as usual. But "it was very, very unusual," said Cary Kranz, president of the local. "Other heads of U.S. Steel would never have dreamed of being in the same room with the union people. He is bringing in a breath of fresh air."
Mr. Kranz's testimony itself represents a significant shift in relations between management and labor at the nation's largest steel company, which had long been characterized by criticism -- not compliments. To many, Mr. Usher, 49 years old, represents a historic changing of the guard at Big Steel, replacing the autocratic managers that President Kennedy once referred to as "a bunch of S.O.B.'s."
"Our long-term interests are exactly the same," Mr. Usher said recently in an interview at the company's headquarters here. "Whether you are a manager or a member of the union, everyone wants to do a good job, and they want to provide for their families. But I think there is a growing realization that we are not going to make it without the union and the union is not going to make it without us."
That realization has led to a number of changes in the way the two sides treat each other and has helped forge a big comeback for America's largest steelmakers. Although the biggest steelmakers are losing money in this recession, there has been a marked improvement in efficiency and quality. For those reasons and others the Bush Administration decided not to extend limits on imported steel.
But the task ahead for Mr. Usher, who took over the steel operation in 1990, is to find ways to cause the business to grow profitably and retain customers as well as find still more ways to make better steel more efficiently.
At the U.S. Steel Group, USX's steel division and America's most efficient large steel producer, there are now regular meetings with managers and union officials that cover everything from retraining and environmental progress to health-care costs. And under Mr. Usher's guidance, groups of union workers and managers have started visiting customers to interview them about their products. Slowly, the carefully drawn line between management and labor, which existed for generations, is beginning to blur.
 
'A Different Breed'
 "He is an excellent manager, and he is a different type of manager from what we have seen before," said Paul T. Sullivan, executive director for purchasing and transportation at the Ford Motor Company, a large USX customer. "From my perspective, Tom Usher is an effective manager who seems to be totally committed to getting everyone involved in the process of quality. To me, he is a different breed of fellow."
Many suggest that Mr. Usher's style reflects his exposure to foreign steel companies, particularly those in Japan and South Korea. Mr. Usher, who came to U.S. Steel in 1966 as an industrial engineer and has held numerous management positions in plants and headquarters ever since, has had his executive tenure shaped by the waves of joint ventures between USX and the Pohang Iron and Steel Company of South Korea and the Kobe Steel Company of Japan.
"He has been more open with customers and employees," said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. "He has managed in a short time to create a sense of team spirit there."
Mr. Usher is unwilling to acknowledge that his management style has been heavily influenced by those partnerships. But he insists that there was a need to run matters differently.
"Twenty years ago, there was very little that was ever expected of anyone who wasn't in management, particularly to come up with an idea," Mr. Usher said. "Everyone looked up to the oracle on high for all decisions."
Indeed, the American steel industry has long been a symbol of rigid management. Like many in American industry, steel executives gave orders to managers, who in turn passed them along to foremen who barked them at workers.
Today, steel managers are more likely to have committees made up of union members and executives to discuss quality, customer service or productivity. Executives often ask workers to help in devising methods to shave minutes from one process or another. "As a culture in this company, we have asked a lot of people's backs, but not enough of their minds," Mr. Usher said.
Mr. Usher's climb up U.S. Steel's corporate ladder began after he earned an undergraduate degree in industrial engineering, a master's degree in operations research and a doctorate in systems engineering, all from the University of Pittsburgh.
By 1975, he had become the assistant to the general superintendent of the company's large plant on the South Side of Chicago, which he recently decided to close. Mr. Usher went on to hold posts in strategic planning and research for the corporation and became vice president for engineering for the steel business in 1984. A year later, he was a senior vice president and five years later became president of the steel division, succeeding Thomas C. Graham, who retired last year at age 63.
Mr. Graham, who came to USX in 1983 after a lengthy career at the former Jones & Laughlin Steel, saw the nation's largest steel producer through its toughest years. Although Mr. Graham is credited with investing huge sums in new equipment and forging important joint ventures with foreign steelmakers, he was nonetheless widely seen inside the company and by workers as having an autocratic style of management.
 
Facing New Tests
 Mr. Usher's management will be put to the test in the coming years. He is leading the steel business at a time when manufacturers like auto makers are turning away from steel to substitute lighter materials. He also faces growing competition from nonunion, low-cost mini-mill steel producers like the Nucor Corporation, which make steel from scrap. Those companies have been more aggressive about taking market share from large steel companies. Also, there will be more stringent environmental regulations.
Mr. Usher said his strategy in dealing with the mini-mills was to make flat-rolled steel -- the steel for cars and appliances and the bread and butter of his company -- as inexpensively and efficiently as he can. He said he would continue to have a presence in the export market, something historically uncommon for steel companies in the United States.
"He has a lot of constituents he has to keep happy," Mr. Jacobson said. "The company has done a good job of cutting, but you can only go so far in cutting. You eventually have to address the issue of how to grow the business profitably and hang on to customers and to assure that steel is going to be desired by various industries."
Mr. Jacobson added that Mr. Usher's big contribution to the company would have to be in "generating dialogue with customers and workers and management so that everyone is talking to each other." He said: "But that's something that will require a shift in that company's culture. It's too soon to say how well he is doing in establishing that, but he has made a good start."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas J. Usher, who took over in 1990 as the president of U.S. Steel, the country's most efficient large steel producer. Under his guidance, the long-established line between management and labor is beginning to blur. (Scott Goldsmith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Adviser to Dinkins Again Tops List of City Lobbyists

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
A law firm headed by a close friend and tennis partner of Mayor David N. Dinkins made more money lobbying the city last year than any other concern. Overall, the amount of money that lobbyists earned for their attempts to influence city government rose only slightly from the previous year.
A report issued yesterday by the City Clerk showed that spending on lobbyists rose 3.5 percent in 1991, to $8.8 million, compared with $8.5 million in 1990, when the figure was up a third over 1989. 
 The law firm of Davidoff & Malito -- which is headed by Sid Davidoff, an administrative assistant for former Mayor John V. Lindsay and a frequent adviser to Mayor Dinkins -- led the list for the third straight year, collecting $1.7 million, or almost 20 percent of the total amount paid to city lobbyists.
The number of lobbyists registered with the city increased to 92 last year, from 89 in 1989, but 72 percent of the fees received by lobbyists were paid to 10 firms.
 
Koch Aides Doubled Revenues
 Another firm, that of Capalino, LoCicero, Marino & Tan, Inc., more than doubled its client list and lobbying revenues last year, collecting $776,931.
The firm's chief lobbyists are James Capalino, who was Commissioner of General Services in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, and John LoCicero, who was Mr. Koch's special assistant.
Its clients include Manhattan Cable Television, Paragon Cable Manhattan, TriBeCa Film Center, Inc., which is partly owned by the actor Robert DeNiro, and Penn Yards Associates, in which the developer Donald J. Trump owns a controlling interest.
New York City law requires anyone who receives more than $2,000 a year for representing someone in legislative or regulatory matters before the city to report fees and clients to the City Clerk, Carlos Cuevas. Such representation includes decisions on laws, rules, regulations and rate-making before the City Council, Mayor, city agencies, boards, and commissions.
 
Growth Is Slowing
 Although growth appears to be slowing with the recession, lobbying the city has increased greatly in recent years, reflecting the election of a new Mayor and the adoption of a new City Charter that changed many goverment rules and procedures.
Gene Russianoff, a senior lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group, which is financed by college students' activity fees, said the Clerk's report showed that not all lobbyists were created equal.
"Sid Davidoff is a classic example of the power that former city officials wield," Mr. Russianoff said. "There certainly are a lot of his clients who believe that he can do a better job than his competitors because he has a higher level of access to the Dinkins administration."
 
The Importance of Access
 Among Mr. Davidoff's clients are the Coca-Cola Bottling Company, the McDonald's Corporation, the New York City Committee of Asphalt Producers, the Trump Organization and Vanguard Meter Services Inc., a small Kentucky company which won $50 million dollars in city contracts to install water meters. But the city stopped doing business with the firm when a grand jury accused Vanguard of undercutting competition.
Mr. Davidoff was not at his firm yesterday and could not be reached for comment. But Howard S. Weiss, who supervises the firm's lobbying activities, said that Davidoff & Malito had no special entree to city government. "The truth is what we do, we do well and we have gained a reputation over the years not only with this administration but with others as well," Mr. Weiss said.
Mr. Weiss said that the firm's lobbying revenues as reported by the City Clerk were misleadingly high because the firm included fees received for representing clients seeking city contracts, although lobbyists are not required to report such fees. But Mr. Weiss declined to say what the adjusted figure would be.
City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman have introduced legislation that would require lobbyists to report such activities.
Mr. Capalino said that charges that former government officials have special access were without merit.
"It's been my experience that we are held to an even higher standard by city government because current officials do not want to be accused of being predisposed," Mr. Capalino said. "We win clients because of our insights. We can tell them what government officials are looking for."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Stock Funds Attract Money But Produce Mixed Results

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
For stock mutual funds, the first quarter was a perplexing combination. The money poured in from investors, but the profits from investing all that money were decidedly mixed.
The average equity fund in the quarter had a total return to investors of a negative 0.82 percent, Lipper Analytical Services reported yesterday. Among the 19 types of funds that Lipper tracks, only one narrow category, financial-services funds, showed a gain of more than 5 percent, with a rise of 6.31 percent. 
 Biotechnology funds, the hottest funds of last year and some of the most attractive to investors early this year, were among the biggest losers. The average health and biotechnology fund lost 9.51 percent in the quarter, Lipper said. The worst performer in the group was Fidelity's Select Biotechnology fund, which fell 16.39 percent.
The worst performers among funds were those dedicated to Japanese stocks. Capstone's Nikko Japan Fund plunged 22.93 percent in the quarter, as the Japanese stock market fell rapidly. The Nikkei index of 225 issues has lost more than half its value since the end of 1989.
Despite the dull overall picture, there were three funds that managed to return better than a 20 percent profit to investors in the quarter. Atop the list, with a profit of 24.59 percent, was Fidelity's Select Automotive fund, which benefited from the rapidly rising stock prices of auto makers. Those stocks, headed by Chrysler's rise of more than 50 percent, reflected investors' expectations of an economic recovery in the United States.
The second-best performer was the Sherman, Dean Fund, a highly unusual and small fund based in San Antonio. It posted a first-quarter gain of 22.17 percent.
With just $2.5 million in assets, the fund is run by the 74-year-old Walter J. Sherman and his 39-year-old son, David. The Sherman family owns about a third of the fund, and the elder Mr. Sherman said yesterday that outsiders had not bought many shares in his fund so far this year. "Marketing is not our forte," he said.
The Sherman, Dean Fund owns only 13 stocks and is officially classified as a non-diversified fund. Last year, it rose only 12 percent. But in this year's first quarter, all 13 of its stocks went up, including some that leaped by large amounts on hopes for turnarounds. For example, Greenman Brothers, a toy distributor and retailer, jumped 53 percent as it reported a sharp increase in profits.
Ranking third was the $40 million Heartland Value Fund of Milwaukee. It is an unusual small-capitalization fund that buys only stocks trading at low multiples of earnings and is willing to take huge positions in companies that it likes. The fund, which is restricted to buying companies with total market capitalizations of less than $300 million, gained 20.05 percent, pacing small-company growth funds, which averaged 2.39 percent.
At one point, Heartland Value, along with other accounts managed by William Nasgovitz, owned a quarter of LCS Industries, a New Jersey company that provides direct-marketing services. Those shares were bought for less than $5 each, and about half were sold during the quarter, when good earnings briefly pushed LCS above $16. The shares fell back, but still ended the quarter at $11.25, more than double their price at the beginning of the year.
One secret to doing well in the quarter was to believe the economic recovery was coming and to buy stocks that would benefit from a pickup in business. Such cyclical stocks led the market and formed the basis for an 18.4 percent rise by Pioneer's Capital Growth fund. The fund's manager, Warren Isabelle, yesterday described it as "an aggressive growth fund" that focuses on small to medium-sized companies and has $44 million in assets.
One might have expected the mediocre performance of stock funds to have discouraged investors from pouring cash into them. But the opposite was true. In February, the net cash flow into stock funds was a record $7.5 billion. And when the March figures are posted, the total for the quarter is likely to be $20 billion.
That flood of money reflected in part the fact that 1991 was an excellent year for stocks and for stock funds. Last year, the average equity fund turned in a gain of 30.66 percent. And it also reflected low short-term interest rates, which have persuaded many investors to accept increased risk in exchange for a chance of getting higher returns on their investments.
For the 12 months ending in March, that average return for equity funds is down to a less impressive, but still substantial, 12.26 percent.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Up, as Are Jobless Claims

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Orders to United States factories were higher in February, but first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose for the second week.
The Commerce Department reported factory orders rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, the second straight small gain. But the second weekly increase in initial unemployment claims showed businesses continued to hand out pink slips. Joblessness typically remains high for a time after the economy begins to turn up. 
 The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and nondurable goods rose to a seasonally adjusted $236.4 billion, the second consecutive one-half of 1 percent advance after falling 3.7 percent in December.
"Manufacturing is on an upswing, but a weak upswing," Kris Bledowski of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said. "The early gains will be only so-so."
The Labor Department said initial claims for unemployment insurance unexpectedly posted the second straight increase for the week ended March 21.
The report said 456,000 claims were filed, up 9,000 from the previous week to the highest level since 460,000 applications were made in the week ended Feb. 29.
The four-week moving average, which many analysts consider a better gauge of labor activity, also rose, up to 448,750 from 444,000 a week earlier.
The Labor Department is scheduled to release its unemployment report for March on Friday. Many analysts expect the rate to remain at about 7.3 percent as previously discouraged workers re-enter the market while job growth remains soft.
Analysts say that businesses often delay hiring workers in the early stages of a recovery. Companies tend to rely on overtime to meet rising demand until they are confident the turnaround can be sustained.
Factory orders for durable goods -- items like trucks and turbines expected to last more than three years -- slipped three-tenths of 1 percent in February, to $120.2 billion, after gaining 2.4 percent a month earlier.
Ms. Bledowski noted that those orders "were heavily affected by the military sector."
Orders for military equipment, which often are volatile, fell 18.7 percent after dropping 20 percent in January and soaring 89.4 percent in December. Excluding this component, orders rose 1.2 percent in February.
On the other hand, orders for non-durable goods such as chemicals and clothing rose 1.4 percent, the first advance in three months. Analysts said growth in this sector usually preceded the more expensive durable-goods category as a recovery began.
Shipments, a barometer of current production, rose 2.1 percent, the 10th increase in 11 months.
But unfilled orders fell 1 percent, their sixth straight decline. Unfilled orders indicate future business and whether additional workers will be needed.
Inventories were down three-tenths of 1 percent, their fifth consecutive decline, to the lowest level since February 1989.
"The lower inventories will help in the end," Ms. Bledowski said, adding that they will "give a kick to production schedules" as businesses replenish their stocks.
Among the durable-goods components, transportation orders advanced nine-tenths of 1 percent after a 1.9 percent gain a month earlier. Excluding transportation, orders rose four-tenths of 1 percent.
Orders for primary metals rose 8 percent after a 2.3 percent gain.
But orders for industrial machinery and equipment such as engines and computers slipped 1.9 percent after rising 5.8 percent.
Electronic and other electrical equipment orders also fell 1.9 percent, following a 5.1 percent loss in January.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft, a barometer of industry plans to expand and modernize, fell 2.9 percent after rising 4.5 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: Officials Question if Newly Passed State Spending Plan Will Remain Balanced

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 2

 BODY:
The New York State Legislature completed work on the new state budget just before 4 A.M. today, giving the state its earliest spending plan in eight years but raising questions among some fiscal monitors about whether the $30.8 billion budget will remain balanced through the year.
The monitors, including State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, expressed doubts about some revenue estimates and noted that lawmakers failed to give legal approval to the sale of property at the Aqueduct Race track in Queens despite a provision in the budget for $50 million in proceeds from the transaction. 
 Mr. Regan, a Republican, pointedly called on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to issue an update of all budget projections in September "so voters are made aware of the state's fiscal situation before the election." All 211 members of the Legislature, but none of the statewide officials including Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Regan, are up for re-election in November.
Nevertheless, after missing the April 1 budget deadline by a record nine weeks last year, there was an air of good feeling and self-congratulation among the state's leaders.
"This should be the start of something good," said Governor Cuomo, who had fought with legislators for five months over the state's finances.
 
Politics Plays a Role
 Cuomo administration officials, who insisted that ample precautions had been taken to insure a balanced budget, brushed aside Mr. Regan's objections, arguing that he could not have reviewed the whole plan. "It's hard for us to understand how the Comptroller could imply the possibility of a deficit when he hasn't studied the bills yet," said Claudia S. Hutton, a spokeswoman for the Mr. Cuomo's budget division.
Electoral politics played a clear role in the budget deliberations, and indeed were responsible for pushing final passage of the budget just beyond April 1, the date lawmakers were hoping to attain for symbolic as well as legal reasons.
In the Republican-controlled State Senate, the final approval did not come until near dawn because G.O.P. Senators were holed up with their leader, Ralph J. Marino, for more than seven hours on Wednesday as several of them pleaded for permission to vote "no" on the tax portion of the budget. That included hundreds of millions of dollars in new fees plus the deferral of $1 billion worth of scheduled tax cuts.
At least seven of the Republican Senators are facing primary races this fall, with many of the challengers emboldened by the guerrilla tactics of Change-NY, a conservative organization. Among other things, the well-financed group has flooded the Senators' districts with mailings reminding voters that their representatives have been voting for higher taxes.
"After what happened in New Jersey, where both houses of the Legislature changed hands, these people are a lot more sensitive to the concerns about taxes," Tom Carroll, the president of Change-NY, said of the Senators. "In prior years they were able to get away with saying one thing in their districts and doing another thing in Albany, but we're not going to let that happen anymore."
 
Soundly Balanced Budget
 Despite the failure in securing legal language for the Aqueduct deal, which Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders said they would try to hammer out later, the Governor said there was enough of a cushion built into the budget that he could confidently take it before credit rating agencies .
Last year's $30 billion budget fell out of balance by nearly $900 million, with state officials blaming the recession -- specifically, declining tax revenues and greater demands for social services -- for the problem.
This time around, Mr. Cuomo said he thought the budget was more soundly balanced than any he had seen in his nine-year tenure. But even at that, he added, there was no way he could guarantee New Yorkers fiscal equilibrium.
"We're trying to make an absolutely firm calculus about something that it is in its nature unpredictable," he told reporters today. "You have to guarantee now that it's going to come out even a year from now whether you have a war or not, a plague or not, crack or not."
Cynthia Green, a senior analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a Manhattan-based watchdog group financed by businesses, said that the goal of a timely budget may have prevented greater budgetary reform. "The timing isn't everything here," she said. "It may be everything in comedy but it's nothing in tragedy, and this is a tragic budget. "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Little Changed in Slow Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as market participants prepared for the release today of March employment data.
"We saw very good buying on Wednesday, and now the market is just evening out going into the numbers," one government securities trader said. 
 Most economists expect the employment data to show that non-farm payroll employment rose by a modest 25,000 to 50,000 last month, and that the unemployment rate remained unchanged at 7.3 percent.
 
Unaffected by Data
 Economic data released yesterday, including a rise in factory orders during February and a surprisingly large rise in initial unemployment claims in the week that ended on March 21, had no effect on prices in the credit markets, traders said.
Analysts said that the increase in unemployment claims, however, coupled with a decline in the employment component in the survey of the nation's purchasing managers released on Wednesday, seemed to increase the odds the March employment numbers might be weaker than anticipated.
"The risks now seem to be on the downside," said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
"We have an economy that is growing in the range of 1 percent to 2 percent," he said. "But without job growth, I don't see us jumping much above that level."
 
Money Supply Falls
 An additional sign of potential weakness appeared late in the day, when the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week that ended on March 23.
A decline of $10.2 billion in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, was much larger than anticipated.
"The slowdown in money supply is just one more piece of the puzzle that we expect to contribute to the more bullish environment this quarter," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said in their daily market commentary.
The analysts added that they expect further declines in the monetary aggregates next week.
The money supply numbers did provoke a small reaction from traders, and prices moved modestly higher. But concern about the coming employment data limited the size of the rise.
 
30-Year Bonds Unchanged
 By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 1015/32 , down by 2/32 , to yield 7.89 percent, unchanged from late on Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10013/32 , unchanged on the day, to yield 7.43 percent. The 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 1007/32 , down by 2/32 , to yield 6.82 percent. And the 5 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 10015/32 , unchanged on the day, to yield 5.49 percent.
Traders reported good demand at an auction of $13 billion in one-year Treasury bills.
The bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.34 percent, down slightly from the 4.37 percent average rate at the last one-year bill auction on March 5.
Rates on outstanding Treasury bills were unchanged to slightly higher.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4 percent late yesterday, unchanged on the day. And six-month bill rates rose by 2 basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 4.10 percent.
Activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by the sale of $1.2 billion in 7-year and 12-year securities for RJR Nabisco Inc.
The $600 million in 8.30 percent seven year notes were priced at $100, or par, 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $600 million in 8 3/4 percent 12-year securities were also priced at $100, or par, 1.29 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
All of the securities priced yesterday are noncallable for life.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
7-Year Bonds Sold
 Investment bankers at Goldman said all of the seven-year securities had been sold, and that commitments for 85 percent of the 12-year bonds had been received.
Proceeds from the sale will be used to retire bank debt the company used earlier this year to repurchase $1 billion in high-cost debt.
Falling interest rates and a sharp rise in the stock market have been a boon to RJR Nabisco, allowing the company to retire or refinance billions in high-cost debt securities.
Terry Dwyer, a group vice president at Duff & Phelps/MCM Credit Research Company, estimates that by the end of the year the company will have pared its total interest expense to $1.4 billion, from $3.2 billion in 1990.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bank Talks Are Delayed By Olympia

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 2

 BODY:
Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the struggling real estate giant that had promised to open its books to 100 creditor banks to renegotiate its debt, delayed the meeting for a week today.
The session between the world's largest commercial property developer and its international bankers, originally scheduled for next Monday, will be held April 13, the company said. Olympia & York said the delay was needed so it would have more time to prepare a financial picture of the company. 
 The company, which is the largest office landlord in New York and Toronto and is owned by Toronto's publicity-shy Reichmann brothers, said it would offer an interim proposal to the bankers while a long-term plan was developed. It is scrambling to restructure its debt because of a cash crunch brought on by the recession, an office-space glut and upward spiraling costs at its Canary Wharf development in London.
Olympia's total debt outstanding, including that of subsidiaries, is about $18.5 billion.
 
Some Debt Is Paid
 The company managed today to come up with nearly $124 million, or $147.3 million in Canadian currency, through an early dividend payment and used it to pay back some pressing debts, including $65 million of commercial paper that was due last month.
GW Utilities Ltd., which is 89 percent owned by Olympia, issued the dividend two weeks early from funds received from the first installment of its sale of Interprovincial Pipe Line Inc., announced in early March.
GW Utilities has been selling assets and passing the proceeds on to Olympia for the last year and a half.
Meanwhile, the Labor Party calmed fears that it might leave the Canary Wharf office development in London's Docklands area without good transportation if it won the general election next Thursday.
The Labor opposition, which opposed the 71-acre project begun under then-Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, is currently leading in opinion polls.
Canary Wharf -- half complete but producing little cash flow -- desperately needs better transportation links to London's financial center.
 
Deal to Sell Headquarters
 "We want to be pragmatic," a Labor Party spokesman said. "We are already committed to the rejuvenation of the Docklands area in East London, and now the Canary Wharf development is a reality, we do not want to fight old ideological battles with O.& Y."
People close to the restructuring said Olympia was working on a deal to sell its 36-story headquarters building, Exchange Tower, in downtown Toronto. The deal would help pay other commercial-paper obligations.
Olympia's $378 million mortgage ($450 million in Canadian funds) on the nearby Scotia Plaza building came due Wednesday without being paid.
The banks holding the mortgage on the 68-story tower could call the loan at any time, forcing Olympia into default, but they appear willing to let the mortgage sit on the table and become part of the restructuring process.
"This will most definitely take a long time," Brian Neysmith, president of the Canadian Bond Rating Service, said of the debt restructuring talks.
Olympia said it would open its books to its major lenders, but the contents were expected to be kept secret for reasons of client confidentiality and the Reichmanns' penchant for secrecy.
"I can't think of any other company where you have so little consolidated information," Mr. Neysmith said.
A group of bankers is reported to have made a loan to Olympia recently, using as collateral the second installment of the proceeds of the $210 million Interprovincial sale.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off as Job Data Hurt Bulls Who Bet on Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday in response to an increase in unemployment benefits claims.
Gold was also lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $340.90 a troy ounce, down $2. A late bid at the Republic National Bank quoted gold at $340.30, off $2.15. 
 The dollar fell early in trading after the Government said unemployment claims for the third week in March were higher than expected, said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange director at the Bank of Boston.
The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose by 9,000, to 456,000. It was the second consecutive weekly increase and the highest level in three weeks. Economists had been looking for little change in the number.
 
Traders Change Positions
 Trading was volatile as investors who had been bullish on the dollar reconsidered their positions, Mr. Lawrie said.
Market participants bought dollars several weeks ago expecting that healthy economic reports would raise the currency's value, traders said.
But the market has not been satisfied with the slightly better-than-expected economic data showing a sluggish recovery. Only much better indicators would push the dollar further, traders said.
There was little change later in the day ahead of full March employment data, to be released today, Mr. Lawrie said.
"There wasn't much in the way of pressure to bring the dollar up again," said Mike Faust, a currency market analyst at MMS International Inc.
A report showing orders to United States factories somewhat stronger than expected did not support the dollar, he said. The Commerce Department said factory orders in February rose five-tenths of a percent for the second straight month.
In New York, the dollar fell to 133.70 Japanese yen from Wednesday's 134.50. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 134.77 yen, from 133.90 Wednesday. But later in London, it fell to 133.80 yen.
The British pound was quoted at $1.7310, up from $1.7260 Wednesday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7314, from $1.7255 Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.64375 German marks, down from 1.6520; 1.5015 Swiss francs, down from 1.5110; 5.5675 French francs, down from 5.6025; 1,240.00 Italian lire, down from 1,246.50, and 1.19195 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19125.

HEADLINE: Father's Papers and a Son's Politics;
When Jerry Finkelstein Buys, Andrew Stein's Foes Wonder

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Jerry Finkelstein's business is newspapers. The business of his son, Andrew J. Stein, is politics.
But now the media company that counts Mr. Finkelstein as its largest shareholder is buying up weekly newspapers all over the New York metropolitan region. Mr. Stein, the City Council President, is preparing for a mayoral race. All of which leaves some of his political opponents wondering if the family businesses have become a little too symbiotic. 
 "These are arguable investments," said Rudolph W. Giuliani, a former mayoral candidate, who contends that Mr. Finkelstein intends to use the weeklies as a vehicle to further his son's election drive.
"You'd have to have your head in the sand not to figure out what he's doing," added Mr. Giuliani, a Republican who lost to David N. Dinkins in 1989 and plans to run again.
Mr. Finkelstein, the 76-year-old former publisher of The New York Law Journal and a man with a long personal history in both politics and newspapers, indignantly denies that the media company, News Communications Inc., is doing anything other than building an empire of weeklies.
 
Neiether Hurts Nor Helps
 "I've been in the business all my life going back to 1939," he said, refering to his founding of The Civil Service Leader. His son, he added, "is an important person in the city."
"He doesn't need a few community papers to help him," he said.
Mr. Stein shrugs off his father's newspaper interests. "I don't think I'm hurt or helped," he said. "I have a 24-year record in public service. It's going to be looked at. My ideas for the city will be judged by all the media. So I don't think this has any effect one way or the other."
Yet the disclaimers do nothing to soothe rivals who remember that Mr. Finkelstein was instrumental in his son's early career, pouring money into an extravagant East Side race in 1968 that catapulted Mr. Stein, who had shortened his name, into the State Assembly.
It does not seem to matter that a year and a half before the election, the newspapers -- in Queens, Manhattan, the Hamptons and Montauk and with a total circulation in the hundreds of thousands -- barely cover Mr. Stein, or that their gossip columns show only the most negligible, perhaps just imagined, tendency to criticize his potential opponents. New York's political circles have been abuzz with each new purchase and Mr. Finkelstein's role has become a subterranean issue in an unofficial race.
"Jerry Finkelstein is a very smart man," said Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, who says she would not challenge Mr. Dinkins but does have mayoral ambitions. "He has always known how to protect his investments. His biggest investment is his son. It doesn't hurt to own all the weekly newspapers in two or three boroughs. It's a resource you can always call on if you really need it."
Even former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who says he does not believe Mr. Finkelstein is involved in anything other than canny business, felt compelled to make a public announcement when he became a movie reviewer for News Communications.
"I said I would not be supporting Andy Stein," Mr. Koch said. "And the reason is that I asked him to support me in my last election and he said he was for me, but did not endorse me." Mr. Koch said he spoke out to highlight his independence from Mr. Finkelstein.
"I was sure that people would think he was buying me," he said. "I'm sure that was not his intention."
Michael Schenkler, the president of News Communications, insists that the newspaper chain is a business, not a political enterprise. He added that the chain is looking to expand into Nassau County and New Jersey.
 
Looking to the Shore
 He noted that while Mr. Finkelstein is the largest shareholder, he owns only 20 percent of the company. The second largest shareholder, with 12 percent, is Gary L. Ackerman, the Queens Congressman who founded the Queens Tribune newspapers, now a part of the chain. Mr. Schenkler, the publisher of The Queens Tribune, is third, with 8 percent.
Among the other members of the company's board are two more people with connections to Mr. Stein: Martin McLaughlin, a consultant and political adviser to Mr. Stein, and Christopher McGrath, who was a deputy to Mr. Stein when he served as Manhattan Borough President.
The chain's first property was The West Side Spirit -- now the Manhattan Spirit -- founded in 1985. In 1988 it purchased Dan's Papers and The Montauk Pioneer, papers that pick up a substantial New York City readership in the summers, particularly many influential politicians and business leaders. One year later it took over The Queens Tribune, which has nine editions, with a total circulation of 146,000.
Last year, Manhattan's Our Town paper was acquired, adding another 119,000 readers. And last month, News Communications signed a letter of intent to buy The Downtown Express, The Chelsea Clinton-News and The Westsider, which would give the chain five weeklies in Manhattan and bring its city and Long Island circulation to about 476,000.
Mr. Finkelstein said in an interview that the company is finished with acquisitions in New York City and needs to diversify because the recession will last longer in New York than elsewhere.
This month, the chain announced plans to acquire two papers on the Jersey Shore. The chain has also had sporadic talks over the last year or so with two Brooklyn newspaper chains and with The Bronx Times Reporter.
 
A Father's Motives
 The newspapers, most of them distributed free, cover community issues that seldom appear in New York's dailies. There are profiles and interviews of local elected officials, and gossip items that Tom Allon, the editor in chief of The Manhattan Spirit, aggressively tries to propel into the gossip pages of the city's tabloids.
Mr. Allon says he resents suggestions that he is beholden to anyone. He said he almost never talks to Mr. Finkelstein and his paper rarely writes anything about Mr. Stein.
"It's hard enough to cover this city, but when you're up against people who try to impugn motives that aren't there it makes it more difficult," Mr. Allon said.
But he ran right into that perception recently when he printed a gossip item, which he also leaked to The New York Post, saying that Mr. Giuliani, a former United States Attorney, was a "major player" in rewriting an extradition treaty that smoothed the way for deportation of Joseph Doherty, an Irish Republican Army member who has been sent to Britain.
Mr. Giuliani -- who denies that he helped rewrite the treaty -- refused to take a call from the weekly. Instead he passed it on to the executive director of his campaign committee who delivered the message that "if Jerry wants to interview us about the Doherty matter we'd be happy to be interviewed directly by Jerry rather than using an intermediary."
Mr. Allon calls the reference to Mr. Finkelstein a "smokescreen."
"Giuliani is a smart politician," he said. "When attacked for something he will wildly counterattack and try to deflect attention from the issue, and that's what he's doing here."
 
Record of Publishing
 Mr. Giuliani, who is collecting a small archive of items from News Communications' newspapers critical of himself or other potential rivals of Mr. Stein, contends that the gossip columns are being used for "hit jobs." He noted that during a week in which Mr. Stein was receiving coverage in the city's dailies -- much of it negative -- for his lavish January fund-raising event, the News Communications gossip column did not carry a word of it.
But it carried items on Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Dinkins and Ms. Messinger. Mr. Allon said that he felt the fund-raiser had already received saturation coverage in the dailies.
The Dinkins administration, meanwhile, is staying above the fray. Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, said that like "anyone who knows anything about the newspaper business in New York," he was aware of News Communications' growth. But he added, "I think we have faith in the objectivity and integrity of the reporters and editors."
As he sits in his midtown office, decorated with pictures of his children and prominent elected officials, Mr. Finkelstein insists that his long career as a publisher should end the speculation about his intentions.
"The record is important," he said. "The record is that in the 25 years that I published the Law Journal, I don't remember one story about Andy Stein. The record is there."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Facing Dangers Of a Global Bust

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE American economic recovery is being threatened by a global recession. In all the major countries, including this one, the recessions of the 1990's have proved to be deeper and more tenacious than the consensus forecasts of economists or governments.
What distinguishes the present slump from earlier postwar dips are the structural drags, especially the huge public and private debts and the inflated asset values built in the careless and speculative boom of the 1980's. "The unwinding of an asset-driven credit mania is always longer and more difficult than observers and economic actors at first believe," said Kenneth S. Courtis, the Tokyo-based strategist and senior economist of the Deutsche Bank Capital Markets in Asia. 
 In Japan, he said, "It is just over these past few weeks that the cozy consensus view has begun to come to terms with the reality that the economy is much weaker than official forecasts and that the trials of the equity market are far from complete."
In Europe, recessions in many countries -- and the difficulty of getting out of them -- are being hampered by Germany. It has the most powerful economy, and is fighting inflation while the others want to fight recession. With its heavy costs of unification, the German budget has swung from a modest surplus in 1989 to a deficit of 5 percent of the gross domestic product this year. Consumer prices in Germany have been rising at a rate above 4.5 percent, high by German standards and an outrage at the Bundesbank.
So the German central bank has held money tight and interest rates up, and other European countries, linked to Germany in the European Monetary System, have had to keep their interest rates higher than their domestic economic conditions would warrant. They are finding it hard to pry themselves out of recession. Many Europeans fear that they are caught in a slump that could last five years or more, stymied by high real interest rates.
Although nominal interest rates are fairly low, Prof. Edmund S. Phelps of Columbia University said that with expectations of inflation low, "what we call real rates of interest are not low by historical standards." He argues that "this interest rate situation" is a major factor behind the slump in the United States, which "suggests the slump will continue to be with us, with only modest improvement, over the next few years."
Could the world economy be facing actual deflation? "I would guess not," Mr. Phelps said, because "the central banks would step in with easier money if that began to happen." But in his view what may well occur, and indeed has already begun to happen, "is deflation in relation to previous anticipations," and as a result, "the real burden of debts is much greater than the borrowers were anticipating when they borrowed."
The problem is how to float companies and economies off the rocks in the short run without causing inflation and instability in the long run. The answer for the United States proposed by 100 economists led by Prof. James Tobin of Yale is for the Administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve to pursue a program of stimulus to achieve a "vigorous" economic recovery in 1992 and higher expenditures to promote productivity growth now and over the long run. The three elements in their program are further cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, tax credits for business investment in plant and equipment and a $50-billion-a-year program of Federal aid to state and local governments, stressing public investment in education and infrastructure.
Some economists are wary of putting the debt problem in abeyance once more. Prof. Benjamin M. Friedman of Harvard said, "In today's fiscal climate, temporary fiscal stimulus has about as much credibility as the tooth fairy." He favors more aggressive monetary ease now, while the inflationary risk is low.
Similarly, Henry Kaufman, president of Henry Kaufman & Company, says the "massive debt overhang" is the biggest drag on the American economy. Now, with the recovery "modest and tepid," he urges the Fed "to take some risks on excessive ease." Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady takes the same position.
The global recession is also restraining the American recovery. Exports, a strong source of support last year, have been dropping, and the rising dollar may push them further down. High interest rates in Germany, sluggish European economies, and the draining of capital funds by Japan are also drags on the American economy.
If the major trading countries and regions were to resort to hostile beggar-thy-neighbor trade and investment policies, the danger of a worldwide bust would be greater still. It has become more urgent than ever that the Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- work together to coordinate their macroeconomic and trade policies. Mutual fears of a breakdown in world trade are making for a compromise deal to settle the long-stalled Uruguay Round of trade negotiations.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

Almost 6 Weeks' Previews for Pacino
Al Pacino is coming to Broadway, but his producers say they can't afford an opening. Circle in the Square will present Mr. Pacino in two plays, "Salome" by Oscar Wilde and "Chinese Coffee" by Ira Lewis, from May 21 through July 18. The more than 600 Tony voters, whose presence qualifies an opening as official, will not be invited, says Circle's managing director, Robert Buckley, who estimates that the theater will save $140,000 in free tickets. 
 Editors, reporters and critics will be given one free ticket apiece, instead of the usual pair. Mr. Buckley confirms that Mr. Pacino and the creative personnel in both shows have agreed to work for union scale (Actors' Equity scale is $900 a week) to help the theater reduce its deficit. But Circle will ask critics not to review the shows until June 29, almost six weeks after the first preview and two weeks before the show closes.
Will the press really wait? The memory of "Nick and Nora" is still fresh, and its nine weeks of previews prompted some critical snooping before the official opening. A star of Mr. Pacino's stature on Broadway is a major news event, after all.
"We normally play 18 previews before the press comes," Mr. Buckley says. "Because these plays are running in repertory with only seven performances a week, we will only have had 14 performances of 'Chinese Coffee' and 19 of 'Salome' when they come this time. When it's explained this way we hope people see the reason behind it."
Circle also says it is in compliance with rules established by the Department of Consumer Affairs that ads must either state when a show is in previews or give a review date. Still, the press may decide not to wait. Linda Winer, the drama critic at New York Newsday who focused consumer attention on "Nick and Nora," and jumped the official review date at the National Actors Theater's long-previewing "Crucible," says, "This is a situation my editors and I will think about seriously."
"Chinese Coffee," co-starring Mr. Pacino and Charles Cioffi, will be directed by Arvin Brown. "Salome" will co-star Mr. Pacino, Sheryl Lee (Laura Palmer in "Twin Peaks") in the title role, Suzanne Bertish and Esai Morales. Lar Lubovitch will choreograph Salome's Dance of the Seven Veils and Robert Allan Ackerman will direct.
 
Season's Finale at the Second Stage
 Carole Rothman and Robyn Goodman, the co-artistic directors of Second Stage, have announced their final production of the season, "Spike Heels," a new play by Theresa Rebeck. Michael Greif will direct the post-feminist sex comedy starring Kevin Bacon, Saundra Santiago and Tony Goldwyn. Performances are to run from May 12 through July 4.
 
The Public Is Taking Papp's Name
 On April 23, the Public Theater, home of the New York Shakespeare Festival, will be renamed the Joseph Papp Public Theater in honor of its founder, on the birthday of his favorite playwright, William Shakespeare. Mayor David N. Dinkins will officiate at the dedication along with Mr. Papp's widow, Gail Merrifield Papp; his successor, JoAnne Akalaitis, the artistic director of the festival, and Robert Pittman, the chairman of the theater's board. The public is welcome.
Mr. Papp purchased the former Astor Library in 1966, saving it from demolition. He named it the Public, in the hope it would be a theater for everyone, fighting for its landmark status and turning it into a five-theater cultural complex. Its inaugural production in 1967 was "Hair."
 
A Roster of Opening-Night Parties
 The crunch is on for Broadway openings: 11 are scheduled this month, trying to beat the April 29 cutoff date for Tony Award eligibility. The stakes are high, the competition fierce. But what does everyone really want to know? "Where's the party?" Even in a recession, the tradition of the opening-night party endures. It is a producer's way of thanking everyone from a show's investors to its ushers, and not incidentally, provides an excellent opportunity for extra press coverage on attending celebrities, anything from "Entertainment Tonight" to the local news.
Here they all are, from the economic to the glorious: "Five Guys Named Moe" will celebrate at the Supper Club, the new hot place for openings this season, where "Death and the Maiden" and "Crazy for You" had their soirees; "A Streetcar Named Desire" will have a traditional night at Sardi's; "Two Trains Running" is going to the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza; "Guys and Dolls" at Roseland with cheesecake (not Mindy's) for all; "Metro" to Tavern on the Green; "The High Rollers Social and Pleasure Club" at K-Paul's for a New Orleans blowout personally prepared by its chef, Paul Prudhomme, a longtime fan of the show's star, Allen Toussaint; "Shimada" to the Marriott Marquis in black tie as well as "Man of La Mancha," which will feature an all-Spanish menu, flamenco guitarists and dancers; "Jelly's Last Jam" in what promises to be the most theatrical of all: black tie at Roseland with black and white decor, Champagne fountains, cigarette and camera girls and a menu of oysters Rockefeller and chateaubriand; "A Small Family Business" at Laura Belle, featuring Lancaster Hot Pots, a British variation on shepherd's pie that is mentioned in the show. Finally, "Falsettos" caps the season in black tie at Tavern on the Green. Party on.
 
Plums for Long-Range Planners
 If you're the type to plan ahead, here are some dates to keep: Performances begin June 2 for Keith Reddin's "Innocent's Crusade," at Manhattan Theater Club, starring Deborah Monk, James Rebhorn and Welker White. Mark Brokaw directs the new play about a student applying to college who rebels against the system. . . . Hector Elizondo joins Eli Wallach in the Roundabout's production of Arthur Miller's "Price" on May 20, directed by John Tillinger. And if your date book is still empty for 1993, don't panic. Kelly McGillis will play the title role in Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler" at the Roundabout from May 26 through July 18. The English director, Sarah Pia Anderson, will direct.
 
Not a Single Star? Don't Get Excited.
 On Wednesday evening, this is what the audience at "Death and the Maiden" heard on the loudspeaker: "May I have your attention, please? At this evening's performance, Glenn Close, Richard Dreyfuss and Gene Hackman will be unable to appear." After considerable groaning, the loudspeaker came back on. Ms. Close, Mr. Dreyfuss and Mr. Hackman spoke together. "April Fool's!"

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

National's Victory
While Christie's may have lost a prized picture, England has secured a national treasure. 
 After weeks of negotiations, the National Gallery in London has succeeded in buying Hans Holbein's "Lady With a Pet Squirrel and a Starling" from the Marquess of Cholmondeley for $17 million. The museum had had its eye on the 16th-century painting ever since Christie's announced six weeks ago that the Holbein would be the star work in its April 15 auction in London. At the time, Neil MacGregor, director of the National Gallery, said that the painting was "one of the greatest of Holbein's works of this kind" and that "its retention in this country is therefore of great importance."
Lord Cholmondeley had been asking $25 million for the painting, and had maintained that the museum could not meet that price. Although he inherited a fortune estimated at more than $170 million in 1990, Lord Cholmondeley said his income was not enough to maintain his two estates, Cholmondeley in Cheshire and Houghton Hall in Norfolk, where the painting has hung since 1780. He said the proceeds of the sale would be used to help pay for the rising costs of keeping these two stately homes.
Although the price was well beyond the museum's annual purchase grant from the Government, which has been frozen at $4.5 million for the last seven years, the National Gallery was determined to find the money. Six weeks of negotiations began between Jack Baer, managing director of Hazlitt Gooden & Fox, the London gallery, which represented the museum, and Christie's, which acted as agents for Lord Cholmondeley.
What is known in the auction business as a private treaty sale -- a negotiated transaction as opposed to a purchase made in a public sale room -- was enacted. After much maneuvering, a $17 million deal was arranged that satisfied both parties. Mr. Baer said that $5.1 million came from the National Heritage Fund, a special state fund; that $425,000 was donated by the National Art Collections Fund, and that the rest would be paid in three annual installments by the National Gallery.
Because of special tax incentives in England for selling to museums works of art that are considered national treasures, Lord Cholmondeley will get the $17 million tax-free. "If Lord Cholmondeley had sold the picture at auction he would have had to pay a 60 percent tax based on the hammer price," explained Mr. Baer. "The negotiations had quite a lot of complications, but in the end it was an elegant transaction. Lord Cholmondeley wanted to raise enough money to ensure the future of Houghton Hall."
In a telephone interview this week, Mr. MacGregor said he was surprised and happy that the negotiations had worked out. "This is a very important painting and there is not a single small Holbein portrait in an English collection," he added. "They've all gone abroad."
Charles Allsopp, chairman of Christie's in Europe, acknowledged that had the painting been sold at auction the house would probably have received a larger commission. "But you can never tell," he added. "At auction anything can happen and nothing can happen." Mr. Allsopp also admitted that, given all the adverse publicity the forthcoming auction has received, he realized it might have been a particularly difficult sale. "From the beginning of this saga we always knew it wasn't going to be easy," he said. "But now everyone is happy, and that's the end of the story."
 
Emergency Arts Fund
 In an effort to help Manhattan's nonprofit arts and cultural organizations, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, in collaboration with almost two dozen representatives of arts councils and arts service organizations in Manhattan, have formed the Special Arts Fund for Emergencies. The fund plans to be open for business on April 15 at the New York Foundation for the Arts, 5 Beekman Street in Manhattan.
"This is the art community's response to a serious need at a time when there's a particular sense of powerlessness," Ms. Messinger said. "Emergencies always exist, and especially in this bad economic climate." Ms. Messinger said that over the last few years arts establishments in Manhattan had lost about one-third of their public subsidies. The new fund will try to make up for at least part of this loss by providing a type of help that has not been available recently to arts organizations.
The fund will provide loans of up to $10,000 for what it considers emergencies -- fires, thefts, canceled tours, performers' illnesses -- that threaten the existence of an arts organization. The fund will be able to respond in as little as three days, depending on circumstances. In addition to addressing immediate problems, it will provide expert help in fields ranging from banking to real estate.
The initial funds that helped start the fund came from Ms. Messinger's office. Loan guarantees and technical-assistance subsidies are being provided by the Joyce Mertz Gilmore Foundation and the Booth Ferris Foundation, two Manhattan-based organizations that have actively responded to crises in the arts.
To raise additional money for the fund, eight young Manhattan artists -- Candida Alvarez, Brett DePalma, Colin Loy Lee, Judith Linhares, Frank Moore, Lorna Simpson, Hunt Slonem and Robin Winters -- have each donated a print that will be on view tomorrow through April 11 at Brooke Alexander Editions, 476 Broome Street in SoHo. The collection has been organized by Tony Whitfield of the Manhattan Borough President's office, and Julie Sylvester, a print dealer. Prints may be purchased for $1,000 each or for $6,000 for the entire portfolio of eight.
 
A Collection Divided>
 Both the Brooklyn Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art received gifts recently from the estate of Edith and Milton Lowenthal. Mr. Lowenthal, a lawyer, died in 1987, and Dr. Lowenthal, a psychologist, died last year. Between 1943 and 1958, they assembled an important collection of modern American paintings and sculpture of the 1930's and 40's. Thirty-one works have been left to the Brooklyn Museum and eight to the Metropolitan.
"For the Met, the donation is building strength on strength," said Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director. "We are strong in American paintings, and the addition of this gift perfectly complements our holdings." The Metropolitan received two works each by Stuart Davis, Marsden Hartley and Charles Sheeler and one by Arthur G. Dove and Max Weber. Three of them -- Hartley's "Mount Katahdin, Maine," and two Sheelers, a drawing, "Open Door," and a painting, "Americana" -- will be on view starting Tuesday in the Met's contemporary-art galleries.
The Brooklyn's gift is far more substantial: 31 works by such artists as Stanton Macdonald-Wright, Milton Avery, Georgia O'Keeffe and Davis, and 8 Hartleys. "The gift fills a substantial gap in our holdings," said Robert T. Buck, the museum's director. "We were spotty in American paintings."
Five paintings have been installed at the Brooklyn Museum this week: Avery's "Artist's Daughter by the Sea," Davis's "Landscape With Clay Pipe," O'Keeffe's "Ram's Head, White Hollyhock Hills," Hartley's "Gull" and Macdonald-Wright's "Synchromy." The entire collection will be hung in September.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Network Relief Fails to Get N.F.L. Support

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
It was a brief, shining moment, a tiny blip in time when the TV networks thought the National Football League would make their financial woes its own and grant much-needed financial relief.
So ABC, CBS and NBC looked toward a Dallas airport hotel on Wednesday, hoping for passage of N.F.L. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue's bold proposal: a $238 million reduction in 1993 payments and a two-year extension at the 1993 level. 
 The deal would ease the pain of the networks' projected $250 million loss for 1993. But all hope was crushed. Tagliabue counted too few owners' votes and compromised with a $28 million reduction in 1993 and no extension.
"It's disappointing," said Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, "because Tagliabue and Art Modell" -- the owner of the Cleveland Browns -- "worked so hard to make it work. The consequence will be that we'll have these huge losses even if the economy grows 5 percent."
The league also cut one week from the planned 18-week 1992 schedule, noting that the networks didn't need to sell another week of commercial time.
Implicit in the relief plan was that by extending the deal for two years at the reduced 1993 level, the N.F.L. would be spared potentially far lower fees in 1994 and 1995 if a new deal was bid in a recession-transformed market.
Dennis Swanson, the president of ABC Sports, said: "Maybe it's a mixed blessing that we didn't get the extension. It was not a great deal. Maybe we're better off negotiating a deal we really like."
Ebersol would have loved to have locked in lower fees through 1995. "Unless they accept a bid from us that assures we will be risk free," he said, NBC may be out of the N.F.L. business.
The league will try to pitch the relief plan again in October.
Val Pinchbeck, the N.F.L.'s broadcasting director, looked for a silver lining in the $28 million sliver of relief, saying: "At least the networks know we did something and went to bat for them in a difficult circumstance."
 
Talk About Not Talking
 The New York Mets' balking at talking to the media is as sad as it would be if Al Sharpton clammed up or if A.T.&T. cut off Jerry Brown's 800-number. The team's moments of silence mean we will be sadly without all cliches and stock answers to: "How do you feel about ---------- ?" and "What pitch did you throw to ---------- ?"
The Mets' discourse does not approach "Masterpiece Theatre."
"They don't want to talk to me," said Bob Page of the MSG Network.
"I'm not talking to them." said Len Berman of WNBC, Channel 4. "What will we do without sound bites? More time for bowling highlights."
The overlapping of sports at this time of year, especially, makes losing the Mets' verbiage easy to accommodate. The absence of MetTalk simplifies life for the TV sports anchors, who have about 3 minutes 15 seconds on the air. With highlights and the police blotter, there is nary 10 seconds for a player comment. Now there is no compulsion to plug in bon mots from Eddie Murray.
"If they don't talk, we'll just go to the manager," said Berman. "We'll talk to the other teams. We'll get more John Kruk. We've backed off on using sound bites, except for big and controversial games."
The possibility of not getting personal comments from players who have done something extraordinary rankles Russ Salzburg of WWOR, Channel 9. "What if Doc Gooden pitches a no-hitter or a shutout or his arm pops out?" he asked.
Perhaps the biggest TV losers from the Mets' silence are the WWOR and SportsChannel post-game shows. "If you watch a post-game show, you want to see the players," said Fran Healy, a SportsChannel announcer.
The muting of the Mets has created a new star: Jay Horwitz, the team's public relations chief. He has substituted for players as a guest with Healy and with Ralph Kiner on WWOR's "Kiner's Korner." He was not bad. To a caller who asked him on Healy's show what he does, he said: "I'm the janitor."
Horwitz has been bobbing around in the background for many years with the Mets, almost anonymous to viewers. But now he's prime-time. Except for Manager Jeff Torborg, who's still talking, Horwitz is all the media's got.
"I'd rather hear what Jay has to say than Doc Gooden," said Page.
Letting Horwitz respond as if he were Bobby Bonilla or Howard Johnson could make for amusing TV. Give Jay a uniform and let him be EveryMet.
"But how many Jay Horwitz interviews can you see?" asked Salzburg.
Many, I hope. I want to hear about his repaired rotator cuff.
 
That Other Final Four
 When CBS hawks March Madness, it means the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament. But during the women's Final Four semifinals (tomorrow at 12:30 P.M.), and final (Sunday at 4 P.M.), we get to see their below-the-rim game.
Ann Meyers, the CBS analyst, said: "I like the way Western Kentucky and Southwest Missouri play defense, and rebounding in their game will be a key. Virginia's been No. 1 most of the season and Stanford 3, 4 or 5. There'll be a lot of scoring."
She added: "If people know the personnel, they'll know it's a fun sport. The men are tremendous, but sometimes they get away from fundamentals. The women don't dunk, so they have to think a little more."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
New York and Clinton

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Suddenly, and with just a few days left to go, the central question of the New York Democratic primary has been turned right around.
The question is no longer whether Bill Clinton will prove himself smart enough for New York Democrats. It is whether they will show themselves smart enough, mature and sophisticated enough to listen to the man. 
 And I mean listen, not just sit there so twitching with gotcha that they do not take in what he is saying. Until now New York -- media and public -- has seemed less an audience than a giant bowl of malevolent jelly quivering with eagerness to swallow him up.
That's an old New York game -- come right on in and make it here, try. But it is getting close to decision day and as those times approach, New Yorkers can put aside games and fright masks and grow up fast.
If they actually listen to Governor Clinton, they may find out that he is telling them he wants the same kind of America that New York Democrats have gone around for decades saying they wanted.
Of course, yes -- there is a long way between saying and doing. Right. But Americans can either rule out every candidate who has never been put to the test as President or Vice President or pick one who has a concept of American purpose that they share, and seems ready to put his life where his mouth is.
At the Hilton Hotel Wednesday, Mr. Clinton did what no other Democratic candidate did and what President Bush seems not to know how to do. He drew the essential connecting lines between the two bedrock purposes of American government: to work for an economy strong enough to give Americans a decent, safe life at home, and to work for political freedom and democracy abroad.
Without the first, Americans must live in fear for their jobs. Without the second, they will have neither the markets, peace or lasting international stability needed for the American economy to grow.
It's a simple reality -- the powerful political conjunction between pragmatism and idealism that can be called American democratic realism. With it, we can fulfill our own hopes and help light the world. Without it, this country will become just real estate from sea to shining sea.
The favorite Democrats of New Yorkers all knew it -- F.D.R., Truman, Kennedy, Scoop Jackson, the Wagners, father and son, A. Philip Randolph, Herbert Lehman, Hubert Humphrey, Mayors Edward Koch and Fiorello La Guardia; that type of Democrat. And there is no place where that simple reality is more important than in New York.
Our New York depends on the world for its trade. It depends on political freedom for the creativity of art and commerce at home and abroad, which is its bread and soul.
But Americans have been forgetting the connection between those two bedrock American purposes, and the importance of working toward them, not just prattling about them.
So it's taken this man from Arkansas to remind New Yorkers what the election is all about. Why not? New Yorkers love political freedom, but we did not invent it.
But now we are told by a bunch of party and union "leaders" that the smart thing to do is to vote for Jerry Brown just to stick the knife into Bill Clinton. Then these party and union statesmen could get together at the convention and find the Democratic candidate for us, even though most of them do not have enough brains to find their way out of the subway.
But, great leaders, don't you see? Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton have had the courage, strength and imagination to run, three important Presidential qualities none of the fence-sitters showed while collecting splinters.
New Yorkers should vote for Bill Clinton if they agree with what he is saying and believes about the connected American purposes. They should vote for Jerry Brown if they really think he would be a better President than Bill Clinton and also want Jesse Jackson as Vice President.
At least it would be interesting to hear Mr. Brown trying to dampen some of Mr. Jackson's vivid views, or to see Mr. Jackson keep a straight silent face while the band plays "Hail to the Chief" to his new commander.
But what's that, great leaders? You still think we should be patsy enough to hand over our voting power to you party and union bosses?
Buzz off.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign;
Clinton: Running Against the Press

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT


GRAPHIC: SCRIPT: "He's stood up to the tabloids, the false attacks, told the truth and shown real character. Bill Clinton.
Chart: "Clinton: Running Against the Press"
 "A lifetime of commitment to fighting for people. Re-elected five times by the people who know him best. Voted most effective by his fellow Governors, Democrat and Republican. A Rhodes scholar, educated at Georgetown and Yale Law School. His state is recognized as a leader in education reform and economic development. Creating manufacturing jobs at 10 times the national rate. A record of achievement unmatched in the last decade.
"Bill Clinton, fighting for the forgotten middle class. He'll put people first."
 
 ON THE SCREEN: Footage of Mr. Clinton at a rally, then with his wife and daughter. Young Bill Clinton as a student, with President John F. Kennedy at Boys' Nation. Mr. Clinton with students, then with workers.
 
 ACCURACY: The claims are accurate though incomplete. Arkansas's growth in manufacturing jobs did outpace the nation's by 10.2 percent to 0.9 percent, but during a relatively brief period, 1985-89. During the 1980's, a time that more closely approximates Mr. Clinton's tenure, the figures for all jobs, including manufacturing, were 25 percent in Arkansas and 18 percent nationwide.
 Arkansas has introduced a number of educational innovations at Mr. Clinton's urging, but the record of educational achievement is mixed at best. Arkansas's schools were ranked among the worst in the nation when Mr. Clinton took office 12 years ago, and by most measures they remain in that position today.
 
 SCORECARD: Increasingly, Mr. Clinton seems to be trying to run against the press, a tactic that could be effective given what polls show to be the unpopularity of the media. The ad has a generally positive tone and represents an effort to give voters a reason to vote for Mr. Clinton rather than against his opponent. But the many claims in the ad seem too diffuse to give viewers a clear impression of the Governor.
