HEADLINE: Tokyo Calls Announcement Of Aid to Russia 'Premature'

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 3

 BODY:
Showing some irritation toward Washington, Japanese officials said today that it was "inappropriate" and "premature" for President Bush to announce a $24 billion aid package for Russia without having worked out details with Japan.
Several officials who insisted on anonymity said they assumed that Mr. Bush had rushed into the announcement this week because of pressure from critics, including former President Richard M. Nixon and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination. 
 Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and other officials said Japan was prepared to join international efforts to stabilize Russia's currency and help it meet its balance-of-payments deficit. But in a careful qualification, officials also said Japan was not yet prepared to do more.
 
Trans-Pacific Confusion
 "As far as our Government knows, there has been no agreement on this package," said a policy maker involved in aid to Russia, referring to the package announced by Mr. Bush and by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany on Wednesday. "These figures are extremely new to us. It was inappropriate to announce them."
Mr. Miyazawa told reporters that Japan "will of course cooperate" with the effort by the International Monetary Fund to stabilize the ruble, an effort estimated as representing $6 billion of the package. Press reports here say Japan's portion of this may be about $1 billion.
But there was confusion in Tokyo on exactly what else Mr. Bush's package entailed, mirroring what appeared to be confusion and contradictions in Washington. Officials said they did not know what in the announcement was new, and what was a restatement of previous commitments of aid.
An official also said that there was concern about too much being announced on rescheduling Russian debts before Moscow had a chance to show it was prepared for austerity programs.
It was also not clear whether the Bush-Kohl package includes the $2.5 billion in export credits and insurance announced by Tokyo last year -- none of which has been disbursed because arrangements are being negotiated.
In any case, officials here said Tokyo could not consider increasing that $2.5 billion until there was greater progress on resolving a territorial dispute with Moscow.
 
Dispute Over Seized Islands
 Among the major industrialized nations, Japan has always been the most cautious in its attitude toward aid to Russia because of the longstanding dispute over a group of islands north of the Japanese archipelago that were seized by the Soviet Union at the end of world war II.
The dispute has long obstructed conclusion of a peace treaty with the Soviet Union after World War II, and it is holding up a peace treaty with Russia at present.
Indeed, many Japanese officials fear that Boris N. Yeltsin and other Russian leaders may be even less flexible about turning over the Kurile islands than their predecessors. Mr. Yeltsin is to visit Japan in September, and talks in preparation for his visit have not resulted in any progress on the dispute.
According to reports in Washington, the $24 billion figure announced by Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl included perhaps $11 billion in new cash outlays, which Japanese officials reject if the plan involves aid going directly from Japan to Russia, rather than passing through a multilateral agency.
 
Domestic Obstacles
 A senior official said Japan would take a "two-track approach," supporting the I.M.F. and other balance-of-payment efforts, but not promising assistance directly from Japan.
Just as Americans are questioning the value of aiding Russia at a time of a deep recession at home, various officials here said it was politically impossible to make huge outlays for Russia without resolving the territorial matter or convincing Japanese that the money would not be wasted.
A Foreign Ministry official said earlier this week that he did not agree with Mr. Nixon's analysis that the West was in danger of "losing Russia" for lack of aid.
"The basic problem is not economics," but one of political disintegration, he said of Russia. "Massive economic assistance will not change the chaotic situation," he said, adding that "the Russian people should do their best" to solve their own problems.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Republics Qualify for Program
 WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- President Bush certified today that Russia and the former Soviet republics of Armenia, Belarus and Kyrgyzstan had adopted policies of free emigration, making them eligible for United States credit guarantee programs.
The certification moves the states closer to winning most-favored-nation trade status, which allows countries to deal with the United States under the lowest tariffs possible.
The Jackson-Vanik Amendment to the 1974 Trade Act stipulates that countries that impede free emigration are ineligible for favorable trade treatment. Mr. Bush waived the amendment for the Soviet Union in return for a sharp improvement in its emigration record, but the breakup of the country requires that each of the new states be judged on their own.
The United States Export-Import Bank is also working on $2 billion worth of requests from American businesses for help in selling their products to Russia.

HEADLINE: As Italy Nears Vote, Rare Anxiety About Results

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, April 3

 BODY:
As Italians reflect on their nation's destiny two days ahead of major elections and in advance of Europe's move to integration, they do so with a heightened sense of uncertainty.
By European Community accounting, Italy is the world's fifth biggest industrialized economy behind the United States, Japan, Germany and France -- a statistic that illustrates the nation's postwar transformation from ruin to riches. Yet as the land votes Sunday and Monday in an election that will decide whether the Christian Democrats of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti maintain the dominance they have held for four decades, Italians are weighing their choices with unprecedented national soul searching and introspection. 
 For the first time in the memories of most voters, the outcome of the vote is uncertain, and after its headlong gallop to wealth and status, the nation seems to have paused, unsure of where it is being led.
"This is a true crisis, a crisis of identity, of credibility," said Giorgio Bocca, a leading political commentator here, alluding to woes that embrace a political system adrift and under challenge, an economy plagued by home-grown debt and official corruption spreading along with the organized crime of the Mafia and its allies.
 
Many Splinter Parties
 The unease is playing itself out electorally in a wider than usual array of often locally based splinter parties committed to single issues. Among the 54 parties hoping to take advantage of a system of proportional representation are new groups from the wealthier north that have tapped into resentment of northerners who feel their taxes are wasted by being spent on a crime-ridden and corrupt south. Umberto Bossi, leader of the Lombardy League, is widely thought to become a focus of dissent if he wins a seat, as is expected.
The extensive list of candidates -- including contenders like porn star Moanna Pozzi and Alessandra Mussolini, grand-daughter of the Fascist dictator -- poses a challenge to the governing four-party coalition dominated by the Christian Democrats and the Socialists. If the coalition does not win more than 51 percent of the votes cast Sunday and Monday, it will not be able to form a new government.
There is no doubt that the Christian Democrats will still control the single largest bloc after the vote, retaining as they do their strong support in the south and the backing of the Roman Catholic Church. What is less certain is whether they will be able to reconstruct the coalition since their chief allies, the Socialists, appear to be seriously weakened by scandals involving charges of misappriation of funds.
In the last election in 1987, the Christian Democrats won 34 percent of the vote and the Socialists just over 14 percent. Together with votes for the smaller partners in the colation, the Liberals and the Social Democrats, that gave the alliance 57.4 percent of the vote.
But even if the coalition survives, the expected presence of a far more vocal opposition galvanizing around critics like Mr. Bossi will press it to take unpopular economic measures that could threaten its survival.
"There probably won't be an electoral earthquake," said Milan's Socialist Party boss, Vittorio Craxi. "But there's a climate of catastrophe. It does exist."
While as is normal in Italian politics few clear issues have surfaced among the broad slogans and vague promises of change, there are many analysts who say the vote for a new Parliament is likely to be far less of ritualistic exercise than most elections since 1948, when frail coalitions formed around the same core of Christian Democrats and their allies.
Underlying the electoral anxieties are broader concerns dealing with the rigors of European integration. In an election eve interview, Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis contended that these processes were confronting Italy's 57 million people and their sense of national identity with the most momentous challenge since the nation opted to anchor itself in the Western world by rejecting Communism at the polls in 1948.
"It is Europe or nothing," Mr. De Michelis said, adding that the economic regulations around which Europe is being organized demand far tighter economic controls than Italy is used to.
The European Community's charter for integration, he said, "lays down new rules in every sector of human life." He continued, "Typical Italian behavior tries to break the rules."
This is a country whose regions maintain their own sense of history and identity. The north evokes images of suits and cellular phones, automobile and riches in a region, and the architecture recalls the Austro-Hungarian Empire to which part of it belonged. In the south, the cellular phones are confined to the mob and the politicians, and central Government and European Community subsidies have sunk without a bubble in a quagmire of graft in the lands the Bourbons once ran.
"Equity is not the rule," said Prof. Paolo Leon, a left-leaning economic analyst in Rome.
And as those social and economic strains have widened, unchecked in the 1990's by the end of global political constraints, the economist continued in an interview, "the difficulty of unifying these things makes for a fracturing of the political parties."
 
Unwritten Compacts Fading
 For many years, most Italians say, their country has been run by a strange compact between the semi-governing and semi-governed: The government looked the other way, while people bent the rules to pursue their own interests. While governments remained inherently weak, political parties drew strength from various sources -- ideology, pork-barrel and the Roman Catholic Church, some of whose prelates still insist that their followers vote for the Christian Democrats.
But those unwritten compacts are breaking down.
Public services are collapsing. People die untended in hospital corridors. Public transport is an overcrowded chaos. The phones are often erratic.
"People are concerned that they are contributing more to the state than the state is giving them," Professor Leon said.
The sense of "public disillusion," Mr. De Michelis argued, relates far more to the changing world around Italy than to Italy's own problems after the end of the cold war.
 
Ideological Barriers Fall
 Indeed, the Communist ideology had deeper emotive and social roots here than in any other West European country, just as Italy's Fascism was second only to Germany's, building a revulsion to centralized power. Now, Professor Leon said, "the ideological barricades are down."
"There are no longer any dikes to be built, anti-Communist, anti-Fascist," he added.
Mr. De Michelis, in an interview Thursday at a luxury retreat near Venice, said: "In Italy, Communism, anti-Communism was a powerful element of order. But now Communism, anti-Communism has gone. So people express their real feelings, and there's a confused desire for change."
Yet the fiscal mess seems peculiarly home-grown. A huge public debt has built partly on financing ambitious, vote-catching pension schemes and other social benefits.
Now repayment of the debt consumes substantial chunks of state money, crippling the system. Many retirees have to wait years before the state begins to pay out their pensions. And the level of public deficit -- on a per capita basis twice the size of that in the United States -- has somber overtones beyond Italy's borders because, unless it is corrected, it will disqualify Rome from joining the leading European powers as they advance toward economic and monetary union.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Guilio Andreotti of Italy, whose Christian Democrats face a serious challenge in the coming elections. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Proposals;
Brown's Tax Plan Seen As Attack on Status Quo

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
In recent weeks one of New York's Senators in Washington, the Mayor and Finance Commissioner of New York City and a host of economists of all persuasions have joined Gov. Bill Clinton in dismissing Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s tax proposals as a sop to the rich, a crushing blow to the poor and profoundly anti-New York.
So why are so many Brown supporters in New York unfazed by their candidate's plan for a 13 percent flat tax on all income and a 13 percent value-added tax on goods? They could, after all, lose the ability to deduct state and local taxes from their Federal tax burden, the largest and most commonly claimed deduction in the state. And they could end up paying a 13 percent national sales tax on top of the 8.25 percent in state and city sales taxes. 
 The response that many give is that while they may not like, or even understand, all the details of Mr. Brown's tax plan, as long those proposals are part of a more general sweeping-aside of the status quo, they do not much care.
Some seem to be so captivated by the simplicity of the former California Governor's proposals that they have not thought through the implications for their own pocketbooks.
 
Expecting Some Modifications
 "Deductions for state and local taxes?" said Denise Fitzgerald, a Brown volunteer, with a queasiness that conveyed her lack of familiarity with such an option. "I haven't thought that through thoroughly."
Others acknowledge having some concerns, but are convinced that before Mr. Brown's proposals went any further they would be modified to protect those at the bottom of the income scale. And indeed, in recent days, Mr. Brown has indicated as much, conceding that the plan is still very much in flux.
Still other Brown supporters say that although they might end up paying more taxes under the plan, that would be a price worth paying if the result was a President whose ideas on the environment, health care and schools are closer to their own.
Underlying many Brown supporters' explanations of their support for the tax proposals is the sense that what exists now is not working, that they are paying an unfair share of taxes while big corporations and wealthy people get away with murder by hiring sharp-eyed accountants who know how to exploit loopholes.
That view is echoed at the national level. A New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted from March 26 to 29 found that 39 percent of the 1,638 people interviewed across the country said the current tax system was quite fair or reasonably fair, while 59 percent considered it somewhat or quite unfair. The poll had a margin of sampling error of three percentage points.
"It's a game now," said Brendan Meade, an economist who wandered into Mr. Brown's mid-Manhattan headquarters this week to lend a hand. "It's a tax-dodge industry, and that's a total waste of economic resources."
Mr. Meade said what he liked about Mr. Brown's plan was that it would put everyone on an equal footing and eliminate the need to pay accountants large sums of money at tax time. As for losing deductions, he said he was not eligible for many of them anyway.
Frank Carr, a Brown supporter who has been unemployed since January and previously made $18,000 a year, said he was not bothered that lowering the top rate on wealthy taxpayers from 31 percent to 13 percent might let them off the hook. "The rich are already off the hook," he said. "What hook?"
As for the 13 percent value-added tax, Mr. Carr rejected the conclusion of most economists that it would end up as a sales tax on retail goods. To the extent that companies could pass that tax along to consumers, he said, they are already doing so now with the corporate income tax they pay.
New York residents who stand to lose the most from Mr. Brown's proposals are those with the lowest incomes, many economists say.
Officials at the city's Department of Finance say about 1.2 million state residents pay no Federal income tax because their income falls below the value of their exemptions and deductions -- about $15,000 for a family of four. About 500,000 of those have actually been getting checks back from the Government in earned income credit, which amounts to about $1,200 for families with more than one child.
All of those breaks would be wiped out under the current Brown proposal.
The accounting firm Arthur Andersen & Company conducted an analysis for The New York Times of what would happen to seven different New York City taxpayers at various income levels. It found that whether it was a home-owning family of four with an income of $50,000, or a single wage-earner making $80,000 who either rents or owns, or a family with an income of $250,000, everyone would end up paying less in Federal taxes under Mr. Brown's proposal than they do now.
But when the accounting firm analyzed those with incomes of $15,000, it concluded that a single parent with two children paying rent of $450 a month would end up paying more in Federal taxes. When rough estimates for the value-added tax were factored in, Mr. Brown's tax plan became even more biased against those with lower incomes, the firm said.
Gary Davidson is one low-income New Yorker who said he believed he would probably pay more under Mr. Brown's tax plan. But he said he intended to vote for Mr. Brown anyway. A freelance photographer who earned less than $10,000 last year, Mr. Davidson said having a President who redirects a large part of the military budget to domestic programs would ultimately improve his quality of life far more than the financial benefit he would enjoy if the current tax system were maintained.
"The money from one bomber could rebuild a borough," said Mr. Davidson, who lives in the rough-edged East New York section of Brooklyn. He said he volunteered to help the Brown campaign to change the system. "After 12 years of yelling at my TV, it feels great to finally be doing something," he said.

HEADLINE: Momentum Is Building for Afghanistan Peace Plan

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, April 3

 BODY:
A peace plan for Afghanistan has suddenly gained momentum, with United Nations officials predicting that President Najibullah could relinquish his office within the next two weeks.
With food supplies in Kabul, the Afghan capital, all but exhausted, restlessness increasing among dissident Government militia leaders and the patience of neighboring countries wearing thin, the United Nations official charged with finding a route to peace says he expects a cease-fire and a new interim government in Kabul by the end of the month. 
 "We believe peace is at hand," Benon Sevan, the personal representative of the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said in Pakistan on Thursday. "We're on the right track and moving fast, faster than expected. With help, we shall be able to resolve the Afghan conflict now -- this month, not next."
 
The Key Concession
 Last month Mr. Naijbullah announced that he was willing to step down as President, meeting a key demand of the Muslim fundamentalist guerrilla factions that have been fighting Afghanistan's Marxist Government for 13 years. Although Mr. Najibullah left the timing of his resignation vague, the concession opened the way for Mr. Sevan to outline plans for a peaceful transition to free elections.
The United Nations plan called for convening a series of meetings of representatives from across Afghanistan's political and ethnic spectrum, with the notable exception of "prominent personalities" like Mr. Najibullah and the mujahedeen leaders.
The goal of the meetings was to create an interim government by June that would organize national elections.
But a rebellion by Tajik ethnic militia forces in the north and critical food shortages in Kabul have prompted Mr. Sevan to speed up his original timetable, United Nations officials in Islamabad, the Pakistani capital, said today.
"Nobody wants a collapse in Kabul," a United Nations official familiar with Mr. Sevan's discussions said. "Everybody realizes that Kabul is up to its eyeballs in difficulties."
The 13-year war between the Government and the fundamentalist guerrillas known as the mujahedeen has left at least two million Afghans dead and another six million in refugee camps in Pakistan and Iran.
Always a poor country, Afghanistan has reached the point where its economy no longer functions. With the countryside littered with millions of mines, even rudimentary agriculture is a risky business.
Three years have passed since the departure of Soviet forces, which intervened in late 1979. The United States, which had armed and supported the mujahedeen, reached an agreement with the Soviet Union last September to cut off military supplies to both sides by the end of the year.
But the turning point came in January, when Pakistan reversed its position after 13 years of supplying the mujahedeen with weapons and military advice and declared its support for Mr. Sevan's peace proposals. Suddenly deprived of their principal backer, the mujahedeen were compelled to take the United Nations peace proposals seriously.
Under his accelerated timetable, Mr. Sevan is now calling for a single conference of as many as 500 Afghan representatives in Geneva or Vienna by the end of the month. In the meantime, a small group of 12 to 15 Afghans regarded as "neutral" is to travel to Kabul and establish itself as an interim government. Mr. Sevan is hoping that the group will be in Kabul within two weeks, United Nations officials said.
"There is a sense of optimism," one official said, speaking on the condition that he not be identified. "It has to happen soon, probably within two weeks."
Chris Bowers, a BBC correspondent in Kabul, reported today that Mr. Najibullah appeared "confident, relaxed, almost relieved," that the peace process was well under way, even though it means giving up the office he has held since late 1987.
The breakthrough has also heartened Mr. Sevan, who has been shuttling for several years from Islamabad and Kabul to Peshawar, the Pakistani city where many Afghan rebel leaders are based, and to Teheran, which supports guerrillas in Afghanistan's west.
 
Big Problems Remain
 But the intense pace of negotiations has not diminished Mr. Sevan's appreciation of the enormous difficulties his plan still faces, officials familiar with his diplomatic activity said. Foremost among the concerns of the United Nations is how to protect the members of the interim government, and guarantee their authority.
Also undecided is how a cease-fire will be declared and enforced. With United Nations peacekeeping efforts already taxed to the limit in a disintegrating Yugoslavia and in Cambodia, there is little expectation in Islamabad, the site of Mr. Sevan's main office, that the world organization is prepared to commit itself to another vast peacekeeping effort.
In the next week or so, Mr. Sevan is to meet with Mr. Boutros-Ghali, who is expected to announce an Afghan peace conference and the appointment of an interim government.
Ahmed Rashid, a Pakistani journalist who has covered the war from the beginning, said the problems confronting the United Nations peace effort were formidable.
"Things are moving very fast now," Mr. Rashid said. "But anything can happen in Kabul at any moment. There are massive food shortages. There's a danger of food riots. Mazar-i-Sharif in the north is controlled by rebel militias now. The militias are a third force now, and nobody knows which way they will go. And today, five rockets landed in Kabul. It's now or never."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Clinton Relies on Voluntary Guidelines to Protect Environment in Arkansas

SERIES: Clinton as Governor: 12 Years at Arkansas's Helm -- Last of five articles.

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERRYVILLE, Ark., April 3

 BODY:
The Kings River tumbles clear and cold out of northwest Arkansas and flows past forest and pasture land that is home to one of the largest concentrations of farm animals in the world. By the time it reaches Table Rock Lake in Missouri, the stream picks up enough fecal bacteria to make it unfit for swimming. It also accumulates nitrogen and other nutrients that spatter its coves and banks with dark green ooze while smothering the stream bed with chocolate-brown algae.
To Gov. Bill Clinton's supporters, the Kings River, untouched by development, and the state's other bountiful natural resources are evidence of an approach to environmental issues that effectively balances economic goals with the protection of Arkansas's land and water. 
 But to Mr. Clinton's environmental critics, the slime that is slowly engulfing some streams in the state is a result of a hands-off approach to conservation that is sacrificing the state's natural gifts to powerful industrial interests.
Two years ago, when the fecal contamination, odors and unsightly slime caused a public outcry, Mr. Clinton reacted with measures that have become typical of his stewardship of Arkansas's natural resources: He appointed a 27-member committee, made up largely of industry executives and state agency heads, to study the problem. The committee was asked to recommend ways that farmers could be encouraged to change their waste disposal practices voluntarily, obviating the need for stringent regulations. It plans to complete its work in September.
Even environmentalists agree that Mr. Clinton has established himself as a staunch preservationist. During his time in office the state has purchased hundreds of acres of wilderness and streams for preservation.
Mr. Clinton also has a strong record of issuing stiff fines against people who violate rules on hazardous waste disposal. And because Arkansas is so sparsely populated, even with some serious problems the state still has some of the nation's cleanest air and water.
But in his 12 years as Arkansas's chief executive, Mr. Clinton has usually dealt with the problems that do arise -- particularly the environmental threats posed by industry -- not by proposing new rules but through voluntary guidelines and tax incentives intended to encourage businesses to change their polluting ways. Environmental leaders complain that the voluntary programs have delayed solutions, allowing the problems to grow bigger and even more expensive to solve.
 
Guidelines on Clear- Cutting
 That was the case in 1980, when Mr. Clinton set up voluntary rules to protect the state's bountiful forests from destructive clear-cutting, while also trying to protect streams that course through those forests. Clear-cutting can cause damage to waterways, too. So the state's guidelines suggested how close to these streams loggers were allowed to cut, while also setting out voluntary criteria for building roads in the timberlands and offering guidance for using defoliants and other chemicals in the forests.
Executives of Arkansas's $3 billion paper and forest products industry, one of the state's largest manufacturing sectors, warmly endorsed the Governor's tact.
"This approach recognizes the economic importance of forestry in Arkansas," Chris Barneycastle, executive vice president of the Arkansas Forestry Association, said in an interview.
But the state's environmental groups take a different view. They say the voluntary guidelines are routinely ignored on thousands of acres. Miles of streams have been destroyed by silt, they say, or scoured to their bedrock by the heavy flows that follow big storms. The reason, they say, is that timber companies have cut all the trees that normally would absorb the moisture.
Environmental groups also charge that defoliants are used so heavily in some areas that the character of the forests is changing. What had been diverse mixed hardwood and pine forests now hold a single variety of recently planted loblolly pines, the kind favored by paper companies.
"I stomp around the woods across this state, and it's just sad to see how the land is being abused," said Tom McKinney, administrative director of the EcoCenter, an environmental education group in West Fork. "The watersheds are degraded. The top soil is washing off. Wildlife is disappearing. The voluntary rules aren't working."
But State Forester Edwin E. Wadell disagrees, saying the environmentalists' varied claims are exaggerated.
"The program is working very well, as evidenced by the results of our continuous monitoring program," he said.
In 1985 Mr. Clinton also tried the same voluntary approach to prevent farmers and some industrial plants from depleting valuable supplies of underground water in the Delta region in southeastern Arkansas. The Delta is the center of Arkansas's crop-growing industry -- an industry that brings in $1.6 billion a year from rice, cotton, soybeans and other crops -- and farmers were drawing water from the aquifer 20 percent faster than it was being replenished.
The Governor and officials of the Arkansas Soil and Water Conservation Commission developed a program of voluntary rules, coupled with tax credits, to reduce consumption and encourage farmers to build rainwater storage facilities. But J. Randy Young, the commission's executive director, says the program has not worked.
"We have not achieved the level of reduction that it will take to reach a balance between withdrawal and recharge," meaning replenishment of the water, Mr. Young said.
Last year, as a result, Mr. Clinton changed course and proposed a new program of regulations that would be enforced with fines and other penalties. The state government is still working on this proposal.
 
What Approach?
Clinton's Policies Resemble Bush's
 Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledge that in many ways, the Governor's approach to environmental problems resembles the policies developed and promoted by President Bush's chief environmental advisers, especially William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Kenneth L. Smith, Mr. Clinton's special assistant for natural and cultural resources, said Mr. Clinton admires Mr. Reilly. "The Governor likes a lot of the work Bill Reilly has done," Mr. Smith said in an interview.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush have quite a lot in common on environmental matters. Both men favor building coalitions with industry to establish pollution control programs; both generally take a skeptical view of critical assertions from environmental groups.
At the same time, though, both men have made efforts to preserve some areas of unspoiled land. Since 1979, when Mr. Clinton established Arkansas's first land bank, the state has spent more than $10 million to purchase land for new parks and wildlife refuges. The purchases include hundreds of acres of hardwood forests, many miles of wild streams and rivers, 500 acres of unturned prairie east of Fort Smith, and a cave west of Fayetteville that is home to the endangered Ozark cavefish and gray bats.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush also have been given credit for enforcing hazardous waste laws, even while often relying on voluntary compliance rules for other environmental problems.
In Mr. Clinton's first term, which started in 1979, the Arkansas Department of Pollution Control and Ecology did not have authority to fine violators. But in 1983 Mr. Clinton sponsored a law to give the agency power to penalize polluters. By 1991 Arkansas was collecting almost $1 million in fines each year, most of it for infractions of the hazardous waste law -- 10 times the amount collected in 1985.
 
Does It Work?
Officials Differ On the Results
 Mr. Smith, the Governor's special assistant for environmental matters, is just one of many state environmental officials who say Mr. Clinton's voluntary approach works. But he acknowledges that, with 2.35 million people in a state 10 percent larger in area than New York, the challenges here are fewer. Arkansas remains a thinly settled region of green forests, clean streams and clear air.
Most of the state's large manufacturing plants were established after Federal pollution control laws went into effect. So Arkansas is one of a handful of states that meet all Federal air quality standards. About 82 percent of the state's rivers and streams are clean enough for fishing and swimming, one of the highest percentages in the country, Federal figures show.
Business executives here say Mr. Clinton's environmental policies have done nothing to mar Arkansas' slogan as "the Natural State."
"Bill Clinton has been given a bum rap on the environment by those people running against him and those who oppose him here," said Charles D. Martin, executive director of the Arkansas Federation of Water and Air Users, which represents 300 of the state's largest companies on environmental issues.
But Mr. Clinton's opponents in the Democratic primaries and caucuses and some conservation leaders say the Governor's hands-off policies for the biggest and most influential industries have not worked in Arkansas, and will not work if he is elected President.
Barry Haas, a former president of the Audubon Society of Central Arkansas who is an animal-feed dealer in West Little Rock, said of Mr. Clinton: "Everything he has done was based on political pressure. He reacts rather than acts. It's unfortunate because we wait for a fire to burn out of control rather than to snuff it out at its source."
 
Cleaner Water?
Runoff From Farms Poses Problems
 The animal waste pollution, particularly around Fayetteville in northwestern Arkansas, may be a case in point. The national Clean Water Act exempts farmers from Federal regulation, so that leaves the problem up to the states. And even with its voluntary controls, Arkansas is one of a few states, along with Florida, Virginia and Delaware, that have an organized program to control runoff from farms.
Each year Arkansas farmers raise roughly one billion chickens, hogs, turkeys, cows and steers, making this state's $2.7 billion animal agriculture industry the nation's eighth largest. But all those animals produce as much organic waste as 40 million people, and state studies show that the traditional practice of spreading the manure and chicken "litter," as it is called, on fields and pastures has allowed fecal bacteria, nitrates and phosphates to wash into streams, lakes and countless wells.
Since 1983 the state has required its hog producers to get permits and follow modest rules for storing and spreading liquid wastes. And since 1989 technical experts from the state and the food companies have been sent into the field to teach thousands of chicken farmers how to apply manure so that it minimizes runoff that could foul streams or pollute underground water.
Randall Mathis, who directs the Arkansas Department of Pollution Control and Ecology, said environmentalists are exaggerating the contamination problems. Nitrate levels, he says, range from 2 to 6 parts per million in streams that have been tested -- less than the 10 parts per million that makes the water unsafe for drinking, according to Federal guidelines.
Mr. Mathis acknowledges that the fecal coliform levels do occasionally exceed the 200 colonies per 100 milliliters of water that make streams unfit to swim in. Still, he said: "It has not had the impact at this point that everybody is afraid of. We're well ahead of the game."
 
Bacteria in Some Springs
 Some fishermen and residents of affected areas disagree. They say the damage from nitrate pollution is already apparent in streams throughout northwest Arkansas. State water quality reports support that claim; they show that virtually every tributary and major river in the area is marred by bacteria.
A tour of northwestern Arkansas this week demonstrated that even some springs are so contaminated with bacteria that residents no longer feel safe drinking the water. Rivers that teemed with small-mouth bass and other game fish just a few years ago now support only red-horse suckers, a species that feeds on algae that proliferates in the region.
Janet Avenoso, who bought 80 acres along the Kings River 10 years ago because she wanted to live along a pristine wilderness stream, said: "I never had any hesitation about swimming in it before. And now it's plain that it isn't as clean as it was. You look at the banks and the bottom of this river now, and it's covered with scum."
The state's own data show that nitrate levels in the Kings River and other tributaries have increased 50 percent since the 1950's, when the animal agriculture industry in Arkansas was very small. In addition, levels of bacteria in the water have increased sharply, the data show.
And David Mott, a hydrologist for the National Park Service in Harrison, Ark., says the problems are likely to get worse.
"The problem is that in these clear, warm, flowing streams in this warm and humid climate, we have the perfect conditions for algae growth," he said. "We're seeing the effects of putting six tons of manure on pastures when three tons is the maximum amount that should be put down. State studies say the poultry and hog industries are going to double in the next 10 years."
 
Data on Impaired Streams
 Still, farm industry leaders say the voluntary controls can work.
"If the best management practices are utilized, the potential threat to excess nutrients will be greatly diminished," said Archie Schaffer 3d, a spokesman for Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest poultry producer and processor, in Springdale, Ark.
But environmental leaders in the northwestern part of the state point to the most recent state data showing that 450 miles of streams, most of them between Fayetteville and Harrison, continue to be impaired by fecal bacteria.
Mr. Young, the executive director of the Arkansas Soil and Water Conservation Commission, says it is too early to tell whether the voluntary programs will work. The state has placed equipment into streams to monitor levels of contamination to see what effect the program is having, but the conclusions will not be clear for at least three years, he said.
"By 1995 we will have conclusive evidence to know whether this is working or not," Mr. Young said. "If it's not, it's fair to say we would be prepared to take legislative action to protect water quality."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The job market showed only slight improvement in March, with the unemployment rate remaining at a seven-year high of 7.3 percent, the Labor Department reported. Payrolls grew by 19,000, a meager gain that owed much to the fact that pollwatchers and other election workers briefly held jobs related to the Super Tuesday primaries, which came during the survey week. With the economy a main electoral battleground, Democrats were quick to urge a permanent expansion of jobless benefits. The President's chief economic adviser noted that improvements in unemployment generally lag economic growth. [Page 1.] 
 The Fed's Open Market committee unanimously decided in February to give Alan Greenspan the latitude to lower interest rates further, according to minutes just released. [39.]
The United Way's ousted president and two aides transferred more than $1 million a year to other organizations they controlled and spent millions more, the charity's new management said. [1.]
Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 5.2 percent in late March, led by a surge in mini-vans and other light trucks. [39.]
The House Banking Committee's chairman introduced a bill that would help pay for the savings bailout with a levy on healthy S.& L.'s. [39.]
 
Companies
 Since Yamaha introduced the disklavier, a high-tech version of the player piano, in 1988, it has gone from an expensive novelty to a major new form of home entertainment. [39.]
Phillips Petroleum has cut 1,350 U.S. jobs since November, a reduction of about 6 percent in its global work force. [41.]
Japanese investors signed an agreement to buy the Seattle Mariners for slightly more than $100 million. The deal requires the approval of 11 of the 14 team owners in the American League and 7 of the 12 National League owners. [35.]
 
International
A dispute between the U.S. and France over how many passengers U.S. airlines may carry between the countries is threatening to disrupt flights and raise ticket prices. [1.]
The Justice Department announced a policy change to allow greater enforcement of U.S. antitrust laws against foreign companies and cartels that try to limit American exports. [43.]
Chile has become the No. 3 exporter of wine to the U.S., surpassing Germany and trailing only Italy and France. [39.]
 
Markets
The price of oil closed at $20.29 a barrel on the New York Merc, the first close above $20 since Dec. 13. [39.]
A blue-chip rally lifted the Dow industrials to 3,249.11, up 14.99 for the day and 17.67 for the week. The broader market lagged. [42.]
The weaker-than-expected employment report helped to push up prices of Treasury securities and force down interest rates. [42.] The dollar fell against most currencies. Gold closed higher. [48.]
 
Today's Columns
The White House has long said that collecting back taxes was a top priority, but the I.R.S. has been falling behind. In 1991, collections actually declined 5 percent. Your Taxes. [40.]
Researchers at a small Connecticut company have patented an electronic muffler that uses computer-generated "anti-noise" to suppress engine roar. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [40.]

HEADLINE: Congress and White House Shed Perks of Power With Rare Zeal

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
With zeal worthy of an inquisition, Congress and the Bush Administration tried today to outdo each other in abandoning the perquisites of power, burning up privileges enjoyed for decades by Government officials.
The Administration announced that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, shocked at the cost of his personal travel on military aircraft, would take commercial flights for private trips whenever possible. The Milwaukee Journal reported this week that the cost to taxpayers for 11 such trips on military planes was more than $370,000. 
 The new policy went into effect immediately, as Mr. Baker and his entourage took a commercial flight for a long-scheduled private trip, to San Antonio. It was not clear how much taxpayers' money was saved because the State Department said little about the flight, except to note that Mr. Baker seemed to enjoy the experience.
 
$400 for Use of Gym
 At the same time, leaders of the Senate and the House of Representatives announced that they were casting off perquisites believed likely to anger voters in this election year.
"Gift items, mementos and souvenir items" will no longer be offered for sale at a discount by the House and Senate stationery supply stores, the leaders said. Members of Congress will have to pay $400 a year to use their gymnasium or other exercise equipment; in the past there was no charge.
Members of Congress will also have to pay $520 a year if they wish to continue receiving medical care previously provided at no charge by doctors and nurses assigned to the Capitol. Lawmakers can no longer get prescription drugs in the Capitol, but must buy such medications "at fair market value" from commercial pharmacies. The Senate dining room will cut back its hours of operation to save money. And, as previously announced, the House sergeant-at-arms will no longer fix parking tickets for House members.
In the current political atmosphere, no custom is too venerable, no official too lofty, to escape the assault on perquisites. Officials are less interested in the reality of Government perks than in the voters' perception of such privileges, because for politicans the voters' fury is political reality.
Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, and Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, illustrate the current mood. They have introduced bills that would outlaw discounts for members of Congress on health care, meals, flowers, plants, pictures, haircuts or other items. "To counter the claims that we are a privileged class," all such perks must be abolished, Mr. Packwood said recently on the Senate floor.
The House bank, the House post office, the franking privilege, the subway that connects the Capitol with Congressional office buildings, the patronage plums, the special restaurants, barber shops, beauty parlors, parking privileges and medical care for members of Congress -- all have come under intense scrutiny in the last few weeks.
Republican strategists, in the White House and at President Bush's re-election campaign, had hoped to thrash Democrats with evidence of scandal at the House post office and the House bank. But Democrats replied this week with a barrage of their own.
 
Bush Called 'King of Perks'
 The Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, assailed Mr. Bush today as "the king of perks," and denounced Vice President Dan Quayle as "the crown prince of perks in this Government."
Representative Vic Fazio of California, who is chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said of the Republicans: "They can take this as a threat or view this as a warning. We will match every ethical impropriety, perk and privilege they level at Congress with the same and more at the White House or this Administration."
E. Spencer Abraham, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said, "Tom Foley ought to put the House in order before he starts criticizing the President or Vice President or anybody else in the executive branch on the use of perks."
Historians see many precedents for the current orgy of abnegation -- in New England Puritanism, in Midwestern populism, in the nation's strong republican traditions.
 
'A Very Old Debate'
 Paul R. Lucas, a professor of history at Indiana University in Bloomington, said: "This argument over the perks of Congress goes to the heart of a very old debate about what a republic should be like. In the 18th century, colonists and the Founding Fathers believed that the rulers of the new nation must avoid an exorbitant life style and must not behave like decadent European aristocrats."
Washington insisted on being addressed as "Mr. President," not as "Your Highness," and he rejected the sort of pomp and pageantry associated with kings, Mr. Lucas said.
Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican, echoed the Founding Fathers when he said this week, "The public wants a House of Representatives, not a House of Lords."
Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Mr. Baker made 15 private trips on Government aircraft in the last three years. In addition, she said, on seven trips the Secretary combined personal and official business.
Miss Tutwiler said Mr. Baker had paid the Government $38,453 to cover costs of private travel on military planes. That is far less than the cost to the taxpayers, as reckoned by auditors from the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress. The Milwaukee Journal said Thursday that the auditors had put the cost for just 11 of Mr. Baker's private trips at $371,599.
 
Some Possible Exceptions
 Mr. Baker learned of the audit results late last week and issued new instructions to his scheduling staff this week. "In the future, on private travel, book me on commercial flights."
Miss Tutwiler said there could be exceptions to this policy, if there was a terrorist threat to Mr. Baker, for example, or a foreign policy crisis in which he needed "continuous 24-hour secure communications with the President" and the Pentagon.
A spokesman for KSAT television. the ABC affiliate in San Antonio, said Mr. Baker arrived there this afternoon on a Continental Air Lines flight.
Miss Tutwiler said Mr. Baker traveled in economy class today and was accompanied by friends and security agents, but she declined to say how many guards were in his detail.
She said she talked to Mr. Baker by telephone when he made a stop on his trip. "Lots of people are coming up and talking to him and he has gotten notes passed up the aisle" of the plane, she said. She quoted Mr. Baker as saying the experience was "terrific."

HEADLINE: Breadbasket of New York Gets a Russian Appraisal

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
The potato machine had received considerable advance billing.
"That's something that should really make their eyes open up," predicted Joseph Carella, a spokesman for Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx, the world's largest wholesale produce market by volume, which a group of 14 Russian economists and businessmen toured yesterday morning. 
 But when Galina Chernyavskaya, an economist and a leader of the group, stepped into the room where an enormous, clattering machine was sorting and bagging potatoes, all that showed in her eyes was recognition.
"I worked on a machine like this when I worked on a collective farm," she said with a nostalgic smile.
And so it went. The Hunts Point Terminal Produce Cooperative Association may, as its executive administrative director, Myra Gordon, averred, employ 10,000 people and do $1.2 billion in business annually. It may draw on 35 countries and 49 states to supply 22 million people with their avocados, their lettuce, and their Jamaican ugli fruit -- a cross between a tangerine and a grapefruit. But it didn't exactly wow the Russians, who seemed far from happy with the conditions back home but also a little weary of being treated like recently thawed icemen.
When Ms. Gordon gestured to a large vehicle and explained, "This is what we call a flat-bed truck," Dr. Chernyavskaya observed, "The Americans think we know very little, and they explain every little thing."
The group, composed of members and clients of the Institute of World Economy and International Relations, had been in New York City for three weeks, visiting sites like the Commodities Exchange and the New York Stock Exchange and attending seminars at the Henry George School, an adult education institution in Manhattan, said George L. Collins, the school's executive director.
The Hunts Point Terminal Market, which sits on 113 acres of the South Bronx sandwiched between the Bronx and East Rivers, is managed by a cooperative of 69 tenants, or "houses," that import produce by planes, trains and trucks to sell mainly to green grocers, restaurants and hotels from southern Connecticut to Pennsylvania, Ms. Gordon said.
For two hours, Ms. Gordon guided the Russians up one row and down another, pointing out Italian radicchio, Belgian endive, baby squash, and the bottled water some houses keep on hand for their workers. "This is bottled water," she said, laying a hand on one specimen.
Like several others, Vladimir Galanov, an economist who is helping establish a commodities exchange in Moscow, said that none of the fruits or vegetables were new to him. He rarely saw artichokes in Moscow, he said, but he didn't like them anyway. "Nobody asks for them, that's why we don't sell," he said.
While they seemed eager to show they had some sophistication about economics and vegetables, the Russians were quick to discuss horror stories about how the dismal distribution system is driving up recently decontrolled prices in Russia.
 
Our Bronx Comrades
 Leonid Cherepanov, vice president of Krakar Manufacture and Commerce Company, an importer of American products, had a friend photograph him lifting a pineapple. "The price of a pineapple in Moscow is from 350 rubles to 500 rubles," he said. "Five hundred rubles is approximately the middle wages of the people in Russia for a month." He blamed high fuel prices and the tariffs that republics have begun to levy on goods transported across their borders.
But for the most part, the Russians seemed to find more at Hunts Point that was familiar than extraordinary. When, after being questioned, Ms. Gordon confessed that some of the potato trucks were "unfortunately" unloaded by hand, Mr. Cherepanov began to laugh. "Americans and Russians are of the same stuff," Mr. Cherepanov said. "We are very similar."
And while they said they were impressed by the quantity of produce, the Russians were less approving of the quality.
"I'd like to mention that the fruits and vegetables do not have the proper taste," said Dr. Chernyavskaya. "They look beautiful, but they are not so sweet."
Pavel Murashkin, the manager of Krakar, bit into his nectarine to discover a worm, or half a worm. With a look of disgust, he showed the fruit to Mr. Galanov, who burst out laughing.
"Just like in Russia!" Mr. Galanov crowed.

HEADLINE: Beach Club Settles Suit On Race Bias

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, April 3

 BODY:
A New Rochelle beach club that had been sued by the state for excluding blacks agreed today to a series of measures aimed at opening its doors to minority-group members.
In a settlement with the State Attorney General, the Colony Beach Club agreed to advertise in black-oriented newspapers, to set aside $15,000 to compensate people who might have been discriminated against and to suspend for three summers rules requiring that applicants be sponsored by current members. 
 But the club did not admit any wrongdoing and its lawyer attacked the Attorney General, Robert Abrams, for filing the suit and calling a news conference last fall without first meeting with club managers.
Mr. Abrams sued in October after receiving complaints, including one from a white woman who said club officials told her a black baby sitter would have to wear a uniform to enter because club officers "want to know the difference between the members and the helpers."
 
Black Resident Locked Out
 During an undercover investigation, a black New Rochelle resident working with state investigators said she was literally locked out of the club's office.
The case attracted wide attention when it was filed because civil-rights advocates have long cited the racial uniformity of many private recreation operations as evidence that discrimination remains pervasive in New York suburbs. Truly private clubs are permitted to discriminate under the law if they satisfy certain criteria, but operations that are actually open to the public must be open to all groups.
Even while the settlement papers were being filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the club's lawyer asserted that Colony, which is in the Davenport Neck area of New Rochelle on Long Island Sound, does not discriminate. The lawyer, Peter Bienstock, said Mr. Abrams should not have filed the suit and should not have said that Colony did not have any black members.
"It is not true," Mr. Bienstock said, "that there have been no African-American members." He declined to say whether the club currently has any black members.
Saying that the cost of the settlement would be less than the cost of fighting Mr. Abrams, Mr. Bienstock added, "But it is a shame that small entities already hurt by the recession must be subject to these costs to resolve lawsuits with no merit."
 
'Difficult' for Non-Whites
 A spokesman for Mr. Abrams, Leslie Gersing, said an investigation had shown that the club "made it very difficult for people" who were not white. She said investigators are unaware of any black members.
Betty Jean Jackson, the black woman who was locked out of the club office, said the settlement was a small victory for black people in Westchester County. But she said she doubted it would alter deep patterns of discrimination. "It's a way of life," she said. "It has worked for so long."
Mr. Bienstock said the club, a privately owned nonprofit corporation, continues to accept people who "agree to abide by the club rules."
In all, Colony agreed to pay $25,000 in settlements costs. The $15,000 set aside for people who claim to have been discriminated against is to be paid to people who make claims to the Attorney General's office in the next 45 days. Under the settlement, the club also agreed to advise state officials during the next three years of the race of applicants and the action taken on applications.
The club charged up to $1,925 annually for family memberships last summer and had more than 300 members.
Mrs. Jackson said she would file an application to join the Colony Club. "I do intend to join," she said. "That's what it was all about."

HEADLINE: FUTURES;
OPEC Cut Sends Oil Above $20

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The price of oil closed above $20 a barrel yesterday for the first time since Dec. 13.
The market pushed prices up when the International Energy Agency reported that OPEC production had fallen 900,000 barrels a day in March, to 23.5 million barrels a day. The agency also said that global demand had increased 300,000 barrels a day. 
 Some dealers also said they saw signs that economic improvements were raising domestic demand, with the possibility of prices rising further.
"I think the bull move has officially started," said Peter C. Beutel, an oil analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group of Hoboken, N.J.
The price of oil rose 49 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to close at $20.29 a barrel.
 
Libya Issue Cited
 Several other factors played a role. Oil traders are concerned about deteriorating relations between the United Nations and Libya, which produces about 1.4 million barrels a day. The United Nations Security Council has voted to impose economic sanctions, and Libya has responded by threatening to halt oil shipments to unfriendly nations.
With Iraq still out of the oil market, and Kuwaiti production still short of its prewar level, world production is now near capacity. In addition, the United States has had unusually cold early-spring weather, which drives up demand for heating oil. Mr. Beutel said that cold weather at the beginning of the heating season made little difference, because tanks were already full, but that when it came in March, an increase in demand quickly rippled through the system.
To some extent, a rising market creates momentum for itself. "When it broke above $20, a lot of new buying came in," said James R. Fiedler, vice president of the energy division at E.D. & F. Man International. "People were short as long as it didn't go above 20 bucks, and when it did, they bought."
In a futures short sale, a trader bets on lower prices by selling a contract that obligates him to deliver a commodity like oil at a fixed price at afuture date.
Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are scheduled to meet again at the end of this month to discuss further cuts in output. According to the International Energy Agency, Saudi Arabia cut its exports by 300,000 barrels a day in February, to about 8.2 million barrels a day. Iran, the United Arab Emirates, Nigeria, Libya and Venezuela also cut production.

Hog Prices Gain Again
 By The Associated Press
Hog futures prices continued to rebound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Strong demand for pork countered news of an expanding American hog herd.
Precious metals, meanwhile, finished mixed in dull trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Gold for April delivery rose 30 cents, to $341.20 an ounce, and the April silver contract rose 0.2 cent, to $4.076 an ounce.
In Chicago, hogs for April delivery rose 0.85 cent, to 41.87 cents a pound. The June contract surged 1.23 cents, to 47.90 cents a pound, for a cumulative gain of 3.65 cents in four days.
May frozen pork bellies rose 0.38 cent, to 35.60 cents a pound. April live cattle rose 0.12 cent, to 79.37 cents a pound, and April feeder cattle rose 0.13 cent, to 79.95 cents a pound.
On Monday, hog futures fell as much as 1.5 cents, the most allowed in a day, after the Agriculture Department reported a larger-than-expected expansion of the hog herd. But prices have climbed back steadily since then, partly reflecting strong wholesale demand for ham and the cuts of pork used for sausage.
The demand for hams by meat processors usually peaks about four weeks before Easter, said Dale Durchholz, livestock analyst with Agri-Visor Services Inc. During the monthlong interval before the holiday, the hams are cured and packaged for the retail trade. But this year, ham demand remains strong two weeks before the Easter weekend. Mr. Durchholz said wholesale prices for 17-to-20-pound hams rose this week to as much as 72 cents a pound, from a high last week of 68 cents.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for May delivery rose 4 1/2 cents to settle at $3.67 1/4 a bushel. Corn for May delivery rose 1 cent, to $2.60 1/4 a bushel. May oats climbed 1 1/4 cents, to $1.42 1/2 a bushel, and May soybeans rose 3/4 cent, to $5.76 1/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New York;
Upstate, Neither Clinton Nor Brown Stir Passions

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, April 3

 BODY:
Four years ago, the key to Michael S. Dukakis's triumph in the New York primary lay in upstate cities like this.
Aided by a large black vote, the Rev. Jesse Jackson carried New York City, despite hostility toward him among many Jewish voters. But while attention was focused there, Mr. Dukakis ran strongly in the suburbs and amassed a huge majority upstate. 
 This year, neither of the remaining candidates seems to have developed any real momentum in the vast expanse north of the Westchester County line, which in most years casts slightly more than a quarter of the statewide Democratic primary vote.
A poll taken on Wednesday in Erie County, which includes Buffalo, showed Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas leading former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California by a narrow margin, but with 53 percent undecided -- the largest such figure that the poll-taker, Prof. Gerald M. Goldhaber of the State University at Buffalo, has ever encountered this late in a campaign.
"What it says is that people can't stand either candidate," Professor Goldhaber commented. "That's not too surprising, since all they've seen is one candidate attacking the other and reporters attacking both."
Laurence J. Kirwan of Rochester, a former state Democratic chairman, said that "thousands of people you'd have hoped to have energized and involved in this campaign just aren't there, because it's a failure."
"There's great disillusionment with a process that brings us a Brown and a Clinton as the choice," he said. "People have no confidence that that's the best the Democratic Party has to offer, and they feel let down. Brown's an anybody-but-Clinton candidate, and Clinton is rapidly dissipating all the big advantages he started with. Didn't inhale marijuana! If my son told me that, I'd tell him, 'Come on, you've got to get serious.' "
 
Sticking With Harkin
 Upstate New York consists, of course, mostly of farms and small towns. Over all, it is heavily Republican. But in the cities strung along the main transportation route -- the Erie Canal followed it first, then the New York Central Railroad, now the Thruway -- there are large numbers of factory workers and others who have traditionally voted Democratic.
Yet at the Xerox and Eastman Kodak plants here, the remaining steel mills in Buffalo, the General Electric and Carrier air-conditioning factories in Syracuse, union officials see little inclination to vote on Tuesday.
Jim Duncan, the political officer for the United Automobile Workers in the area, foresees a record low turnout. In an effort to gain some sort of leverage at the Democratic National Convention, especially over the platform, he is urging members in Western New York to vote for the slates of delegates pledged to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who pulled out weeks ago.
Asked why he was not backing Mr. Brown, who was supported by some U.A.W. locals in Michigan in the primary there last month, Mr. Duncan replied, "I don't think they have the wherewithal to make a good showing." With two mailings to 11,000 members in three Congressional districts, he said, "I think we can do rather well for the Harkin slates around here."
If the U.A.W. strategy seems improbable, The Buffalo News has felt compelled to advocate something even more far-fetched. After commenting in an editorial the other day that Mr. Brown is "not qualified to be President," the newspaper urged its readers to cast "a well-placed protest vote" against "the Clinton juggernaut" to keep the race open. Such a vote would have to go to Mr. Brown, it said, because only he seemed likely to get the 15 percent needed to gain delegates.
 
Hierarchy Backing Clinton
 Across the state in Albany, Mayor Thomas Whalen 3d, whose Democratic organization retains vestiges of machine power, is also supporting Mr. Brown, reportedly in the hope that a brokered convention would lead to the selection of someone other than the two active candidates as the party's nominee.
But almost everyone else in the party hierarchy is backing Mr. Clinton, and his list of supporters has continued to grow despite his troubles with tabloids and television questioners in New York City. On Thursday, for instance, he won the endorsement of Rochester's Mayor, Thomas P. Ryan Jr.
Mr. Brown has drawn large, enthusiastic crowds on college campuses in Rochester and Buffalo, and his backers in Ithaca, site of Cornell University, say they have registered several thousand new voters in recent days.
Apparently sensing that the situation remains fluid, the former Governor plans a swing through the area this weekend, starting Saturday in Syracuse, and Mr. Clinton is also also visiting upstate cities this weekend.
Perhaps Mr. Clinton's biggest asset in Buffalo, the state's second-largest city, is Dennis Gorski, the Erie County Executive. He said Mr. Clinton would carry the county "because he comes from the middle of the political spectrum, like most people here, and because our organization will get out the vote for him."
 
Playing Economic Fears
 Attacking Mr. Brown as "a man who finds out wherever he goes what people fear and then plays on it," Mr. Gorski said that Mr. Brown's proposed 13 percent value-added tax would cripple Buffalo's economy by making goods so expensive that hordes of people would no longer cross the Peace Bridge from Canada to go shopping.
But Mr. Gorski conceded that Mr. Clinton's lead had been eroded by "the cumulative effect of the character assassination he's been subject to, which is recirculated from the tabloids to the television and from there through the bowling alleys and coffee shops and bars and living rooms."
Professor Goldhaber, the poll-taker, said Mr. Clinton had been hurt by the response of his wife, Hillary, to charges that her legal career had enmeshed her husband in conflicts of interest. She said angrily that she supposed she could have stayed home and baked cookies, and that, Professor Goldhaber commented, "sent a chill through all the communities around here where the women car-pool, cheer for Little Leaguers and hold bake sales."
In a sense, Buffalo is the eastern terminus of the Rust Belt, and there is economic dislocation there and in other upstate cities. But Joseph Crangle, who spent 23 years as the Erie County Democratic leader, retiring in 1988, said that the state budget and its estimated $1.8 billion in tax and fee increases could prove to be the most important economic issue.
"The budget inevitably spills over into anti-government feeling," Mr. Crangle said, "and that could help Brown a bit. Fair or not, Clinton has become the Establishment candidate. He's almost an incumbent in this race."

He and security officers were surrounded by students yesterday as he arrived for a campaign visit to Hendricks Chapel at Syracuse University. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. and France Fight Over Piece of Airline Market

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
Just as the summer season for trans-Atlantic travel begins, a dispute between the United States and France over how many passengers United States airlines may carry between the two countries is threatening to disrupt flights and increase ticket prices.
After the latest round of negotiations in Washington ended fruitlessly on Tuesday, France warned that it intended to act unilaterally to restrict the capacity of the American carriers, which have made strong gains recently, perhaps as early as this weekend. 
 But by this evening it was uncertain what steps, if any, the French Government would take immediately. It appears that the uncertainty might last for a few days, if not longer, as the brinkmanship that typifies such negotiations takes over.
The dispute could have implications for Americans flying to other countries as well. The Bush Administration is reluctant to accede to the French demand out of fears that Germany, Japan or other nations might follow suit. Eventually, airline and Administration officials warned, the dispute may severely disrupt air travel.
France wants the eight American carriers that fly to France to cut their available seats by 500,000, or nearly 20 percent, in the coming six months. Then, Air France, which is heavily subsidized by the French Government, would face less pressure to compete for passengers by cutting fares. Passengers from both nations would end up paying higher fares regardless of which airline they chose.
Although the United States has been pressing its trading partners for more free trade in airline flights, this dispute shows how far from a free market the situation remains. Although domestic air travel was deregulated in the 1970's, for international routes the airlines and the governments in effect negotiate cartel-like marketing agreements that vary in the kinds of restrictions they impose.
The dispute comes as travel between the two countries is recovering strongly from the recession -- mainly to the benefit of the United States airlines, which have captured at least two-thirds of the market.
Most of the eight American carriers that fly to France resubmitted their schedules today, ignoring the French demand. Some made modest reductions, but without eliminating anything near the 20 percent, 500,000-seat cut that the French have demanded, representatives of several airlines said.
"We are planning to fly our schedules as announced," said a spokewoman for United Airlines, Lynn Martenstein. "We remain confident that the U.S. Government will be able to resolve outstanding issues with the French Government."
On Tuesday, Transportation Secretary Andrew Card signaled a tough negotiating stand in a speech before a large gathering of aviation industry executives in Washington. He said he had spoken to his French counterpart, Paul Quiles, and had insisted that the Americans be allowed to fly their full schedules.
"Let me be clear about this issue: the United States places a very high value on its bilateral agreements," Mr. Card said, referring to a 1990 agreement between the two countries. "We respect those agreements, and we honor them faithfully. And we do expect the same from our trading partners."
Laurent Aublin, the spokesman for the French Embassy, replied that in the French view the 1990 agreement, which would have accommodated the increase in service sought by the Americans, was superseded by the original 1946 aviation treaty between the two nations and could be revised at will.
In any event, he said, the French are willing to allow an increase in seats, but not as many as the Americans have sought.
The Americans hope to sell 2.7 million tickets between the two countries for April through October flights, better than a 40 percent increase from the 1.9 million tickets sold in 1991. The French have insisted that the total come to no more than 2.2 million seats this summer.
 
Many Different Air Fares
 Thousands of different air fares are in effect between various American and French airports, depending on when a flight is, how far in advance it is reserved, special promotions and other factors, but as one airline executive said, if the number of seats is cut back, the lowest fares will be the ones to go.
The United States carriers flying to France are American, Continental, Delta Air Lines, Northwest, Tower Airlines, Trans World Airlines, United Airlines and USAir. None are heavily dependent on flights to France, but several are planning to add to their service between the two countries this month.
For example, United Airlines will begin using a Boeing 747 instead of a smaller plane from Washington's Dulles International Airport on Saturday, and will inaugurate nonstop 767 service from San Francisco on Sunday.
If France turns down increases in service, Washington can retaliate immediately by restricting Air France flights to the United States.
The only reductions that the United States is willing to offer would be those proposed voluntarily by American airlines. During the negotiations, the airlines volunteered to cut between 100,000 and 150,000 seats, but the French rejected the offer.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

God and Misery
Popular wisdom has it that the tougher the economic times, the more people go to church. Like the old saying about atheists in foxholes, the reasoning goes that people with holes in their pockets are also drawn to the Lord. 
 But a new report by the Princeton Religion Research Center, an affiliate of the Gallup Poll, challenges that assumption. "The historical record shows very minor swings, if any, in both church attendance and membership when the economy either goes boom or bust," the report said.
The research center analyzed statistics gathered over the last 40 years and through the nine recessions that occurred in that period. It found that the difference in church attendance between the recession and the year preceding it never has exceeded 2 percentage points.
Through it all, church attendance -- that is, people who say they attended at least once in the last seven days -- has hovered about 40 percent. In 1991, 42 percent of those polled said they were weekly churchgoers, compared with 40 percent in 1990. But the upswing in churchgoing in the 1991 recession was only the second time more people reported going to a church in an economic downturn. On three past occasions there was a slight decline in membership, and four times it held steady.
As for those church officials hoping that an economic recovery will bring more people to church, the results are no more encouraging. In six of the eight recoveries, no change was registered; once the numbers went up slightly and once they went down. The margin of sampling error for the surveys was plus or minus three percentage points.
 
War of Words
 Bishop John S. Spong, the head of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, attracted attention on Tuesday when he assailed the policies of the Roman Catholic Church with regard to women and homosexuals.
His language was strong, using words like prejudiced, hypocritical and repressive. The reaction that followed was also strong.
"Your hostility against the Catholic Church has grown apace until today it seems obsessive," Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick, the Catholic Archbishop of Newark, wrote to Bishop Spong in response. "I truly regret that you have decided to move in the direction of such personal attacks on the Catholic Church by making a parody of our teaching and a caricature of our theology."
Bishop Spong's criticism of the church appeared in the April edition of the Virginia Quarterly Review, a scholarly journal. In it, he argues that the differences between the Episcopal and Catholic Churches are so great that their long-established dialogue should cease.
His call was rejected by Catholic Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee and Episcopal Bishop Theodore Eastman of Maryland, who head the ecumenical committees of their churches in the United States. Bishop Eastman said, "We would not want to close the door to what the Holy Spirit may do for both churches through these continuing dialogues."
 
Primate Confusion
 The nave of a church (the main part of the building) has nothing to do with a knave (a rascal). A missal (prayer book) has nothing to do with a missile.
But a primate, whether in the jungle or in the church, are spelled the same and open to confusion. Take the case of Archbishop Michael Peers, primate of the Anglican Church of Canada. Not long ago, he received a request for information from the Wisconsin Regional Primate Research Center, which was gathering information for an "International Directory of Primatology."
The Archbishop's secretary, the Rev. Michael Ingham, took the letter in stride. He responded: "I think the primates in your study are perhaps a different species. While it is true that our primate occasionally enjoys bananas, I have never seen him walk with his knuckles on the ground or scratch himself publicly under the armpits."
An apology came swiftly from Dr. John Hearns of the primate research center. "We have strayed on this occasion from the arboreal to the spiritual," he wrote.
 
Rabbi Reissues
 Three classic works by American rabbis -- one Reform, one Conservative and one Orthodox -- have been reissued in new editions in recent months. "9 1/2 Mystics," Herbert Weiner's 1971 exploration of the spiritual tradition of Judaism has been reissued by Collier Books, with a new chapter on Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the mystical leader of the Lubavitch Hasidim.
"Judaism," an introduction to the faith by Arthur Hertzberg, first issued in 1961, has been brought back by Simon & Schuster with new information on such topics as women's rights, homosexuality and Arabs and Jews.
And Doubleday has published Joseph B. Soloveitchik's "The Lonely Man of Faith," a personal meditation on faith and loneliness that first appeared in the scholarly journal "Tradition" in 1965. Rabbi Soloveitchik's essay has never been in book form before but was photocopied and has been circulated for more than 25 years.
