HEADLINE: New York Area Shows Job Gain

 BODY:
New York and New Jersey both showed improvements in their employment pictures during March, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.
In New York, the unemployment rate dropped to 8 percent in March from 8.9 percent in February, while in New Jersey the rate went to 7.1 percent from 7.6 percent. 
 "I think we have to take it as good news," said Prof. Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. But, he cautioned: "It may be that we had just hit bottom. You have to see more than one month of this to draw any conclusions."
He speculated that the drop could most likely be attributed to unemployed workers who decided to stop looking and take lesser jobs than they had, a major turnaround in financial services, and the simple fact that the employment picture had gotten so bad there was no way to go but up.
There were no figures available for Connecticut. Unemployment in Massachusetts, which has been battered by sharp reductions in defense, rose a sharply to 9.1 percent from 7.5 percent.
"The New England economy is much worse than New York's," Professor Moss said.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Stays at 7.3%, With Scant Job Market Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The job market showed only slight improvement in March, with the nation's unemployment rate remaining at a seven-year high of 7.3 percent, according to Labor Department figures.
Payrolls grew by 19,000, a meager gain that owed much to the fact that many poll watchers and other election workers briefly held jobs related to the Super Tuesday primaries, which came during the survey week. 
 With the economy a main electoral battleground and employment the most politically sensitive indicator for incumbents, Democrats were quick to spot political ammunition and to urge a permanent expansion of jobless benefits.
 
Bad News, Democrat Says
 "This morning's report cannot be read as good news for the millions of jobless Americans who read and took hope from the assertions that a recovery has begun," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, head of the Joint Economic Committee. "Employers remain cautious about hiring, and the labor market is showing little sign of life."
At the White House, Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, gave the kind of circumspect appraisal he has in the past. "While sales and production have been improving," he observed, "improvements in unemployment generally lag behind. Stronger economic growth and job creation is the Administration's top priority."
The reaction of securities markets initially appeared to be one of disappointment, with bonds rising and stocks falling. Later, however, the stock market rallied, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining almost 15 points. This may have reflected the sentiment of more optimistic analysts, who found the March data quite consistent with expectations for steady, if subdued, recovery.
"I see an emerging momentum of the economy that is still well maintained," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, dismissing month-to-month fluctuations in the statistics. "The dynamics of a self-sustaining recovery are in place."
In keeping with the halting recovery that most economists believe is now under way, today's report included bits of good and bad news and a lot that was inconclusive.
There was no significant movement in the jobless rate for any of the main demographic groups, the length of both the average workweek and of jobless spells held steady and there was no appreciable change in the Labor Department's quarterly tabulation of Americans who have given up looking for a job because they think they would be unable to find one.
"It's basically a no-change report," declared Walter M. Cadette, an economist at J. P. Morgan & Company, noting that while there has been little job gain from recent surges in retail sales it is also true that job erosion in general has ended and that the labor force has begun to grow again.
Among the 11 biggest industrial states, three showed meaningful changes in their jobless rates. The rate for New York, which conducts primary elections Tuesday, fell to 8 percent from 8.9, while Illinois saw its rate fall to 7.8 percent from 8.5.
 
Kennedy Demands Action
 The rate for Massachusetts jumped 1.6 points, to 9.1 percent, causing Senator Edward M. Kennedy to complain that his state's economy "is far from out of the woods" and calling on Congress, the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve to "do more to stop the recession and insure that a vigorous recovery actually begins."
William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee he found it "noteworthy" that the 303,000 rise in the labor force last month was the fourth in a row, bringing the total since November to 1.2 million.
Other analysts said this probably reflected increased optimism about the prospect of obtaining jobs, with about half the 1.2 million having done so.
Typically, such optimism causes the jobless rate to rise until recovery is well under way but in March the economy generated just enough jobs, 305,000 as measured by the department's survey of households, to absorb them all.
The ranks of the jobless thus edged down to 9,242,000 from 9,244,000.
But economists disagreed about how to interpret the household survey's 305,000 job gain, with some dismissing it as statistical quirk in light of a payroll gain of only 19,000 while others regarded it as solid evidence of improvement.
Taking the latter view, Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Chemical Bank, said that the household survey showed a 620,000-job gain since last July and, whatever its deficiencies, has proved a reliable predictor in previous business recoveries. He said these numbers, which included an 882,000 March surge without seasonal adjustment, were "so strong they shouldn't be ignored."

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Growing Backlog of Delinquencies

BYLINE: By John H. Cushman Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Though the White House has long said that collecting back taxes is a top priority, the Internal Revenue Service has been falling farther and farther behind. In 1991, collections actually declined by 5 percent, to $24.3 billion from $25.5 billion.
What's going wrong? "As we chat about this at the G.A.O., we feel this is one of the mysteries of the Government," said Jennie S. Stathis, director of tax policy for the General Accounting Office, a Congressional auditing agency. 
 One reason for the growing backlog is that Congress extended the statute of limitations on tax-dodging from 6 years to 10 years, even though older debts are harder to collect. That technicality accounts for $6 billion of the $14 billion increase in accounts receivable in the 1991 fiscal year.
The lingering recession may be another reason that many people and companies are not paying their taxes. Of the $111 billion owed, $27 billion is tied up in insolvencies and bankruptcies (which were up 24 percent last year). Another $28 billion cannot be paid because of personal hardships.
But the question that most troubled members of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee at a hearing this week was why Congress saw no quick results after providing $55 million to hire 1,000 new tax collectors in 1991.
The General Accounting Office contends that the I.R.S. used some of that money to pay for unbudgeted cost increases, like higher rent for its offices and a pay rise. That would mean it hired fewer collectors than Congress had intended. But the I.R.S. said that it had indeed hired the tax collectors. It has taken some time to bring them up to speed, but the results are now beginning to appear, I.R.S. officials said. In the first five months of fiscal 1992, through February, collections on delinquent accounts increased by an average of $55 million a month above a year earlier, the service said.
That is progress. But Shirley D. Peterson, the new I.R.S. Commissioner, demurred when asked whether she would promise, as did her predecessor, Fred T. Goldberg Jr., to halt the backlog's growth. To the extent that the agency becomes more efficient in identifying deadbeats, like the estimated six million people who don't bother to file a return at all, the backlog will rise, she said.
 
I.R.S. Help Line Gets Mixed Review
 The General Accounting Office has offered a mixed review of the performance of the Internal Revenue Service's telephone help line, a toll-free service for befuddled taxpayers. (The "800" numbers are listed in the tax instructions.)
The good news is that the people answering taxpayers' queries are more likely than they used to be to give right answers. There is now about an 87 percent chance that questions will be answered correctly, up from about 81 percent last year and 2 points above the target set for this year.
On the other hand, the chances of getting connected to a helpful person have declined sharply, because a surge of users is tying up the lines.
Only about 27 percent of the attempted calls are being answered this year, compared with 42 percent last year, the G.A.O. said. "As far as we know, this is an all-time low," the agency reported.
About 10 million calls had been answered through March 7, at least 260,000 above last year's pace. But the phones have rung 13 million times more than last year; millions of callers evidently got a busy signal or they hung up while on hold.
This week, Senator Pete V. Domenici's Albuquerque office called the line 70 times at all hours of the day over a three-day period, and 57 times got a busy signal, getting through only 18 percent of the time. In 1990, the staff of the New Mexico Republican got through 3 times out of 35, or 9 percent, and in 1991, 23 times out of 35, or 65 percent.
 
An S.& L. Wrinkle On Retirement Accounts
 Failed savings and loans often pay off high-yielding certificates of deposit designated as individual retirement accounts by sending checks to the depositors. If that happens, the certificates' owners must be careful to reinvest the money within 60 days. If not put in a new I.R.A., the money will be taxed as income, and there will be a 10 percent penalty to boot. That is true even if the payment comes from the failed institution's receiver or from a deposit insurance fund.
The United States Tax Court recently rejected an argument by a Maryland couple who contended that they did not receive a taxable distribution when their $10,659 savings certificate was involuntarily cashed out by First Maryland Savings and Loan Inc. when it failed in 1986.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls After Bad News On the Unemployment Rate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most currencies yesterday after the release of disappointing data showing that the nation's jobless rate held at a seven-year high in March.
Gold prices closed higher. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $341.20 a troy ounce, up 30 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank quoted gold at a late bid price of $340.70, up 40 cents. 
 The dollar opened the New York session lower in anticipation that the unemployment report would be weak, said Kevin Logan, chief economist of the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Investors were looking for poor jobless figures because economic data released earlier this week had suggested that the recovery was cooling.
"The dollar held its own for a while," Mr. Logan said. "Then, after an hour or so, the buyers weren't there, and the dollar gradually eroded."
The Labor Department said the unemployment rate was 7.3 percent in March, unchanged from February. The number of jobless people was 9.2 million, 2.5 million more than at the start of the recession in July 1990.
As the dollar's decline gained momentum, the currency broke out of a tight trading range for the first time since mid-February, Mr. Logan said.
He predicted that the dollar would remain weak in the near term, amid signs that the economy is not as strong as expected. "For the dollar to move upward, there needs to be a sense in the market there is stable, sustained growth taking place," Mr. Logan said.
The dollar is faring somewhat better against the yen as the weakened economy in Japan and declining interest rates there have scared away investors.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 133.57 yen, from 134.77 on Thursday. In London, it declined further, to 133.33 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 133.40 yen, down from 133.70 yen on Thursday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bonds Rally in Reaction to Jobs Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An employment report that was generally weaker than anticipated helped to push up prices of Treasury securities and force down interest rates yesterday.
The report, which showed that non-farm payrolls expanded by just 19,000 in March, came a day after the Federal Reserve Board said that important monetary aggregates contracted in the week that ended March 23. Most analysts had forecast an increase of about 50,000 jobs in March. 
 Traders said the employment statistics and the downturn in money growth were allowing market participants to become more comfortable with the notion, widespread among analysts, that recovery would be distinctly less robust than in most rebounds.
 
Sluggish Numbers
 "If this were a traditional recovery, we would be seeing employment rising by 200,000 to 250,000 a month," another trader said. "But right now we are struggling to see positive numbers."
In addition to the softer-than-expected employment data, a report yesterday said that March car sales were at a sluggish seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.2 million.
"Car sales were fairly poor in March," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., "and that means retail sales will probably be flat to down."
Many of yesterday's price gains were recorded among short-term securities, suggesting that market participants were now beginning to think that the Fed might again ease monetary policy. Indeed, minutes released yesterday from the February meeting of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee reinforced the notion that the central bank could well act to lower interest rates.
At the February meeting, the committee voted to lean toward easing. The group met again this week, and most analysts said the committee was likely to have chosen to keep the bias toward easing in place.
 
The Fed's Options
 "What we are seeing is a subtle shift in emphasis that suggests the Fed once again has the option of considering another cut in short-term rates," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds.
"Against the backdrop of weakness in money, there is good reason to think the Fed will be more inclined to ease," he said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10114/32 , up 3/8, to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Thursday and 7.94 percent on March 27.
Among outstanding Treasury notes, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/4, up 11/32 , to yield 7.38 percent. And the 5 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 3/4, up 1/4 point, to yield 5.34 percent.
In the when-issued market, the new seven-year Treasury notes to be auctioned on Wednesday were offered at a price to yield 7.10 percent.
 
Bill Rates Decline
 Short-term Treasury bill rates fell sharply. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.95 percent late yesterday, down 5 basis points, or five one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 6 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.02 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 13 basis points, to 4.19 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Texaco Capital Inc., a subsidiary of Texaco Inc., offered $200 million worth of 40-year noncallable bonds through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 8 5/8 percent bonds were priced at $99.50 to yield 8.669 percent, 80 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.

HEADLINE: Fed Policy Panel Favored Easing if Needed

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee unanimously decided in February to give Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, the latitude to lower interest rates further if the economy continued to languish.
The minutes of the February meeting of the Open Market Committee were released today. Minutes of previous meetings showed that the 12 members of the committee, while concerned about the economy's sluggishness, were divided on whether to ease monetary policy. 
 Traditionally, a unanimous decision has empowered the chairman to cut rates by up to one-half of 1 percent without consulting the committee. But Fed officials say Mr. Greenspan is generally loath to adjust rates by even one-quarter of 1 percent without consulting committee members.
Economists who follow the Fed say the central bank has not lowered rates since the Feb. 4-5 meeting because the economy has shown some signs of recovery since then. The last time the Fed lowered rates was Dec. 20, when it cut the discount rate to 3 1/2 percent from 4 1/2 percent.
The report noted that during discussions at the meeting many members expressed fears that the effects of earlier moves to ease "could prove to be less stimulative than anticipated." It added that "the persistence of a weak economy might well have especially severe consequences, and, in the view of some members, signs of such an outcome would call for prompt action."
The Open Market Committee met again on Tuesday, but the minutes of that meeting will not be released until May 22. Many experts speculate that the Fed again adopted a bias toward easing that would empower Mr. Greenspan to lower rates if the signs of recovery sputtered.
The February minutes say the members were in favor of "some bias" toward easing, while the minutes of the December meeting, shortly before rates were lowered, spoke of a "marked bias" toward easing.
 
Mixed Signals
 Fed officials have been encouraged by recent increases in retail sales and housing construction. But some economists said reports released today, showing the jobless rate unchanged at 7.3 percent and employment up only slightly, could be signs that the incipient recovery was faltering.
The Open Market Committee comprises the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board and five presidents of Federal Reserve districts.
According to the February minutes, "The members generally agreed that enough monetary stimulus probably had been implemented to foster the desired upturn in economic activity without further policy moves." But the report added that the outlook was so uncertain that the committee "needed to remain alert to the possibility of developments that might require additional easing."
In appearances before Congressional committees, Mr. Greenspan often reiterated these views, saying he thought that enough monetary easing was in the pipeline to bring about a recovery, but adding that additional insurance, in the form of lower rates, might be warranted if the economy trailed off.
 
Careful Wording
 The report said that many of those leaning toward easing stated that "there should not be an unusually strong presumption that any easing would in fact be implemented" between the February meeting and the meeting on Tuesday.
"The committee should ease only in response to cumulating evidence that economic activity was not picking up or that monetary growth was falling appreciably short of expectations," the report said.
In the discussions, a few members argued against a bias toward easing, saying more emphasis needed to be put on the inflationary risks of overreacting to economic weakness. But when the vote came, these members joined the unanimous decision, apparently because their views were not so strong that they thought it was worth dissenting.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Rose In Period

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 3

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 5.2 percent in late March, led by a strong buying surge of mini-vans, pickups and other light trucks.
Analysts remained divided whether the United States automotive market had turned for the better and was gaining strength. Financial analysts tended toward caution, while automotive executives expressed optimism. 
 "We've had indications that the market is reviving, but we've had our fill of indications," said Tom Pappert, vice president of sales for the Chrysler Corporation. "These are results, and we'll take continued sales improvement, big or small."
 
Sluggish a Year Ago
 David Bank, general manager of Bloom Pontiac in Long Island City, Queens, said: "Traffic is still slow. Sales are up for January, February and March but that's not a fair comparison" with last year's unusually sluggish sales. "Sales aren't up as much as we'd like," he added.
Sales of domestically built cars fell 1.2 percent, to 229,317, compared with a year ago, while light-truck sales advanced 16.7 percent, to 152,234, in the March 21-31 period. Vehicle sales totaled 381,551. The seasonally adjusted annual rate for car sales in late March was 6.2 million, compared with 5.8 million in mid-March and 6.3 million during the corresponding period last year.
For all of March, vehicle sales of all types, imported and domestic, were up 2.5 percent, to 1,104,807. The total was made up of car sales of 723,691, a drop of 1.7 percent, and light-truck sales of 381,116, an increase of 11.5 percent. The seasonally adjusted annual rate for domestic car sales for the month was six million, roughly in line with the trend of the last few months.
 
Production to Increase
 Makers of domestic cars, which consist of the Big Three as well as several Japanese auto makers, are betting that the automotive market will continue to gain strength. Production of cars during the second quarter is scheduled to rise 9 percent over last year's level, to 1,455,788; production of light trucks is scheduled to rise 13.6 percent, to 920,190.
The General Motors Corporation sold 258,313 cars in March, imported and domestic, an increase of 1.2 percent over a year ago. The Ford Motor Company sold 148,409 cars, a drop of five-tenths of a percent, and Chrysler sold 55,727 cars, almost exactly equal with last year's total.
The G.M. Oldsmobile division reported a 9 percent increase in vehicle sales, partly from the popularity of the new Achieva mid-sized model.
The Honda Motor Company sold 59,458 cars in March, a drop of 20.7 percent from a year ago; the Toyota Motor Corporation sold 73,036 cars, an increase of 9.3 percent, and the Nissan Motor Corporation sold 29,446, a drop of 9.3 percent from a year ago. The Mazda Motor Corporation sold 30,732 cars, a drop of 4.8 percent.
Toyota said its Lexus luxury division sold nearly twice as many cars during the first quarter of this year as the corresponding period a year ago.
In the light-truck segment, G.M. sold 127,062 units, imported and domestic, for the month, an increase of nine-tenths of a percent, Ford sold 119,834 light trucks, an increase of 21.3 percent, and Chrysler sold 89,476 light trucks, an increase of 25.5 percent. Toyota's light-truck sales for the month rose 21.9 percent, to 16,692, and Nissan's light-truck sales fell 11.1 percent, to 12,722.
"The truck market is much more indicative of the overall retail climate," said Robert L. Rewey, vice president of sales for Ford. He said Ford's gains in light-truck sales resulted from the auto maker's redesigned Econoline/Club Wagon, F-Series pickup trucks and Explorer utility vehicle.
Big Three auto makers were able to increase their share of the domestic car market in March to 61.5 percent from 59.8 percent a year ago. Sales of models made by Japanese auto makers, including transplants, slid to 30 percent, from 31.4 percent last year. Sales of all other imported cars dropped to 8.4 percent of the market, from 8.8 percent last year.
The Big Three also increased its share of the light-truck market, to 87.9 percent, from 85.6 percent last year. The share captured by Japanese auto makers dropped to 10.9 percent from 13.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Bias-Crime Rate Up 18%, And Juveniles Led the Surge

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 3

 BODY:
Led by a surprising number of hate crimes committed by juveniles, bias offenses increased 18 percent last year in New Jersey, despite one of the toughest laws in the nation, state officials said today.
"The perpetrators of hate crimes in New Jersey are most likely to be between the ages of 7 and 18," the head of the state's bias-crime office, Paul Goldenberg, said today as the state released its fourth annual Bias Incident Report. Officials also announced a pilot program to try to stem the increase in juvenile bias crimes. 
The report, compiled by the state police, showed that 976 bias offenses were reported in 1991, compared with 824 in 1990, and that blacks were the victims in 358 cases, or 37 percent of the total.
Mr. Goldenberg blamed "a lack of self-esteem and identity" for the increase in the number of juveniles involved in bias crimes. He said the problem was fed by parents and grew worse with the economy.
 
'Act Out Their Parents' Anger'
 "When people are out of work, they tend to vent their frustrations and anger on other groups of people, often in front of their children," he said. "The youth, in some cases, act out their parents' anger and fears by scapegoating on other people, especially minorities."
It was the fourth year in a row that reports of bias crimes had increased in New Jersey. There was an increase in the number of reports from 15 of the state's 21 counties. Increasingly, the attacks occurred on highways and in parking lots, now the second-most-common locale. The most common site was the victims' homes, the officials said. Nearly a third of the offenses took place there, and they usually involved vandalism.
Racial bias accounted for 513, or 53 percent, of the crimes in 1991, and Jews were the most frequently victimized religious group. Twenty-one incidents involved homosexuals as victims.
The bias incidents generally involved cross burnings, the painting of swastikas or graffiti and racial or religious insults delivered in person, by telephone or in letters. The report listed a lone murder, in Passaic County, as bias related.
What most surprised and worried officials was the number of young people involved. Ten juveniles younger than 10 were charged with bias crimes in 1991, and there were 173 defendants between the ages of 11 and 17, the report said.
"We are finding out that it is juveniles, and not organized hate groups, who are responsible for most of the bias crimes in New Jersey," said Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo.
Two years ago, Gov. Jim Florio signed into law the Ethnic Intimidation Act, creating what state law enforcement officials called the toughest anti-bias law in the nation. It allows a judge to give an extended prison term to anyone convicted of a crime in which ethnic or religious hate was a motivation.
Although the law applies to all defendants, it was aimed at organized hate groups, and law enforcement officials said today that it has rarely been used to prosecute juveniles.
Partly for that reason, Mr. Del Tufo announced the creation of a program to rehabilitate juveniles and their parents through "re-education."
Mr. Del Tufo said the program would be an option a judge could consider when sentencing a juvenile. The juvenile and the youth's parents would be required to attend classes and meet victims of hate crimes.

HEADLINE: Latest Fraud Preys On Loan Applicants

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Scam artists have found a new way to profit from the recession: bilking hard-pressed consumers who are looking for loans.
The ways of deception are many, but the most common is for thieves to set up a company that poses as a lender or loan broker promising a "guaranteed" loan. What's the hitch? The prospective borrowers must pay a fee up front. 
 The hoodwinked consumers never see the loan, nor do they ever see their up-front money again. On Wednesday, the police in New York arrested three Florida men who formerly ran a company called the First Southeastern Corporation, which had been based in New York. The State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, charged them with larceny of more than $900,000 from loan seekers by demanding up-front fees but never delivering the loans.
In addition, Mr. Abrams had planned to bring action against seven other companies engaged in requiring up-front fees for loans, but when he tried to serve them with legal papers he found that three had been shut by the Federal government and a fourth had disappeared. Up-front fees are illegal in New York and many other states. New York bars any advance charge for loans, except real-estate loans, and limits that charge to one half of 1 percent of the loan amount, or $50 per $10,000.
"Some companies tell you to send $250 by express mail," said Leslie Gersing, a spokeswoman for the Attorney General.
 
False Promises
 In the case of the men from First Southeastern, the Attorney General's office said they collected fees from more than 3,500 people, many of whom were attracted by ads in the Army Times and Navy Times offering "guaranteed loans." None got loans, Mr. Abrams said.
Robert L. Ellis, a lawyer for one of the three, Marc Hameroff, of Altamont, Fla., said, "these men tried to help people, who were difficult credit risks, in getting a loan." Mr. Ellis insisted that no guarantees were ever made and that his client had made his "best efforts" to obtain the loans. Mr. Hameroff and his associates, Arnold Eisenstadt and Wilfredo Gonzalez, both of Miami, pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
The State of New York charges that First Southeastern told its customers that it was merely a broker but had sent their applications on to loan companies, which rejected them for "insufficient income." But Mr. Abrams said the "loan companies" were First Southeastern itself.
The ploy is common, according to government officials and consumer advocates. At the New York State Banking Commission, Clare Sykes, a spokeswoman, said, "they prey on the people who are most vulnerable, people who have exhausted the traditional resources to obtain money." If a lender turns down your application for a loan, she said, the lender is required to return the application fee.
Another fraud used on credit-hungry consumers is a "900" number for loans. Callers may find it is nothing more than "someone reading a list of banks from the phone book," said Ms. Gersing of the Attorney General's office. Usually, such numbers are useless, she said.
Experts advise those seeking loans not to look for a loan from a company in another state. State banking authorities can sometimes force loan companies to make refunds, but generally the aggrieved party must complain to the authority in the lender's, not the applicant's, state. Dealing with a regulatory authority in a far-off state can be difficult.
A faraway address means potential trouble, said Carrie Getty, vice president of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York. "The rule of thumb is that a lender that is 2,000 miles away isn't more likely to give you a loan than the local lender who has turned you down," she said.
The picture is made even more complicated because comparison shopping for a loan these days should in fact look beyond banks for the best deal. For example, if you are looking for a real-estate loan, independent mortgage companies, with names most people have never heard, often offer better rates.
The Better Business Bureau, one of the few sources for comparative information on consumer frauds, reported recently that personal financial services rocketed into first place in 1991 as the most inquired-about category of business, with nearly 14,000 inquiries, up from 2,800 in 1990. Complaints about financial services were also up sharply, although mail-order companies still led in the number of complaints.
 
False Identities
 Ms. Getty said that still another scam is for a company to tell an applicant that it will obtain a loan or a credit card for him despite past credit problems. "But you have to be completely honest with us," the company tells the customer, she said. The company then asks for extensive personal data, including date of birth, social security number and various account numbers. Con artists use this information to create false identities under which they obtain telephone service and rent post office boxes from which they run illegal operations.
The bureau, which has a new computer system for tracking complaints and inquiries, said in its report for 1991 that the largest number of inquiries, 11,400, concerned loan companies, up from sixth place the previous year. Banks and credit unions drew nearly 800 inquiries.
Of the five companies about which the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York received the most inquiries, four were loan companies. Two, First Southeastern, and Roman Enterprises of Staten Island, are no longer operating. Two that may still be in operation are E. Raynor & Associates and MJ Industry, both of the Bronx. All four had unsatisfactory ratings with the bureau.
Neither E. Raynor nor MJ Industry have listed telephone numbers.
 
 
 
BEING A WARY APPLICANT
 Consumers applying for a loan who wish to check out a company can call their state's banking commission. New York's, like many, will say how many complaints are outstanding against lending companies of various types, not just banks.
In addition, your local Better Business Bureau will say whether a company has a satisfactory rating. To inquire about a business in New York City or Long Island, the number is (900) 463-6222. The call costs 95 cents a minute, with an average of $3.80 a call.
Members of the public who want to inquire or complain without paying for a "900" call can write to the bureau, at 257 Park Avenue South, New York 10010.

HEADLINE: When to Wink at Price-Fixing

 BODY:
Price-fixing is a dirty word, conjuring up images of corporate C.E.O.'s conspiring against defenseless consumers. But not all price-fixing is bad.
Resale price maintenance, for instance, can help consumers. That's the practice whereby a manufacturer sets a minimum price below which retailers are not allowed to sell a product. Manufacturers like the practice, even though it is nominally illegal, to insure that retailers provide sales information. So when the Senate recently passed legislation to make prosecuting manufacturers easier, it did consumers no favor. 
 The House has passed similar legislation, but with an all-important addition. The practice is now hard to prosecute successfully. An amendment by Tom Campbell, Republican of California, would keep prosecution difficult where resale price maintenance does only good: in competitive markets.
Conspiracies among several manufacturers to set prices always harm consumers and are illegal. But resale price maintenance involves only a single manufacturer. Many economists have come to believe that the practice is generally pro-consumer. The Supreme Court has reflected this new thinking in two decisions, making prosecution more difficult. It is now harder to prove the existence of an illegal agreement. The proposed legislation would reverse the effect of these decisions.
The complaint that resale price maintenance is primarily designed to raise prices doesn't make much sense. The manufacturer could do that simply by raising the price to retailers. The practice has a subtler, better purpose.
Consider the task of marketing a computer that looks like its rivals but is technologically superior. Most customers wouldn't know the difference unless a knowledgeable salesman patiently explained it. That costs the retailer money.
Yet, once informed, customers are free to walk down the block to the neighborhood discounter. That imperils full-service dealers and high-quality manufacturers. By setting minimum prices, manufacturers could force retailers to compete for customers by offering better service.
In a market dominated by a few large sellers, manufacturers could conspire to use retail price maintenance to charge high prices. But, as Mr. Campbell observes, such conspiracies can't survive in markets with plenty of competition.
His amendment would exempt competitive companies -- sellers too small to control prices -- from the legislation. That would make prosecution difficult where price maintenance is likely to do consumers good, but easy where it could do bad.
Conferees are about to decide the fate of Mr. Campbell's amendment. Here President Bush could help out by delivering a swift veto threat: No amendment, no approval.

HEADLINE: Welfare Reform Proves Sluggish

 BODY:
The 1988 Family Support Act, celebrated by liberals and conservatives alike, promised to transform welfare into a program that provides education, training and jobs to the needy rather than cash alone. So far, it hasn't worked out as its proponents had hoped.
A study released this week by two professors at the State University of New York at Albany found that states have been painfully slow to put the new program into effect -- reluctant to spend, during these recessionary times, much money on radical new programs. 
 Instead, about 40 states have decided to cut benefits and stiffen eligibility requirements. But turning harsh won't make the welfare problem disappear. It will simply make the needy more desperate than ever.
That's why the Family Support Act went a different route. The Government would provide a full welfare check if the recipient participated in training and education. Mutual obligation would replace mutual resentment. And to help the states along, Congress provided $1 billion a year to be matched with state funds.
But as the study shows, the contract hasn't so far taken hold. What got in the way was recession, which swelled welfare rolls and budget deficits. Unwilling to fork over their share, the states haven't touched 40 percent of the Federal money. State initiatives have been extremely modest.
That said, the researchers do not conclude that the law can't or won't work. After all, the program has only just begun. And states have met their enrollment goals, if only grudgingly. What's lacking, the researchers say, is any sense of urgency and excitement.
That can be remedied. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a sponsor of the 1988 law, proposes to make even more Federal money available, lower the required state contribution and boost the proportion of welfare recipients that states are required to incorporate into training and education programs. Senator Moynihan's bill, or a less expensive version, is the right response.

HEADLINE: Chilean Wineries Outgrow the Jug

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PIRQUE, Chile

 BODY:
During the day in this semiarid river valley some 20 miles south of Santiago, the sun is hot and dry. At night, a chill descends. There is little rain throughout the year, and the winters are cold.
"A perfect climate for producing very fine wine," said Eduardo Guilisasti, president of Chile's largest vineyard, Concho y Toro. "We really have it all." 
 A few years ago, that might have been hard to say. Chile made wine for hundreds of years, selling it locally and to its Latin American neighbors. But most of it was jug wine, and most of the rest was hardly appropriate to grace tables in New York, London or Montreal.
 
No. 3 Wine Exporter to U.S.
 No more. Thanks to foreign investment, Government tax breaks and a market economy that has given rise to entrepreneurship and growth, Chile has surpassed Germany to become the No. 3 exporter of wine to the United States, selling almost 1.4 million cases last year. Only Italy, with 8.1 million cases, and France, with 5.8 million, sold more.
Only seven years ago, Chilean exports of wine to the United States were so insignificant that they hardly showed up on the charts, a mere 180,000 cases, or about what a mid-size California winery produces in a year. But while Chile's market share has doubled in the last two years, those of Italy and France have fallen 40 percent. And Chilean wine importers predict that their share will rise another 30 percent this year.
Today, vineyards like Concho y Toro, which accounts for about half of the Chilean exports to the United States, are turning out cabernets, pinot noirs, merlots, chardonnays and sauvignon blancs, some of remarkable quality considering that they sell in the United States for as little as $4 a bottle.
"It's beyond what we could have imagined several years ago," Mr. Guilisasti said as he offered his vineyard's Don Melchor cabernet sauvignon, which it sells as its premium wine in the United States. "We feel Concho y Toro, and Chile as a whole, is coming into its own."
One reason for Chile's success is that much of the wine falls into the fast-growing price niches in the United States, the $4-to-$5-a-bottle bracket and the $8.50-a-bottle neighborhood.
Chile's cost advantages arise from two main sources -- labor and land. Workers are paid about one-third what they are paid in California and France. And while land suitable for vineyards sells for $1,200 to $5,500 an acre in Chile, the cost in California ranges from $40,000 to $60,000 an acre and in France from $100,000 to $140,000 an acre, industry experts say.
The result is that the merlot and cabernet produced by Concho y Toro start at about $4 a bottle, its better Don Melchor cabernet sells for around $10 to $12, its chardonnay has a $9 price tag and its brut champagne can be had for $7 a bottle.
"Our advantage is that we can produce a terrific cabernet sauvignon or chardonnay for one-half the price of a comparable California wine and one-third the price of a French wine," said Goetz von Gerdsdorff, Concho y Toro's chief oenologist.
"We sell a ton of Chilean wine," said Jeff Zacharia, vice president of Zachy's Wine and Liquor, a large merchant based in Scarsdale, N.Y. "We love it because it is a great value. No one is producing the quality and quantity of wine selling for $8 a bottle that Chile is."
"French wines are going up and up in price, and so are Italian wines to a lesser extent," Mr. Zacharia said. "And people are always going to look for value. They come in and buy a few bottles of Chilean wine and then come back and buy a few cases."
But price alone does not assure Chile of continued success. As long as it continues to bring a good value to America it should do well, wine merchants say. But as with all wine, quality can vary, and if it varies too much, wine buyers can be an unforgiving bunch. Also, some Chilean wines turned up on a Food and Drug Administration list last year with lead levels higher than Washington considers safe for drinking.
Lead damages the nervous system, bone marrow and kidneys, and has been linked to birth defects and to mental retardation in children. Lead can get into wine through the lead foil capsules used to seal bottles. The F.D.A. said it intended to ban the use of lead foil wrappers, but it has not begun the formal rule-making procedure. In California, lead wrappers were illegal as of April 1 for all newly bottled wine sold there, foreign or domestic.
The history of Chile's wine industry in recent years is not unlike that of the entire Chilean economy, often looked to as a model for development in Latin America.
The industry's success is linked to the generous tax breaks available to exporting industries, but also to the open-market economy that was passed on by the military Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet and essentially unchanged by the democratically elected Government of President Patricio Aylwin.
As a consequence, more than $20 million in foreign and domestic capital has been sunk into the wine industry here in the last five years. Among prominent investors are Franciscan Vineyards in Rutherford, Calif., which bought 50 percent of Errazuriz Panquehue (pronounced Eh-rah-zoo-RIZ Pan-KAY-way) in the mid-1980's, then sold its interest and established its own vineyard with a $3.5 million investment.
More than half a dozen investment projects from French and Spanish wineries are in the works. And Robert Mondavi Winery of Oakville, Calif., is said to be currently looking for a Chilean wine venture.
But the biggest splash was created in 1988, when Baron von Rothschild, owner of the famous Chateau Lafite-Rothschild in France, bought 50 percent of Los Vascos family winery.
While some of the new money has gone into buying new vineyards, much has been put into updating and modernizing Chile's once woefully antiquated wine-making technology.
A walk through Concho y Toro's wine operation here illustrates where the money has gone. Cement vats used to ferment wines have been replaced with dozens of spanking clean stainless steel, automatically cooled vats that can produce world-class white wines.
Concho y Toro's 100-year-old behemoth wine barrels, some 15 feet tall and 10 feet wide, are now used only for jug wine production or for decoration. Stacked throughout the cellars are hundreds of small 58-gallon barrels made from American and French oak, in which the best red wines for export are aged.
French and American oak barrels, which can cost up to $900 each and impart the rich woody flavor to red wines, are considered essential for making wine that can compete with California cabernet and French Bordeaux.
Old manual presses stand as museum pieces and have been replaced by pneumatic presses. And workers no longer stick labels on and stuff corks into wine bottles by hand; assembly-line machines do everything but put the bottles into boxes.
 
Fruitier, Crisper Flavor
 The new technology has resulted in a new generation of white wines that tend to be fruitier and crisper, and red wines that are more complex, full bodied and smooth.
Undurraga Vineyards is another example of aiming at the lower end of the price range with wine of exceptional quality made with new equipment. Over the last four years, the vineyard has invested $600,000 in stainless steel vats and refrigeration units and now produces wines selling for less than $5 that critics say could match $8 to $10 California wines.
"What we offer is a fruitier, fresher flavor, something that the American wine palate seems to want," said Francisco Santelices, exporting director for the Undurraga Vineyards. "But we realize the price is a very sensitive issue. Chilean wines cannot afford to outprice themselves. "
Undurraga's exports went from 11,000 cases in 1989 to 72,000 two years later, and Mr. Santelices predicts that the winery will sell a minimum of 85,000 cases this year. It has turned down several takeover offers.
Other prime exporting vineyards include Cousino-Macul, which sells an exquisite Antigua Reserva carbernet and a Chardonnay Reserva, both for less than $10 a bottle, and Santa Rita, which markets a Medalla Real carbernet and a chardonnay, also for less than $10.
"We know we have to be very careful with the price," said Mr. Guilisasti of Concho y Toro. "The temptation at this point is to start raising prices. Other countries did that, and they made a mistake."

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
REGENERATION, by Pat Barker. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $20.) Ms. Barker takes brilliantly to semihistorical fiction with a polemic-free tale of war, manhood and madness, about the rebellion, the psychiatric treatment and the return to the front of the poet Siegfried Sassoon in World War I.
WAKE UP LITTLE SUSIE: Single Pregnancy and Race Before Roe v. Wade, by Rickie Solinger. (Routledge, $25.) A scholar's grim analysis of the treatment -- and the difference in treatment -- accorded women and girls who became extramaritally pregnant.
I AM ZOE HANDKE, by Eric Larsen. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $16.95.) In highly mannered but precisely controlled prose, this novel pursues a daughter's struggle with the most destructive and terrifying of childhood emotions: abandonment and loss.
THE MISMEASURE OF WOMAN, by Carol Tavris. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A social psychologist examines the scientific study of fundamental differences between men and women; she finds much of it just plain wrong, even when its agenda is feminist.
LETTERS OF GUSTAVE COURBET, edited by Petra ten-Doesschate Chu. (University of Chicago, $55.) Wonderful, intense stuff by the great painter, who was a raving democrat when looking above him in society, a solid bourgeois when looking down.
THE LOVE QUEEN OF THE AMAZON, by Cecile Pineda. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A droll novel about sex and stuffy society on the upper Amazon, full of well-handled incongruities and characters who insist on making theatrical fools of themselves and others.
POSTCARDS, by E. Annie Proulx. (Scribners, $22.95.) This lovely novel of the 1940's-80's era turns on a murderer's exile and the decline of the family and the landscape he left behind in Vermont.

HEADLINE: Art and the Oldest Profession

BYLINE: By Grace Glueck; Grace Glueck is a former art news editor at The New York Times.

 BODY:

PAINTED LOVE
Prostitution in French Art of the Impressionist Era.
By Hollis Clayson.
Illustrated. 202 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $45. 
 AS a way of making a living in 19th-century France, prostitution was a popular choice. There were few other opportunities for an unmarried working-class woman to earn her bread and have a little fun besides. But bourgeois French men -- according to Hollis Clayson in "Painted Love" -- were terrified that the ubiquity of prostitutes would bring sexual liberation to decent women, and so a strong system of police control, which lasted from 1800 to 1946, monitored the activities of the fallen ones, creating an underclass of "deviants" in which professionals were not distinguished from amateurs.
The flamboyant presence of sex for sale in Paris made it a hot topic for (mostly male) artists and writers: Alexandre Dumas fils presented his play "La Dame aux Camelias" in 1852, Edouard Manet unveiled the nude "Olympia" in 1863, Paul Cezanne painted a series of brothels between 1870 and 1877, Edgar Degas did a group of brothel prints in the late 1870's, Emile Zola wrote "Nana" at the end of that decade and Manet painted "A Bar at the Folies-Bergere" in 1882.
For a revisionist, feminist, sociologically-oriented art historian, what better subject than this heated conjunction of art and the oldest profession? Ms. Clayson -- an associate professor of art history at Northwestern University and a former student of T. J. Clark (a professor of art history at the University of California at Berkeley and the guru of French 19th-century revisionism) -- tackles it with gusto, but also a heavy overdose of academic jargon. What she's out to prove is that artists, even the most avant-garde of them, helped perpetuate the popular view of prostitutes (to whom she refers as "sexual workers") as a sub-human species endangering the social order.
Analyzing the production of painters ranging from schmaltzy Salonists like Henri Gervex, whose superheated canvas "Rolla" showed a young male aristocrat as the victim of a lowdown temptress, to haute avant-gardists -- Cezanne, Degas and Manet -- Ms. Clayson concludes that even the work of what she calls the most "modern" practitioners fails to contradict popular sexual stereotypes. Take what she calls that "widely admired icon of modernist uncertainty," Manet's famous painting "A Bar at the Folies-Bergere," with its double image of a waitress. Although the painting has hitherto gone unnoticed as an antifemale tract and has even been considered a defense of working-class women, Ms. Clayson, following her mentor, Mr. Clark, makes the case that Manet's "deadpan" treatment of his subject raises moralistic questions about her sexuality.
The painting presents a frontal view of a woman behind the bar at a busy nightclub. Her expression is guarded; her eyes do not indicate that she is talking with anyone. But the reflection of her back, in a wide mirror behind her, shows that she is addressing a male customer. According to Ms. Clayson, "the possible double profession of the barmaid -- serving and prostitution -- was clear to observers in 1882," since one image of the barmaid is "cool, detached, aloof," and the other, which puts the woman in a subservient position to the man, hints at a sexual transaction. While Manet's ambiguity is essentially modernist, Ms. Clayson holds, at the same time his raising the question "Was she or wasn't she?" actually helped reinforce stereotypical thinking about prostitutes and intensified the public perception of them as commodities rather than women. But couldn't Manet's work also be read a comment on what the working girl -- greedily ogled by her customer -- was subjected to by her exposure in a public bar?
As for Degas, although he broke with Salon cliches about courtesans by depicting them as decidedly not sirenlike, and with apish faces, they were in his eyes "objective commercialized matter" and he presented them "not only as sexual deviants but as threatening social deviants," Ms. Clayson writes. Still, she observes, Degas in his monotypes also made the male clients complicit by projecting them as "buyers in a sexual market." He attacked their fantasies of control over prostitutes by indicating that the "psychic advantage was actually (only) economic." (Later, in a 20th-century reprise of Degas's brothel prints, Picasso took a giant step backward, she adds, demonstrating "the ultimate misogynistic cultural perception": assuming that all sexual women were prostitutes.)
What's more, Ms. Clayson surmises that certain of the Degas prints show that, despite his disgust with what she calls the "commodified" women (meaning those he regarded as commodities rather than individuals), the artist shared the cultivated male's attraction to certain portions of their anatomy, notably their buttocks, which he rendered with obvious zest.
The idea of exploring public attitudes toward prostitution through the art of the period is a provocative one. Yet Ms. Clayson's heavy political agenda leads her into highly debatable assumptions. It could be argued, for instance, that it is not the "canny masculine achievements" of Manet and other French avant-gardists that, as she says, helps to explain their popularity, but their talents as painters. After all, how can we expect politically correct thinking from artists whom we cherish for their "ambiguity"? And is it reasonable to expect that artists, even the most avant-garde of them, will be immune to the faults of their society?
MS. CLAYSON is on firmer ground when she uses her art-historical scholarship to provide a wealth of information about the workings of the 19th-century Parisian social order. She describes in detail, for instance, the system of police regulation of prostitutes and its "definition of female sexuality solely in relation to the needs and desires of men." In a chapter on working women, she reminds us that single or married ones who had jobs outside the home often took to prostitution to eke out their miserable salaries. Hat stores in particular were seen as dens of iniquity; Renoir -- for one -- in a painting on the theme suggested "his ease with a definition of the millinery shop as a place of female scheming and collusion, where the groundwork might have been laid for sexual dealings." (But here again, assumption looms. Note the tricky wording: "His ease with a definition," "the groundwork might have been laid.") Although he and other avant-gardists did not depict the shopgirls as sexual commodities, the elliptical way in which they did present them, Ms. Clayson insists, helped to reinforce the belief that working-class females were sexually unstable.
In short, Ms. Clayson does well at describing a societal problem -- coping with prostitution by declaring the victims an underclass subject to humiliating regulation. Where she is on shakier ground is in trying to establish the complicity of artists. And she does not help her case by cloaking her insights and information with politically correct revisionist jargon.

HEADLINE: Note With Pleasure

 BODY:

Rich in Time
The basic difference between our acquisitive societies and those of hunter-gatherers isn't a matter of sophistication, Juliet B. Schor suggests, but of desires. This is from "The Overworked American: The Unexpected Decline of Leisure" (Basic Books). 

Faith in progress is deep within our culture. We have been taught to believe that our lives are better than those who came before us. The ideology of modern economics suggests that material progress has yielded enhanced satisfaction and well-being. But much of our confidence about our own well-being comes from the assumption that our lives are easier than those of earlier generations or other cultures. . . . The lives of so-called primitive peoples are commonly thought to be harsh -- their existence dominated by the "incessant quest for food." In fact, primitives do little work. By contemporary standards, we'd have to judge them extremely lazy. If the Kapauku of Papua work one day, they do no labor on the next. !Kung Bushmen put in only two and a half days per week and six hours per day. . . . The key to understanding why these "stone age peoples" fail to act like us -- increasing their work effort to get more things -- is that they have limited desires. In the race between wanting and having, they have kept their wanting low -- and, in this way, insure their own kind of satisfaction.
 
Love's Crowded Bed
 Around the beds of longtime lovers hover many ghosts, as this excerpt from a monologue by Joan Logghe about a farmer's wife reflecting on her marriage illustrates. It is included in "The Unmade Bed: Sensual Writing on Married Love," edited by Laura Chester (HarperCollins).
 
 When you know somebody that deeply, so many bodies lie in the bed alongside. We need a king-sized bed to contain them. Our bed is full of farmland, 200 acres including the back pasture. And you know, that is where the best sex always is, despite the scent of cows. The Jungians say that in bed there are always at least four people, invisible man and dark surly woman. But in our bed there is a herd -- siblings and offspring, his parents, my parents, and the church, full of incense and Latin. My temple, so old it's got the history of God engraved in the bedsheets. It isn't a bed, it's a text, a Russian novel.
 
The Mirror of Our Age
 Jonathan Raban reminds us that our view of the natural world, far from being an exact rendering, is shaped by each age's hopes and needs. This is from his introduction to "The Oxford Book of the Sea" (Oxford University).
 
 The sea is one of the most "universal" symbols in literature; it is certainly the most protean. It changes in response to shifts of sensibility as dramatically as it does to shifts of wind and the changes of the moon. The sea in 18th-century literature is one place, the sea in 19th-century literature quite another; as the American sea is importantly different from the British sea. Conrad's title for his collection of maritime essays, "The Mirror of the Sea," puts it nicely: the writer who goes to sea finds himself confronting a disturbed reflection of his own age, personality and preoccupations. The sea in literature is not a verifiable object, to be described, with varying degrees of success and shades of emphasis, by writers of different periods; it is, rather, the supremely liquid and volatile element, shaping itself newly for every writer and every generation.
 
The Art of Knowing How
 Baltasar Gracian (1601-58), a Spanish Jesuit, offered a succinct and still pertinent argument for injecting a touch of the practical into our affairs in his collection of maxims "The Art of Worldly Wisdom: A Pocket Oracle," translated by Christopher Maurer (Doubleday).
 
 Not everything should be speculation; you must also act. The wisest are easiest to deceive: they may know extraordinary things, but they know nothing of life's ordinary necessities. The contemplation of sublime things keeps them from lowly, easy ones, and because they don't know the first things about living -- an area where everyone else is so sharp -- they are either marveled over or considered ignorant by the superficial crowd. So let the wise have a touch of the practical, enough not to be deceived or mocked. Know how to get things done: it may not be the highest thing in life, but it is the most necessary. What good is knowledge if it isn't practical? These days true knowledge lies in knowing how to live.
 
An Orchestra of Angels
 In the scramble to explain the dazzling originality of Mozart's music, commentators have often turned to heaven for an analogy, as Wolfgang Hildesheimer points out in this excerpt from "Mozart" (Noonday, paper).
 
 The theologian Karl Barth . . . imagines that the angels, left to themselves, play Mozart, and that the dear Lord likes especially to listen to them then. I am a stranger to those spheres, but can visualize a pretty picture: I see God like Rembrandt's Saul enjoying the music of David's harp, lost in the thought that one ought perhaps to have done something for this divine musician during his earthly life. Musicians, too, have availed themselves of the analogy with divine realms: "Others may reach heaven with their works. But Mozart, he comes, he comes from there!" This exclamation, with its rhetorical repetition, also reveals an emotional relationship to its object rather than a valid statement about it. . . . And yet we must admit that, on some uncomfortably irrational level, we apprehend what is meant: recognition of the miraculous quality in Mozart, the deepest reason for all work about him, a reason so deep that its premise is beyond thought.

HEADLINE: College vs. Community: The Civil Wars

BYLINE: By William Celis 3d

 BODY:
IN THE MIDDLE of the night, residents in a toney Coral Gables, Fla., neighborhood have been awakened by University of Miami students celebrating too loudly. The residents have grumbled to city officials about finding fraternity members passed out on their front lawns, apparently from too much revelry the night before.
But the breaking point came with the university's proposed expansion under its master plan. After three years of negotiations, Coral Gables officials approved the plan last December; residents, however, did not. Last month they filed a lawsuit in Dade County Circuit Court, charging that the master plan violates the zoning code by proposing dormitory-style housing near single-family homes. 
 "How the university can think people will live with this and not do anything about it is beyond me," said John G. Fletcher, a lawyer representing the irate residents in the suit, which names both the city and the uni-
versity as defendants.
Like Coral Gables and the University of Miami, many other towns and universities throughout the nation are clashing over a host of nettlesome issues, casting a pall over relationships that have always been tenuous. Residents in university towns grouse about traffic and litter generated by students. Universities complain about rigid zoning codes that bar or stymie growth and development. Town councils complain, particularly in these recessionary times, that public universities are not required to pay local taxes, even though towns finance street maintenance, mass transit and other services used by university populations.
The universities counter that they are good neighbors and major employers, and that the towns derive other benefits because of their presence.
"The problem is we're looking at two different entities with two different missions," said Donna London, a researcher at the Strom Thurmond Institute for Government and Public Affairs at Clemson University in South Carolina who studied so-called town-gown relations in 26 university hometowns and cities nationwide. "One of them is having to answer to a very large body of students and you have the city trying to answer to taxpayers. When you are dealing in close proximity with one another, sometimes toes get stepped on."
Relations in some places have so soured that lawsuits are becoming a common form of town-gown communication. Northwestern University, for example, filed suit against Evanston, Ill., over the city's plan to levy its hotel and motel tax on the university's management center, where visiting corporate executives live and take classes. Last November the Illinois Appellate Court ruled in favor of the university.
In Malibu, Calif., a group of residents took Pepperdine University to court trying to block the university's proposed expansion along the coast. The residents have twice appealed court verdicts in the case, which is now before California's Second District Court of Appeals.
Sometimes communities have not one but two or more universities with which to contend. Cambridge, Mass., one of the best known of the academically well endowed, has engaged in skirmishes and full-fledged battles with Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology over a host of issues, from development to compensation for services rendered to the municipal dangers posed by university lab experi-
ments. "Each university has had its periods of ups and downs with the city," said James Maloney, the city's finance director.
Even when a community has invited university involvement, friction sometimes results. For example, after Boston University assumed management of the troubled Chelsea, Mass., school system at Chelsea's request three years ago, animosity flared among some teachers who thought the university was too heavy-handed and residents who thought it too arrogant.
Universities, for their part, are slowly but increasingly recognizing the tense nature of the town-gown relationship and are taking action. Some have agreed with local officials to make annual contributions in lieu of taxes or to help buy equipment for the city. In Columbia, Mo., the University of Missouri contributed enough money recently to remodel a fire station that serves the university.
Other institutions have embarked on projects with widespread community appeal. In Greeley, Colo., the University of Northern Colorado, the city and the business community have come together to help address the public school dropout rate.
Behind these efforts are formal agreements struck between universities and their communities. In addition, the National League of Cities in recent years has established a standing committee on university-town issues, a reflection, many say, of the growing importance of these relationships. "Obviously universities are a large asset to communities," said Mary Anne McCollum, the Mayor of Columbia, Mo., and chairwoman of the league's university-town caucus. But Ms. McCollum said the caucus increasingly was looking at ways to lessen the financial onus of being a college town or a univer-city.
 
Social Worries: Differences in Life Style
 From parties to student behavior to parking to housing, life-style differences tend to be the biggest town-gown issue. The existence of multifamily dwellings (home to students) amid single-family houses (home to what some residents think of as normal people) has generated sparks too. The resulting traffic congestion, lack of parking and presence of litter have angered permanent residents, prompting some cities to take action.
In Seattle, the University Park neighborhood just north of the University of Washington became so clogged with student resident and nonresident vehicles, some parked in front of private homes, that residents complained about having to park blocks from where they live and walk home at night -- an arrangement that single working women considered unsafe. So the city initiated a neighborhood parking permit plan, requiring both townspeople and students living in the neighborhood to pay $27 a year for the privilege of parking there. Neither students nor residents were happy about the cost. "But generally I believe that residents are pleased with the results because it has cut down on the amount of traffic and parking in the neighborhood," said Robert H. Hardy, a member of the neighborhood association board.
The sprinkling of fraternity houses throughout residential neighborhoods continues to bedevil university towns. In Ann Arbor, Mich., the decibel level of fraternity parties in areas abutting the University of Michigan became so high that residents complained to fraternities. When those protests failed, residents complained to city officials and the university.
"We have our problems," said Walter Harrison, the university's executive director of university relations. And one of those problems -- loud students -- "is a timeless irritant."
As a result the Noisy Party Task Force, comprising representatives of the city, the university, residents and fraternities, was formed last spring to find a solution. Residents went for the jugular; in the initial agreement stiff fines and even jail sentences were proposed for repeat noise offenders.
"There is a fair amount of animosity between the neighborhood and certain fraternities," said Matthew Commers, past president of the Interfraternity Council, a student group that oversees the university's 37 fraternities and a task force member. "The problems would begin with irate neighbors calling at night to a fraternity house and having the phone answered rudely."
Fraternity members, with the university's help, succeeded in eliminating jail sentences from the final pact; it calls for citations with cash fines that increase with repeated offenses. "We are desperately trying to change things here," said Mr. Commers, adding that the pact is a step in the right direction.
 
How Universities Affect the Economy
 If life style is the ranking issue, a university's effect on the local economy is a close second. The University of Michigan and the city of Ann Arbor no sooner set limits on fraternity party noise when another issue surfaced: the city's fiscal contribution to the university's well-being. "Without the University of Michigan, the city of Ann Arbor would be completely bereft of its economic base," said Mayor Elizabeth S. Brater. "Having said that, we have to pay for services for which we are not adequately reimbursed." The city, for example, is spending $4.3 million for fire protection in the current fiscal year ending June 30. Of that amount, $1.8 million is spent to protect the university's 2,607-acre campus.
In an unusual arrangement, the city receives some aid under a state reimbursement plan designed to help defray the cost of fire protection for the university. But Mayor Brater said the Legislature in recent years had allocated only 47 percent of the money authorized by the legislation for the reimbursement plan.
"Relations between universities and their towns are always going to be contentious," said Mr. Harrison, the university's executive director for relations. "It's my personal contention that the current economic climate has made universities tempting targets for towns. Universities are under the same financial pressure as everyone else, but we appear to be more prosperous." That perception, he said, is untrue.
Economic issues have also surfaced when universities establish bookstores, bowling alleys and eating establishments that compete with local businesses. That's the rub in Blacksburg, Va., where Virginia Tech University recently opened a "food court," where several restaurants operate under the same roof.
"That has taken traffic away from the town, and merchants are not very happy," said Thomas G. Goodale, the vice president for student affairs, who also handles calls from community residents. The town proposed to increase a local meals tax on prepared food and drink to 4 percent from 3 percent, but the university, as a state agency, is exempt from local taxes.
Merchants who run downtown restaurants and stores won a point when the university agreed to remove advertising for the food court and other university-based businesses like the bookstore from the downtown area and from the town's two newspapers. But the sour feelings persist because the food court is just the latest economic slap at a town buffeted by the recession and the loss of about 400 jobs. "All this together spells tension," said Mr. Goodale.
 
The Politics of Town-Gown Contention
 To no one's surprise, the economic and social contention between universities and towns has generated political friction. To the clashes over university expansion plans and zoning codes can now be added student involvement in local politics.
Some communities have made it difficult for students to register to vote in local elections by holding voter registration drives during summer months or, as several New York State college towns have done, by attempting to impose extra conditions on voters.
In Syracuse, for example, students were required over the last several years to fill out a three-page questionnaire in addition to the normal registration requirements to determine whether their primary residence was their college address. If not, they were not allowed to register. The questionnaires, initiated by Onondaga County, were discontinued in January.
A bill approved last month by the New York State Assembly would force the rescinding of all such election codes that discriminate against students. The legislation, however, is not expected to receive Senate approval because of strong opposition from many college communities.
"It's not that towns don't want students voting on campus," said Jerry Koenig, a legislative specialist for the New York Assembly's election-law committee. "They don't want them voting period. A lot of these towns are paranoid that the students will overwhelm the other voters. They're afraid that what happened in Ann Arbor will happen in their towns."
Student turnout from the University of Michigan there has occasionally tilted elections in favor of student candidates for local office, electing people whose views are more in tune with the university than with the permanent residents.
However, anecdotal evidence from nearly 20 college towns suggests that fears of student voters regularly altering local election results are unfounded. Student candidates have just as often lost political races. And even when they win office, they often confront the hostility of permanent residents.
"Some of them told me I had no right to represent them since I'm not from the area," said Scott J. Ziance, a 21-year-old junior at Bowling Green University in Ohio who is from Altoona, Pa. Despite the resentments, Mr. Ziance was elected to the Bowling Green City Council last November as a Republican, beating another student and the Democratic incumbent, an education professor at the university.
Since his election, Mr. Ziance says, fellow Council members have been supportive. "People have begun to realize that not all college students are bad," he said. "And I think that students are beginning to see that not all town people have a negative view of them."
 
Pulling Together: Solutions in Action
 Students elected to city councils are part of a detente that is gathering momentum and is rooted in the belief that universities and towns can work together for mutual benefit. Increasingly, task forces and committees are being considered or have been established in university towns to tackle housing problems, life style differences and economic worries.
For example, discussions are under way between Arizona State University and Tempe city officials to establish a standing committee that would meet regularly to discuss issues affecting both entities.
And the University of California at Berkeley, under an agreement that went into effect in 1990, will pay the city of Berkeley $24 million over a 15-year period to help buy fire trucks and pay for sewage costs and other services that the city provides without charge.
Although such university largess is still rare, more universities are engaging in community outreach projects of some kind. In Clemson, S.C., town residents can use the nursing services at Clemson University for a minimal charge. In New York City, students at Co-
lumbia University's Graduate School of Business are helping Harlem residents with their taxes. In New Haven, Conn., Yale University has established a center designed to help public school teachers update themselves about curriculum and other education issues.
Many of the universities or town-university partnerships address education issues. The University of Northern Colorado's participation in Greeley's dropout prevention program is a case in point. It is one of the projects the university and the city embarked on together in a relationship that both sides assert is becoming stronger. The next step, according to Greeley's Mayor, William J. Horton, is to explore the economics of the relationship. Both the university and the city maintain parks, Mr. Horton said, and the cost of maintenance should be shared to save tax dollars.
"It would save a lot of money," said Mr. Horton, who added that he has been pushing hard to share infrastructure costs and other services. "We need to pull together."
