HEADLINE: Lean and Mean Is Foreign to Schools

BYLINE: By Steve Lohr

 BODY:
THE DEBATE over education spending in the United States is often a hostage to ideology. Liberals see rundown schools, tattered textbooks and beleaguered teachers -- a system starved for resources. Conser-
vatives see rising education budgets and international comparisons showing that America is a big spender yet its students are underachievers -- a system bloated with waste and inefficiency.
But the two sides do find common ground in the view that how the nation's education dollars are spent may be as important as how much is spent. President Bush has declared that "dollar bills don't educate students." Yet even Chester E. Finn Jr., a professor at Vanderbilt University and a chief architect of the Bush Administration's education strategy, conceded: "We're going to spend more on education in this country -- there's no doubt about that. But people like me want to make sure the dollars are spent where it counts, so that kids learn more." 
 The case for reform is a strong one. Study after study, typically at the school district or state level, has found that an increasing share of education spending has nothing to do with the classroom. In Georgia, for example, the percentage of education spending on classroom instruction fell from 77 percent in 1970 to 52 percent in 1990, according to a recent report by the Georgia Public Policy Foundation, a research group. The foundation, based in suburban Atlanta, cited ever-higher administrative costs as a key culprit.
A recent report by the Business Council of New York State titled "The $11-Billion Mystery" also singled out swollen bureaucracy as an explanation for where the big increase in the state's annual education budget since 1980 was spent.
 
Declining Percentages
 Nationally the picture is much the same, though the most reliable national statistics are in head counts, not dollars. From 1950 to 1989 the portion of total staff members in the nation's public schools who were teachers declined from 70 percent to 53 percent, according to the National Center for Education Statistics, the Department of Education's number-gathering unit. The other large category of personnel, "support staff" -- a catch-all grouping that includes secretaries, custodians, food service workers, nurses, bus drivers, accountants and computer programmers, grew from 23 percent in 1950 to 31 percent of the education work force by 1989. Teacher's aides, who proliferated from 1.7 percent in 1970 to 8 percent in 1989, followed by principals and assistant principals, school district administration and other categories accounted for the remainder.
Many experts agree that the "middle management" ranks of the education system -- the layers of people between the school principal and the school board -- have grown partly through bureaucratic inertia and could be trimmed back. The middle management jobs would include business managers, teaching supervisors, compliance officers, directors of special education programs and others. The advocates of this kind of streamlining compare it to the so-called restructuring process that corporate America has been going through in recent years to become more efficient and competitive enterprises.
In the business world, the justification for operating with fewer people in middle management posts is that the information-gathering work traditionally performed by these people can now be done by computers and that having more decisions made by the salespeople and factory workers closest to the customers will result in better decisions.
"The education world simply hasn't gone through that process yet," said Harold Howe 2d, a senior lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. "And it is the real hope for saving money, especially in large school districts."
Still, cutting the education bureaucracy may be more difficult than it seems at first glance: What fueled its growth were the twin requirements for federally and state-mandated special education programs for the handicapped, the disadvantaged and students in need of bilingual instruction, along with offices set up to administer those programs. The oversight and staff were added in the name of public accountability.
 
Bigger Tasks
 Some layers of administration can be pared down, experts say, but much of the growth results from America's schools being asked to handle a larger population of children whose parents are poor, uneducated and may have drug or alcohol problems. "These are the problems you get when you have more and more children living in poverty," said Marc S. Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a nonprofit research organization. "The schools didn't create those problems, but they are being forced to deal with the results."
Besides thinning out management ranks, the other major target for savings in public schools is basic support functions such as custodial work, food service and clerical help. The recent controversy over the pay levels for custodians in New York City's public schools -- average pay $58,000 a year, more than the teachers' top-scale pay of $52,750 -- seemed to underline how inept school districts can be in purchasing basic services.
 
Nationwide Problem
 The same problem exists nationwide, according to David Bennett, president of Education Alternatives Inc., a consulting firm that privately manages public schools in Arizona, Florida and Minnesota. Mr. Bennett, a former superintendent of schools in St. Paul, says that school districts typically pay far more for custodians, secretaries and food service workers than people in those occupations receive in the private sector, from 50 to 100 percent more.
Strong unions, he says, are only part of the explanation for generous compensation. "The main reason is that you have almost a complete lack of management scrutiny of these services," Mr. Bennett said. To trim those costs, school districts are increasingly opening those services to bids from private contractors, bringing the benefits of market competition.
Some education experts are skeptical of the effort to transplant business techniques to school districts, noting that various management nostrums have been tried over the years and the current enthusiasm is merely the latest fashion. Others disagree, saying that past efforts tended to deal with the style of school administration, but left the bureaucratic monopoly in place. "The capacity to save large amounts of money by cutting back nonclassroom spending is clearly there," Mr. Bennett said. "But the real question is whether the political will exists to change things, whether at the district school board level or nationally."

HEADLINE: Separation Anxiety

BYLINE: By Roberto Suro

 BODY:
WHEN A SMALL university is situated in a small town, the relationship between them can be defined by a few individuals, especially if they are extraordinary people. That seems to be the case for Southwestern University and Georgetown, a little town in central Texas.
With just 1,200 students, Southwestern is tiny compared with public institutions like the University of Texas at Austin, 30 miles away, which has an enrollment of some 47,500. In Georgetown, however, with a population of just 14,800, Southwestern is the largest employer, the biggest budget and the most extensive landowner. 
 Ostensibly the university ought to be an overwhelming factor in Georgetown's life. But even here there are impermeable membranes between town and gown. Differences in goals, constituencies and mindsets create barriers, as they do for most universities and their municipalities. But in this case, the small scale means that individuals who cross the barriers can do so with dramatic effect.
Esther Weir, who went to Georgetown in 1938 to teach women's physical education at Southwestern and has been active at the university and in the town ever since, describes the relationship through three such individuals -- all women.
 
Three Quietly Effective Lives
 There was Laura Kuykendall, dean of women who from the 1910's through the 1930's organized flamboyant May Fair celebrations that drew visitors to the town by the trainload. From 1948 to 1965, when local schools were still segregated, Iola Bowden, a music professor, ran the Negro School of Fine Arts, bringing black students to a Methodist church to learn piano and other artistic skills with her university students serving as teachers. "It wasn't exactly a secret," Mrs. Weir said, "but it had to be done quietly and it affected many lives."
Finally, there is Martha Mitten Allen, who has taught history at the university since 1960 and is currently the department chairwoman. In 1983 she organized Handicrafts Unlimited as an outlet for arts and crafts produced by Georgetown area residents age 50 and older. Their creations are sold at a store on the town square. Last year more than 400 artisans contributed while 50 volunteers from the university and the town ran the store.
The links between town and university predate Dean Kuykendall, and the nature of those links seem to be more durable than her May Fair celebrations. They began in 1869, when Texas Methodists were looking for a place to build a university and Georgetown competed with other towns for the site. During the Depression local merchants accepted the scrip issued by the university to faculty members when it was virtually broke, and ended up forgiving many of their debts.
This symbiotic history set the stage for current town-gown dealings. The university's library, for example, was built as a project of the Works Progress Administration during the Depression with the stipulation that local residents could use it; the tradition continues. The university also has a history of collaborative efforts with local schools, such as "Operation Achievement," in which 40 junior high school students come to the campus once a week for tutoring.
Still, there are inevitable distances between Georgetown and Southwestern, highlighted during the 1980's when each set out to define a new identity.
Southwestern has spent the last 10 years working to make itself a liberal arts college of national repute, and it has largely succeeded. The endowment was tripled to exceed $125 million, and faculty salaries were boosted to competitive levels. The academic mission was more tightly focused as the number of degrees offered was cut from nine to four. Teaching was emphasized over scholarship, and the size of the student body rose from just under 1,000 to the 1,200 target. The number of applicants has since jumped 130 percent, allowing the university to be ever more selective in admissions.
This success has not come without some cost to the university's relationship with Georgetown. "The big impacts on the town are positive, and the university is so important here that nobody likes to talk about the negatives," said the head of a local business who asked not to be identified. "But it's clear that the university's priorities have changed and that Georgetown just isn't as important to them as it used to be."
 
'Little Things That Add Up'
 This longtime resident complained that on several recent occasions people at the university had committed themselves to help with local projects only to back out later. "It's little things that add up to an impression that as an institution Southwestern doesn't see itself tied to Georgetown on an everyday basis anymore, even though on some major issues, like economic development, it really does deliver," said the business owner.
Roy B. Shilling Jr., who as university president since 1981 has led its move to establish a national reputation, generally acknowledges the changed focus. "In several important ways we have redefined the meaning of town and gown for Southwestern," he said. "Our hometown is here and we have deep roots in this community, but our mandate in recent years has been to develop and expand our ties to constituencies in every major city in Texas and across the country. In many ways Dallas, Houston and San Antonio are our towns as well as Georgetown."
While Southwestern was broadening its horizons, Georgetown was coping with the boom and bust of the 1980's Texas economy. The population grew more than 50 percent, to 14,800 from 9,800 inhabitants, and it struggled to avoid becoming an Austin suburb.
Once an important way station for cattle drivers on the Chisholm Trail, Georgetown had suffered the economic decline experienced by many small towns during the mid-1900's. By the late 1970's many buildings on Main Street and on the courthouse square were deteriorating; some were boarded up.
Those structures, most dating from 1885 to 1905, became the focus of Georgetown's effort to retain a small-town identity. Ornate limestone facades were restored as part of an $8 million project that renovated some 50 buildings between 1983 and 1986. Now the square is lined with restaurants, shops and professional offices.
The university played no role in this project, but was drafted into a campaign to draw new businesses to Georgetown. On June 1, 1989, Mr. Shilling signed a resolution committing the university to support the town's economic development plan, making specific promises to do things like putting on receptions to promote the city to industrial prospects. By all accounts the promises have been kept.
Still, in Georgetown personal rather than institutional initiatives often produce the clearest results. For one example, since 1988 Southwestern has helped the local school raise $325,000 in foundation money for "Partners in Reading," a joint computer-based program that helps develop verbal skills in those from kindergarten age to adults who did not complete high school. That program grew out of a late-night phone call from Mr. Shilling welcoming a new school superintendent.

HEADLINE: Industrial Revolution

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein

 BODY:
SOMETIMES, in a town-gown relationship, the gown can remake the town and become more stylish itself. Ask George Bugliarello.
In his 18 years as president of what is now Polytechnic University in downtown Brooklyn, Mr. Bugliarello has shepherded the institution and the neighborhood through a $1 billion-plus construction program called Metrotech -- a 16-acre, university-corporate park that has risen in what was once a rundown neighborhood. 
 The development, one of several projects that herald the rebirth of downtown Brooklyn as a business and commercial district, is considered by many people in academia, real estate and government to be a prime example of how a university can improve its environment, and by doing so enhance its own image.
Metrotech includes four new commercial buildings with 2.9 million square feet of office space. The Brooklyn campus of Polytechnic, which consisted largely of a converted and modernized 150-year-old razor-blade factory, has a new, $42 million library that includes the New York State Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications.
Plans call for more commercial buildings, a total of five million square feet of office space, the bringing of 16,000 jobs to the area and the continued renovation and expansion of the university, which is generally rated in the top 5 percent academically of all United States colleges and universities.
"The Metrotech complex has really provided a wonderful foundation for the redevelopment of downtown Brooklyn," said Robert B. Catell, president and chief executive officer of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, a participant in the complex. "It has brought together the business community and the education community and offered a wonderful alternative for firms that are thinking of leaving the city."
The genesis of Metrotech can be traced to the early 1970's, when Mr. Bugliarello was dean of the College of Engineering at the University of Illinois at Chicago Circle. He and the college received a National Science Foundation grant to study the role of engineering schools in the community.
"We came to the conclusion that indeed the engineering schools were potentially a good resource for the community," Mr. Bugliarello said.
In 1973, before the report was finished, he became president of Polytechnic. There he found that before he could act on the report's conclusions he would have to help Polytechnic emerge from "a very difficult time."
Founded in 1854 as the Brooklyn Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute, the university had been known as Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and was renowned for its distinguished faculty. Budget problems surfaced in the late 1960's, the result of cuts in Federal support and a decline in engineering enrollment nationally.
In 1973, just as Mr. Bugliarello was taking over the reins, Polytechnic was forced to merge with New York University's School of Engineering and Science in the Bronx. He and his staff began an intensive student recruitment program, initiated large-scale fund-raising and started an undergraduate engineering program at Polytechnic's Long Island campus in Farmingdale.
In 1975 Mr. Bugliarello proposed to the board of trustees creating a university-industry park in the university's Brooklyn neighborhood, which at the time was a rundown area. "It was difficult to attract students," he said. "It was costing us faculty. Crime has never been too high here, but it was more the perception of a lack of safety than the actual lack of safety."
At the board's behest, he said, "we then started looking for what kind of industry made sense to us."
New York had a powerful industry, but it was not a traditional one -- the use of information and telecommunications in the financial sector, and more generally in the service sector.
 
City Began to Move in Early 80's
 Mr. Bugliarello assembled a team for the project. Providing political savvy was Seymour Scher, former Deputy Comptroller of New York City; he became a senior vice president of the university and president of the Metrotech Corporation, a Polytechnic affiliate.
In early talks with New York City and New York State, Mr. Bugliarello said, "we got very little attention." But in the early 1980's, the city decided to stem what was becoming a major outflow of jobs, primarily to New Jersey, and to create more jobs in the outer boroughs. The city told Polytechnic that if it could find interested companies, discussions could begin about developing the area.
Mr. Catell of Brooklyn Union, who was on the university's board, was interested because the company's building was too constraining. Brooklyn Union gave Mr. Bugliarello a letter of intent saying it would move if other companies came. The Securities Industry Automation Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York and American Stock Exchanges that processes financial transactions, also gave a letter of intent.
It was 1982, and after seeing the letters the city gave the university the go-ahead, "provided we build 350,000 square feet of commercial space, put up an additional academic facility and find a commercial co-developer," Mr. Bugliarello said.
No one in New York was interested. "So we looked at a developer in Cleveland, Forest City Ratner Companies, which had worked on a large industrial park at M.I.T," he said. Forest City is owned by the family of a former New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Bruce C. Ratner. The company agreed.
Meanwhile, New York State was anxious to build regional centers for advanced technology at universities statewide. In 1983, it designated Polytechnic home of the Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications and threw in its financial weight -- a long-term, interest-free $16.5 million loan.
In June 1987, after a three-year study, the New York City Board of Estimate approved Metrotech, which is between the access ramps to the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges. To make the complex more attractive, the city has provided $325 million in subsidies, including site improvements; a 13-year exemption from real estate taxes on new buildings; a 12-year elimination of the commercial rent tax, and a 12-year corporate tax credit of $500 a year for every employee moved to Brooklyn.
As with many redevelopment projects, there were protests. All, however, were settled.
In November 1988, the Chase Manhattan Corporation agreed to shift what is now 6,000 employees to two Metrotech buildings, which are to be completed this spring. With last October's announcement by Bear, Stearns & Company, the financial concern, that it was moving 1,500 employees to Metrotech, the first two buildings have been fully leased. Polytechnic's Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology was completed in February. In the middle of it all is a 3.3-acre, tree-lined commons, the center of a quadrangle that is two sides university, two sides business.
"The creation of Metrotech has given us a campus," Mr. Bugliarello said. "There is no longer that sense of depression, that perception of fear. And it shows that a university can help its community, and at the same time help itself."

HEADLINE: Universities Grope For Lost Image

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
WITH ONE of New Jersey's state colleges named for his family, it is only natural that former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, now the president of Drew University, should be more sensitive than most university officials to the public's image of higher education.
Recently Mr. Kean addressed 400 educators in Philadelphia and leveled with them about how colleges and universities, including Kean College of New Jersey, are now perceived by the public.
 
Ivory Tower Besieged
 "Here is the reality, plain and simple," he told his audience. "Our ivory tower is under siege. People are questioning our mission and questioning who we are. They claim we cost too much, spend carelessly, teach poorly, plan myopically, and when we are questioned, we act defensively." 
 Higher education may have been the last great institution in American society to enjoy unstinting public trust -- but no more. Now, like medicine, religion and other important and once revered fields, higher education is discovering how difficult, and how costly, it can be to be scorned. Louis Harris, the public opinion pollster who has been tracking confidence in public institutions since 1966, says that trust in universities has been ebbing over the last five years. Now, only 25 percent of those polled say they have a great deal of confidence in the people running higher education, as against a high point of 56 percent in 1966.
"Universities did better than other institutions for a while," Mr. Harris said in an interview, "but now they're coming back to the pack."
The loss of public trust has been most dramatic in public higher education. Until the end of the 1980's, the state university systems had enjoyed more than 30 years of steady financial support.
The economic recession of the last few years would have forced the states to moderate spending anyway, but as universities' image grew darker it became easier for legislators to target professors who seemed underworked and administrative staffs that appeared to be bloated. In almost every state, the universities are getting a shrinking percentage of the state's overall spending, an indication, many say, of a public perception that higher education has grown fat.
Part of the reason for universities' unpopularity is a string of unsavory episodes. These include college athletics scandals over point-shaving and improper recruiting; the controversy over the inclusion of non-Western authors in humanities curriculums at the expense of traditional Western figures; a United States Justice Department antitrust suit against Ivy League colleges, which were accused of colluding on financial aid grants; and the disclosure -- for many, the last straw -- that Stanford and other universities had improperly charged the Federal Government for indirect research expenditures that included the upkeep of a yacht and the purchases of personal furniture and flowers.
 
University-Bashing
 Tainted by such allegations and by lingering suspicions among parents and legislators that tuition hikes are not justified, most colleges and universities have indeed come under siege. University-bashing has become so popular that the American Association for Higher Education, an organization of 8,000 administrators, professors and staff members, has chosen as the main topic for its annual conference "Reclaiming the Public Trust." The conference begins today in Chicago.
"It just seemed more and more that higher education was falling out of favor," said Louis S. Albert, a vice president of the association. "Our conclusion was that there has been a real decline in public trust and we need to take steps to reclaim it."
It is not only here that universities are under attack. In England, the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher severely reduced higher education appropriations in 1981. Mrs. Thatcher had determined that while population changes meant fewer college-age students, many voters had grown increasingly convinced that universities were pampered.
"Universities were deeply shocked to have been cut in this way," said Auriol Stevens, director of the universities information unit of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals of the Universities of the United Kingdom. "And they were even more deeply shocked that no one seemed to mind."
To regain their high ground, the universities became more responsive to the needs of British industry, creating private research partnerships and changing curriculums to better prepare students for work. They also established Ms. Stevens' office in London, their first public relations effort to control the debate.
Higher education in the United States may lag a few years behind the United Kingdom in that respect, but it seems to be following a similar path. Catherine T. Stimpson, dean of the graduate school at Rutgers University and a scheduled panelist at the American Association for Higher Education conference, said universities are only partly to blame for the shift in public attitudes.
"If there has been a loss in public trust it has come from two sources: what we've done to ourselves and what has been done to us," Dean Stimpson said. In the first category she includes the athletic scandals, high minority dropout rates and confusion over curriculum. She is more bitter about the second category, which she describes as "a decade of half-truth and distortions about the reality of higher education, all of which culminated in the P.C. debate."
 
A Catch-All Putdown
 P.C., or political correctness, has evolved into a catch-all campus putdown. It is used to accuse universities of pandering to members of minority groups and others who might be considered "victims" by adopting requirements such as multicultural curriculums and codes to ban offensive speech.
Academic traditionalists such as those in the National Association of Scholars have portrayed these trends as an orthodoxy of liberal ideas. And they say the universities' loss of face is deserved. Dinesh D'Souza, the traditionalist author of "Illiberal Education," an indictment of higher education, has said that universities have lost the public's confidence because they "have not given an ample accounting of themselves."
Once the universities' image was tarnished, it didn't take long for the public to turn away. No one knows how long it will take to reclaim this lost trust, but there are signs, such as Stanford's rigorous new accounting system and Harvard's new emphasis on teaching, that universities have gotten the message.
"If those good things start to spread," said former Governor Kean, "then the period for reclaiming trust could be relatively short." On the other hand, he argued, "if we stonewall, if we think we're better than everyone else, if we think we know better, then it will take far longer."

HEADLINE: FOOD;
A Man for All Seasonings

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:
IT IS 10:45 ON A SATURDAY MORNING, and Daniel Boulud, the 37-year-old chef of Le Cirque, strides into the kitchen. Trim and diminutive under a starched chef's jacket and white apron, he wears pin-striped trousers, precisely cuffed, perfectly pleated, and spit-polished shoes. Half of Boulud is a big-city executive; the other half is a shy, fastidious Frenchman who cooked his way off his family's farm to the apex of his craft.
Le Cirque's kitchen is backstage to the most glamorous dining room in Manhattan. Serving both the passing fancies and inflexible tastes of the rich and the urbane, the kitchen has been a major way station on the road from Escoffier's dictums to exotic cuisine. With his instinct for the chemistry of food and a cautious Gallic originality, Boulud turns trends into new classics. 
 "Bonjour, chef!" Boulud is carrying a list of the day's 20 specials in his left hand. His right hand stretches toward the 14 cooks who leave their stations to greet him. "Bonjour!" he says. "Good morning!"
It could be any morning, at almost any country restaurant in France; for a moment, the white-jacketed huddle is family. It was like this when Boulud, the son of a Lyonnais farmer, left his family at 14 to apprentice in Lyons, where he worked 13-hour days for 5 French francs a month. "No one asked if you were happy with the arrangement," he says.
Within three years Boulud moved to Georges Blanc, the three-star restaurant in Vonnas, where his technical skills evolved into flawless technique. He then signed on with Roger Verge in Mougins. It was Verge, Boulud says, who gave him "an energy, a spirit of adventure."
Boulud moved on to Copenhagen to run the kitchen of a restaurant for which Verge was a consultant. There he applied his French technique to unfamiliar ingredients, like elk, lingonberries and a variety of smoked fish. He learned an essential lesson: "With the known, you are in control. With the unknown, you have no choice but to trust your instincts and just cook." The pull between control and inventiveness is still central to Boulud's particular genius.
Boulud worked briefly with Michel Guerard in the south of France, moved to Washington as the private chef for the Frenchman who was head of the European Economic Community delegation and finally settled in New York, where he ran the kitchens at the Polo in the Westbury Hotel and Le Regence in the Plaza Athenee.
By the time Boulud arrived at Le Cirque in 1986, his vivid modernity was already becoming legend. A subtle exoticism has continued to creep into his dishes. He mounds fresh crab claws on a confetti of julienned mango, chayote and almonds and seasons it with lime and coriander, gives a carpaccio of salmon a lemon-grass dressing, wraps a roasted duck breast in a bacon jacket, pairs a puree of fava beans and diced root vegetables with plums and combines roasted pigs' feet with fresh morels and Chinese pea shoots.
On the surface, Boulud is cordial and calm. Other chefs say he has a streak of diplomacy as wide as the Rhone. They credit him with bridging the traditional gulf between what they call the "French chef Mafia" and young, emerging American chefs. But something in the set of his Lyonnais jaw belies the warm, easygoing smile that he flashes for the cameras of food and society magazines. Behind his wire-rimmed glasses, his green eyes flash restlessly. He is easily bored, relentlessly demanding.
As soon as his assistants return to their stations this Saturday, Boulud swings into Type-A French chef personality, moving through his kitchen and finding annoying imperfections along the way.
One hand testing the mettle of the day's lamb, the other rubbing a basil leaf to check its perfume, he instructs an apprentice in the correct cleaning of a sea urchin. "Do you see?" he asks gently. His tone becomes more clipped as he moves to a group of more experienced assistants. "Bon, good," he says, checking stocks and sauces. Not so a melange of leeks and celery root. "Do it again -- you need more bacon," he says. And the flageolets! "You've overcooked them. Here. Let me show you." Without a wasted motion, he demonstrates both dishes in less than five minutes.
"It's like this every day," he says. "You plan. You have perfect control. And then something happens. You can never trust it."
He stalks among the day's food deliveries, checks the refrigerators, tastes a petit four, winks at the French butcher and moves toward the line of stoves where his top three assistants are finishing their lunch preparations. He nods, sniffs and nibbles his way past each. Nervously he consults the clock. He glances at the swinging doors that separate his domain from some of the most demanding palates in the world.
"I do my best work when I don't know what I am doing, when I cook from myself, not from some recipe on a piece of paper," Boulud says.
Still, a scintilla of the unknown causes his knuckles to whiten around the handle of his chef's knife as he chops herbs for a specially requested dish. With their sassy interplay of contrasting flavors, textures and temperatures, his most memorable dishes seem to reflect this tension.
There is also a consistent unifying principle in the cuisine of Boulud -- something that is at once familiar and startling. Boulud brushes a stray leaf of chervil from his trousers and says simply: "I'm French."
 
NAPOLEON OF TUNA WITH A MOSAIC SALAD
(ALL RECIPES ADAPTED FROM DANIEL BOULUD)
 
The salad:
 
 1 1/2 tablespoons lemon juice
 1/4 cup olive oil
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper
 2 artichoke hearts, cooked, cleaned and cut into 1/8-inch cubes
 1 large, ripe tomato, peeled, seeded and cut into 1/8-inch cubes
 4 large white mushrooms, cleaned, stemmed and cut into 1/8-inch cubes
 1 small ripe avocado, peeled and cut into 1/8-inch cubes
 1/4 cup nicoise olives, pitted and coarsely chopped
2 1/2 tablespoons chopped chives
 
The napoleon of tuna:
 1 10-ounce piece of fresh tuna, about 1 inch thick
 1 tablespoon olive oil
 6 slices good quality white sandwich bread, crusts removed, toasted and halved
 1 clove garlic, peeled
 4 tufts mache lettuce, rinsed and dried.
1. In a small bowl, whisk together the lemon juice, olive oil, salt and pepper. Put the artichoke hearts, tomato, mushrooms, avocado, olives and chives in a large glass or ceramic bowl, toss with half the dressing and set aside.
2. Preheat the broiler. Brush the tuna with the olive oil. Place under the broiler, 4 inches from the heat and broil until rare at center, about 3 to 4 minutes per side. Brush both sides of the tuna steak with the remaining dressing. Refrigerate until cold.
3. To assemble the napoleon, rub the toast with the garlic clove and discard the clove. With a sharp knife cut the tuna steak on an angle into 12 thin slices. Cover each piece of toast with one layer of sliced tuna; trim the edges. Stack three slices of toast to make each napoleon.
4. Put each napoleon in the center of a serving plate. Spread a layer of the salad on top of each napoleon. Garnish with a tuft of mache.
Yield: Four servings.
 
SWEET LEMON TART WITH PLUM TOMATOES AND VERBENA
 
The pastry:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
 1/4 teaspoon baking powder
 7 tablespoons unsalted butter, chilled and cut into small pieces
 3/4 cup confectioners' sugar
 1 egg, lightly beaten
 
The tomatoes:
 1 cup sugar
 1 1-inch piece lemon peel
 1 verbena tea bag
 1/2 cup water
 6 fresh, ripe plum tomatoes, about 1 1/2 pounds, peeled, cored, seeded and quartered lengthwise
 
The custard:
 3 lemons, peeled to the pulp, seeded and cut into thick slices
 1 egg yolk
 2 whole eggs
 1/2 cup sugar
 3/4 cup heavy cream
 1 tablespoon grated lemon rind.
1. In a small bowl, combine the flour and baking powder. Set aside. Put the butter and confectioners' sugar in the bowl of an electric mixer and beat until smooth. Add the egg, beat for a few seconds, then add the flour mixture all at once. Beat the ingredients until just incorporated, about 1 minute. Shape the dough into a flat disk, cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
2. Meanwhile, put the sugar, lemon peel and verbena tea bag in a saucepan, add the water and bring to a boil. Add the tomatoes and simmer gently over medium-low heat until they are soft, about 20 minutes. With a slotted spoon, remove the tomatoes to a plate covered with paper towels. Pat dry and set aside. Let the syrup simmer gently until reduced to1/3 cup, about 10 minutes. Set aside.
3. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Sprinkle a handful of flour onto a flat surface. Roll the dough into a large circle, 1/8-inch thick, and gently press it into a 10-inch tart pan. Prick the bottom with a fork, line the shell with wax paper, fill with pie weights or dried beans and bake until golden, about 15 to 20 minutes. Set aside to cool.
4. Put the lemon slices, egg yolk, whole eggs, sugar and cream in a blender and puree until smooth. Strain, and stir in the lemon rind. Pour 1/4 cup of the lemon custard into the tart shell. Arrange the tomato wedges, cut side down, in a circle at the center of the tart and slowly pour in the remaining custard. Bake until the custard sets, about 30 to 40 minutes. Set aside to cool. Cut into slices and drizzle 2 teaspoons of syrup around each slice.
Yield: Six to eight servings.
 
COLD CELERY SOUP WITH PINK RADISHES
 
 1 teaspoon olive oil
 2 medium leeks, white parts only, well rinsed and thinly sliced
 3/4 pound celery, rinsed and thinly sliced
 2 teaspoons curry powder
 6 cups chicken broth, homemade or low-sodium canned
 1 white boiling potato, about 1/3 pound, peeled and diced
 1 bunch pink radishes, rinsed, green tops reserved
 1 cup low-fat yogurt
 1/2 teaspoon Tabasco sauce
 Salt and freshly ground pepper
 12 shrimp, steamed, peeled, cleaned and cut in half lengthwise.
1. Warm the olive oil in a stockpot over medium-low heat. Add the leeks, celery and curry, and saute for 4 minutes. Add the chicken broth and potatoes, bring to a boil, lower the heat and simmer for 17 minutes.
2. Meanwhile, finely chop all but 2 of the radishes. Discard any bruised radish greens and finely chop the rest. When the soup has simmered for 17 minutes, add the chopped radishes and greens and simmer for an additional 3 minutes.
3. Puree the soup in a blender until smooth and strain through a sieve. Refrigerate until cold.
4. When the soup is thoroughly chilled, stir in the yogurt and Tabasco. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Thinly slice the two remaining radishes, float a few slices in the center of each serving bowl and arrange six of the shrimp halves around the radishes like the petals of a flower.
Yield: Four servings.
 
CHICKEN WITH MORELS, FAVA BEANS AND SPRING POTATOES
 
 1 teaspoon salt
 1 pound fresh fava beans, shelled
 2 tablespoons vegetable oil
 1 3 1/2 pound chicken, cut into 8 pieces
 1/2 pound small new potatoes, scrubbed and halved
16 garlic cloves, skin intact
 8 small shallots, peeled
 2 tablespoons fresh thyme leaves
 2 bay leaves
 1 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 4 cups fresh morels, stems removed, cleaned and cut into 1/2-inch slices
1 1/2 cups chicken broth, homemade or low-sodium canned
 3 tablespoons minced chives.
1. Add 1/2 teaspoon salt to a large pot of boiling water and cook the fava beans for 1 minute. Drain, submerge them in ice water, drain again, peel off the outer skins and set aside.
2. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a large cast-iron skillet over medium-high heat. When hot, add the chicken, skin side down, and cook until golden brown, about 3 minutes. Remove from the heat, turn the chicken and add the potatoes, garlic, shallots, thyme and bay leaves. Add the remaining salt and the pepper and put the skillet in the oven.
3. Meanwhile, heat the remaining oil in a large saute pan over high heat. When hot, add the morels in one layer and saute until golden brown. Add the chicken broth, bring to a boil and remove from heat.
4. When the chicken has roasted for 10 minutes, pour the morels over the chicken. Stir until the vegetables are coated with broth. Continue to bake the chicken, basting with the pan juices, until tender, about 20 to 25 minutes longer.
5. Add the fava beans and chives to the chicken. Stir until the beans are coated with the pan juices and bake for 2 to 3 minutes more. Arrange the pieces of chicken in the center of a warm platter, pour the vegetables and pan juices over the meat.
Yield: Four servings.

HEADLINE: Another Opening, Another Show

 BODY:
The curtain may have rung down on commercial touring classical acting troupes in America, but the Acting Company is keeping the tradition alive. The nonprofit group based in New York is a bridge between conservatory training for actors and the profession. For the last six months the 16-member ensemble has been on the road with Shakespeare's "Midsummer Night's Dream," directed by Joe Dowling, and Athol Fugard's "Blood Knot," directed by Tazewell Thompson. After stops in 23 states, the company begins performances at the John Jay Theater in Manhattan on Monday for a 10-day run of both plays in repertory ending April 15. 
 During the tour, from Burlington, Vt., to Little Rock, Ark., from Iowa City to Green Bay, Wis., members of the company recorded their impressions of the road. Here are excerpts from their tape.
 
Dan Berkey -- We get these high school kids kicking and screaming at "an educational experience." Inside of 20 minutes they discover we are cool. They relate to us in an MTV kind of way that makes us subversive. Shakespeare becomes exciting, fun. At the end, when they leap out of their chairs, you know something has happened.
 
Lisa Benavides -- On the road you see how empty some of these downtown areas are. You see how the economy is affecting everyone. And you feel touched that you can get someone from a "Curley Sue" movie audience to go to a play and have a truly enjoyable time.
 
Jeffrey Wright -- I was sitting in the hotel bar in Green Bay, and this guy I was talking to was surprised we were doing Shakespeare. "You're doing Shakespeare? Here? I love Shakespeare!" He was so excited and wanted to know when and where the show was. They have nothing like that there.
 
Rainn Wilson -- What is great is playing to the whole nation, to its ugliness and the horror of some of its consumer-mall-culture ways. At the same time, it's glorious to see how magnificent the country is and how wonderfully spirited the people are.
 
Jonathan Earl Peck -- After a performance of "Blood Knot," the audience, which had been very enthralled, began to discuss the play. I sat in the room with my baseball cap on backward and listened. At the end I stood up and thanked them for coming. They looked at me quizzically and one guy said, "Were you in the play?" You forget that there are people not used to seeing actors walk in the street.
 
Derek Meader -- It is important, even revolutionary, to see a black man playing Oberon, a Puerto Rican woman playing Titania and a fairy played by a big strapping man or a small Oriental woman. When people end up loving it, we make a strong point. We become, as Shakespeare said, like a mirror held up to society. (Photographs by George Gryzenia for The New York Times)

TITLE: MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM, A (PLAY); BLOOD KNOT, THE (PLAY)

HEADLINE: TALES FROM THE BABY FACTORY

 BODY:
Couples suffering from infertility technology are fighting a war on many fronts. They must compromise their attendance at work, undergo invasive procedures, have their sexual relationship on display, cope with family and personal differences and constantly keep abreast of the discriminatory, ever-changing insurance regulations affecting the reimbursement they may receive for their treatment. What such couples should be spared are the morality-laced parables that seek to define what is "reproductively correct." 
 Assisted reproductive technology is an experiment in consumer medicine brought about by the deliberate economic and political decisions made over the past 10 years. The Federal Government refuses to provide traditional National Institutes of Health funding for the nascent technology, deeming it "fetal research." Since such money was not forthcoming in the face of consumer demands, the present unregulated situation has come about. The ramifications of the Government's desire to drop the ball on this issue will continue to be felt throughout the current decade. The absence of research funding will greatly slow the accumulation of the knowledge about these techniques and keep the patient's cost high.
 
NANNETTE SANTORO, M.D.
Director, Division of Reproductive Endocrinology, University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey
Newark

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: $2 Million-Plus;
High End Sales Rise

 BODY:
For the past few months buyers, sellers and real estate brokers have had their poles in the water in a search for signs of a bottoming out in the cooperative apartment market.
The most recent prediction that a market recovery may be near comes from The Corcoran Group, a Manhattan residential sales company. It holds out as evidence a surge in sales of apartments selling for $2 million or more. 
 "Historically," said Barbara Corcoran, head of the firm, "the highest end of the market is the first to recover during a sustained recession."
In an analysis of sales completed from September 1990 to March 1991 and from last September to March of this year, the Corcoran Group found an 80 percent rise (from 41 to 74 sales) on Park and Fifth Avenues and a 100 percent rise (from 7 to 14 sales) on Central Park West. For the same periods, the study showed a slight increase in the average selling price -- from $3.45 million to $3.6 million -- for apartments on Park and Fifth Avenues. The average price on Central Park West remained stable at about $2.8 million.
By the Corcoran Group's standards, $2 million might be characterized as the low end of the high end. But it still buys a pretty nice apartment. One $2 million sale was of an eight-room penthouse on Fifth Avenue in the 60's with a greenhouse and maid's quarters. In a $2 million sale on Central Park West, the buyer got 11 rooms including a 50-foot living room, a library and an eat-in kitchen.

HEADLINE: Prime Area Town-House Sales Rebound

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
TOWN-HOUSE sales in Greenwich Village, the Upper East Side and other prime Manhattan and Brooklyn neighborhoods have rebounded after a three-year downward drift. In recent reports, brokerage companies said that last year brought their highest volume of sales since 1988, when the phenomenal price rises of the mid-80's for town houses shifted into reverse.
Many of the buyers in the market in 1991 were responding, the realtors said, to softening prices and the start of the drop in mortgage interest rates. But practical considerations aside, the upsurge in sales also is strong evidence that town-house living still has a strong appeal in a city where space is a precious commodity and most people must live in apartments with no more charm than a shoebox. 
 "I wanted to live in a brownstone," said Dr. Danielle Gilman, who last month bought her first residence, a 19th- century house on a tree-lined street in Greenwich Village. "I didn't look at regular apartments. As long as I was going to be buying, I wanted the things like a fireplace, high ceilings, the features that make you feel you are in a home."
After looking mostly at floor-through apartments in town houses because that was all she thought she could afford, she found a tiny house she was able to buy for a price in the low $400,000's. It is about as different from a cookie-cutter apartment as it could be. It is triangular in shape and has a top-floor master bedroom with a skylight that suggests the Parisian garret where Rodolfo met Mimi in "La Boheme."
Sotheby's International Realty, which tracks town-house sales in Manhattan south of 96th Street, recorded a 26 percent increase in the sale of one- and two-family houses, from 50 in 1990 to 63 in 1991. At the same time, the dollar volume remained virtually the same, meaning there was a 20 percent drop in the average selling price of town houses. The average was $1,710,019 and the range was $200,000 to $12 million.
"I sense that people got tired of waiting and decided to bite the bullet," said Joan Ambrose, a principal of Ambrose-Mar Elia Company, which recorded 69 town-house sales last year, including transactions on properties in the low 100's blocks of the Upper West Side.
There also was a feeling among buyers, some brokers said, that prices had bottomed out.
Sales jumped noticeably during the third quarter, which Ms. Ambrose believes was influenced by the resolution of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The firm recorded 14 sales each in the first and second quarters and then 24 in the third quarter before the year ended with 17 in the final quarter.
But prospective town-house buyers looking for the same free fall in prices that hit some segments of the co-op and condominium market were dissappointed. There were no fire sales or auctions for town houses.
THE main reason is that one- and two-family town houses are relatively scarce. Few are being built theses days, and the city's Department of Finance counts only 1,696 residences that it categorizes as single-family mansions or town houses. By contrast, the Real Estate Board of New York puts the number of co-op and condominium apartments in the city at about 120,000.
Adding to the appeal of town houses is that they tend to be in historic districts and in such gentrified old neighborhoods as Park Slope and Chelsea. Others are in attractive enclaves in otherwise troubled areas.
The Upper East Side and Greenwich Village saw the strongest increase in sales last year. But the Upper West Side was not part of the market's 1991 upswing. Brokers said that sellers and buyers just were not in sync when it came to prices.
Harlem, an area that saw an influx of enthusiastic middle-class town house buyers during the 1980's, has not regained the momentum of the past decade. There are no statistics on the volume of sales because so many transactions are private. But Harlem realtors say sales have slowed to a trickle compared to the levels of the 1980's. One reason is that there are not enough properties to meet the demand.
In the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope and Prospect Park, one brokerage company that tracks sales in those areas said that house prices actually bumped up a bit last year. Roberta Faulstick, a senior vice president of William B. May, said the average closing price went from $489,000 in 1990 to $518,000 in 1991. In 1990, the selling prices ranged from $200,000 to $767,000 and in 1991 the range was $320,000 to $915,000.
But realtors say selling prices of homes in other Brooklyn town-house neighborhoods, among them Fort Greene, Clinton Hill and Bedford-Stuyvesant, have fallen since 1990.
Eva M. Daniels, a broker whose territory includes those neighborhoods, used sales on South Portman Place, a prime block in Fort Greene, to illustrate the trend. "The selling prices for the block peaked in 1988 at $500,000," said Mrs. Daniels, "but recent sales there have been in the range of $350,000 to $375,000 and a house there recently went for $300,000."
Mrs. Daniels said that some people who have $500,000 to spend are now looking in Park Slope, a more established neighborhood.
While overall the town-house market held up well against the ills of New York's weakened economy, some brokerage companies saw significance in a noticeable increase in sales of Manhattan town houses selling for less than $1 million.
Sotheby's International Realty, for example, found that by the end of 1991 24 town houses had sold in Manhattan for under $1 million. That number was the highest since 1987 and was more than twice as many as were sold the year before when only 11 town house sales were recorded at under $1 million.
But 1991 did bring at least one eye-popping sale.
Last April, Leslie Wexner, who owns The Limited clothing chain, got $12 million for his 13,000-square-foot, six-story house at 5 East 74th Street. Mr. Wexner, who sold it to the German Goverment, had paid $5.8 million for the house in 1985.
That deal nipped at the heels of a 1989 transaction at $12.5 million, the highest price ever paid for a Manhattan house. The house was 603 Park Avenue at 64th Street.
"I THINK the East Side in the 70's and 80's is still the neighborhood of choice for people who have $2 million or more to spend on a residence," said Lillian Fisher, a vice president of Sotheby's.
In Greenwich Village, prices for town houses have eased significantly.
"It was not so long ago," said Robert Eychner, a principal of Eychner Properties, "that an owner of a town house in the Village on a really good block could name his price and get it. Price adjustments for town houses in the village came late in the economic cycle and followed co-ops, condominiums and lofts. But the adjustment did come, and now there are some very nice deals out there"
Mr. Eychner is negotiating a sale on a home off Fifth Avenue on a choice block just to the north of Washington Square in which the owner is expected to accept $1 million less than the original asking price of $2.8 million.
A few years ago, when people came into Mr. Eychner's office with $500,000 to $600,000 to spend on a town house, he would have to tell them that there was nothing available. "Today when buyers come to us with that kind of budget looking for an apartment or a loft," he said, "we might ask them if they are interested in a house. There has been that much of a change in the market."
After a deal to buy a brownstone duplex fell through, Dr. Gilman discovered a house that was just close enough to the top of her budget to be worth a look. She believes that its peculiar shape --triangular -- and configuration, helped her bring the seller down from the original asking price of $495,000. The house has a kitchen, dining room and laundry on the ground floor, a living room on the second, a bath and dressing room on the third and a bedroom on the fourth.
LOUIS B. KAYE, president of L.B. Kaye, one of the most active town house brokerages, believes that the flexibility of sellers in Greenwich Village is giving sellers on the Upper West Side their strongest competition.
"Homes are not moving on the West Side now," said Mr. Kaye. "One reason is that owners are staying pretty firm on their asking prices. In the meantime, buyers are finding that they can get a town house in the village or on the East Side if they are willing to go east of Lexington Avenue, for what sellers on the West Side are asking."
Of the 69 sales of Manhattan properties tracked by brokers last year, 52 were on the Upper East Side, 14 were in Greenwich Village and only 3 were on the Upper West Side.
"There are plenty of listings," said Mr. Kaye, "but right now buyers' interest is just not there."
Jessie Burnett, an agent with Webb & Brooker, the largest Harlem-based real estate company, has a problem that is the opposite of Mr. Kaye's. "I don't think we have more than a dozen listings." she said.
The asking prices fall into the $250,000 to $350,000 range and most are in established town house areas like Striver's Row, along Convent Avenue near the campus of City College or on Hamilton Terrace.
"In most cases they are in very good condition because the same family has been in them for 40 years or more," she said. "But to buy a home in that price range takes a salary of at least $100,000. People who are in the market today are looking for something in the $150,000 to $200,000 range."
As recently as the early 80's homes in these areas could be had for $70,000 to $150,000. Those in need of repair or on less well known blocks could be picked up for $50,000 or less.
"In the late 70's," said Russell M. Banks, a vice president of Webb & Brooker, speaking from the vantage point of 12 years as a realtor in Harlem,"Harlem was the last place in Manhattan where you could get a brownstone or row house for less $100,000."
Although most buyers now realize that Harlem is not likely to become a gentrified neighborhood like the Upper West Side, Mr. Banks said, more areas would have been upgraded if it were not for the enactment of the city's S.R.O. law. In 1985, in an effort to stem the rising tide of homeless people, the city put a moratorium on the conversion of single-room-occupancy hotels and rooming houses into apartments and single family residences.
"I understand the motive behind the law," Mr. Banks said. "But it helped to kill the market in Harlem. A lot of people who could not meet their mortgages took boarders to hold on to their houses. If they could convert their homes back into single- or two-family residences, I think there would be a strong market for them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Danielle Gilman in the town house she bought last month in Greenwich Village and is now remodeling. Originally seeking a floor-through apartment in a town house, she found that lowered prices made it possible for her to purchase a whole house. (Steve Hart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Perspectives: City Housing Cutbacks;
New York Slashing an Array of Programs

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
OPPORTUNITY knocked, and Alice Davis responded. "I'd better jump on this," she remembers telling herself.
She was thinking of buying a new two-family house built with city and state assistance in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. She bought just in time. Drastic cuts sought by Mayor David N. Dinkins for a planned revision in the capital budget for coming years would all but end city assistance to this and other housing production programs. 
 "I was hearing rumors that the city was cutting out funds for the program," said Ms. Davis, a 39-year-old repair-service attendant for the New York Telephone Company. "I said to myself, 'with all the layoffs, how could they go on building houses?' "
Ms. Davis has gone to contract on a $154,000 two-family house being built on DeKalb Avenue through the New York Housing Partnership's production program. There are 68 houses in the development, named Sojourner Truth Homes, on three blocks off Stuyvesant Avenue near Broadway. Sixty have been sold. Occupancy will start in May.
Completion of this development and others for which funds are already committed is not affected by the prospective cuts. But the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has been told by the Office of Management and Budget to find $510 million by the end of April to slash from the four-year capital spending plan that the Mayor announced in January. City spending would fall from the planned $1.34 billion to $835 million over the four years starting with fiscal 1993, which begins July 1.
The agency has responded that to accomplish this it will have to eliminate the major production programs -- new houses for moderate- to middle-income people and gut rehabilitations of vacant buildings. Funds that help existing rental housing also would be cut sharply.
A key program that would be spared is the newly announced plan to rehabilitate occupied, tax-foreclosed, city-managed buildings in preparation for stepped-up transfers to private or nonprofit management. There are 3,200 such buildings with 33,000 apartments, currently costing the city about $130 million a year to run.
The cutbacks would mean no city money to support the Partnership program or the Nehemiah program, through which church organizations develop housing in East Brooklyn and the South Bronx. The Partnership also gets state assistance. Early Thursday morning the Legislature adopted a budget that includes funds for affordable housing programs, but it comes on a matching basis, so that the city could lose its share if it makes no appropriation itself. The Nehemiah program might qualify for funds under a newly available Federal program, known by the acronym HOME.
The vacant building program, under which both private and city capital has been used for gut rehabilitations of city-owned buildings, would cease. A gradual phase-out would end city aid to gut rehabilitations of low-income rentals by nonprofits through the Local Initiatives Support Corporation and the Enterprise Foundation, which raise tax-credit financing for the projects.
New city-financed gut rehabilitations that have produced permanent housing for homeless and low-income families, under nonprofit ownership and management, would also cease. Other programs, though surviving, would be cut back severely.
City funding of public-private participation loans for existing rentals -- usually occupied buildings with low-income tenancies getting building-systems replacements -- were set at $80 million last January for the four-year period. They would be cut to $36 million.
City loans to rehabilitate single-room-occupancy buildings for the neediest poor were to have been funded at $68 million. That would drop to $15 million.
ALL of this is a striking reversal of the plans Mayor Dinkins announced two years ago. At that time the housing department under a newly appointed commissioner, Felice Michetti, was looking forward to administering a balanced preservation and production program that would essentially complete a 10-year housing plan begun by Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1986, but with greater emphasis on nonprofit participation.
With the recession, many housing specialists would agree on the need for shifting the balance in the allocation of city resources toward preservation-oriented from production-oriented policies. The question is how to strike the balance.
Through the Housing Parnership program, a formidable housing delivery system has been established, capable of developing, financing, building and marketing for-sale housing citywide. Chase Community Development Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Bank affiliate that financed Sojourner Truth Homes, has itself committed nearly $200 million to assisted-housing production in the city. The investment has provided ownership opportunity, construction work and neighborhood stabilization.
THE stabilization effect is on view in the vicinity of the Sojourner Truth development, which is named for an upstate woman who ran an underground railroad for slaves.
The homes are on scattered sites along Hart, Pulaski and Kosciusko Streets and DeKalb Avenue. It was a dreary neighborhood of blight amid demolished sites when construction began.
The builder, The Hudson Companies, a Brooklyn company that has built 400 housing units through the Partnership program, bought vacant city land for 10 of the houses at a city auction in 1990. The city gradually expanded the site by adding new parcels, so that the development has transformed a broad area.
Hudson's community-based partner in the project is the Northeast Brooklyn Housing Development Corporation. Nicholas Lembo, who is also president of a Brooklyn contracting company, Monadnock Construction, William Fowler 3d and Alan R. Bell are the principals of The Hudson Companies.
Certain characteristics of the homes are distinctive. First, they preserve the street line. There are no curb cuts for parking pads. Instead, parking is at the rear. At the end of a row of houses is a driveway entrance to the commonly owned paved drive that separates the rear yards of back-to-back houses. Buyers get one rear space on their properties.
The 2,760-square-foot houses, with 920 square feet on each of three levels, are described as two and a half stories because the lowest level is a basement, half below street level. However, broad metal-guarded windows give them extensive light.
The owner can use the space as a family room, and add a bathroom as well. But there is no practical way of building an outside entrance to the space, so that it cannot be subdivided by an owner to create a second rental apartment. This is a possibility buyers often consider.
The rental apartment is on the third floor, entered through a separate door at the top of a common concrete stoop. The facade uses precast lintels and decorative brick to create design interest. The architect is the firm of Harden/Van Arnam of Brooklyn.
The buyers at Sojourner Truth Homes are local working people who have managed some savings.
"YOU always wanted a place of your own, a little backyard, but most of the places you see are out of your league," said Jimmy Talton, a purchasing agent for a small Brooklyn manufacturing company, who bought a Sojourner Truth house with his wife, Daisy. They had lived for 20 years in Eleaner Roosevelt Houses, a public housing project.
Now, said Ms. Davis, it costs no more to own than to rent. "You get something you can own and control," she said. Ms. Davis, who is divorced, will be moving with her two children, Josette, 21, and Joseph, 18, both college students.
Another house was sold to Betty and Seymour Clarke, who have a 2-year-old son, Galen. They are moving from a $600-a-month rental in Park Slope. Mrs. Clarke's sister will rent the upstairs apartment.
"The house is something we would be able to handle even without the rent," said Mrs. Clarke, who calculates her monthly costs at $1,100 to $1,200, before rental income. Mrs. Clarke works for a law firm; her husband is a printer.
The builder, The Hudson Companies, calculates after-tax housing costs to buyers at about $500 a month. The buyer needs about $15,000 in cash for the down payment and closing costs.
It is possible because of a $50,000 subsidy per house ($25,000 per apartment), $30,000 from the state and $20,000 from the city. It is that subsidy level that is in jeopardy because of budget cuts. If it doesn't come from some level of government, new home construction will not be feasible in New York City, even on free land, for buyers in the $25,000-to-$50,000 income range.

HEADLINE: Talking: Minorities;
Removing Barriers To Loans

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
MINORITY and ethnic home buyers have long sensed that they do not get equal consideration when they apply for mortgages and suspected that they were rejected more hastily than whites with similar financial profiles.
Studies have recently confirmed this. A Federal Reserve Board study based on 5.3 million applications from 9,300 banks, published last October, found minorities twice as likely to be rejected as whites with the same household income. 
 A similar study by the Department of Housing and Urban Development found that lenders in the New York City area had a particularly bad record on minority loans. This was followed by a study by Barry Leeds & Associates, a Manhattan financial market research firm whose findings, released in February, showed subtle levels of bias in the less-than-helpful way many loan officers handled nonwhite applicants.
Bankers have since concluded that a major reason for the high rejection rate may be that many minority and ethnic applicants, among them recent immigrants, do not have credit or employment histories that conform to anticipated norms.
As a consequence, the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) have issued what they call "clarified" guidelines to encourarge lenders to become more flexible in their interpetation of qualifying criteria. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are Government-chartered corporations that buy mortgages from lenders. In making a secondary market for home loans, these agencies set lending standards for the entire mortgage industry.
Derrick Cephas, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, sent a letter to some 500 lending institutions reiterating the theme.
Mark Willis, a member of the American Bankers' Association Residential Mortgage Task Force, who is working on similar goals, said: "We have all begun re-examining the criteria to make sure we are excluding only those people who won't pay and making sure we don't overlook people who will."
For a loan to be salable on the secondary market, the borrower needs to show a stable income for the prior two years. Under the old guidelines, lenders often held this to mean they had to exclude an applicant who had changed jobs too often in that time or those who had to incorporate part-time earnings, seasonal work or unemployment compensation to maintain a certain income level.
Under the new guidelines all these sources are now considered "good" income.
A lack of credit history also tended to be a drawback. This was particularly hard for some immigrants who are used to dealing only in cash and are not connected to the world of credit cards and American-style banking. The credit history requirement can now be met by documenting a history of timely telephone, rent and utility payments or other proofs that bills are paid on time.
Even certain blots on a credit record will have to be more carefully scrutinized by lending officials before they can form the basis for rejection. "We emphasize that excellent credit does not have to be perfect or spotless, since certain circumstances can be beyond a borrower's control," notes Robert J. Engelstad, Fannie Mae's senior vice president for mortgage and lender standards in his directive to lenders.
Other modifications allow grants from church, municipal or community sources to replace the portion of the down payment that can be supplied by a gift from a relative. Even the definition of "family member" as the source of these funds can now be broadened in many instances to encompass large extended families or the closely-knit "savings clubs" common among certain groups.
In addition, the condition of the home may be evaluated in comparison to others in the neighborhood and not judged by a more arbitrary standard that often exluded many houses. Even if a neighborhood has many offices, stores or gas stations and is thus not strictly a residential area, this should no longer preclude a loan.
DESPITE these changes, reformers fear that deep-rooted practices and attitudes will not alter overnight. Thus they urge potential borrowers who fear they may be rejected to take advantage of counseling services to help them through the mortgage maze.
One of these is Acorn (the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now), a group that helped redraft the language of the Freddie Mac guidelines. It has just opened offices in Brooklyn (call 718-693-6700). It also maintains branches in St. Louis, Dallas, Phildelphia, Houston, New Orleans, Little Rock, Ark., Chicago, Washington, Des Moines and Minneapolis.
John Hemschoot, director of home mortgage standards for Freddie Mac, said that banks and savings and loans associations are expected to respond more rapidly to the directives than independent mortgage companies since these institutions are under greater pressure from regulators to fulfill their responsibilites to minorities and the poor under the Community Reinvestmet Act.
In the New York area, Chemical Bank in January began an Affirmative Mortgage Progam and a Neighborhood Homebuyers' Mortgage Program, both incorporating virtually all the changes in the Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae directives.
These programs should also reduce the regular points charges and application fees and assure any rejected applicant a second review to see if exceptions might be made. They further provide counseling services and a $10 million fund to cover loans that would not be salable on the secondary market because special exceptions are being made, said Carol Parry, Chemical'st managing director for community development. Call (800) 243-6226 for more details.
Chase Manhattan Bank has established a similar program combining counseling services with a redefinition of qualifying criteria. For more information, visit any local branch and ask about the bank's Community Development Programs, or call its New York area mortgage hotline at (718) 797-5441.
Nancy Gordon, vice president of Globe Mortgage, of Hackensack, N.J., which has handled many minority applications in the region, warned, however, that documentation will still be needed to substantiate deviation from the norm.
If, for example, a car is to be sold to raise money for a downpayment, rather than tapping into a long-term savings account, proof of this sale will have to be produced. Similarly, independent corroboration of a lengthy illness or family breakup will be needed to explain a credit problem.

HEADLINE: ART;
At Yale, a Photographer's Images of Pain

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
SEBASTIAO SALGADO'S fame began in the 1980's with his photographs that showed the effects of starvation sweeping across Africa. Then came the shots of the Serra Pelada gold mine in his native Brazil. These were taken for The New York Times Magazine, as was a scene of a Kuwaiti oil field, one of a series published in the issue of June 9, 1991.
Though the photographer has not focused exclusively on human anguish, it would seem that during his 19-year career he has been on hand for just about every major disaster, except for Bhopal, Chernobyl and the Challenger explosion. Hence, there are those who regard him as something of global ambulance chaser. Otherwise, the response to his images has been widespread admiration together with honors on the order of the W. Eugene Smith Memorial Award in 1982 and citation as Photojournalist of the Year by the International Center for Photography in 1986. 
 Now Connecticut viewers have a chance to form their own opinions. The Yale University Art Gallery is offering a score of Salgado black-and-whites excerpted from "An Uncertain Grace," a show generated by the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art that is touring the nation. The Yale display was inaugurated by the photographer when he recently visited the university as a guest of the Chubb Fellowship.
Mr. Salgado's subjects seldom inspire anything less than awe. In Mali he records a solitary naked figure who stands supported by a stick on the desert that has filled in a lake bed. It is hard to tell if the figure is a man or a boy, and it hardly matters, for he's barely more than the sum of his bones, which echo the branches of a dead tree in the background. A younger skeleton, also in Mali, hangs in a sling being weighed in order to establish how much food he needs. The dial is illegible, but the needle is only one-quarter the way around.
But the final word on starvation is the picture of a man laying out a child according to the Coptic rite in Ethiopia. The corpse is as desiccated as a mummy except for swollen hands that lie, little curled paws, on what was once a belly, while the bent-over father hovers above. It seems safe to say that in all of art there is no Pieta as affecting, and there it is, in a small tent made of translucent plastic.
When interviewed by John Bloom in the November 1990 issue of Photo Metro magazine, Mr. Salgado expressed admiration for Cartier-Bresson, W. Eugene Smith, Walker Evans, Alvarez Bravo and others. He also mentioned writers -- Gabriel Garcia Marquez, for one. His photographs, however, speak of 19th-century French Realism -- in word and paint -- and none more so than those in the gold-mine series. In a cut that looks as deep as the Grand Canyon and twice as wide, labor myriad figures, including one who has just scaled one of the countless ladders lashed to the rock walls. In panoramic views of the scene, the figures swarm as if they were larvae just hatched from the eggs of a monstrous insect.
Noting that he is concerned with paying homage to the working class, Mr. Salgado said in this interview that the old ways of producing are "fast disappearing." Yet his pictures suggest the very opposite. In the age of high technology, the need for backbreaking labor is clearly as great as ever, if not greater.
But Mr. Salgado may be a hard-core romantic and optimist. The son of a cattle rancher and a former economist, he said that the working class is one group he can get "inside of." Whether or not this is the case, he always leaves his subjects their dignity, as did Lewis Hine, with whom he has often been compared.
Most photographers would italicize aspects of horror in order to convey their own feelings and to make the viewer feel guilty. Mr. Salgado lets a situation speak for itself. He does not, he says, interfere with "anything in reality" or with the people that he photographs; he does not want to give his audience "a bad conscience," nor does he seek out the picturesque aspects of pain and destitution, although his Madonna and Child from Ethiopia seem too good to be true.
There are pictures of suffering that should never have been taken -- notably the famous shot of the Vietnamese child on fire. But whatever the outrage engendered by Mr. Salgado's prints, it is not directed at the photographer, because somehow he seems trustworthy.
Still, that is only one opinion. At their first publication, the Kuwait pictures, in which the landscape is nothing but sludge and lakes of oil, came with an essay by Martin Wade. This tells of Mr. Salgado burying an Iraqi soldier he found under a coat of oil. A fellow journalist asked him if he did this "so that no other photographers would get the shot." Oddly enough, Mr. Salgado dignified the question with an answer. In Brazil, he explained, the soul of a body left unburied would get no rest for all eternity.
The photographs of Sebastiao Sal gado remain through April 19 at the Yale University Art Gallery, 1111 Chapel Street in New Haven.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Among the photographs by Sebastiao Salgado on display at the Yale University Art Gallery are those showing a woman and her child at Korem Camp in Ethiopia, the Serra Pelada gold miners of Brazil and oil workers in Kuwait.
