HEADLINE: New Move To Combat Sex Bias in Classroom

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
THE Lawrenceville School is suspending classes on Thursday and Friday so that students and faculty members can attend a conference dealing with the role of sex bias in education. Teachers in the Princeton public schools have begun to monitor one another's classes, in part to insure that girls are being called upon as often as boys.
At Douglass College in New Brunswick, a summer- school program offers girls entering the 11th grade special classes in mathematics, science and engineering. 
 Across the state, an increasing number of New Jersey schools and colleges are taking a hard look at the so-called gender gap and are revising curriculums and teaching methods to eliminate possible bias against girls.
Their efforts received a major boost recently with the release of a report by the American Association of University Women that summarized hundreds of national studies on the subject. The report concluded that girls begin school with roughly the same ability as boys but fall behind in a number of areas, including mathematics, science and self-esteem, by the time they graduate from high school because they receive neither the quality nor the quantity of education that boys do.
For many New Jersey educators, the report seemed to validate what they have been arguing for years. "What is really exciting is that the A.A.U.W. can move some of the research center stage," said Dr. Margaret Crocco, dean of students at the Oak Knoll School of the Holy Child, a girls' elementary and secondary school in Summit.
New Jersey was one of the first states to take charges of sex bias in the classroom seriously. In 1988 it became the first state to attempt to incorporate scholarship on women's studies throughout the college curriculum.
The New Jersey Project, as the effort sponsored by the Department of Higher Education is known, works with both public and private colleges and publishes a hefty journal of scholarly articles and teaching recommendations that is circulated to 1,500 New Jersey educators and 4,000 educators outside the state twice a year.
 
'We Have a Long Way to Go'
 "Some school districts and institutions have done quite well," said Prof. Paula Rothenberg, executive director of the New Jersey Project, "but I think for the most part we have a long way to go."
Oak Knoll was the site of a 1988 conference on sex bias that was attended by public and private school educators and that led to a booklet on ways to eliminate bias against girls in elementary and secondary school curriculums. The booklet has gone through several printings and is being used as a textbook at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I.
The faculty at Oak Knoll carefully examines its curriculum and teaching materials to root out sex bias. Textbooks that ignore women or treat them superficially are eliminated. For example, a 10th-grade history book that included biographies of famous women but did not discuss the lives of everyday women was recently dropped.
"We see that as a primitive approach to women's history," Dr. Crocco said. "We're now trying to understand the way women lived their lives, rather than what they did of value for the public culture, which is a more masculine view of history."
Oak Knoll's advanced-placement American history textbook, with its heavy emphasis on politics and economic history, has also been replaced by a book that takes a more social approach to history. Students spend more time discussing "material culture" -- how people built their homes, for example, and what was in the kitchen.
"We're not eliminating treatment of the Presidents of the United States or the important pieces of legislation, but we've enriched it by understanding what happens in the lives of everyday people," Dr. Crocco said.
 
The 'Evaded' Curriculum
 Emily Style, the diversity coordinator for the Madison public schools, finds herself increasingly addressing in her English classes what the university women's report calls the "evaded" curriculum. She begins discussion of John Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men" by writing on the blackboard statistics about battered women to help students understand the character who is known simply as Curly's wife.
Half the women murdered in the United States, she tells her students, were killed by their husbands or lovers. She juxtaposes the classic 1925 tale of white American affluence, F. Scott Fitzgerald's "Great Gatsby," with Anzia Yezierska's "Breadgivers," a novel published the same year about poor Russian Jews growing up in New York's Lower East Side.
Ms. Style said she was trying to achieve a balance of "windows and mirrors," so that students could learn to understand themselves and others.
"For a lot of kids, the windows at school are looking at the lives of dead white men," she said. "Not that dead white men didn't do a lot of things we can learn from. But if that's the constant diet and there's hardly ever a mirror of your gender or color, it can be terribly damaging."
 
Boys Are Also Affected
 Ms. Style said it was as harmful for boys to learn in a "house of mirrors," since it "gives them a false picture of the planet -- it doesn't give them windows into people not of their gender or race."
Ms. Style co-directs a summer workshop for elementary and secondary school teachers on women's studies for the Wellesley College Center for Research on Women, which developed the university women's association report. More than 200 teachers, both men and women, have attended the workshops over the last six years and returned to their school districts around the nation to instruct other teachers on how to eliminate bias against girls in the curriculum.
Verdelle Freeman, a participant in one of the workshops, returned to her job as an English teacher at Piscataway High School and, with her husband, Alexander Jones, assembled a girls' performing arts troupe that presents the history of African women since the 11th century. Mrs. Freeman said it was particularly important for black girls to have role models that predate slavery.
"If you don't know where you've come from, you can't know where you're going," Mrs. Freeman said.
 
Math and Science Singled Out
 The association's report singled out the way math and science are taught to girls for special criticism. It contends that girls are discouraged from taking advanced math courses and are less likley than boys to pursue scientific or technological careers even if they are talented.
The report cites a study of Rhode Island high school seniors, indicating that 64 percent of the boys who had taken physics and calculus were planning to major in science or engineering, compared with 18.6 percent of girls with the same background.
There are a number of college-based efforts in New Jersey to lure elementary and secondary school girls into these areas. A summer- school program in math, science and engineering for girls entering the 11th grade that was offered by Douglass College had 467 applications for 46 openings last year. The project is now focusing on younger high school students with a series of Saturday programs.
Teaching math has also changed in some schools. At Oak Knoll, such standard classroom rituals as time trials in multiplication tables are de-emphasized because of research showing that girls learn more in cooperative settings than in competitive ones.
In Princeton public schools, teachers have begun to analyze their own classroom behavior to see if they unwittingly favor certain students. The teachers have been asked to identify their highest- and lowest-achieving students, and other teachers sit in the classroom to observe and measure who is allowed to answer questions in class, among other things.
 
An Effect on Self-Esteem
 "It's based on the simplest concept that if you send out cues to students that they are competent and capable and can achieve, they probably will," said John Sakala, the Princeton school district's assistant superintendent for curriculum and instruction. "If you identify students as underachievers and they recognize it, it is probably a self-fulfilling prophecy."
Princeton is one of five school districts to participate in a five-year pilot program of the New Jersey Department of Education to integrate multiculturalism, including the study of women's issues, throughout the curriculum.
While most school districts would like to think they are treating girls and boys equally, there is often unintentional discrimination, said Dr. Gilda Rorro, director of the Education Department's Office of Equal Educational Opportunity, who oversees the pilot program.
"It's a question of omission," she said.
New Jersey chapters of the university women's association have sought to take advantage of the attention the report has received. In one of several events association chapters have sponsored around the state, representatives from more than 60 educational groups and businesses gathered at Jersey City State College last month to discuss the report and develop strategies for increasing educational equality in New Jersey.
 
'Concern Is Growing'
 "We really didn't expect such a large response," said Arlene Inglis, chairwoman of the event and of the business department at Morristown High School. "But interest is growing and concern is growing, and we're hearing from organizations we didn't even know existed."
Next week, a number of public and private school officials and representatives from the Y.W.C.A. and American Association of University Women from the Princeton area will be meeting at Princeton University to discuss the report.
Not everyone has greeted the association's report with praise. Diane Ravitch, an assistant United States Secretary of Education, has been one of the sharpest critics of the association report.
She said that schools were the wrong target and that television and advertising were more to blame for shaping girls' attitudes about themselves. She said girls should stop complaining and simply take more math and science courses if they want to get ahead in those areas.
Dr. Crocco of Oak Knoll believes that Dr. Ravitch is only partly right. "There's truth about what she says about the media," she said. "But that doesn't deny the fact that kids today spend more hours in school than in front of the TV. I don't think she's being realistic when she's talking about the way things work with juveniles."
Feminists have been known to say that it will take at least 100 years until school curriculums are fairly balanced. Professor Rothenberg of the New Jersey Project is not quite so pessimistic.
"We've got at least another 20 to 30 years' work before it will begin to look good to me," she said. "To really replace what is fundamentally a white male perspective on reality with a much more inclusive starting point is going to take a long time. These habits die hard."

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 4; Column 4; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1241 words

HEADLINE: Towns Respond to County Overture

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
AFTER nine years as the Bedford Town Supervisor, Lawrence E. Dwyer was recently forced to take an action he thought would never be needed in his affluent community. He wrote personal letters to 70 residents urging them to pay their taxes.
The response was immediate. "People came in, very upset, talking about their problems," he recalled last week. "Many are out of work and others bought big houses when the market was good, homes they can't sell in this economy," he said. "It's not 'Panicville,' but people are truly in trouble." 
 With his town facing a $650,000 shortfall in tax money that it must pay the county, Mr. Dwyer was one of 20 Westchester town supervisors and city officials who accepted last week's invitation from the County Board of Legislators and senior members of the County Executive's staff to discuss common problems.
Local officials shared their concerns about what they called the tax crisis affecting all local governments. The situation, they said, has been perpetuated by state officials' setting unfair tax-equalization rates while courts tend to favor small-property owners in lowering assessments and a poor economy makes taxes more difficult to collect.
 
Legislative Revision Urged
 "You can help right now," Mr. Dwyer told the assembled legislators and members of the County Executive's staff, describing corrective legislation pending in Albany, which is backed by Mr. Dwyer and the members of the Municipal Officials Association, a Westchester-based organization he heads. "It is critical that you write our state representatives now," he said.
The legislation would require the State Board of Equalization and Assessment to change the method it uses to establish tax-equalization rates -- the ratio of real to assessed property value, a figure used by the state to determine school-aid formulas and to establish real property tax values.
The current practice of estimating value rather than actually surveying property has caused state officials to misjudge the impact of a declining real estate market, local officials say. Estimates are used because state budget cutbacks have reduced the number of available assessors. But the effect on municipalities has been severe, Westchester town supervisors agreed.
"It's a bureaucratic nightmare," said Supervisor Mark S. Tulis of the town of New Castle. "The state is trying to save money, but the expense is borne by the local communities."
Factual errors have compounded the problem, Mr. Tulis said. Last year, New Castle challenged state estimates of the value of 51 of the 70 land parcels surveyed by the state, saving residents an estimated $350,000.
 
Guaranteed Tax Payments
 The courts, meanwhile, have gone in the other direction, using real property values to grant property owners large tax reductions while municipal legal expenses for defending against citizen suits have risen dramatically. "Our towns are losing millions of dollars through the small claims process," Mr. Dwyer said, adding that recent legislation has compounded the problem, increasing the ceiling on tax reductions to 25 percent of assessed value.
Westchester is the only county in the state that is guaranteed payment of taxes from its towns and cities. (Elsewhere, towns may collect taxes for a county, but the towns are not directly liable for the bills.) While guaranteed tax collection has helped Westchester maintain a Triple A bond rating, town supervisors last week said the time has come for Westchester County to help towns fight local tax battles.
"Westchester County has an excellent bond rating as a result of our collections," said John A. Lombardi, the North Castle Town Supervisor. "It's a horrible day when the little communities have to fight Westchester County's battles to keep that bond rating."
The legislators and members of the County Executive's senior staff at the meeting promised to support the proposed state legislation and to consider providing aid to communities that face challenges to their tax levies. Town Supervisors attended the regular meeting of the Board of Legislators on Monday at which legislation was introduced that would assist municipalities in cases that exceed $100,000.
 
A Commission Called LINK
 Stephen V. Reitano, the county's Commissioner of Finance, said last week that he would consider changing the deadline for payment of county taxes to ease the burden on municipalities. Among other possibilities, the percentage of money that local governments owe to the county could be staggered to allow communities more flexibility, Mr. Reitano said.
This first meeting of the two levels of government was sponsored by a special commission established by the Board of Legislators and named LINK, which is not an acronym but a label that refers to the goal of fostering cooperation among various groups, including business, labor and municipalities. The commission's co-chairwomen are the Board's vice chairwoman, Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican-Conservative from Yonkers, and its former minority leader, Sandra R. Galef, a Democrat from Ossining.
Last week's meeting took place in a much warmer atmosphere than that prevailing two years ago when several local officials were invited to the legislative chambers to suggest ways the county could save money. "They were not received well," Mrs. Galef recalled. "Some legislators were asking why local officials should have any input. Now, that has all changed."
Mrs. Carsky agreed. "It's high time the legislative body held out its hand," she said. "We are trying to reduce what had been an adversarial relationship, and if we can keep this arrangement going, it would be great."
 
Some Tension Over Recycling
 Most participants in the meeting last week agreed that the new spirit of cooperation would continue but so would the frank exchange of views that marked this first encounter between leaders of two different levels of government, who have different perceptions of their responsibilities.
That tension was evident last week when Mr. Tulis said he hoped that county legislative efforts to mandate recycling "would be careful not to hurt successful programs already existing." The state has required municipalities to have mandatory recycling programs in place by Sept. 1.
The county program should allow communities to establish for themselves what products are marketable, Mr. Tulis said, noting that New Castle has established its own standards and found its own markets. "We'll meet state standards," Mr. Tulis said. "Why should you care how we do it? Why do I need another regulatory environment?"
 
More Meetings Anticipated
 Calling the county the designated planning unit for the state, Marilyn J. Slaatten, the County Attorney, said the county must establish standards but that variances would be given.
"We need the data," added James Hogan, the county's Recycling Coordinator. "Not all communities have programs as good as yours."
Despite some obvious frictions, most participants in last week's meeting agreed that they would get together again soon.
"We have a communality of concerns, and we can share ideas to do better government," Mr. Dwyer said. "That desire hasn't been there before. It was us talking up and them down. It was adversarial, parochial and controlling. This new responsiveness may indicate that it's the desire to serve and not political considerations that motivates this government."

HEADLINE: Competing for the Democratic Primary Voter

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE struggle for the Democratic Presidential nomination came to the county last week in the form of two dramatically different campaigners, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, competing for the New York primary vote on Tuesday.
Mr. Clinton, seemingly well financed and backed by the county's Democratic leadership, campaigned as a candidate who could no longer depend on his lead over the insurgent Mr. Brown, whose Westchester backers began to organize only three weeks ago in an effort to influence the county's 151,147 registered Democrats. 
 Supporters of Mr. Clinton, who made up most of the 500 party regulars attending the annual Westchester Democratic dinner on March 26 at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, seek a decisive primary victory as an effective conclusion to Mr. Brown's uphill effort to capture the party's nomination.
Mr. Brown's backers, by contrast, say the discomfort expressed by many Democrats for Mr. Clinton may well be transformed into support for Mr. Brown; they acknowledge, however, that the former California Governor carries his own negative image for a similarly significant segment of Democrats.
One of Mr. Clinton's local backers, former County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, said: "He has been holding up well under the attacks, showing strength, composure, leadership and control. It's a quality I haven't seen in a candidate for a long time."
Mr. DelBello added: "Most of the attacks against Bill Clinton have been superfluous, although some are serious. Nevertheless, in every case he has kept his campaign on course and kept himself under control. He has a big negative in the polls -- people say they don't trust him -- but I think that is going to disappear when he gets into the election campaign and goes head to head with George Bush."
Mr. Clinton's Westchester campaign is being run by Oren J. Teicher. "Since December, when the Governor's wife, Hillary, came here to organize his campaign," he said, "we have been able to put together a broad coalition of Democrats just as he has done at the national level."
Mr. Teicher, who lost two close races for the House of Representatives in 1984 and 1986, said the Clinton team reflected that diversity. "I had been active in Governor Dukakis's campaign," he said, referring to the 1988 Democratic Presidential candidate, Michael S. Dukakis, while County Legislator Herman Keith "had helped run the Jesse Jackson campaign" and Toby Nussbaum of Scarsdale, a Clinton backer with her husband, Bernard, "had been a Simon delegate," a reference to Senator Paul Simon of Illinois.
Mr. Teicher said other Clinton supporters in the county had in previous years supported Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.
He said the county's Clinton campaign had two opponents: "Jerry Brown and an apathy based on the feeling that the Governor has the primary sewed up."
"A number of people at the dinner were asking each other, why vote?" Mr. Teicher added. "There's a greater-than-ever turn-off this year."
As a result, the Clinton campaign strategy has been to "get the public involved." Political advertisements on local radio stations have been geared to getting people to come to Clinton rallies; his message is "Give me an opportunity to be heard." Clinton backers have also been handing out campaign literature.
Eli Vigliano, a Yonkers lawyer, is chairman of the Brown campaign in Westchester. "We started after the Michigan primary" on March 17, he said, in which Mr. Brown came in second with 28 percent of the vote, beating former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts. Mr. Tsongas, who got 18 percent of the Michigan vote, withdrew from the primary race a few days later.
The growing uncertainty of the New York Democratic primary and the strong showing by Mr. Tsongas in Connecticut, where he got 20 percent of the vote even after he had withdrawn, put the Westchester Tsongas Committee "back in business" last Wednesday, said Marc S. Oxman, who heads the committee. "Although Paul Tsongas has suspended his campaign," Mr. Oxman said, "many Democrats believe that he is the only candidate who can defeat George Bush in November."
Mr. Tsongas remains on the New York primary ballot, as do Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who also left the race. Also on the ballot are former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota and Lawrence A. Agran, a former mayor of Irvine, Calif.
Mr. Clinton, who won 46 percent in Michigan and an equally decisive victory in Illinois, has nearly half the number of delegates needed to win the nomination and has a 7-to-1 lead over Mr. Brown. Nevertheless, Brown backers were heartened by the Michigan results and found newcomers volunteering to aid his campaign.
"I've been active in many campaigns in Westchester, but what struck me about the first meeting of the Brown campaign was there was not one familiar face," Mary Ann Phillips of Rye said. "These were young and eager people, with a lot of energy, who had been apolitical but who now felt something was seriously wrong but that with Brown, now we're going to have a voice."
Mr. Brown's campaign, which Ms. Phillips described as "strictly grass roots," was represented at one of the 35 tables at the Democratic dinner. "We distributed a lot of literature and attracted a lot of attention," she said.
 
Rally at G.M. Plant
 Mr. Vigliano said that since then the campaign had concentrated on preparing telephone banks and organizing motorcades throughout the county.
Mr. Brown's backers were out in full force last Monday when the candidate, in his first campaign appearance in Westchester, conducted a vigorous rally outside the General Motors assembly plant in North Tarrytown. About 300 supporters from all parts of the county waited in a light drizzle for the candidate to appear.
Timed for a shift change at the sprawling assembly plant, the rally nevertheless failed to attract many automobile workers. The majority of them drove out of the parking lot as usual. For those who stayed, Mr. Brown, wearing a union jacket, was no disappointment.
The nation "needs better housing, better health care, better neighborhood security," he said. "This won't happen if we close down the plants," a reference to General Motors's announced intention to close the Tarrytown assembly plant in 1995.
"They can find millions of dollars to clean up the savings and loan mess," Mr. Brown said, referring to the Federal Government, "but nothing to help modernize industry."
 
Plans for Foreign Plants Criticized
 Taking his cue from signs held by plant workers denouncing General Motors for planning to open assembly plants in Mexico and Europe, Mr. Brown criticized "selfish executives" who would make it possible for G.M. to hire "millions in Mexico willing to do what you do for a buck an hour."
Mr. Brown said that his rival, Mr. Clinton, "is backed by people who will finance your extinction and then run ads saying he's for the working people. It's baloney."
Mr. Brown drew cheers, whistles, shouts of "You got that right" and the chant "Jer-ree, Jer-ree."
In the crowd, Debbie Cooper of Peekskill held a posterboard depicting a broken heart and reading "G.M.: The Heartbreak of America." Her husband is one of the General Motors workers who will lose their jobs when the plant closes.
 
$3 Million Pledged for Brown Race
 Bob McCracken, president of Local 1103 of the Communications Workers of America, with headquarters in Port Chester, said: "I like Brown. He's talking about the issues that affect workers, about jobs leaving the country."
Mr. Brown said $3 million "is now pledged" for his campaign and so "we're still in the race." He spoke vigorously, but with the hoarseness of nonstop campaigning. As his white van pulled away from the rally, a woman broke through a barricade to thrust a box of herbal tea -- Throat Care Tea -- into his hands.
Mr. Clinton also demonstrated a common touch after his speech at the Democratic dinner, in which he covered the spectrum of his positions on economic, social, health, educational and tax issues. He left the ballroom not as he had entered, through a side door, but through the clusters of tables. The audience members were on their feet, eager to shake Mr. Clinton's hand, comment on his campaign or ask a question.
Shane Tierney, a 16-year-old of Rye, introduced himself as an R.O.T.C. cadet and said he was "wondering about your policy on the military and cutbacks because I want to know if I have job security."
Mr. Clinton thought for a moment and then said: "Here's what I think. We need fewer people in Europe, perhaps fewer people in Japan, but more mobility on land, air and sea. So I have come out for cuts greater than the President has recommended, focused mostly on the deployment in Europe where a third of our defense budget is now committed, defending against a Soviet threat which isn't, and where a lot of those nations are richer than we are."
 
'They'll Have a Job for You'
 Mr. Clinton spoke of a need for a "new line of submarines," new aircraft and a continuing need for carrier groups, "although not at the levels the Administration wants."
"So the answer is," he concluded, "if you get through and become an officer, they'll have a job for you. We're still going to have a substantial military, but it should not be as big as it is now."
He paused and the Secret Service agents resumed nudging him along. But Mr. Tierney wasn't finished.
"Are you going to have a plan for the people coming home?" the cadet asked. "Are you going to have jobs for them?"
Mr. Clinton replied, "Absolutely." He said that recycling closed bases into training sites for troubled kids and for other uses would be part of a "careful conversion" over five or six years. He spoke of programs to "redirect the energies and abilities" of military personnel.
"Every serious academic study shows that if you cut defense in the proper way you will create more jobs at home," he said.

HEADLINE: Picking Up Pointers for a Self-Help Clearinghouse in Poland

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
A GROUP of community leaders from Poland received a primer here recently on the care and feeding of volunteers and the steps needed to establish an effective self-help network. Eight representatives of the newly formed Ochota Self-Help Association, from the Ochota district of Warsaw, completed a two-week study tour of the United States with a morning session at the Westchester Self-Help Clearinghouse, a division of Westchester Jewish Community Services.
The Polish leaders, their translators and members of the Delphi International Group, a Washington-based organization that arranged the tour, heard Leslie Borck Jameson describe how a successful self-help association works. Dr. Jameson is a psychologist and director of the clearinghouse and is the assistant executive director of special programs for Westchester Jewish Community Services. 
 The White Plains clearinghouse, which Dr. Jameson founded 13 years ago, coordinates services for about 230 support groups in the county. The Polish group, representing such organizations as homeless shelters, church welfare groups, sobriety clubs and associations for the retired or unemployed, serves an area of 180,000 people in the Ochota district of Warsaw. The tour was financed in part by the United States Agency for International Development.
 
Information on Index Cards
 Dr. Jameson described the basics of her operation. "We are very non-fancy," she told her visitors. "You don't need a lot of money to start a self-help clearinghouse." Holding up a well-worn index card file, she said: "This is our information system. You don't need a computer."
She talked about the core of the system -- the white cards listing mutual support groups, the pink cards listing professional services in the county. She also distributed the organization's directory, now in its eighth edition, noting that the book and card system went hand in hand.
Self-help groups, held together by volunteers, spring up because "I believe few people come to professionals for help in most situations," Dr. Jameson said.
Elise Ginsburg, an associate with the Delphi group who helped lead the tour, said volunteerism in Poland was in its infancy. The church or government used to take care of people's needs, she said, so that volunteer work had never been encouraged. Indeed, one man drew a laugh when he said that "Under Communism, anytime we wanted to do things ourselves the regime took down our names."
Now, Ms. Ginsburg said, a small number of people usually did all the volunteer jobs. But because of growing problems caused by homelessness and unemployment in Poland, she predicted that "once volunteerism is understood, I think it will spread like wildfire."
The Poles were surprised to hear that Americans, through their state and county taxes, were willing to subsidize their more than 60 self-help clearinghouses nationwide, mostly in California and the Northeast. Dr. Jameson explained that because self- help programs had grown into a popular movement, people also contributed funds directly to the clearinghouses as a charity.
A former factory worker in the group who said he wanted to organize the unemployed in Warsaw asked Dr. Jameson "how to start the business in motion." Dr. Jameson outlined the steps: find a place to meet, define whom you want to attend, announce a date and hold the meeting.
Then she spoke about the dynamics of leadership and the importance of group participation. "People are expected to give as well as take," she said. "Long term, this gets people involved in a community, helping each other. In psychological terms, it is important to have the chance to help someone else."
 
From Small Beginnings
 Groups can be formed by people in need -- by parents of disabled children, for example -- or by a professional wishing to help as a volunteer. The problem with professionals, she said, was that people expected them to lead and might not take an active part themselves in the group.
Seated around a long table in a large conference room in a pleasant, modern office, the visitors seemed to need convincing that they, too, could achieve such success. Dr. Jameson repeatedly stressed that her own organization had begun "in a closet," with little money and only a few calls each month. The Westchester Self-Help Clearinghouse had responded to a grass-roots movement, similar to Warsaw's, she said, forming only after 70 mutual-support groups had begun meeting in the county.
"It grew up," she said, spreading her arms.
Before arriving in White Plains, the study group had visited various social-service agencies in Chicago, Washington and upstate New York. Other members of the group also visited the Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. Ms. Ginsburg said the Polish leaders had been "impressed that it is prestigious to be a volunteer" in this country. They were also "amazed at how well Americans work together," she said, and "amazed at how efficient we are."
In their travels, the Poles had been especially impressed with a political activist in Chicago, Ms. Ginsburg added. "They loved her -- the way she fought the system for health and welfare rights," Ms. Ginsburg said. "She was angry, determined and stubborn."

John Holman is with Delphi International Group. (Photographs by Roberta Hershenson)

HEADLINE: Life Before Gorbachev

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am delighted that Melor Sturua finds my book "What Went Wrong With Perestroika" to be "useful, even successful" (Feb. 2). But he misconstrues several of my arguments. 
 He criticizes me for writing that there were "record-breaking rates of industrial growth in the 1930's" in the Soviet Union, and then notes that "not even one of the five-year plans in the 1930's was fulfilled." Both statements are true -- but the failure to fulfill the plan does not cancel out the fact that there were record rates of growth, even if that growth did not benefit the people. There is a danger that in examining what happened in the Soviet Union, we will ignore the fact that a very impressive industrial and military structure was created. It produced the wrong kinds of goods and collapsed quickly, but it does scholarship a disservice to disavow what in fact did happen in the era before Mikhail Gorbachev.
Mr. Sturua takes several of my statements out of context. For example, I do indeed say that "economic life in the Khrush chev era seemed to be approaching Western standards." But it is clear in context that the emphasis is on "seemed to be." The point is made that the Soviet economy was still a long way from Western equilibrium, and the paragraph that follows makes very clear why the anticipation of an improved economy was unrealistic.
Mr. Sturua also says, "Mr. Goldman . . . writes that Mr. Gorbachev's predecessors Yuri Andropov and Konstantin Chernenko 'might have adopted a more radical approach [to the economy] if they had lived longer.' " But he does not mention that I devote almost two pages to a discussion of why "it is doubtful that Andropov had in mind anything far-reaching": "His solutions went no further than the old patchwork approach to the Soviet economy." I go on to say that "Andropov's behavior suggests that Gorbachev's actions were instead a discontinuity, not an evolving process, and . . . if he had lived, Andropov might have adhered to very different domestic and international policies from Gorbachev's."
As for Chernenko, I say that "there was never much chance that he would do anything substantial in the way of reform."
 
MARSHALL I. GOLDMAN
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Japan's Bubble Is Deflating, But Not Gently

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Nobody has had a tougher job than Yasushi Mieno, the Japanese central banker who set out in 1989 to pierce Japan's "bubble economy," as he called it, without hurting the real economy.
Now, with the Japanese economy reeling -- auto sales have been down for 16 of the last 17 months and industrial production is down 4 percent from a year ago -- Japan is confronting the reality of what John Kenneth Galbraith wrote about Wall Street in 1929: "A bubble can easily be punctured. But to incise it with a needle so that it subsides gradually is a task of no small delicacy." 
 In Tokyo last week, the Japanese market sneered at the Government's caricature of a fiscal-stimulus package and then scorned Mr. Mieno's decision to cut the discount rate by only three-quarters of a percentage point. When the dust cleared, the Nikkei 225 index was down 5.5 percent for the week, despite a small rebound on Friday.
"For the first time in modern history, the Japanese market has not responded to lower interest rates," said Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley's global strategist. "That is very negative."
For optimists, there was some cheering news. Fundamentals, which Japan used to ignore, actually seem to count now. Such blue-chip stocks as Sony and Matsushita were up for the week, and it is possible to argue with a straight face that, based on cash flow, some Japanese blue chips are not much more expensive than their American counterparts. It is tempting to conclude that any market selling for less than half its high must be a good buy.
On the other side are the fears that there are still many losses yet to be admitted by the banks and insurance companies, some of which placed big bets against falling stock prices a couple of years ago. Maybe some of those bets were hedged. And maybe not.
Unfortunately, it appears that corporate cash flows are destined to drop, and not just because of the economy. No country was a more eager participant than Japan in the easy credit craze of the late 1980's. Companies borrowed trillions of yen at interest rates that were very low or even, as James Lyle, the manager of Fidelity's Overseas Fund, points out, negative. That was because the bonds came with warrants, allowing the buyer to profit if stock prices kept rising. More than $100 billion of such bonds will mature in the next two years, to be refinanced at much higher rates, if they can be refinanced at all.
Japan is not popular in the United States these days, and few tears will be shed if a severe recession does develop. But the world has good reason to hope that does not happen. With imports shrinking, Japan's trade surplus is on the rise again, a fact that will not help America's recovery.
It is far from clear what Mr. Mieno should try now. When bubbles burst, ridiculously high prices have a way of falling to unreasonably low levels. And, in Mr. Biggs's words, "at its peak, the Japanese stock market was the biggest bubble of all time."

HEADLINE: Mellowed by Age, but Still a Tough Boss

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
MINNETONKA, Minn.
When Marilyn Nelson describes her father, 77-year-old Curtis L. Carlson, the founder and sole stockholder of the Carlson Companies, she says this: "If Curt were riding a bicycle, he'd peddle downhill."
The remark helps explain why Mr. Carlson, who started at the height of the Depression what would grow into a hotel, travel and marketing company, became impatient last year when the recession seemed to be taking its toll. "The margins evaporated," Mr. Carlson said, sending profits down substantially. He wanted more from his company, even though the war in the Persian Gulf and the recession had sent the travel industry reeling. 
 "We had too much gloom and doom around here," Mr. Carlson explained in a recent interview in his office here in this Minneapolis suburb. "People were waiting too long for things to turn around."
Mr. Carlson didn't say it directly, but it was clear from the context that what he meant by "people" was largely Edwin C. (Skip) Gage, Mr. Carlson's son-in-law who in 1989 became Carlson's chief executive and heir apparent.
So, with the suddenness of a South American coup, Mr. Gage was out last November. Mr. Gage says he quit, but the shift has all the earmarks of an ouster. And Mr. Carlson, who just 10 months before had quadruple coronary bypass surgery, was back running things day to day. He now seems to be grooming his elder daughter, Marilyn, 52, for the top job. Mrs. Nelson, who is married to a surgeon, and her sister Barbara, 49, who is married to Mr. Gage, are in line to inherit the company when Mr. Carlson dies.
But Curtis Carlson's gloom and doom could easily be considered joyous boom times at many other companies. Systemwide revenues, including sales at Carlson's extensive franchise operations, rose nearly 15 percent last year, to $9.3 billion, from $8.1 billion in 1990. And Carlson properties have continued to multiply at a breakneck pace. The company is now adding almost 30 travel agencies a month to the 2,100 it already has. It is adding one hotel every six days to the 315 it operates under the Radisson and Colony names. And by 1996, it expects to more than double its chain of TGI Friday's restaurants, which now number 200.
 
'Already Major Players'
 Indeed, despite all the bumps of the past year, Carlson still seems to be on a roll, cushioned from any really painful shocks -- at least so far -- by the global nature of its operations, its minimal debt load and Mr. Carlson's hold-their-feet-to-the-fire management style.
"With their global view and the way they have diversified, they are already major players, and well positioned for the future," said Paul E. Wise, director of the hotel, restaurant and institutional management program at the University of Delaware.
Carlson's hotel operation, added Edward Watkins, editor of Lodging Hospitality magazine, "kept its head on straight in the 80's, when everybody else was going overboard."
Many experts now think Carlson is well on its way to becoming the undisputed giant of the travel industry. With a network of 75 companies in 38 countries, Carlson has its hand in virtually every art of the business, posing a vigorous challenge to better-known competitors like American Express and Thomas Cook.
Travelers need never leave the Carlson fold. They can book plane tickets through a Carlson travel agency, stay at a Radisson hotel, eat at any of several kinds of Carlson restaurants and pay for everything with Carlson travelers checks or a Carlson credit card. They will soon be able to book passage on the Radisson Diamond, a futuristic-looking twin-hulled cruise ship that goes into service on May 7.
To be sure, the lingering effects of the recession are probably still pinching profits, although the company will not disclose exact figures. The precise financial condition of Carlson is said to be known only to Mr. Carlson and a few close associates.
And then there is the matter of who will succeed Mr. Carlson. Though his daughters are in line to inherit the company when Mr. Carlson dies, the question remains whether he will turn over the reins before then.
Mrs. Nelson is now serving as vice chairman of Carlson Holdings Inc., the parent not only of the Carlson Companies but also of the family's investment and real estate arms, although she joined the company full time only two years ago.
If Mr. Carlson should again have second thoughts about a successor, he could turn to either of his two chief operating lieutenants: Juergen Bartels, the 51-year-old president of the hospitality group, who has been with the company since 1983, and Charles Schmid, 49, president of the marketing and travel groups. Mr. Schmid, a former senior executive with the Miller Brewing Company, was brought in last summer by Mr. Carlson to prevent any further erosion of profits.
For now, the founding father is being cagey. "I'm going to stay on for an indefinite period," a hale-looking Mr. Carlson said during the recent interview. "I don't want to retire. My daughter is busy learning the business, and she has tremendous capacity. But time will tell where we are."
 
The Long View
 Curtis Carlson has been taking the long view almost from the beginning. At the same time, Mr. Carlson, born in Minneapolis with what he describes as "restless Swedish genes," has never been one to wait for things to happen. "Even now, the idea of coasting just hasn't occurred to him," Mrs. Nelson said about her father.
Mr. Carlson's refusal to coast, for example, led him to give up his job as a top soap salesman for the Procter & Gamble Company and take on the risks of entrepreneurship during the Depression. He was barely out of his teens in 1938 when he formed the Gold Bond Stamp Company, selling trading stamps to retail outlets.
Trading-stamp companies like Gold Bond had swept the nation by the 50's, inspiring consumer loyalty by offering appliances and other premiums to those who saved enough stamps. But by the mid-60's, the stamp companies had reached the saturation point.
Mr. Carlson had seen the handwriting on the wall some years earlier and began to diversify into real estate in Minneapolis' western suburbs. In 1962, he bought the Radisson Hotel in downtown Minneapolis. By 1973, the company had diversified enough to warrant dropping the Gold Bond name. (Gold Bond stamps are still being circulated, primarily at truck stops.)
In 1975, the Carlson Companies bought the Dallas-based TGI Friday's. Three year later, it bought the Ask Mr. Foster travel agency. Each step led to the next step.
"When we diversified into hotels," Mr. Carlson said, "I learned we had people with know-how in the restaurant business, so we went into Friday's. And the hotels are synergistic with our travel agencies."
By 1985, Carlson owned all or part of 22 hotels. "But we were only earning 5 percent on our money," Mr. Carlson said, "and I knew we had to take another approach." Today, the company owns only 10 Radisson hotels, just 3 percent of the total, and a little more than half of the 2,100 retail travel agencies that bear its name. The rest are franchises or are run by Carlson under management contracts.
Carlson is now divided into three operating groups. The biggest by far is travel, which had overall revenues, including sales at franchises, of $6.1 billion last year. The group, known as the Carlson Travel Network, was buoyed last year by the strong performance of its British chain, A. T. Mayes, Mr. Carlson said. But domestic agencies saw profits weaken and some defections occurred.
 
Breaking Away in Utah
 For example, Morris Travel Express of Salt Lake City, which has 23 offices in Utah and Idaho, recently dropped its affiliation with Carlson to join the American Express travel network. "We felt that American Express is a better fit for our marketplace," said Mark G. Flack, Morris's president, who declined to elaborate.
After pointing to the "record growth" of its travel franchise program in 1991, when it added 329 franchises for a total of 902, a spokesman for the Carlson Travel Network said of the Morris defection, "Unfortunately, there will always be those who want to try new affiliations -- it's a business reality."
The hospitality group, with overall revenues of $2.3 billion, is the second biggest. It encompasses both hotels and restaurants, including its jewel, the Radisson chain.
"Radisson appears very well positioned for the 90's," said Mr. Watkins of Lodging Hospitality, citing its relative lack of debt and the business it gets from the Carlson Travel Network. The only negative, he said, is that the Radisson name is not as well known as that of some of its competitors.
The smallest group is marketing, with sales of $900 million. Marketing manages the frequent-flier programs of Northwest, British Airways, SAS, KLM and Swissair. It also puts together incentive programs that companies offer to employees. Sometimes those incentives are trips, which Carlson also puts together. In good times, the Big Three auto companies sponsor lots of incentive programs, but last year they cut back hard -- and that sharply affected the marketing group's bottom line, Mr. Carlson said.
In all, Carlson directly employs 35,000 people, with an additional 63,000 at affiliated and franchise operations. About $6.1 billion, or roughly two-thirds of systemwide revenues, go directly to Carlson.
At the company's annual sales meeting in February, Mr. Carlson said he had decided to abandon his practice of using five-year sales targets in favor of a three-year time frame. "Three years is more realistic going into the 90's and the year 2000," he said. "We will simply examine our progress more often," reflecting his belief that the company needs greater flexibility as competition intensifies.
But while the words are different, Mr. Carlson has not changed his basic tune. Executives are on notice to increase business 15 percent this year, presumably including profits. He insists there is plenty of room for growth even in a weak economy.
Mr. Carlson has mellowed some with age, according to those who have known him for years, so that his public outbursts over what he considers managerial lapses are less frequent. But he remains a tough boss, they say.
"He can tolerate an occasional failure, but not repeated failure and not lack of effort," said Mr. Bartels of the hospitality group.
If Mr. Carlson should find his daughter's leadership abilities wanting, J. B., as Mr. Bartels is known, would clearly be a candidate for the top job. In the respectful tone of one workaholic speaking of another, Mr. Carlson said, "J. B. never flies into any city without having at least four appointments lined up."
For her part, Mrs. Nelson acknowledges that she has yet to master the nuts and bolts of the varied Carlson holdings. "I didn't come up through the business," she said, "so I don't know every single thing. But I feel that I'm continuing to learn." Current and former Carlson employees say she has the intelligence, acumen and drive for the top position.
 
Living by the Lake
 Mrs. Nelson joined Carlson full time in December 1989. An economics major at Smith College, she has owned the Citizens State Bank of Waterville, Minn., with her sister, Barbara Gage, since 1971. She is also on the board of three other companies, including the Exxon Corporation. She is married to Dr. Glen D. Nelson, who is vice chairman of Medtronic Inc., a pacemaker manufacturer. Dr. Nelson is also on the board of Carlson Holdings.
Despite the executive suite shuffle that cost Skip Gage his job last year -- but not his board seat -- the Carlson, Nelson and Gage families are said to remain close. They live side-by-side on lakefront property not far from the company's headquarters, as they have for years, and they still worship together Sundays in the United Methodist Church in downtown Minneapolis.
When Mr. Gage gave up the chief executive's title, he was allowed to buy three marketing companies from Carlson. Operating as the Gage Marketing Group, the three have about 1,500 employees and revenues of $120 million. For the time being, the group is based at the Carlson headquarters.
Mr. Gage said last week that he quit because of pressure building up between Mr. Carlson and himself.
"Curt and I were both trying to do the C.E.O.'s job at the same time," he said. "It wasn't satisfying for either of us, and we had different views of how to approach the problems."
Mrs. Nelson is likely to have a smoother relationship with Mr. Carlson, and not just because she is his daughter.
"She has a lot of Curt's qualities, including his determination to succeed and his salesmanship, but she brings a lot of caring and a lot of concern about relationships," said Peter Davis, academic director of the Family Business Executive Programs at the Wharton School. "She's not at all pretentious, and she's very willing to communicate."
Professor Davis added that those qualities are likely to be more important than hands-on management, once the torch is passed, because the Carlson empire is "substantially professionalized now, with some high-powered managers already in place."
In the long run, what really matters is not whether others think Mrs. Nelson is qualified to run the company, but whether her father thinks so. For after Mr. Gage's departure, few think that Curt Carlson will be guided by sentiment in the matter of his succession.
Mrs. Nelson certainly does not. "I understand to the depths of my being what this company means to Curt," she said in a recent interview. "This is his child, and he couldn't stop being its parent any more than I could stop being my kids' mom."
 
 
 
GROWTH BY FRANCHISING
 Changing its focus in the mid-80's, from owning hotels and travel agencies to franchising and managing them, has enabled the Carlson Companies to expand quickly at a time when money has been tight.
"Other people put up the money, we train them and if they want we put in our own management team until they're ready to take over," said Curtis L. Carlson, the company founder. "We're literally spending millions of dollars on training and advertising."
The company is also making millions in fees and royalties, based on the following formula for its retail travel agency franchises:
Associates, as the franchisees are called, sign a three-year contract and pay a one-time fee of $3,600 for the first office and $1,500 for each additional office. Each year, they pay a royalty of 4.5 percent of the first $300,000 in gross commissions, 3.5 percent of commissions between $300,000 and $500,000 and 2 percent above that.
They also pay a marketing fee of 1.5 percent of gross commissions, up to a maximum of $7,500, for national advertising. And they agree to spend 3 percent of commissions on local advertising and promotion. Finally, the Carlson name must be placed before the agency's own trade name.

 
 
KEEPING BUSINESS ALL IN THE FAMILY
 More than five decades after the Carlson empire was founded, the business remains largely a family affair.
Curtis L. Carlson is chairman, president and chief executive of Carlson Holdings Inc., the umbrella company, and he remains the sole stockholder. Marilyn Nelson, his older daughter, and Edwin C. (Skip) Gage, the husband of his younger daughter, are vice chairmen and directors. Also directors are Mr. Carlson's wife of 54 years, Arleen; their younger daughter, Barbara Gage, and Dr. Glen D. Nelson, their other son-in-law.
The only nonfamily directors are Matthew J. Levitt, a Minneapolis attorney, and Rodney Wilson, the chief financial officer.
The board of the Carlson Companies, parent of the three operating groups, consists of Mr. Carlson, his two daughters, Mr. Gage, Mr. Levitt, Mr. Wilson and one other outsider, Carl R. Pohlad, president of the Marquette Bank Minneapolis and owner of the Minnesota Twins baseball team.
Mr. Carlson's will provides that the business will be left in equal shares to his daughters. In the event they disagree about corporate matters, each will be allowed to choose a lawyer acceptable to the other to try to work things out. If they still disagree, an arbitrator will be named to settle the dispute.
The Nelsons have three adult children and the Gages have four, all of whom will eventually receive stock under terms that will require them to sell the shares back to the company if they decide to cash in.
Only one of Mr. Carlson's grandchildren is involved in the business: Curtis Nelson, a 28-year-old graduate of Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration. Mr. Nelson is director of marketing at the Radisson Mart Plaza Hotel at Miami International Airport.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 29 - April 3

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Bush's Surprise Plan to Help Yeltsin's Government 

When President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany announced that the world's wealthiest nations would give $24 billion to the Russian Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin, all that was lacking was the vision thing. Though the figure was broken down -- $6 billion to stabilize the ruble, $2.5 billion to reschedule Russia's debt, $4.5 billion in aid from the International Monetary Fund and $11 billion in direct aid -- aside from the United States ($4.5 billion), just who would give what was left hanging. When Mr. Bush called a news conference, he failed to notify Japan. That miffed Tokyo. And what would all that direct aid be used for? A quarter of the American aid will be in the form of food credits -- a bad idea some say. "They don't need food, they need food processing equipment and trucks," said Benjamin Weiner, of Probe International, a consulting firm. "Food credits are for the American farmers."
 
Japan -- Bad News and Rice
 
When it afflicted Europe, it was called Euro sclerosis -- a mixture of slow growth and rigid labor markets resulting in rising costs and shrinking profits. Now Japan may have caught the malady. Economists put Japan's growth rate at 1.5 percent this year, lower than the Government's estimate, and the country's no-layoff policy means costs could rise even as growth slows. Profits and investment are starting to sag, the stock market is at 1986 levels and rather than investing overseas, Japan is repatriating funds. Last week Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa proposed a cure: a $37 billion public works program. The Bank of Japan followed by clipping three-quarters of a point from the discount rate, bringing it to 3.75 percent. But economists doubt the efficacy of the remedy. "The party's over," said Paul Summerville, of Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo.
 
For years, trade negotiators have been pressuring Japan to open its market to American rice. Last week, Tokyo finally agreed, but with a catch: American rice may be displayed at a food fair later this month but "the U.S. may not promote the rice for sale or let the participants taste it during the exhibition," said Masami Tanabu, Japan's Agriculture Minister.

Exit Cresson, Enter Beregovoy
 
Tough-talking Edith Cresson, who resigned last week as France's Prime Minister, managed to offend almost everyone during her 10 months in office. Among other things, she questioned the virility of British men -- Anglo-Saxon men are not interested in women as women, she said -- and called the Japanese, "worker ants." But when she offended French voters it was too much. With an election looming, a recession underway and the popularity of the ruling Socialist party tumbling -- only 31 percent of the voters support it -- Mrs. Cresson had to go. French President Francois Mitterrand appointed Pierre Beregovoy, the Finance Minister, to take her place. It was Mr. Beregovoy who brought France's inflation rate down to 3 percent and liberalized its financial markets.

Beer Attack on Canada
 
Getting American suds into Canada has been difficult at best, even with the free trade pact and pressure from the Bush Administration. Last week, Canada's Trade Minister, Michael Wilson, said Canada would open up its beer market in about three years. But three years is not fast enough to slake the the President's thirst for open markets. The Administration let it be known that it may impose duties on Canadian beer this week.
 
South Carolina, Meet BMW
 
Rumor has it that BMW, which builds its ultimate driving machines only in Germany, is considering placing a plant in the United States, specifically in Anderson, S.C. Last week, Eberhard von Kuenheim, BMW's chairman, admitted that Anderson was being considered. He also admitted BMW, which had sales of $18.2 billion last year, more than half from exports, needed more capacity. If built, the new plant would probably be small, analysts say. "It could do well with a volume of 50,000 cars a year," said Philip Ayton, who follows BMW for Barclays de Zoete Wedd in London.
 
The Squeeze on Olympia & York
 
Olympia & York Ltd., the big Canadian developer, owes its creditors $18.5 billion. It owns millions of square feet of vacant space and is strapped for cash. So last week, when $450 million of its loans came due, it tried to get its creditors to extend that debt for another year. The bankers refused to comply. The loan's collateral, the 68-story Scotia Plaza in Toronto's financial district, may now be seized.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Keating Accountants Pay Up
 
Twenty-three thousand investors -- more or less -- were defrauded by Charles H. Keating. They invested in worthless securities sold by Mr. Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and its parent company, the American Continental Corporation, and lost $430 million. The investors argued that they wouldn't have bought those securities if Mr. Keating's auditors had done their job and called attention to irregularities. They also argued that by fending off the regulators, Mr. Keating's lawyers were part of the scam. Last week, in an out-of-court settlement, Ernst & Young, the nation's second-largest accounting firm, agreed to pay $63 million in fines, and Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, the nation's third-largest law firm, agreed to pay $24 million. Neither firm admitted guilt.

G.E.'s Cameo at the Oscars
 
When the film maker Debra Chasnoff accepted the Oscar for best short-subject documentary, gasps could be heard in Fairfield, Conn. That's where the General Electric Company has its headquarters. In front of an audience of about one billion people, Ms. Chasnoff, who won the award for "Deadly Deception: General Electric, Nuclear Weapons and Our Environment," urged consumers to boycott G.E. She mentioned its involvement in the manufacture of nuclear weapons at the contaminated Hanford Nuclear Power Reservation in eastern Washington. G.E., was not amused. "These people's goal is unilateral disarmament, and unilateral disarmament has virtually no support among the American people," said Joyce Hergenhan, a spokeswoman for G.E.

Disney's TV Strategy
 
Last week the deal makers at the Walt Disney Company agreed to an interesting swap. They will trade KCAL-TV in Los Angeles for a 45 percent stake in Pinelands, the company that owns WWOR-TV, Channel 9, in metropolitan New York. The deal, which is worth about $210 million, means Disney gives up full control of one broadcast station but gets partial control of two. It also gives Disney "a wealth of programming opportunities," said Richard Frank, president of Disney's studio division.

G.M. to Part With Allison
 
The General Motors Corporation has had its share of red ink lately. To raise a little cash, it said it will sell its Allison Gas Turbine Division -- which manufactures turbine engines. Allison builds aircraft and helicopter engines and power-generating turbines.

 
 
ECONOMY

 
Tiptoeing Toward Recovery
 
The economy may not be bungee-jumping off the Hollywood sign, or doing one-handed push-ups a la Jack Palance on Oscar night, but it is starting to show a little life. The Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators advanced eight-tenths of 1 percent for February, the second rise in a row. "A recovery does seem in place after 18 months of recession and 11 quarters of distinctly sub par economic growth," said Allen Sinai, of the Boston Company Economic Advisors. Mr. Sinai expects first-quarter growth of between 1 percent and 2 percent.

The Consumer Smiles, a Little
 
Consumers, in the doldrums for months, are beginning to get a little more confident, the Conference Board reported last week. The Board's consumer confidence index jumped to 54 in March, from 47.3 in February. The index was 100 in 1985. Consumers are a little less worried about their job prospects, it seems. But they are not yet ready to open up their wallets. The board said just 5.9 percent of those who responded to its survey said they were planning to buy a new car. Even fewer -- just 3.3 percent -- said they were planning to purchase a house. According to Fabian Linden, the survey director, the results should be "assessed with considerable caution."
 
Not Much Hope on Jobs
 
Unemployment remained unchanged for March at 7.3 percent, the Labor Department said last week. "Overall labor market conditions as measured by our data held steady in March," said William Barron, deputy commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Steady or not, what was worrisome to economists was how few jobs were created last month -- just 19,000, well below the consensus forecast of 45,000. "The numbers are not good," said Frank Pusateri, an economist at the Bank of Boston.

In S.&L's, Even the Bailout Stalls
 
Many in Congress feel the Government's bail out of the savings and loan industry has been managed about as badly as the savings and loans themselves. Billions of dollars are unaccounted for, questionable deals abound and the bailout is proceeding slowly. So slowly, in fact, that the Resolution Trust Corporation still has $17 billion left in its till from the $25 billion Congress authorized it to spend in December. The R.T.C. was supposed to dispense that money by April 1. Last week it asked Congress for more time. The Senate said yes, but the House overwhelmingly voted no. The House vote shut down the bailout. The R.T.C. said it would stop arranging sales of troubled institutions. Last week, a bill was introduced in Congress to get things going again.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Is the Forecast Too Good to Be True?

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Fabian Linden says he is known around the Conference Board, the business-research organization, as Mr. Doom and Gloom. For one thing, he is in charge of polling consumer confidence, which has lately been more of an oxymoron than an index. "I can't be accused of being an irrepressible optimist," he said in a recent interview.
Nevertheless, Mr. Linden is author of a report, released late last month by the Conference Board, that seems to contradict the pessimistic figures that cascade across his desk every month as well as the pessimistic prophecies from America's departments of economics. "The Great Income Reshuffle" predicts that the 90's will be a period of economic growth, expanded personal and household income and increased opportunity. "The idea that we are losing the middle class and the American dream is tarnished has no basis in reality," Mr. Linden said. 
 Mr. Linden argues that the United States has demographics on its side: a huge segment of the 78 million-member baby-boom generation is about to hit its so-called peak earning years of 45 to 55, which will expand higher-income brackets; the numbers of women entering the labor force will continue to grow and, as they gain experience, they will achieve wage parity with men. And, Mr. Linden predicts, the young segment of the baby-boom cohort, which hasn't married yet, will soon start to marry in droves, creating multi-paycheck households.
Little is loved more in journalism than the contrarian point of view, and Mr. Linden's study has made the rounds in the last week. Its sudden intrusion into the discussion of the future of the American economy and its workers and businesses infuriates holders of more conventionally downbeat opinions.
"It hurts people because it gets in the way of a constructive discussion of work in America," said Dan Lacey, editor of Workplace Trends, a Westlake, Ohio-based newsletter. "When some high-profile person from a place like the Conference Board throws out a report like this, it sets us back."
The problem seems to be not so much Mr. Linden's data as his interpretation. "The data are not untrue," said Heidi Hartmann, an economist who is director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. "It is just a different way of looking at the same data."
Richard S. Belous, a senior economist at the National Planning Association, also in Washington, was a little blunter about the study: "If you torture data long enough it will testify to anything," he said.
Mr. Belous, who once worked at the Conference Board, says he was amazed at the study's projections. "We have projected that the 90's will be slow growth, with no real increase in the living standard." he said. "I do not see a fast-growing economy. There is no engine to growth and I don't see one coming."
There is some dispute on facts. Ms. Hartmann is dubious about the report's characterization of women's income: "Their earnings contribute more to families at the bottom than families at the top," meaning that their wages are more likely to maintain than expand household income. And the Census Bureau projects nowhere near the huge growth in the marriage rate predicted by the Conference Board.
But the fundamental issue, according to critics, is that the study's focus on demographics misses the point. For example, Mr. Linden argues that the demise of the middle class is greatly exaggerated and that Labor Department figures do not support the "alarmist" thesis that middle-income jobs are vaporizing. "The distribution of occupations per se doesn't say anything about income," said John Bregger, an assistant commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, echoing the sentiments of other experts.
And that seems to be the crux of the criticism: "It's ignoring the key thing people care about -- their wages," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard economist who said there has been a great polarization of earnings in the last decade. "People with low skills have taken a big beating; people with high skills have had a rise in earnings." He added: "If the study is a marketing guide, it may be exactly what people want to know. Marketers don't care why people have more money."
Because his study is a marketing guide, Mr. Linden, whose official title at the Conference Board is director of the Consumer Research Center, sounds slightly startled by his critics. His intent was to provide information businesses could use to predict consumer behavior in the 90's. He says he has no political agenda and he does not sound like someone who much enjoys spending time reading the entrails of economists: "We shouldn't whip ourselves into the notion that we are going straight to hell."
 
 
 
THE END OF UPWARD MOBILITY?
 Part of the objection Dan Lacey, editor of Workplace Trends newsletter, has to the Conference Board's rosy scenario for the 90's is that he spends a lot of time traveling and talking to people with horror stories about losing jobs, medical benefits, homes, savings, whatever. "It's not as bad as you've heard," he said. "It's worse."
Baby boomers have yet to come to grips with the fact that their parents' expansive access to opportunity, from which their own expectations were derived, was almost certainly anomalous. "The postwar boom was experienced by one generation of American workers," he said. "To extrapolate anything from those decades is foolish."
Is he perhaps confusing an extended recession with the twilight of civilization? "A lot of unhappiness some economists have is that we are in a recession and have some severe social problems," said Fabian Linden, author of the Conference Board report.
But Richard Belous, an economist, says the recession isn't the issue: "It will pass. There are still long-term structural problems that will diminish growth."
