HEADLINE: Canada's Mighty Banks on a March to the South

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
A new group has joined the cross-border shopping spree: Canadian banks. Prodded by the drive for free trade between America and Canada and the recent wave of bank mergers in the United States that has threatened their North American standing, Canada's banks are jockeying to acquire American assets.
* Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the country's second-largest bank, bought $750 million of secured loans from the failed Bank of New England in 1990 and now has its line out for a full-scale bank. 
 * The National Bank of Canada, the country's sixth-largest, bought secured commercial loans from the Bank of New England and nine branches outside of New England from the New England Financial Corporation, an arm of the Boston Bancorp, giving it 16 offices in the United States, more than any Canadian bank. "Our strategy is to build on what we have in mid-size lending to mid-sized business," said Pierre Paquette, senior executive vice president.
* Since it was acquired seven years ago by the Bank of Montreal, Harris Bancorp of Chicago has bought 13 suburban banks. Anticipating the purchase of at least one more significant financial institution in the United States, Matthew W. Barrett, chairman and chief executive of the Bank of Montreal, said he expects the United States to account for 50 percent of earnings by the year 2000, up from less than 30 percent today.
Canadian banks are foraging to the south in part because they are reaching expansion limits at home. Although Canada has only a handful of banks, compared with 12,400 in the United States, it is perhaps the most overbanked country in the world in terms of branches per customer, with more bank branches than bars, according to Peter C. Newman, a columnist for Mclean's.
"We have 25 percent of the market here," noted Allan R. Taylor, chairman and chief executive of the Royal Bank, Canada's largest. "To achieve 30 percent would take a great deal of doing. The United States is the most logical place for expansion."
And American regulators seem to be welcoming Canadian buyers wholeheartedly, in part because they are more robust and profitable than their cousins to the south. The southern expansion is not likely either to be slowed by the crisis afflicting Canada's richest family, the Reichmann brothers, whose Olympia & York real estate empire, one of the world's largest, recently ran into a liquidity crisis. Bank shares on the Toronto Stock Exchange have fallen about 15 percent since Jan. 1, due to the difficulties of the Reichmanns and profit-taking after setting new highs last year. But the banks seem well postioned to weather any losses.
Analysts say the Olympia & York developments might even provide greater impetus for banks to push into the American consumer market. "Once again, as in the failure of Dome Petroleum or Campeau Corporation, we're finding that corporate banking tends to be high risk," said Alain Tuchmaier, financial services analyst for McLean McCarthy Inc., a subsidiary of the Deutsche Bank of Frankfurt. "This will intensify efforts to diversify into retail banking -- clearly one of the potential avenues of growth in the U.S."
Canadian banks are among the most profitable and secure in the world. While loan losses have been rising during the recession, which has hit Canadians far harder than Americans, four of the Big Six banks still reported record profits for last year. Over the past two decades, just 20 thrifts and two small regional banks failed in Canada, compared with hundreds in the United States.
The reasons for their good performance are a savings rate that is two to three times that in the United States and a friendly regulatory environment. Seen as a great unifying force, banks here have been left relatively free to run their own affairs. Nationwide banking is encouraged. Banks even own investment houses, whereas in the United States banks have been largely barred from stock market activities since 1933.
Thanks to the favorable regulatory environment, Canada's Big Six national banks -- Royal, Canadian Imperial, Bank of Montreal, Bank of Nova Scotia, Toronto Dominion and the National Bank of Canada -- control about half of all Canadian personal deposits, nearly two-thirds of personal loans and one-third of all mortgages outstanding. The rest of the Canadian market is divided by 58 smaller banks, 56 of them foreign owned; 80 trust companies and 3,000 credit union branches.
But some analysts say they need to expand in the United States if only to protect their positions in Canada. As barriers come down under the 1989 Canadian-American free trade agreement, warned James L. Darroch, professor of international business at York University, "Canadian banks risk losing market share in Canada if they can't help their clients in the United States."
The merger wave in the United States has also added a sense of urgency. Since the marriage of Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover, the Royal Bank has dropped to third place among banks in North America, from second. "The Canadians desperately want to find the right property," said Jeffrey N. Wieser, former president of the Manufacturers Hanover Bank of Canada.
High in the towers above Bay Street overlooking gray-blue expanses of Lake Ontario, senior officers of Canada's top banks sift piles of data on American banks. "What we have in mind is buying something that is really small and then adding to it," said Mr. Taylor of the Royal Bank. "We'll start regional, but of course we have national aspirations because that's what we know best."
The Royal Bank was rumored last year to be interested in linking with the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York, which would give it access to a huge retail business. But both banks have stoutly denied any such marriage plans. Royal's chief acknowledges that his special acquisitions committee has looked closely at "maybe 30 or 35" American banks, but will not name prospective candidates.
Yet the name of one candidate came out last fall in a bidding war for Security Bancorp Inc. of Southgate, Mich. Royal faced off with the First American Bank Corporation of Kalamazoo, Mich., which won with a share swap worth $552 million, nearly three times book value. Price rather than country of origin seemed to be the deciding factor. "I think three times book is too much, just way too much of a premium," Mr. Taylor said.
Jeffrey S. Chisholm, vice chairman of the Bank of Montreal, said his institution is also looking hard at the Middle West. "We need a good cultural fit," he said.
Southward expansion is not without pitfalls. Royal Trustco Ltd. for example, talked glowingly about North American prospects in 1989, when it paid $212 million for the Seattle-based Pacific First Financial Corporation. It has since had to write off an unexpected large volume of bad loans.
Misjudgment of cross-border market risks were spotlighted in the collapse of retail empire of Robert Campeau; Peoples Jewellers Ltd., whose Texas-based Zale Corporation recently filed for Chapter 11, and Canadian Tire, which muffed an expansion in Texas a few years ago.
Not all Canadian banks even agree that an American presence is desireable. "You can't buy a bank in the United States that would give you a reasonable amount of market share without spending a huge amount of money, and you can't make money in the United States unless you have a big market share," said R. M. Thomson, chairman and chief executive of the $68.9 billion Toronto Dominion Bank, which has been especially hard hit by the economic downturn in Ontario. "We feel we can build a strong North American position without buying anything."
 
 
 
PREPARED FOR OLYMPIA & YORK
 Noting that assets of the Reichmann family's Olympia & York real estate and natural resources empire still outweigh their debts, many banking analysts here see the crisis as essentially a short-term cash problem that should not impair banks.
Canadian banks' outstanding loans to the Reichmanns are believed to be in the range of $2.5 billion to $3 billion, representing about 10 percent of the industry's equity base.
Kersi Doodha, a banking analyst at Maison Placements Canada Inc., said the banks over two years might eventually have to write off 20 percent of their Reichmann exposure, or about $600 million. But the industry traditionally makes generous provisions for possible write-offs -- $3.2 billion this year at the Big Six banks. Against such numbers, Mr. Doodha said, "the Olympia and York situation is really quite manageable."
Allan R. Taylor, head of the Royal Bank, said that even if there should be some Olympia & York write-offs, he sees no need to alter the $740 million in loan-loss provisions his bank has set for this fiscal year. Olympia & York's debt restructuring, Mr. Taylor observed, "is not a life-threatening event for the Royal Bank of Canada."

HEADLINE: A Not-So-Unfortunate Career

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The unfortunate story that Webster Brown portrays is not so unfortunate. During his 26-year career, there have been serious recessions that displaced millions of employees throughout America. How unfortunate is it that Mr. Brown, as part of I.B.M.'s financial assistance program, received in his early retirement program two years of full salary, a lifetime pension eligibility, free health care for himself and his spouse plus many other company-paid benefits? 
 How much is employee loyalty supposed to be worth? Mr. Brown should look at the Americans who have lost jobs with little or no severance, no pension, no health care and no financial security.
 
SHELDON I. KURTZ
Warren, N.J., March 23
 
The writer is president of Kurtz Pro-Search Inc. and has specialized in recruiting and outplacement in the computer industry.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Swarthmore;
No Trees Fall in Forest, And 3 Hear Triumph

DATELINE: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

 BODY:
By turning their final project for an ecology class into a legal appeal to the United States Forest Service, three Swarthmore College students have blocked management policies that they said endangered the ecosystem of the Monongahela National Forest in West Virginia.
"Rather than fall into the trap of making academia a detached endeavor, we decided to confront the ecological crises of our times directly," said Brendan Kelly, a senior in political science from Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Kelly, along with another political-science major, B. J. Chisholm, a junior from Manchester, Conn., and David Tecklin, a senior from San Juan Ridge, Calif., majoring in biological anthropology, filed a legal appeal on two issues affecting the Monongahela ecosystem. 
 The students combined their ecological knowledge with the provisions of the National Environmental Protection Act and the National Forest Management Act to make their case. They objected to a plan for Monongahela that would allow oil and gas wells to be drilled in the next 10 to 15 years and call for the construction of new roadways.
They also appealed the sale plan for timber, which grants the highest-bidding private timber company access to more than 1,700 acres of the forest. The winning company is allowed to clear-cut 1,000 acres, removing all timber with a diameter of two or more inches.
 
Preliminary Injunctions
 In addition to destroying the "biological integrity" of the forest, the students said, the propositions would sacrifice the environment to business interests. "The taxpayers' money pays for the assessments and the drawing up of the plans, and private companies reap the profits," Mr. Kelly said. "The Forest Service is creating economic markets that are destroying the natural forests."
The proposals under attack were approved by James Page, the Monongahela Forest Supervisor. He recommended to the regional supervisor that the appeals be dismissed without review because the environmental studies called for would take at least eight years.
The regional director, Floyd Marita, responded to the appeals by granting two out-of-court preliminary injunctions, halting all actions permitted by the propositions until their ecological impact can be re-assessed.
As a result of their successful appeals, the grass-roots environmental group, Preserve Appalachian Wilderness, invited the students to testify before the House Interior Appropriations Subcommittee against Forest Service management policies and to lobby members of Congress to encourage support for the Ancient Forest Protection Act and the Forest Biodiversity Protection and Clearcutting Prohibition Act.
 
Technical Skills
 "I was told a number of times by Congressional aides that it was very refreshing not to be sitting with a professional lobbyist, but to talk with someone who was more invested in the issue," Ms. Chisholm said.
"As students, we have access to a lot of information and technical skills," Mr. Tecklin said. "Our role is to provide those to concerned citizen groups to facilitate their own efforts."
Known as the Eastern Forests and Mountains Conservation Project, the group has expanded this semester to more than 20 from the three Swarthmore students, Mr. Tecklin said, allowing them to review in detail policies affecting other national forests. They plan to organize a course on conservation biology and applied ecology to monitor forest management using current environmental research.

HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
2 Rarities From The Young Rossini

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH

 BODY:
The Rossini bicentennial celebration this year is not likely to elicit as many performances of early Rossini as the Mozart bicentennial last year did of early Mozart. That is all to the good, for there is less to be learned from the contrast with later works than in Mozart's case: Rossini's early operas already contain most of the elements of the mature composer's work, albeit less fully developed.
Still, there are fresh and individual delights to be had in those youthful creations as well, and it is pleasant to encounter an occasional program like the Rossini double bill the John Brownlee Opera Theater is presenting at the Manhattan School of Music: "L'Occasione Fa il Ladro" ("Opportunity Makes the Thief") and "La Scala di Seta" ("The Silken Ladder"), two one-act comic operas from 1812. Not surprisingly, both plots involve amorous deceits and misadventures, and in each case the pairings shake out properly at the end. 
 Though the "Scala" overture is familiar, the lovely opera as a whole is seldom performed. (The Children's Free Opera of New York staged it in Brooklyn 12 years ago.) Deservedly, "L'Occasione" is an even rarer item; it was reported at the time of its premiere to have been written within 11 days, and alongside "La Scala," it sounds it.
Or at least it did in the second performance, on Friday evening. In widely disparate performances by separate casts, only "Scala" was done justice vocally.
Tamara Hardesty was a particular joy as Giulia, singing with a clear, agile soprano and spinning out the coloratura with ease. But the rest of the cast was reasonably strong as well. As Giulia's secret husband, Dorvil, Matthew Chellis, a tenor, negotiated high florid passages honorably despite constricted tone in his upper register. Keith Spencer made much of relatively unpromising material as the servant Germano. Steven Gaertner, as Giulia's suitor, Blansac, and Belinda Pigeon, as Giulia's cousin, Lucilla, had good moments.
"Occasione" was a sadder affair, salvaged only by fine work from Andrea Wilkomirski, a soprano, as Berenice. Mark Heimbigner sang Berenice's would-be fiance, Don Parmenione, with a presentable baritone, but tended, with flabby articulation, to disappear in patter and ensembles. Jorge Garza, as Berenice's actual fiance, Count Alberto, produced attractive sounds in his middle register but could muster only ineffectual stabs at the top notes.
In both works, but especially "Occasione," the singers seemed to have difficulty at times finding their way into Christopher Larkin's tempos. Erratic orchestral playing reinforced the gloom in "Occasione" but detracted little from "Scala."
Johnathon Pape's stage direction brought out a lot of silly hamminess from several of the men, but the physical production was admirable in its economy. Peter Eastman's set design used the same basic framework for both works. A running theme carried through the decor: an uplifted hand with an orb suspended above it that looked at first like a basketball, at times like the earth and finally like the sun, perhaps grandiosely symbolizing the Enlightenment.
The program will be presented once more, this afternoon with a somewhat different cast, at the Manhattan School, 122d Street and Broadway.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Belinda Pigeon, left, Keith Spencer and Tamara Hardesty in the Rossini work "La Scala di Seta." (Jeffrey Langford)

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
In Florida, Testing Road to the Future

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
IT used to be that automotive technology had to do with . . . well, with cars. Ultimately, if you were a manufacturer, you went with Cadillac's electric starter. Or with Ford's inexpensive V8. Or with Plymouth's hydraulic brakes.
These days, though, the innards are pretty much alike. To be sure, some cars lack air bags and antilock brakes, but those things will come, dictated by the marketplace. And so, more and more, the technology has to do not with rods and levers and multiple-valve engines, but with the periphery. 
 There are things, for instance, like sound systems with compact-disk changers mounted in the trunk. There are push-button keychains to let you unlock the doors or open the trunk as you approach the car. There are dashboard video screens and radar add-ons that beep if you get too close to the car in front.
Things now work with infrared rays and sonic senders and microwaves, and none of them have a lot to do with the actual mechanical function of the car. But they are where we are -- and, face it, they are kind of neat.
The latest of these peripherals combines Oldsmobile's built-in video screen with a network of "smart" roads in Orlando, Fla., where a yearlong test of TravTek began last week.
The name, short for Travel Technology, designates a $12 million project that, at long last, could make reality of the future that was forecast at the 1939 World's Fair and that kept a lot of us reading Popular Science magazine through the 40's, 50's, 60's, 70's and 80's.
The idea is a system to help drivers -- through various technologies including triangulation by satellite -- to find out where they are and where they would like to be. TravTek provides instant access to video map displays, gives you audio and visual driving directions, tells you about current traffic conditions, and can even make a reservation at a four-star restaurant. Well, maybe.
Partners in the experiment, among others, are the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Avis Rent a Car System, General Motors, Navigation Technologies Corporation, Etak Incorporated and Motorola. At the announcement in Orlando, Secretary of Transportation Andrew Card said the project was much needed and would explore technologies "to ease traffic congestion and improve travel conditions in many American cities."
The test will involve 100 '92 Olds Toronados whose computers receive information on traffic conditions from Orlando's traffic management center. The information, in turn, comes from highway video cameras, road sensors, emergency vehicles and construction reports. Each car's location is pinpointed by the satellite and through compasses and wheel sensors on a computerized dashboard map that operates with a database provided by the American Automobile Association.
While driving, the map and the audio information, tell you exactly where you are and where to turn. When the car is parked, the dashboard display offers information on hotels, restaurants, attractions and special events in the area.
By all accounts, it works wonderfully well, although the start of the project was less than auspicious. Robert Frosch, a General Motors vice president and one of the first drivers to try it out, got into his Toronado, started the engine, checked the information and put the Olds into gear.
He ran over an orange traffic cone and smashed it flat.
Meanwhile, the University of Michigan has put out a forecast for the automobile industry through the end of the century, and the study notes that electronic components, currently amounting to 10 percent of a car's value, will climb to nearly 20 percent of the total value in the next eight years.
The survey, based on responses from more than 200 engineers, scholars and consultants, also notes that Government regulations rather than fuel prices will force major changes in the design of automobiles. The price of gas, the study said, will increase modestly through the year 2005, rising to about $1.75 per gallon in 1990 dollars.
According to the study, regulations will mandate fuel economy increases from today's level of 27.5 miles per gallon to 30 m.p.g. for 1995, 33 for the year 2000, and 36 m.p.g. for 2005.
In order to meet those standards, the university report said, manufacturers will reduce the weight of vehicles through the use of more plastics, aluminum, magnesium and powdered metals.
Recycling will be a big issue in the future, according to David Cole, director of the school's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation, and manufacturers eventually may be required to buy used cars back from their customers.
Not surprisingly, Cole also said that air bags will be standard for the driver and front-seat passenger on all cars produced in America by the end of the decade. But he added that air bags to protect rear occupants and to ward off side impacts will be widely available. And, he said, radar controlled brakes and alarms to prevent collisions are on their way.
Seems to me I read something about that. I think it was in Popular Science. Somewhere around 1948.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 11; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Setting Priorities In Public Education

 BODY:
The article "Public Colleges Face Bitter Economic Lessons" (March 8) prompted me to write this letter.
As a person who grew up in a lower-middle-class household in New York City and is now a resident of Connecticut, I am concerned about the remarkable difference in priority placed on public educational institutions and access to higher education between these two jurisdictions. 
 While growing up in New York City, I attended Stuyvesant High School, a publicly funded school for gifted students. I received an excellent free education, one that can be surpassed by few, if any, private preparatory high schools in the country. New York City, despite its current fiscal problems, is currently putting the finishing touches on a new Stuyvesant High School in downtown Manhattan.
After graduating from high school, New York City residents had, and still have, the opportunity to attend many well-funded high-quality public institutions. Additionally, New York State residents can also be awarded a merit-based New York State Regents scholarship that can be used at any public or private institution of higher learning in their state.
Now that I am living in Connecticut, the most affluent state in the nation, the choices available to my children are not quite as varied. All across the state, programs for all, from elementary through high school, are being curtailed. Connecticut's institutions of higher learning are not adequately funded, even in times of economic prosperity.
Despite a tuition increase of 78 percent in the last four years, the University of Connecticut is not considered to be a first-tier institution, due primarily to a long-term lack of adequate funding. Connecticut does not have a "portable" public scholarship program to assist its students in attending in-state private or public institutions. Additionally, access is now being greatly restricted at all public institutions of higher learning because of recent drastic reductions in funding.
The dichotomy between the many options to students in New York City, with its associated low per-capita income and constant budget problems, and Connecticut, with its high per-capita income and sporadic budgetary problems, is clear.
It appears that the long-term position of the Connecticut legislature is that education to meet the needs of all is not to be provided. Rather, needs at the elementary through high school levels will continue to go unmet because of inadequate funding, while access to institutions of higher learning will be limited by ability to find space available at community colleges and state universities, and by ability to pay at private institutions.
Is this really how the most affluent state in the country wants the educational needs of its residents addressed?
 
WESLEY L. WINTERBOTTOM
West Hartford

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Growing Black Debate on Racism: When Is It Real, When an Excuse?

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
At church meetings, at social gatherings and in informal conversations across the country, more and more blacks, many for the first time, have become openly critical of apologists for certain members of their race.
They contend that the actions of national figures like Mike Tyson, Marion S. Barry Jr. and Dr. Leonard Jeffries Jr. are disgraceful and cannot be excused and that, as role models, their behavior can bring shame to the race. 
 But there are those who still maintain that these individuals are victims of the white establishment and should be defended no matter what.
The emotionally charged debate has prompted blacks, from celebrities to day laborers, to re-examine what it means to be black in America today. Many say they are finding that the old unanimity no longer stands; the historic sense of a communal psychology is slowly dissipating.
"The question that would typify our dilemma is: What happened to the values, attitudes and exemplary personal examples by which we, as African-Americans, defined the civil rights movement and its offspring, the feminist movement?" said Arthur Ashe, the tennis star and author of "A Hard Road to Glory: A History of the African-American Athlete" (Amistad-Warner, 1988).
"During the civil rights struggles," he continued, "we definitely laid claim to the high moral ground, and now, by condoning what some of our leaders do and not acting in a manner we would have been proud of in the 60's, we are being seen as no better than anybody else."
The internal conflict among blacks is no more evident than in blacks' responses to three highly publicized cases. In the Tyson rape trial, for example, some saw the conviction as just Yet there were those, including several leading black ministers, who said the odds were stacked against Mr. Tyson right from the start: the jury was predominantly white.
To many black Washingtonians, last year's conviction of Mayor Barry on charges of cocaine possession was a miscarriage of justice. The prosecutors acknowledged that the Barry case was the first time the Federal Government had used sexual enticement to lure a target into criminal behavior. But other blacks said Mr. Barry used charges of racism to defend his brazen personal behavior and political failures.
The recent removal of Dr. Jeffries as head of the black studies department at City College in New York is still another example of black ambivalence. Some blacks contend that racism was a motivating factor in the decision to oust him, but there are also those who say the professor was tempting fate with his incendiary remarks, including those directed at Jews and white historians.
 
Keeping in Mind a Racist Society
 "This is a racist society, and it will be for a long time to come," said Roger Wilkins, a former Assistant Attorney General who is a history professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va. "That people make racist attacks on certain black people does not absolve those who have been attacked of behaving decently and keeping their human commitments."
Most of the two dozen blacks interviewed say they do not want to give blacks an excuse to be lawless. Nevertheless, they may find themselves in the uncomfortable position of defending other blacks who have been accused of actions they may not condone because of a strong and persistent conviction that there is a double standard for blacks and whites, whether in judging political, criminal or personal behavior.
In an article, "The Rape of Mike Tyson," published in the March issue of Paper magazine, the film maker Spike Lee and the rap star Queen Latifah convey the angst some blacks feel. Both said that although Mr. Tyson's victim was black, one had only to weigh the verdict against those in other headline-grabbing rape cases involving white men to see that the scales of justice were out of balance.
"In the Kennedy case, it was his word against hers, and he was found not guilty," said Queen Latifah, referring to the rape trial of William Kennedy Smith. While Mr. Lee said he did not want to pass judgment on Mr. Tyson, he believed that the system was "trying to demoralize him" because "he was making too much money."
During the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings last October, Judge Clarence Thomas was able to turn the tide of public support, especially among blacks, by calling the investigation into Prof. Anita F. Hill's accusation of sexual harassment "a high-tech lynching" of "an uppity black." Many blacks around the country immediately agreed, saying the hearings smacked of an orchestrated setup in which a black woman was being used to destroy a black man.
"Every black official ought to assume that someone is after them because of racism, so they ought to behave the way anyone would if someone was out to get them," said Mary Frances Berry, a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania and a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. "Racism is a fact of our lives. You can't be an African-American and not have to deal with racism."
 
The Silence Of Solidarity
 In recent weeks, prominent blacks, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the Rev. Al Sharpton and Dr. Alvin Poussaint, the Harvard psychiatrist, have publicly chastised other members of their race for failing to live up to the moral standards of earlier generations of black Americans.
The issue was the focus of discussion on March 27 at a community forum on violence, morality and values at the Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in Harlem.
James Goodwin, 20 years old, who abandoned his life as a leader of the Decepticons gang to become a director of the City Kids Foundation's repertory theater, told 150 people gathered in the church's auditorium: "Kids are making decisions for themselves, not for the black community or some black organization. Yeah, we all know racism exists, that it's still a white world. But we also have to take some of the responsibility and blame: kids not respecting each other or Mrs. Jones down the block. Kids killing each other. Racism should make us love one another, not disrespect or murder each other."
In the past such issues were seldom discussed outside private conversations among blacks and sympathetic whites, because blacks feared that any criticism of their community would be used by some whites against the entire race.
"It's almost as if the wish were: 'Gee, I wish I could talk to kids in high school about this, but I don't want whites to listen to it,' " said Andrew Hacker, a white professor of political science at Queens College who has written a new book, "Two Nations" (Scribner's), about race relations. "Blacks feel as if they have no privacy, that whites will quote them out of context or say, 'Hey, even blacks are admitting they're in a bad way.' "
Other blacks said they remained silent out of a sense of commitment to their race, of not wanting to air dirty linen in public, knowing that those who did speak out were often ostracized or "read out of the race."
"A lot of us are afraid that if we aren't intraculturally politically correct, we'll have people coming down on us, and so we just keep quiet," Mr. Ashe said. "Who needs it?"
 
Actions Speak Loudest of All
 Many middle-aged blacks, especially those who are parents, now wonder whether their silence may have been taken by some young blacks as tacit approval of their antisocial behavior, everything from criminal activity to a disregard for others' rights.
"Our young people consider little of what we say and most of what we do," said Robert Woodson, the president of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, a not-for-profit service group in Washington, who has written extensively on the need for moral consistency among blacks. "When we look at the examples they are following in their unlawfulness, we don't have to look at whites. Many of our black leaders are ignoring the dangers of the precedents they are setting."
During a speech to students at Thomas Jefferson High school in Brooklyn, where on Feb. 26 two black students were shot to death by another student, also black, Mr. Lee said: "We don't need the Ku Klux Klan anymore. We're killing ourselves, and it has to stop."
Mr. Jackson, another of the speakers at the high school, echoed the message, saying: "What difference does it make if it's a white police officer who shoots you down or a brother in a black coat because of some drug thing? You're dead."
Mr. Sharpton, who has been accused of defending questionable behavior by blacks after his involvement in the Tawana Brawley case, conceded that some of the current conduct was inexcusable. But he said he was still cautious about where to draw the line.
"I think that it is becoming difficult to walk the balance between racism and what is not," he said. "For the first time in the movement's recorded history, you have an element of professional apologists who have created a climate of totally excusing the racism. So when you want to discipline the negative elements in your community, you have to worry that you are not feeding into the hands of those who want you to discipline blacks as a way of relieving America and white society of its general racism."
While some blacks have criticized Mr. Sharpton for crying racism before the facts were in, he countered that he was one of the first to speak out about the stampede at City College last December. "I admonished the kids," he said, "by saying a trap may have been set, but just because it was set, you don't have to put your foot in it."
 
The Expansion Of Public Dialogue
 The emergence of an expanded public dialogue in newspaper editorials, rallies and other forums reflects an effort by blacks to focus the discussion from two perspectives: blacks cannot blame everything on racism, and whites cannot deny that race could be a factor.
"We don't want black men going around committing homicide and abusing our people," said Dr. Poussaint, the psychiatrist. "We know that's horrible and bad for blacks. At the same time, we feel, in the face of whites, that we have to put out to them that the institution of racism still exists and allows blacks to be treated differently and more harshly than whites."
Blacks worry that in crying racism too often, much like the boy who cried wolf, legitimate cases in which racism is a factor may be undermined. Even more disturbing, some say, is that age-old values like taking responsibility for one's actions, knowing right from wrong and loving one another, which were the cornerstone of the black creed in the era of racial segregation, seem to have been abandoned.
"Anyone who did not abide by the rules or brought shame to the community was labeled 'a disgrace to the race,' " said Henry Louis Gates Jr., the W. E. B. Du Bois Professor of the Humanities at Harvard. "Those who understood the importance of values and excelled were considered 'a credit to the race.' "
But today, with blacks more than ever separated from each other economically, socially and geographically, many of these messages are muted as young blacks mimic the narcissistic attitudes and values embraced by the Me Generation. Rather than turning the other cheek, many young people are more inclined to respond by striking back at anyone who offends them, much as the Homey the Clown character does on the popular television show "In Living Color": "Homey don't play that."
"I don't think a lot of young people today have that kind of historic sense of communal psychology," Dr. Poussaint said. "They're behaving more individualistically. On one level, they may be right. We shouldn't have to feel we are representing the whole race all the time. That is a burden, but that's the reality of racism."
Audrey Edwards, who with Dr. Craig Polite wrote "Children of the Dream: A Psychology of Black Success" (Doubleday, 1992), said: "As horrible as segregation was, the one thing it provided was a sense of community, a recognition that we are all in this together. Whatever intra-racial conflict we had, the black community understood we were in a depressed state. With integration, you have less of a sense of community, and it grows out of a sense that we are under a state of siege."

HEADLINE: What Japan Knew of Plan On Aid to Russia Is Debated

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Senior Administration officials vigorously asserted today, despite Tokyo's denials, that Japan had agreed with the size and timing of the $24 billion aid package for Russia announced by President Bush on Wednesday.
The officials said Japanese finance ministry officials attended a meeting last weekend in Paris where the Group of Seven industrial nations, according to the Americans, agreed to a vast package to help Russia. 
 "That the Japanese have been on the sidelines is absolutely untrue," a senior American official said. "They were aware of everything that's going on. They were aware of our action."
 
Move to Aid Yeltsin
 American officials also rebuffed the Japanese charge that the announcement had been premature, saying that all the Group of Seven nations knew the importance of unveiling a package that backed President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia before a parliament hostile to his economic changes convened next week.
"The Japanese Deputy Finance Minister was part of the discussions," another senior Administration official said in an interview. "They understand the stakes. They understand the importance of the aid."
Several Japanese officials said on Friday that there was no agreement on an overall aid package. "As far as our Government knows, there has been no agreement on this package," said a Japanese policy maker involved in aid to Russia. "These figures are extremely new to us. It was inappropriate to announce them."
The Japanese criticism has lent support to charges that the Bush Administration timed the announcements to gain advantage in the Presidential campaign.
The package that President Bush announced Wednesday includes $6 billion for a ruble stabilization fund, $2.5 billion in deferred debt payments and $4.5 billion from the International Monetary Fund and other international organizations. The plan also calls for $11 billion in direct aid from individual nations.
The American officials acknowledged that much of this $11 billion in bilateral assistance was announced months ago by individual Group of Seven nations.
 
A Consensus Among the Seven
 Senior Treasury Department officials said Congress would not have to authorize any of the $2 billion that Washington has committed toward this $11 billion, saying the whole $2 billion has already been authorized. The Administration called on Congress to approve a $12 billion contribution to the I.M.F. and to approve some humanitarian aid and export credits for next year.
"The essential point is there is a consensus among the Seven that the $11 billion is committed to and will be provided," said one senior American official. "Each of the countries has indicated what amounts they're prepared to do."
The Group of Seven consists of the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada.
Several American officials said it would be presumptuous for Washington to say how much other Group of Seven nations planned to commit. In interviews, officials from Canada, Britain, France and Japan said they had little idea how much their countries were supposed to have committed to the $11 billion in bilateral aid.
"It's all a bit mysterious," said a French official. "There are still discussions going on on the details."
A Canadian official said he thought the White House was including $1.5 billion his country announced in a multiyear aid package, most of which was in agricultual and export credits. But he said perhaps just the $700 million to be disbursed this year was included in the package.
 
Reassuring the Russians
 President Bush's announcement, like the one Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany made the same day, aimed to assure Russia that it would get the aid the I.M.F. said it needed this year.
These officials said the seven nations accepted the I.M.F. estimate that Russia would need $18 billion in aid to finance needed imports and another $6 billion for a ruble fund. Then the seven pieced together a plan that met this $24 billion need, they said.
In an interview today, a senior Japanese Finance Ministry official said that the Group of Seven had discussed providing $12 billion to fill an expected gap in Russia's balance of payments this year. He added that the group talked of an additional $6 billion as a contingency if the $12 billion was not enough.
Japanese officials said one of their complaints was that announcing the aid package at this point would reduce the pressure on Russia to pursue a tough reform program because it would think it would receive the aid no matter what. But American and I.M.F. officials say some of the aid can be cut off if Moscow fails to adhere to its I.M.F. program.
"We certainly appreciate Mr. Bush's efforts in supporting democracy and the transition to a free-market economy in Russia," said a senior Japanese Finance Ministry official in an interview today. "But we certainly think it was premature to make an announcement before there was a plan."
American officials suggested that the Japanese Government was complaining partly to appease voters, since Tokyo has long tied large-scale aid to Russia to resolving a dispute over islands in the Kurile chain north of the Japanese archipelago. The chain was seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II. One official said the Japanese Government also did not want to appear as if Washington had pushed it into aiding Moscow.
The Japanese criticism that the plan was announced prematurely appeared to fuel the charges that a disorganized Administration rushed to unveil the package before the front-runner in the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, gave a major foreign policy speech on Wednesday.
Clinton campaign officials have asserted that the White House scheduled the announcement at the exact hour of Mr. Clinton's speech to pre-empt Mr. Clinton's criticisms and to divert attention from his speech. But Administration officials say it was a coincidence that the President's news conference was scheduled at the same time as Governor Clinton's speech.
Administration officials said the speech was timed principally to two events. Because the Group of Seven has decided to let the I.M.F. take the lead in organizing aid to Russia, Administration officials said the aid package was timed to follow the I.M.F.'s endorsement of Russia's economic reforms. On Tuesday, the I.M.F. announced its endorsement of Russia's painful reforms, which include removing price controls and plans to slash its budget deficit.
"The idea that the timing of the package was dictated by some more immediate events is not so," said one official. "It was recognized that the commitment on the package could not get out front of the perceived commitment that the Russians were prepared to make economic reforms."
The second event that President Bush's speech was tied to, Administration officials said, was next week's session of the Russian Congress of Peoples Deputies. Administration officials said that in recent weeks Mr. Yeltsin has pressed the Group of Seven to come forth with an aid package to bolster his position against the many parliamentarians who oppose rapid free-market reforms.
"The big interest all of us had was to do it in a fashion that would be timely for Yeltsin," one American official said.
American and other Group of Seven officials also said they wanted to unveil a package before the I.M.F.'s April 27 meeting in Washington, when Russia and several other republics are expected to become I.M.F. members.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 26; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2259 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Brown Opened Doors but Failed to Build Coalitions

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS with KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 4

 BODY:
Edmund G. Brown Jr. left an unmistakable imprint on California in his two terms as Governor, with a record of far-sighted achievement when he could realize his own vision, but grand failure in matters requiring him to cooperate with other branches of government.
There is broad consensus here, where the Brown legacy can still provoke emotional debate, that the Governor's greatest accomplishment was opening the doors of government to women and minorities and truly integrating the state's highest offices, boards, commissions and judiciary. Mr. Brown served from 1975 through 1982, and his appointees have put in motion pioneering air quality standards, energy conservation programs and consumer protections that became models for the rest of the nation. 
 On the other side of the ledger, Mr. Brown is widely criticized for not heading off a taxpayers' revolt that produced Proposition 13, the ballot measure that in 1978 slashed property taxes and sent the state's finances reeling. Had Governor Brown been more attentive to angry citizens whose property taxes were soaring at a time of huge government surplus, critics say, he might have crafted tax relief legislation that was less severe. The loss in revenue from Proposition 13 has been blamed for contributing to crumbling infrastructure, overcrowded schools and understaffed law enforcement and public health departments.
"He was bold and innovative in the areas where he could just do it," said William Schneider, a political analyst at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. "But he cannot construct a coalition. All he can say is, 'I'm right, follow me,' and that doesn't work in politics."
 
Appointments
Talent for Tapping Diverse Nominees
 Mr. Brown often said as Governor that the power to appoint was the most significant part of his job, and by all accounts he did it well and innovatively, with the dramatic exception of Rose Bird, an obscure lawyer with no judicial experience whom the Governor made Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court. After overturning every death sentence conviction that came before her, Ms. Bird was recalled in 1986, along with two other liberal judges appointed with her. This populist purge opened three seats on the court for the conservative appointees of Gov. George Deukmejian, Mr. Brown's Republican successor in the statehouse.
Overall, Mr. Brown's appointments created what was probably the most diverse administration anywhere in the nation. According to the California Almanac, 49 percent of Mr. Brown's 6,866 executive appointments and 40 percent of his 800 judicial nominations were women or minority members.
Diversity under Mr. Brown was not limited to lowly posts. Half of his Cabinet officers were women, as well as his press secretary, finance director and transportation chief. He appointed a Hispanic secretary of health and welfare and named the first two black state Supreme Court justices.
Besides integrating the government, Mr. Brown brought in fresh (some would say inexperienced) faces and new (some would say crazy) ideas.
In choosing judges, he bypassed the established law firms and instead reached into legal aid offices and public-interest firms. He made a former astronaut his science and technology adviser, an expert on compost toilets the state architect, a quadriplegic the chief of the Department of Rehabilitation and a beat poet the head of the Arts Commission.
Mr. Brown was in his element when such appointees gathered for all-night intellectual salons: government by dialectic, it was called then, with far more questions asked then answered. But the Governor's weakness as a manager and coalition builder became insidious at other times, particularly in budget- making season.
 
Budget and Taxes
Misread, Then Fed Taxpayers' Anger
 In 1978, as Mr. Brown ended his first term, the growing protest over taxes was exploding into a full-fledged taxpayer's revolt. The state budget surplus swelled to nearly $4 billion, fueled in part by the income tax indexing measures of Ronald Reagan's previous administration, which forced workers into ever-higher tax brackets even as their pay raises only kept up with inflation.
Homeowners saw their property tax bills growing up to 50 percent a year as California housing rapidly inflated in value. For many low-income and retired people the huge tax bills threatened their very ability to remain in their homes.
For all his vaunted powers as a prophet, Mr. Brown utterly failed to read the mood of the public accurately and work with the Legislature toward a solution.
As an organized effort grew to place a property tax-cutting measure, Proposition 13, on the June 1978 ballot, Mr. Brown remained convinced it would not pass and proposed more unusual solutions, like a 55 percent tax credit to homeowners who installed solar heating.
Belatedly, Mr. Brown joined in supporting an alternative to Proposition 13 that would have offered partial property tax rebates. The voters defeated it and passed Proposition 13 by 65 percent.
 
Spent Surplus on Schools
 With Proposition 13 a fait accompli, Mr. Brown directed $2.2 billion of the state surplus to the schools and $1.85 million to the counties and cities as emergency relief, actions which make it possible for him to accurately make the campaign claim today that taxes were cut and financing for schools increased in his administration.
But seeing that government's response to their demands for limits was resulting in a handout of the surplus, voters rose up again in 1979. They passed another ballot measure that placed a lid on government spending, tying it to inflation and forcing government to receive voter approval for increased taxes.
Because the state constitution grants the governor the power to veto appropriations, Mr. Brown was eventually able to slash $2 billion from various budgets. But overall, state spending increased by nearly 120 percent during the Brown years after Proposition 13, even as the measure pushed down the individual state taxpayer's burden from $158 per thousand of taxable income in 1978 to $108 per thousand when Mr. Brown left office in 1982.
By that time, Proposition 13 had cut average property tax rates to $1.13 per $100 of assessed valuation in 1982 from $11.24 per $100 in 1972, and forced $7 billion in spending cuts. The budget surplus had evaporated into a deficit of more than $1 billion and the state's general fund reserve had fallen from nearly $2 billion to zero. The unemployment rate, worsened by a national recession, had risen to a record high of 9.9 percent.
Today, over a decade after Mr. Brown left office, the state faces a budget deficit of more than $14 billion, county governments are on the verge of bankruptcy and homeowners face wildly disparate property tax levels, depending on whether they bought their homes before or after Proposition 13 was passed.
 
Policy
Much Innovation, But Some Setbacks
 On policy matters, Mr. Brown's record is quirky, reflective of a man with a pattern of becoming absorbed in one issue to the neglect of all others. He was strongest, experts agree, on environmental and energy matters, far ahead of other states and setting a model for regulation and legislation elsewhere.
During the Brown years, California tightened air quality standards, which cut pollution by 25 percent and forced Detroit automakers to design new exhaust systems for the nation's largest car market.
Also, through tax incentives and tough action by his apointees to the Energy Commission and the Public Utilities Commisssion, Mr. Brown encouraged alternative, renewable energy sources, like generating electricity by burning industrial waste and woodchips and by using windmills, which now dot the California landscape. The Energy Commission he created also blocked construction of new nuclear power plants.
One of Mr. Brown's most widely respected monuments is the California Conservation Corps, which put men and women to work, New Deal-style, fighting fires and floods, restoring streambeds and the like.
But Mr. Brown had one notable collision with environmental groups, involving the notorious Mediterranean fruit fly, which infested farms and orchards in the state late in his second term. Pressed from both sides, by environmentalists who predicted disaster if there was aerial pesticide spraying, and by farmers who predicted economic doom, Mr. Brown dragged his feet and the pesky medfly wrecked havoc. Finally, he authorized the spraying, but by then had lost friends on both sides of the issue, and it weighed heavily in his 1982 race for a Senate seat, when Mr. Brown took a thumping at the hands of Pete Wilson.
 
Union for Farm Workers
 Mr. Brown's most heralded legislative success, early in his administration, gave farm workers organizing and bargaining rights for the first time in United States history. Prodded by his friend, Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farmworkers Union, Mr. Brown ended a decade of boycotts and bloodshed in the lettuce and grape fields by pushing through a bill establishing the Agriculture Labor Relations Board, which supervised union elections.
Analysts suggest that Mr. Brown was weakest in the areas where his father had earlier made his mark as a two-term governor. Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, an affable man who led the state from 1959 to 1967, is best known here as the master builder of California's highway, university and water systems. His son, by contrast, preached "small is beautiful" and is widely faulted for letting highways decay and cutting public education budgets early in his administration.
An examination of Mr. Brown's record involving highways and education indicates that he was more hostile in word than in deed, although hardly a champion of either roads or schools.
Consistent with his ideas about the environment and energy, the Governor sought to de-emphasize the automobile. Some new highways were built in Mr. Brown's tenure, apparently on the drawing board from the Reagan Administration, but older highways deteriorated. The Governor focused instead on modest mass transit projects, including a few commuter train lines, a trolley across the Mexican border and a fleet of experimental state cars that ran on methanol.
 
Ahead of His Time
 A major dispute of Mr. Brown's tenure involved a proposal to put car pool lanes on the Santa Monica Freeway, an experiment that was stalled by public protest. As with many ideas, including the proposed launching of a state telecommunications satellite, Mr. Brown was a few years ahead of his time. The so-called diamond lanes, then considered a heretical encroachment on motorists' rights, are now an accepted part of life here.
Public education fared poorly in the Brown years, even before the stringencies of Proposition 13 and a series of court rulings that altered education spending formulas. Mr. Brown threatened early to squeeze school budgets to inspire "reform." When asked what he had in mind, the Governor said, "I don't know yet" and never clarified the issue. California slipped from 18th to 31st nationally in per pupil school financing.
At the university level, Governor Brown froze faculty salaries, arguing that professors were compensated by their "psychic income."
The journalistic record of the Brown administration reveals little about the Governor's health policy, which was not a looming issue then as it is now. So, too, on crime the Brown years were relatively quiescent. The Governor signed several tough bills regarding mandatory prison terms for certain serious crimes. As a result, the number of felons sent to prison each year more than doubled in the Brown years.
 
Political Record
As Popularity Fell, G.O.P. Gained Entry

Some people say the singular contribution Mr. Brown made in state office was a political reorganization measure that was passed by voters here in the same year they elected him Governor. The Political Reform Act of 1974, while far from inclusive, fundamentally changed the nature of politics in the state capitol of Sacramento by limiting the influence of lobbyists.
Mr. Brown, then Secretary of State, was the act's principal author and touted it as the "two hamburgers and a Coke" measure. He rode to victory on a tide of post-Watergate disgust with politics as usual. Political observers here note, with a sense of deja vu, that the passage of the act depended on Mr. Brown's gift for galvanizing angry voters and showed him to be an effective agent for change, outside the confines of executive office.
Much of the criticism of Mr. Brown's tenure as Governor involves style more than substance, although it was style that many people say impeded his ability to govern. People who worked with him say he had a difficult personality.
The citizens of California also lost patience and changed from adoring to bemused to downright unhappy about their Governor. Fourteen months into his first term, according to The California Poll, Mr. Brown's job performance was rated as excellent or fair by 85 percent of those polled. When he left office in 1982, that approval rating had dropped to 58 percent.
Shortly thereafter, with Mr. Brown as the opponent, California voters elected Mr. Wilson to the United States Senate. The governor's chair was filled by Mr. Deukmejian. Mr. Schneider of the American Enterprise Institute said, "Jerry Brown was so disliked in his home state that he elected two Republicans on the same day and singlehandedly created a fashion for boring politicians."

HEADLINE: British Candidates Still Rely on the Hustings

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 4

 BODY:
When Britons vote on Thursday in 651 Parliamentary districts, they will be casting ballots for candidates who, in theory, have won their confidence the old-fashioned way.
Barred from buying time on television, and limited by law to spending no more than the equivalent of about $15,000 apiece, anyone who wants a seat in the House of Commons has no alternative but to campaign vigorously at the grass roots, knocking on doors, shaking hands and handing out leaflets. 
 But while British election law scrupulously limits the amount individual candidates themselves may spend, there are virtually no restrictions on how money can be raised or spent at the national level by Britain's political parties. Indeed, British election law does not even require the parties to disclose the names of private donors, no matter how much money they give.
As a result, with Britain's national election less than a week off, the Conservatives, the Labor Party and the Liberal Democrats are busily spending millions of dollars out of their central office election coffers.
While the legal prohibition against paid television advertising eliminates the most costly -- and most powerful -- opportunity for marketing their message, the national parties are buying up billboard space and newspaper ads, running computer data banks and tracking polls, employing marketing consultants and organizing Presidential-style whistlestop tours by the party's national leaders, in the hopes some of their televised glamour will rub off on the Parliamentary candidates.
There are no hard figures on how much the British parties will spend by the time ballots are counted Thursday, although reports in British newspapers estimate that spending by the three major parties will range from $35 million to $50 million for the monthlong campaign.
Traditionally, the Conservatives have outspent Labor by a margin of two to one. In 1987, according to the official records, total central office expenditures on the election alone were about $26 million, with the Tories spending about $15.5 million; Labor, $7.2 million, and the old Alliance Party, the predecessor to the Liberal Democrats, $3.5 million. The 1987 total, in turn, was twice as much as was spent for the 1983 election.
Meanwhile, expenditures at the local level have grown only slightly, as spending limits have been adjusted for inflation. In 1987, candidates for the three parties spent about $12.9 million, in current dollars, compared with $9.5 million in 1983.
Despite the increases in central office spending over the decade, Michael Pinto-Duschinsky, a professor of political science, said the British political system has so far been spared the dizzying financial pressures that have caused American campaign spending to soar because of the ban on candidates' buying television time.
Instead, the Government allots each of the main parties five free political broadcasts in the month-long campaign, in which they may broadcast 5- or 10-minute programs they have produced themselves. The parties also receive free postage on some mailings.
Currently, about two-thirds of national campaign expenses go toward advertising, including newspaper advertisements and the political billboards that dominate the British landscape during campaign season.
As costs have been rising, British political parties have also had to work harder to find contributions, including telephone and direct mail solicitations. Both the Labor and the Conservative parties are running deficits.
Corporate donations, which provide the bulk of Conservative funds, are decreasing. And the Labor Party, which has relied on union contributions, has seen union membership shrink from 12 million to 8 million in the last decade.
But parties are reluctant to discuss the source private contributions, since there is no law requiring disclosure.
Some Conservatives joined Labor and the Liberal Democrats last year in proposing election law changes, including forced disclosure of the names of private donors, as well as public financing of campaign costs. But any election reform will now have to wait for the new Parliament.

HEADLINE: Bracing for Worst in West Coast Salmon Country

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHINOOK, Wash., April 2

 BODY:
Faced for the first time with a possible shutdown of all salmon fishing off the West Coast, the coastal communities dependent on the seasonal returns of the legendary fish are bracing for a season of despair.
Anticipating the worst, owners are boarding up their fresh fish markets instead of preparing to open. Big trolling boats that rolled through a half-century of hook-and-line chases are for sale, and others are being auctioned to pay off bank loans. 
 And charter operators, who usually are already filling in their calendars with bookings for the peak summer months, are telling callers they cannot make a commitment now.
"Who would ever have thought we would be looking at a season with zero salmon?" asked Bob Eaton, executive director of Salmon For All, which represents commercial net fishermen and processors here at the mouth of the Columbia River. "I mean, this is the Pacific Northwest. We are supposed to have these pristine rivers -- and look what's happened."
 
Formula for Disaster
 What has happened is a combination of human degradation of the streams in which salmon spawn -- from excessive logging to development -- and a series of dry years.
On April 10, the Pacific Fishery Management Council, appointed by the Federal Government to control the take of West Coast salmon, will meet in to decide if this year's season will be drastically curtailed or eliminated. The three options range from a massive reduction in the salmon harvest to a coast-wide ban on all salmon fishing by commercial, recreational and American Indian fishermen.
The tribes, which have their own fishing rights based on century-old treaties upheld by the Supreme Court, are likely to see the amount of fish they can take and the length of their season reduced by the Federal council.
 
Alaska Not Affected
 Though the council meets every year to set the limits on what has become an increasingly small catch, never before have such draconian measures been under serious consideration.
"Whether you are a charter boat operator, a restaurant owner or an ocean troller, this is going to hurt real bad," said Phil Anderson, chairman of the 13-member fishing council. "But the other side of this is, if we overfish this year, there may be nothing in coming years."
The economic cost of a coast-wide shutdown has been estimated be as high as $60 million. The market price of chinook, or king salmon, and coho, or silver salmon, is not expected to be affected because fishing in Alaska, which provides most of the nation's Pacific salmon, would continue without restrictions.
But the fleet of fishing boats from Santa Barbara, Calif., to the Canadian border at the Strait of Juan de Fuca are important to the regional economy, and to the cultural and recreational life of the West Coast. Some of the fishermen are making plans to go after cod and rockfish, but that involves changing over their boats for a different type of fishing that pays less because the price of these fish is usually half that of salmon.
It was 200 years ago this spring that Capt. Robert Gray became the first white man to see the Columbia River, the biggest salmon stream in the American West. Captain Gray traded nails for salmon with the Indians who lived here.
More than 50 salmon canneries used to dot the Columbia River. They are all gone. Nearly 16 million salmon used to return to this river, but perhaps only a million will come back this year. Salmon typically spend a year in fresh water, near the spawning grounds where they were born, before going out to sea, traveling vast distances in the ocean, and then returning to the stream of their birth to spawn and die.
 
Salmon Need Clean Water
 Biologists have said that what the fish population needs more than anything to remain stable is free-flowing, clean water.
"If you got salmon coming up your stream, you have clean water. It's that simple," said John Baker, who has been a commercial fisherman for the last 25 years.
The main causes for the decline of the salmon runs can be seen from the bow of Mr. Baker's 38-foot ocean troller, the "Murzy," which is anchored at this small port at the mouth of the Columbia. On both sides of the river, rising to the skyline, the hillsides show the scars from decades of clear-cut logging in which all all the trees are taken. With no trees to hold the soil in place, the sediment clogs and suffocates the salmon spawning streams.
Another problem, salmon-eating sea lions, are within barking distance of his boat. The sea lions are protected by Federal law, but as their numbers have grown, they have become a target of fishermen. "If we had plenty of fish we wouldn't worry about sea lions," Mr. Baker said. "But when you have so few salmon, what the sea lions take makes a big difference."
A third problem, cited by Federal officials as the main killer of salmon, are the dozens of dams that block the downriver passage of young fish. By some estimates, more than 95 percent of all young salmon are killed in the dams' turbines, or in the sluggish water created by the dams, as the fish attempt to move out to sea.
This month, dam operators have been experimenting with a "drawdown," whereby much of the water backed up behind Columbia River dams is released to create a better current for the young fish. The measure is a reponse to a listing of Idaho sockeye salmon under the Endangered Species Act. Two other Columbia River salmon species are expected to be listed under the act this spring.
 
Effort to Save Jobs
 Unlike the fight over the northern spotted owl, which has tied up logging on Federal land in the Northwest, the Federal effort to restore the salmon would, in the long run, save thousands of jobs. The owl is costing logging jobs because its nests mean that forests cannot be cut. In meetings this week in town halls along the coast, fishermen have blamed loggers for many of their problems.
The effort to restore fish runs on the Columbia is expected to cost more than $1 billion. But it will not bring back the fish in Northern California, where the Klamath River coho are at all-time low, or in Hood Canal, a natural arm of Puget Sound, where another coho run is nearing extinction. In the Puget Sound area, experts cite explosive population growth, and the paving of wetlands and the loss of clean water that comes with unrestricted development, for the decline of the fish.
"It's going to take a concerted effort to manage the land and water as well as the fish," said Larry Six, the executive director of the Federal fishery council.
The council, which will make its decision on West Coast restrictions at the end of a three-day meeting, regulates fishing in United States waters from 3 miles to 200 miles offshore. The states control the rivers and the ocean waters closer to the coasts, but usually follow the lead set by the Federal fishery council.
Mr. Six said he hoped the council would find a way to allow for a short fishing season to help those fishermen who are close to bankruptcy. But it may already be too late.
In the harbor at Astoria, on the Oregon side of the mouth of the Columbia, Chuck Thompson prepared a 48-foot troller, "The King," for auction. Mr. Thompson, a former fisherman who was hired to inspect the boat, said the vessel would have been worth $100,000 a year ago. But now, with prospects for the future fishing bleak, the boat's owner will be lucky to get $40,000 at an auction, he said.
"We've had freaks of nature in the past, and bad years that came with it, but what's going on now is no freak of nature -- it's a tragedy," Mr. Thompson said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN WATCH;
Gotti and Good Humor Hone Campaign Focus

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
The Democratic Presidential candidates have seemed a little more likable on television the past few days, and it's possible that most of the credit belongs to John Gotti. His conviction not only distracted the press corps from exploring the candidates' flaws, it also provided perspective: While the background pieces on the candidates' records may not be flattering, at least there's no footage of bullet-riddled bodies.
But the candidates deserve credit, too. They have occasionally lapsed from their programmed promises and invective into moments of spontaneous charm. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas did his Elvis imitation and called himself a control freak. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said he was studying Mr. Clinton's smile in an effort to improve his own, and the former California Governor stopped assailing the corrupt elite long enough to talk about a sense of humor. 
 "If you can't laugh at yourself, if you don't have a good belly laugh, forget it," he said on WNYW's "Good Day New York" on Friday when asked about his attitude toward campaiging. "It's a real test of -- I don't know if it's a test of character, it's a test of psychological balance in the face of the continuing harassment."
The much-harassed Mr. Clinton seemed to start enjoying himself more at week's end. During his Elvis imitation -- a clip from "The Charlie Rose Show" on WNET that made most newscasts -- he collapsed in laughter after losing his voice on the line that he dedicated with open arms to the New York press: "Don't be cruel."
 
Pleased With Each Other
 Yesterday, he and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo both managed to look relatively pleased with each other at an Albany press conference. Mr. Cuomo interceded at one awkward point -- when Mr. Clinton was asked if he would support Mr. Cuomo, should the New York Governor somehow be the nominee -- to explain to Mr. Clinton: "That was a typical New York question. That's our view of graciousness."
The local style of graciousness has engendered sympathy for Mr. Clinton even from his constant tormentor, Johnny Carson. On Friday night, after yet another joke about Mr. Clinton's now-immortal "I didn't inhale" line, Mr. Carson paused to discuss Phil Donahue's interview of Mr. Clinton last week.
"He relentlessly questioned Clinton about his character and his morals," Mr. Carson said. "This questioning from a man who did an entire show wearing a dress."
Mr. Clinton found himself on the defensive again yesterday, apologizing for remarks that his wife, Hillary, made in a Vanity Fair article. Mrs. Clinton complained that the press was unfairly investigating her husband's past while ignoring rumors that President Bush had had a mistress. "Hillary Goes Tabloid," read The New York Post's headline.
 
Rumors Were Discounted
 The rumors about Mr. Bush had been briefly mentioned on television earlier this year in several discussions by Washington insiders. During one discussion, the columnist Jack Germond took pains to point out that the rumors had long ago been investigated and found baseless, but further analysis now seems inevitable. If nothing else, political analysts must ponder whether Mrs. Clinton's remark constitutes a campaign blunder or a brilliant tactic to smear the President by getting analysts like themselves to keep publicizing the rumor.
Mr. Brown had to deal with a CNN report that an operator at his toll-free telephone had given instructions on how a donor could evade Mr. Brown's famous $100 limit on individual campaign contributions. "I will stake my life on it that that didn't happen," Mr. Brown said, and then seemed to put his life in jeopardy by continuing, "And if it did, it was someone who was completely unauthorized."
The CNN recording of the phone call appeared to back up Mr. Brown, since the operator said that she was not supposed to be giving the instructions, but Mr. Brown was not content to let matters rest there. At a press conference, he suggested that the operator might be "some kind of Clinton plant." The theory seemed a particularly hard sell on the evening news, because viewers could also hear the CNN recording of a young woman's voice discussing the $100 limit:
"There's, like, ways around it. I mean, like, if you have, like, family members -- I'm not supposed to tell you that -- but, you know, and each of them gives or something, but, like, $100 per person." At the risk of being unfair to Valley Girls, this did not sound like the voice of a carefully trained double agent.
 
Invitation to Revolution?
 But such inconsistencies often seem unimportant when watching Mr. Brown on television, because he has a quirky sincerity that transcends whatever details the reporters are pestering him about. After he offered his theory about the Clinton plant, the cameras caught him walking out of the press conference and saying to a reporter: "Don't be part of the whole corrupt media game! Be part of the insurgency!"
It was hard not to admire a man who could make such a startlingly quixotic suggestion to a member of the New York press corps -- and make it with such hope and conviction in his eyes. Such moments help explain how Mr. Brown has appealed to such disparate groups as blue-collar workers, intellectuals, unemployed inner-city residents and even, it seemed, the family of John Gotti.
Although the Gotti family has not formally endorsed either candidate, Mr. Gotti's daughter Victoria did go before the cameras with a message that was familier to anyone who has watched Mr. Brown's "Take Back America" campaign commercials. As she complained about her father's conviction, she also issued an appeal to the press corps' higher instincts: "This is your government, all you people. It's about time that you stood up and took it back. Don't you see what's happening? Take it back."
