HEADLINE: Paper Says Fitzwater Threatened To Quit Over 'Gridlock' at the Top

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Bush Administration sought today to play down a report that Marlin Fitzwater, dismayed by "gridlock" at top levels of the White House and Mr. Bush's campaign, had threatened to resign as the President's press secretary.
The report, in The Washington Post today, said Mr. Fitzwater had left abruptly for Bermuda last week after complaining at a meeting that he had "just about had enough" of top officials' inability to execute the President's political agenda. 
 The Post reported that Mr. Fitzwater had told associates that he was frustrated and considering quitting his job, but that he took a vacation instead after friends talked him out of it.
 
'Shakedown Problems'
 In a statement issued today from Bermuda, Mr. Fitzwater said his vacation was unrelated to the events described in the article, and he praised the "strong management team" assembled since Mr. Bush's new chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, took over in December. The statement, read by White House aides, did not say whether Mr. Fitzwater had considered resigning.
Other senior Administration officials and political advisers to Mr. Bush described Mr. Fitzwater in interviews today as upset and frustrated by what they called "shakedown problems" in Mr. Skinner's staff. But they said they had not heard him threaten to quit.
One of those officials said Mr. Fitzwater was "pretty vocal in his disappointment" at a recent meeting of about 20 White House aides, convened to discuss the President's long-range political and governmental agenda.
"He said that they have endless meetings, endless planning, replanning and revisiting and that nothing ever gets done, and there's some merit to that," said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Others are very frustrated as well."
Besides serving as Mr. Bush's spokesman, Mr. Fitzwater oversees the White House public-relations operations and its communications strategy. He works daily to plan those operations both with Mr. Skinner and with the President's campaign manager, Robert M. Teeter.
 
No Reliable Strategy
 Mr. Fitzwater's frustrations were said to stem from the fact that he has no reliable strategy to work from, because White House and campaign officials have proven unable to agree on an agenda for the President to follow for any length of time. To the contrary, they say, Mr. Bush appears to switch messages and even policies frequently, and Mr. Fitzwater is left with the task of explaining those changes to a skeptical press corps.
Mr. Skinner, who effectively runs the White House staff for Mr. Bush, has endured some obvious and much-discussed problems in melding his four-month-old staff with Mr. Teeter's campaign, in a private building near the White House. Both operations are but four months old and were assembled amid an unexpectedly fierce primary election challenge from the conservative commentator, Patrick J. Buchanan.
Critics have frequently accused Mr. Skinner and Mr. Teeter of failing to devise a consistent, appealing message for Mr. Bush to deliver on the stump. They also complain that the two men have reacted too slowly to Mr. Buchanan's attacks and to the day-to-day course of national and world events.
Until recent weeks, Mr. Bush's campaign rhetoric and the themes of his appeals to voters seemed to change almost daily, leaving the impression that he held few principles. Within the White House, Mr. Skinner's staff has been accused of failing to set clear policies and to devise events -- political theater -- to back up the President's words.
One frequently cited example is Mr. Bush's warnings to members of Congress, made repeatedly since January, that he would wage political war against them if they did not pass his economic package by March 20. Since that deadline passed, Mr. Bush has proposed a relatively minor series of cuts in the Federal budget and has criticized Congress as inefficient and imperial, but has made no consistent attempt to dramatize his threat.
Criticism of both Mr. Skinner and Mr. Teeter has faded since Mr. Bush won a string of primaries in convincing fashion last month and Democrats began to stumble under the weight of Congressional scandals and a bloody primary battle. But some Administration officials and political advisers have seen scant improvement in the White House's own bumpy operations.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 14; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Middle-Class Protests Cast a Cloud on Democracy in Venezuela

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 3

 BODY:
Two months after a failed military coup here left dozens dead, rising protests by a middle class galvanized by the military action have cast dark shadows over this country's three-decade-old democratic system, Venezuelan experts and foreign diplomats say.
This city has long been accustomed to confrontational student protests and labor strikes. But these experts and diplomats say raw new displays of anger by the middle class over a patronage-riddled political system and falling living standards threaten the survival of the elected Government of President Carlos Andres Perez as much as continued rumblings in the army. 
 Since March 10, when hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans began banging pots and pans from their windows and balconies and shooting off firearms into the night sky, each week has seen new, widespread expressions of discontent.
On top of angry demands that Mr. Perez step down, two years before the end of his term, have come calls for the prosecution of members of a political class that is almost universally perceived as deeply corrupt. Some protesters have also called for the liberation of the officers arrested in connection with the failed coup.
 
Complaints of Corruption
 With over $117 billion in oil exports during the last 10 years alone, Venezuelans have begun to bitterly insist that hardship is growing among salaried workers who can no longer afford to buy cars, own homes or send their children to good schools primarily because elected leaders have busied themselves robbing state coffers instead of working for the welfare of the country's 20 million citizens.
"None of the politicians are any good," Jose Herrera, a 36-year-old factory worker said during an anti-Government demonstration in downtown Caracas Thursday in which scores of policemen in riot gear fired tear-gas volleys and chased onlookers, striking some with blunt-edged sabers. "They all make us sick. What we need to do is get rid of them and find a whole new generation."
Venezuelan political leaders and ordinary citizens, as well as foreign diplomats, say they fear that if the protests continue to build, the army, riddled with many of the same resentments over perceived corruption among politicians and senior officers, may again be tempted to mount a takeover.
In an attempt to discourage coup plotters, the United States Ambassador to the Organization of American States, Luigi Einaudi, warned army officers in a speech at the War College here last month that a military takeover would plunge Venezuela, South America's oldest democracy, into international isolation.
"There is still a ferment and uncertainty here that is very clear," a Western diplomat said. "We sit around everyday and say, are we up or down."
 
Perez Promises Reforms
 Mr. Perez, who was elected for the second time as President in 1989 after a first five-year term during the economic boom years of the 1970's, has sought to calm civilian cries for his departure by promising an array of reforms that run from creating a more politically independent judiciary to reimposing price controls on some commodities.
Already, in the two months since the coup attempt, the President has twice reshuffled his Cabinet in search of a combination that can help restore credibility to his Government, but the clamor for his resignation has only grown.
As the atmosphere of crisis has mounted, Mr. Perez has faced increasingly insistent calls from newspaper editorialists and members of Parliament, including a minority in his own political party, Accion Democratica, to amend the Constitution or accede to a referendum to curtail his term.
In recent interviews, he has defiantly vowed that he will serve out his mandate and "not one day more or less."
"The dilemma here is as follows: if we blow up the CAP Administration, anarchy will follow," said Eugenio Soler, an adviser to Mr. Perez, calling the President by his initials as is common here. "People who are calling for a change of government want an improvement of the situation in 24 hours, but things cannot be settled in two weeks or two months."
 
Action on 'Thieves' Demanded
 Ordinary Venezuelans who wish to see Mr. Perez serve out his term say he must quickly crack down on high-level corruption to regain their confidence. "If he is going to stay on, he will have to take a hard line against the thieves," said Juan Gustavo Lopez, a 30-year-old auto garage employee, echoing a widespread view.
Seeking to quiet these concerns, Mr. Prez recently named as Interior Minister a former political rival, Luis Pinerua, a stern law-and-order advocate who has long urged a crackdown on official corruption.
Blunting the possible benefits of this move, in the eyes of many, however, have been recent statements by the President that have described large-scale, high-level corruption as mostly a phenomenon of the past.
His views on more recent corruption have provoked widespread repudiation, including one from the politically independent Attorney General, Ramon Escovar Salom, who said in a recent interview: "I have seen no progress in this area. I see no political will power in the fight against corruption, and I must say this with great frustration."
Many Venezuelans and foreign diplomats say the country's political system, dominated by two highly centralized parties, has long tolerated, even encouraged official corruption. The governing party appoints judges who often do its bidding, doles out jobs and lucrative favors, and has traditionally received kickbacks and other emoluments from official business, these analysts say.
"Perez is not to blame so much as the structure of the parties," a presidential adviser said. "The parties see the Government as their thing, a way to make money."
If many Venezuelans complain about corruption, for the agitated middle class the foremost concern remains living standards, which have plummeted in the face of economic liberalization that has won Mr. Perez widespread support abroad.
 
Subsidies Curtailed
 In a surprise for most Venezuelans that inspired heavy rioting shortly after his inauguration in 1989, Mr. Perez, who campaigned with a traditional populist message immediately, initiated a series of free-markets policies aimed at curtailing extensive Government subsidies and price controls.
The changes, which have attracted new foreign investment and reduced fiscal deficits, also quickly brought devaluations and high inflation rates that Venezuelans, unlike many of their neighbors, were unaccustomed to.
For many middle-class Venezuelans, the sudden hardships after years of rising expectations fueled by an oil boom were unpardonable.
"Carlos Andres Perez promised a return to the good old days and the abundance of the past; instead we got 80 percent inflation," said Eduardo Fernandez, the leader of the main opposition party, Copei, which has supported the Government in the current crisis. "We are a modern country, and must find a way to convince the people that we can no longer afford to live by the practices of the past."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Demonstrators and journalists fleeing from tear gas used by the police last week to break up an anti-Government rally in downtown Caracas. Protesters were demanding the resignation of President Carlos Andres Perez and the release of the leaders of the failed military coup of Feb. 4. (Howard W. French/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues;
Responses of Rivals Cover Up Similarity

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
On a television show in New York last weekend, Gov. Bill Clinton and Edmund G. Brown Jr. were asked where they stood on laws that set aside a specific proportion of Government contracts for blacks.
Mr. Clinton answered at length. Such laws are "on balance" worthwhile, he said, because "in order to change the nature of poverty and the nature of our cities, we have to have an empowerment agenda." 
 Mr. Brown answered the question with one quick sentence: "Sure, I support that."
The exchange typifies how the Democratic Presidential candidates treat the issues of the campaign. Mr. Clinton often talks in think-tank jargon and has mastered nuance like a law student prepared for the bar exam. Mr. Brown talks in sweeping generalities about a corrupt political system and seems impatient with facts and figures.
 
Plans for All Issues
 Before the campaign began last year, the Arkansas Governor published a booklet that set forth his views on everything from the economy to the cold war, from race relations to the environment. In anticipation of the New York primary, he released a 10-page paper on urban policy.
He has a five-point plan for ending the recession and another five-point plan for long-term economic growth. He has three "principles" for invigorating cities, nine ways of "empowering inner-city youth," a four-part "crime strategy" and a four-point health care plan.
Mr. Brown, on the other hand, has little use for detail. He often offers proposals that contradict one another and numbers that do not add, and when this is pointed out to him, he shrugs it off as immaterial. Questioned this week about his urban policy, Mr. Brown referred to a $30 billion wish list he had recently seen that was prepared by the United States Conference of Mayors and said those proposals for grants to the cities were fine with him. He offered no indication he had studied the proposals and no clue how he would pay for them.
Asked in a debate the other day how he would govern the country if he became President, the former California Governor replied: "You can't govern. It's not governable now."
 
Bush on Different Road
 Their opposite styles mask the fact that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown agree on fundamental precepts much more than they disagree, and the views they hold in common are very different from President Bush's. If either Mr. Clinton or Mr. Brown is elected President and fulfills his campaign promises, the country will be run on principles quite unlike those of the last 12 years.
The Democrats believe that the Government should have an active strategy for directing the economy. Mr. Bush takes a basically hands-off position that relies on the markets for economic direction.
The Democrats, unlike the President, support new Federal spending on schools, housing, jobs and a variety of other programs that the Republicans have cut back in the last decade. And while the Democratic candidates do not specifically advocate higher taxes, they do not rule them out.
Both Democrats place greater emphasis on the environment than on development, which Republicans tend to favor. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown have different approaches toward medical care, but both support radical new national health insurance systems. Mr. Bush would only tinker with the current system.
The Democratic candidates favor deeper cuts in military spending than does the President and oppose his position of withholding immigration assistance to Israel until the Israelis stop building settlements on the West Bank. In contrast with many Democratic candidates in past primary campaigns in New York, neither candidate this year is arguing that the American Embassy in Israel should be moved to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv.
On social issues, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown, in contrast with the President, strongly favor unrestricted abortions, gun control and affirmative action for members of minorities. And while Mr. Bush talks about tightening welfare rules, the Democrats want to increase subsidies to the poor.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown even duck the same basic question: Neither says how he would reduce the budget deficit. And when pressed on the point, they say merely that they would rely on the peace dividend.
Few economists believe the deficit can be reduced to a manageable level just by cutting the military budget, even if no big new spending programs are introduced. And the Democrats are indeed advocating expensive new measures like Mr. Brown's grants to the cities and Mr. Clinton's plans for national service by young people.
To accomplish such goals, the next President would almost certainly have to raise taxes or make significant cuts in what the Government spends on the elderly through Social Security and Medicare. Neither Democratic candidate sees mileage now in endorsing such potentially unpopular steps.
In some cases, the two Democrats agree more or less on policy but stress different aspects. For example, Mr. Brown emphasizes the Government's obligation to care for the poor, while Mr. Clinton stresses the obligation of welfare recipients to behave responsibly.
In his stump speeches, Mr. Brown places greater emphasis on environmental protection than does Mr. Clinton and promotes an ambitious but rather vague plan to cut energy use in half. Mr. Clinton puts his biggest stress on the help he would give the middle class
One specific area where Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton have a basic disagreement is tax policy. Mr. Clinton would retain the existing tax system but modify the rates, deductions and credits so that taxpayers earning more than $200,000 a year would pay more and everyone else would owe less.
Mr. Brown would scrap the Federal taxes on income, Social Security, Medicare and gasoline and replace them with a 13 percent flat tax on income and a 13 percent value-added tax, similar to a national sales tax.
His critics maintain that this would be a boon to the rich and would cost the treasury hundreds of billions of dollars. In response, Mr. Brown says that he does not believe the critics are right but that if they turn out to be, he will just modify his plan to make it fairer and raise more revenue.
They also disagree on trade policy. Mr. Clinton generally argues against trade restrictions, taking the view of most economists that the overall economy benefits from free trade among nations.
Mr. Brown says free-trade policies have put American workers at a serious disadvantage. So he opposes a trade agreement with Mexico and supports various protectionist measures.
Mr. Clinton also advocates foreign aid, saying that America must remain a world leader. Mr. Brown maintains that the United States must take care of the immediate needs of its own people before it assists others.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Democrats on the Issues"
 
TAXES
 Brown: Replace the Federal income, Social Security, Medicare and gasoline taxes with a flat, 13 percent tax on income, allowing deductions only for mortgage interest, rent and charitable contributions. Impose a 13 percent value added tax, similar to a national sales tax. Give businesses tax breaks for hiring workers from poor neighborhoods and for investing in equipment and research.
 Clinton: Cut income taxes of most Americans by 10 percent and offset the cost with higher taxes on those with incomes above $200,000. Replace the current $2,100 dependent exemption with a tax credit of $800 per child. Cut capital gains tax for investments held at least five years in new businesses. Give investment tax credits to small and medium sized businesses. Prohibit businesses from writing off the cost of excessive salaries and bonuses for executives.
 
HEALTH
 Brown: Install a national health insurance system, similar to the one in Canada, operating on a fixed national budget, in which patients choose their doctors, fees are set by the states and private insurance companies are bypassed. Vague about how the new system would be financed. Would support more AIDS research.
 Clinton: Require employers to provide private insurance coverage for workers or pay an additional tax into a public fund to cover the uninsured. Establish a Government board to regulate medical-care prices. Vague about how the system would be financed. Would support more AIDS research.
 
TRADE
 Brown: Opposes giving the President authority to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico. Supports a variety of measures designed to limit imports into the United States.
 Clinton: Favors the Mexican free-trade agreement but would require stricter environmental and labor standards in Mexico. Says he is basically a free-trader but supports retaliation if Japan keeps out American products.
 
MILITARY SPENDING
 Brown: Cut the military budget in half over the next five years. Remove all troops from Europe. Otherwise not specific about how this deep reduction would be achieved.
 Clinton: Cut the military budget by one-third over the next five years. Stop production of the B-2 bomber and the Star Wars missile defense system but continue production, at least for the time being, of the Sea Wolf nuclear submarine.
 
FOREIGN AFFAIRS
 Brown: Mostly avoids foreign policy matters, which he says draw attention away from critical problems at home. At times voices support for aid to Israel and Russia but at other time says the country cannot afford foreign assistance while Americans have needs. Says he would have waited longer before taking offensive action against Iraq.
 Clinton: Argues that the United States must be engaged in foreign affairs to remain a world leader. Says he supported President Bush's intervention in Iraq but criticizes the President for failing to get a handle on relations with Japan, for being slow to respond to events in Russia and for not imposing trade sanctions on China. Opposes Israeli settlements in the West Bank but says that should not stop immigration aid to Israel.
 
CITIES
 Brown: Give cities roughly $30 billion in new annual grants and loans for public works, transportation projects, public safety, job training and other programs. Establish urban enterprise zones in poor neighborhoods where businesses could get tax breaks.
 Clinton: Give Federally owned housing and housing on closed military bases to community groups to house the homeless. Encourage resident ownership of low-income housing. Give cities matching grants for crime-control projects.
 
ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT
 Brown: Cut energy consumption in half over the next 10 years. Phase out all nuclear power plants and emphasize energy sources like solar and wind power. Stop new offshore oil drilling. Increase protection of wetlands. Require public utilities to spend more than $600 billion over the next 15 years for conservation. Otherwise vague about achieving conservation and financing alternative energy.
 Clinton: Reduce energy consumption by at least one-quarter. Through new regulations, encourage utilities to invest in conservation. Stop building new nuclear power plants unless a safe way can be found to dispose of the waste. Emphasize natural gas over oil and promote solar and wind power. Opposes oil drilling in the Arctic refuge. Might support a small increase in Federal gasoline tax.
 
EDUCATION AND TRAINING
 Brown: Increase Federal education spending. Replace tuition loans with scholarships and work-study grants. Establish a civilian conservation corps where young people can develop skills.
 Clinton: Double Federal spending on education, aiming the extra money mostly at poor inner-city neighborhoods and rural areas. Give states and communities more direction in education policy. Let college students pay off tuition loans by performing national service. Create apprenticeship program to train high-school students not bound for college and adult-education programs for those without high school diplomas.
 
WELFARE
 Brown: Encourage businesses to hire poor people and supplement their salaries with a welfare check, Medicaid and food stamps. Withdraw those benefits at a rate of 20 percent a year for five years. Vague about what he would provide poor people without jobs.
 Clinton: Provide training and child-care but in most instances require an adult, after two years on welfare, to take a private or public service job or lose benefits. In some cases, allow people to stay on welfare more than two years if they were making progress in education programs. Vague about what he would provide for children if their parents refused to work.
 
ABORTION
 Brown: Supports freedom of choice for women and Medicaid funding of abortions for poor women and opposes laws requiring parents to be notified before their daughters can have abortions.
 Clinton: Supports freedom of choice for women. Would not press for law allowing Medicaid funding of abortions but would sign such a law if Congress passed it. Signed a law in Arkansas requiring a girl under 18 to notify her parents or a judge before she could have an abortion.
 
GUN CONTROL
 Brown: Favors registration of all guns and a ban on assault-type weapons. As Governor, supported and signed a California law requiring a 15-day waiting period before a firearm could be purchased.
 Clinton: Favors legislation now before Congress for a five- or seven-day waiting period before a firearm could be purchased. As Governor, signed a bill supported by the National Rifle Association making harassment of hunters a criminal offense, but vetoed a measure backed by the N.R.A. that would have prevented local governments from regulating guns.
 
CAPITAL PUNISHMENT
 Brown: Opposes in all cases.
 Clinton: Favors the death penalty.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: The Candidates, on April 7;
For George Bush and Bill Clinton

 BODY:
The New York Presidential primary election has rarely meant much. Often, all the suspense has been squeezed out by the momentum of prior results. This year, New York counts.
If Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas runs strongly, he will virtually lock up the Democratic nomination. If former Gov. Jerry Brown of California does well, he will strengthen his politics of anti-politics. An ambiguous outcome could encourage dissatisfied voters to keep shopping. 
 The choice Tuesday is thus unusually consequential and unusually complex. That is why The New York Times, which customarily reserves candidate recommendations until the fall, now offers its views of the race so far.
 
THE REPUBLICANS
 Lamentably, there will be no Republican ballot Tuesday. President Bush, prudent player on the stage of a new world order, warrants his party's renomination, and he surely would have won it in New York, as he has elsewhere. But party officials seized on the state's notorious petition rules to keep Patrick Buchanan off the ballot.
We disagree heart and soul with Mr. Buchanan's fearful isolationism and protectionism. He manifests a nativism so harsh it also sounds like anti-Semitism and racism. Even so, the absence of a contest diminishes democracy -- if only because it denies New York Republicans their chance to roundly reject the Buchanan message.
 
THE DEMOCRATS
 Though there are seven names on Tuesday's Democratic ballot, they present only three choices: Jerry Brown, Bill Clinton or Neither. Two names are wishful. The ambitions of former Senator Eugene McCarthy and Larry Agran, former Mayor of Irvine, Calif., still flicker. Two names are vestigial. Senators Tom Harkin and Bob Kerrey, 1992 ambitions dimmed, have withdrawn.
And at the moment, it is hard to tell into which category Paul Tsongas belongs -- wishful, vestigial or both. If he were to re-enter the campaign, a clear choice would become much harder.
Jerry Brown When people describe the former California Governor, adjectives spill out, not many of them friendly: audacious, mercurial, visionary, expedient, self-absorbed, restless -- and reckless, even to the point of being mean.
Critics do not do justice to his 1975-83 record. California introduced auto emission standards, a Conservation Corps, a pioneering right-to-die law. But supporters do not do justice to his record, either. It also includes reduced spending on education, disastrous dithering about a fruit fly epidemic and fiscal management that so infuriated voters they imposed the choke hold of Proposition 13.
Since then, Mr. Brown has changed directions as often as he changes costume -- from Zen reflection to high-roller insider's politics to his present persona as Mr. Outside. He still spins brilliantly, but his visionary optimism seems to have soured. He fluently denounces those he is against. He does less well expressing what he is for.
His program as a whole is sketchy and even its centerpiece, his 13 percent flat tax, turns out to be a careless caricature of the original idea. The hasty Brown version would burden the poor and swell the deficit. Jerry Brown gives voice to the widespread frustration with politics. He gives no evidence of knowing how to relieve it.
 
Bill Clinton

People acquainted with the Governor of Arkansas before this campaign and people who have met him since sometimes make the same observation -- that the Bill Clinton they know is an intelligent, experienced, gregarious politician with powerful ideas for the country. Why does he so often come across as an evasive, philandering ol' Southern pol insensitive to ethical conflicts?
One answer is that he is new to the national stage; many voters got their first impression of him from a string of embarrassing episodes. First came Gennifer Flowers, claiming a long relationship with the Governor . . . Then accusations of escaping the draft in 1969 . . . Then lame answers to questions about his relationship with a savings and loan head subject to state regulation . . . Last Sunday, he admitted trying marijuana in words ("didn't inhale") so grudging as to invite ridicule.
Some of these episodes have been unfair or exaggerated. Together they leave enduring doubts. But what's obscured in all the commotion is a record of accomplishment that gives credibility to the cogent program he proposes. In Arkansas, Governor Clinton has been as good as his words. Last summer, his fellow governors voted him the best in their business.
His domestic agenda rings with sensible priorities. He has yet to define a foreign and defense policy that would free the Federal funds needed for his domestic agenda. But his program aims to fix what's most wrong with the American economy.
He thinks government should invest in people -- notably through education, training, early childhood intervention, national service and welfare reform. What makes that doubly appealing is that as it encouraged economic growth, it would also advance social justice and racial healing.
One day last January, Mr. Clinton was talking to a business group in New York's Regency Hotel. He held up that day's New York Post, whose banner read BLACK KIDS PAINTED WHITE, and asked: "Why did they do that? Because they live in a world in which nobody has told them the truth. That we're all in this together. These white kids [are told] 'Ain't nothing wrong with you. It's always Them . . . Them, them, them. It's time somebody stood up and said there is no Them. There's only Us."
 
Neither
 Some voters, troubled about Bill Clinton and uneasy about Jerry Brown, push for a brokered convention -- that is, one in which Paul Tsongas or someone not yet a candidate could emerge. One way to do that would be to cast a protest vote for Mr. Tsongas.
That would pay deserved respect to a candidate who persevered for long, lonely months on behalf of his sound program for growth. It would be wholly understandable, should Governor Clinton falter, for Mr. Tsongas to contemplate returning for the California and New Jersey primaries June 2. He might win enough delegates to gain bargaining power at a brokered convention.
But even if all that did happen, voters who like the prospect of a brokered convention would need to consider three points:
Americans have worked hard to shift the choice of nominees from pols to voters -- and are not likely to welcome giving it back. Second, not even people close to Mr. Tsongas are confident that the power brokers would choose him. Third, it's far from clear that some compromise choice, untested and unscarred by the primaries, would look like such a savior in an even-rougher fall campaign.
At this time, in this churning primary campaign, Bill Clinton remains the superior choice for Democrats.
These are not endorsements for November. This has already been a bumpy campaign year for both parties -- and is likely to become more so, given the prospect of a formidable independent challenge by Ross Perot, self-made billionaire.
Even so, President Bush stands head and shoulders above the pinched negativism preached by Patrick Buchanan and deserves the renomination his party seems certain to give him.
On the Democratic side, meanwhile, Bill Clinton offers a plausible path to economic growth and racial unity. Jerry Brown appeals to anger. Bill Clinton appeals to hope.

TYPE: Editorial

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Wreck Or Rescue?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
This is a year of anger in politics. Voters are angry at economic misery, at politicians who give themselves perks, at institutions that do not work. They are in a mood to punish, to destroy.
Jerry Brown fits that mood. He comes on as a Savonarola who would purge an impure system. And if there is a real Jerry Brown underneath the various political masks, it may be something like that: Savonarola. 
 As Governor of California he was a wrecker of institutions. The University of California, the courts, the mental hospitals -- institutions in which the state had taken great pride -- were savaged by Governor Brown. All in the name of profound rethinking, and without regard for the human cost.
Stanley Sheinbaum, an outstanding liberal Democrat, was named to the University of California Board of Regents by Governor Brown and served for 12 years. He remains "grateful" for the appointment, he says, but his memories of what Mr. Brown did to the university are not happy.
"He had a disrespect for the university," Mr. Sheinbaum told me. "He was very rough on the budget, and not just for lack of money. He virtually eliminated extension courses, with the comment, 'Why have courses for housewives?' "
I visited the University of California during the Brown years, doing some teaching, and found that faculty and staff members thought him so contemptuous of the university that they pined for his predecessor as Governor: Ronald Reagan. They thought they were treated more fairly, and more straightforwardly, by Governor Reagan.
"The president of the university tried to get an appointment with Governor Brown for weeks to discuss the financial crisis," Mr. Sheinbaum said. "Finally he was told he could see him late at night just before the Governor submitted his budget. When he got there, he found that the Governor had two students there to take part in the meeting."
Governor Brown left five or six vacancies on the Board of Regents unfilled for an extended time, Mr. Sheinbaum said -- "It crippled us." Mr. Brown did that with many state boards and agencies, saying that he was rethinking their functions.
Governor Brown cut funds for mental hospitals and let conditions in them get so bad that the hospitals were decertified and Federal funding cut off. Interviewing him in 1978, I asked him why he had done that.
"I was not confident that I understood the program," he said. "I've had some doubts about the role of psychiatry and the approach in mental illness."
One may well have intellectual doubts about the treatment of mental illness. But for a governor to let patients go hungry, dirty and neglected while he mulls those doubts is something else.
The institution that suffered most from the Brown years, I think, was the Supreme Court of California. Governor Brown made some good appointments. But he made one fatal one: of Rose Bird, one of his assistants, as Chief Justice.
Rose Bird was a thoughtful and decent person with modest experience in the law. She might have been an appropriate choice as a lower court judge. For Chief Justice of California she was completely inappropriate. Lawyers and judges took the appointment to be an expression of Jerry Brown's contempt for the law.
The end of the Rose Bird story was terrible for her and for the Supreme Court of California. Right-wing forces started a campaign that ended with the voters removing her and two respected colleagues from the court, and with its once high reputation among state courts degraded.
In times of stress there may always be an urge to destroy institutions, to purify and start over. Think of the 1960's. But is that what the United States needs today?
The Reagan and Bush years have seen the weakening of our constitutional institutions. The Federal courts have been stacked with ideological zealots, Government agencies with people who do not believe in their missions. The need is not to destroy but to restore.
Consider just one thing: the President's power to name Supreme Court Justices, for me his single most important duty. Would we want those appointments to be made by Jerry Brown?

HEADLINE: BASEBALL '92: AMERICAN LEAGUE EAST;
Jays Add Morris and Winfield to a Potent Mix

 BODY:
This preview was prepared and written by Murray Chass. Teams are presented in alphabetical order and the starting lineups are his projections. His probable starters for the Yankees appear on page 3. Relief pitchers listed are the closers.
Staff predictions for the teams' order of finish in each division appears on page 6. 

Baltimore Orioles
If the Orioles' M&M's don't melt in the heat of competition, the Orioles could make the longest strides in the division. McDonald, Mussina, Milacki and Mesa -- Ben, Mike, Bob, Jose -- are the pitchers Johnny Oates is counting on, along with veteran Rick Sutcliffe, to add luster to the team's new park.
Mussina, who has a degree in economics from Stanford, showed his pitching credentials as a rookie last year, only his second as a professional, when he allowed no more than two runs in each of his last six starts. The Orioles have been waiting for McDonald to fulfill his promise, and this could be the year he does, if he can avoid injury.
Glenn Davis, plagued last year by a problem with a nerve in his neck, could be poised for an explosive year himself.
KEY ADDITIONS: After two seasons of shoulder ailments, Sutcliffe could be ready to resume his career in earnest. Storm Davis is around in case one of the starters falters.
KEY LOSSES: None.
KEY TO SEASON: It's a long way from 67 victories to a competitive status, but Glenn Davis and the pitchers can make it attainable.
 
Boston Red Sox
 Playing we-can-match-this, the Red Sox snared Frank Viola the day after Jack Morris joined the Blue Jays. But if the Red Sox rotation begins with the inimitable Roger Clemens and Viola, it ends with Matt Young, who has a career 49-77 record and only one winning record in eight seasons.
But Butch Hobson, the new manager, will rely on his hitters as much as his pitchers. The hitter to watch in the collection of good ones is the newest one, Phil Plantier, who in 53 games last year batted .331, hit 11 home runs and drove in 35 runs. Not so impressive was Mo Vaughn (.260, 4 homers and 32 r.b.i. in 74 games).
As good as the collection is, the Red Sox need a resurgence from Ellis Burks, whose medical record (hamstring, knees, back) was more impressive than his hitting record (.251, 56 r.b.i.)
KEY ADDITION: If ailing fingers were really responsible for his 2-10 second-half record with the Mets, Viola should join Clemens in frightening teams that have to face them in the same series.
KEY LOSSES: None.
KEY TO SEASON: The hitters, particularly Jack Clark, have to be consistent throughout the season, while the other pitchers have to share some of the burden with Clemens and Viola.
 
Cleveland Indians
 This could be an interesting team to watch, but its youthfulness will lose games as often as win them. The Indians are not helped by the presence of two promising rookies, first baseman Reggie Jefferson and third baseman Jim Thome, on the disabled list at the start of the season.
Sandy Alomar Jr., once billed as the next great catcher, is back after missing 111 games with shoulder and hip injuries. Albert Belle missed time, too, but for disciplinary reasons. The Indians want him playing full time this season because he had 17 percent of their runs batted in and 35 percent of their home runs.
KEY ADDITIONS: Rookie Kenny Lofton could provide an offensive spark, but Jack Armstrong and Scott Scudder, acquired in a trade for Greg Swindell, have to supply effective pitching.
KEY LOSS: Swindell was a solid pitcher despite his 9-16 record.
KEY TO SEASON: Manager Mike Hargrove can only be patient while his players learn from their mistakes.
 
Detroit Tigers
 In leading the league with 1,185 strikeouts, the Tigers had four of the seven players who had the most strikeouts. That's hitting, not pitching. As a team, they were second in the league in runs scored (817) but were last in batting average (.247). When they made contact, though, they batted .315.
The primary project this season is to reduce the number of strikeouts while increasing the number of runs, which should follow from making contact more frequently.
Bill Gullickson somehow gained 20 victories, but the Tigers can't expect a duplication of that feat.
KEY ADDITIONS: Dan Gladden, the new left fielder, can remind his new teammates what it means to win; he scored the winning run in the World Series.
KEY LOSSES: None.
KEY TO SEASON: Cecil Fielder has a broad, strong back, but asking him to carry the Tigers for a third successive season would be unfair. He needs help.
 
Milwaukee Brewers
 Phil Garner, who has never managed anywhere, can show off his 1979 World Series ring and tell his players how he hit .500 in that Series, but the players have to do more than listen.
This is a team that could go in various directions, meaning they need solid performances from many of Garner's audience. The pitchers especially have to maintain good health, a condition not familiar to the Brewers. Their onetime ace, Ted Higuera, hopes to be back by midseason.
Before the end of the season, Robin Yount hopes to have 122 hits, which would put him at 3,000.
KEY ADDITIONS: Kevin Seitzer, released by Kansas City, would help if he could reverse the trend that has seen his batting average drop every season for the last four seasons, since he batted .323 in his first full season.
KEY LOSS: They might discover that not trying to re-sign Willie Randolph as a free agent was a mistake.
KEY TO SEASON: A strong start could dispel doubts, but the Brewers still aren't ready to match strides with the serious contenders.
 
Toronto Blue Jays
 Like the little engine that could, the Blue Jays always think they can, think they can, think they can win the American League pennant. But they get to a certain level on the mountain and they chug no farther.
That's where Jack Morris and Dave Winfield come in. They were hired to be special engineers, the operators who are expected to nudge the Blue Jays the rest of the way.
Morris, who was a more significant operator for Minnesota last October than the previous six months, joins an already loaded pitching staff. Once Dave Stieb comes off the disabled list, before the end of the month, the Blue Jays, who had the league's lowest earned run average last year, 3.50, should be able to dominate the division with pitching alone.
KEY ADDITIONS: Morris and Winfield will contribute battle-hardened experience, but the Blue Jays are also eager to see their rookie right fielder, Derek Bell.
KEY LOSS: Tom Candiotti took his knuckleball to Los Angeles.
KEY TO SEASON: The pitchers just have to do their jobs, with swing man David Wells moving to the bullpen when Stieb is ready to start but standing ready to return to the rotation if necessary.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

A FAREWELL GALA
 For 21 years Liz Rockwell has guided Westchester's Rondo Dance Theater in Bedford, and for 40 years she ran the Elizabeth Rockwell School of Dance. Now, Ms. Rockwell is retiring, and she will make that announcement during Rondo's gala performance at the State University of New York at Purchase Saturday at 8 P.M. After the performance a reception will be held for her in the Follow-Spot Cafe across from the Performing Arts Center ticket office. 
 Eleanor Bunker, a dancer and rehearsal director with the company for many years, will assume Ms. Rockwell's duties as the new artistic director, and her husband, Addison, will expand his position as part-time manager to full time.
Saturday's performance, to be repeated Sunday at 3 P.M., will include choreography by Jose Limon, Moses Pendleton, Murray Louis, Doug Verone and others, demonstrating Rondo's commitment to preserving and performing the works of great choreographers of the 20th century.
Tickets at $12 for Saturday night and $10 for Sunday afternoon can be reserved by calling 251-6200.
 
WATERSHED CLEANUP
 A massive volunteer cleanup of the Croton Watershed is scheduled from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. Saturday by the local chapter of Trout Unlimited. "Our members know of old tires, refrigerators, washing machines and stoves that were dumped by or into our streams in the dark of night," said Richard Jogodnik, a spokesman for the chapter.
A number of other organizations will join the effort, sending teams of volunteers to one or more of eight designated meeting places. The groups are Hilltop Sports and Conservation, the Kent Rod and Gun Club, Northern Westchester Fish and Game, Patterson Sportsmen, the Putnam County Federation of Sportsmen, the Putnam County Fish and Game Association, the Ossi Sport Club and Bass. New York City has consented to dispose of all the garbage and debris collected.
The cleanup is necessary as a step toward preserving the region's drinking water, threatened by debris thrown into streams and reservoirs that are depleted by a lack of rain.
Volunteers will be supplied with plastic bags and instructions. They should wear sturdy shoes and gloves and rain gear if necessary, because there will be no cancellation for bad weather. For more information or to volunteer, call 666-5727.
 
ADELE MYERS EXHIBITION
 Works by Adele Myers are to be shown at Hopper House in Nyack through the end of the month, opening with a reception for the artist today from 1 to 5 P.M. Adele Myers is a Dominican Sister who founded and directed the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill for 15 years until it closed this year.
The signature component of her work is cement, a material she began using with oils many years ago. In 1986 she switched from cement and oils to cement and fresco, which she calls a more compatible combination. Her pieces are as sculptural as they are painterly, sometimes leaving expanses of lime exposed.
Sister Myers studied painting in Florence, and she is now an adjunct professor of art at St. Thomas Aquinas College in Sparkill. She was one of the first recipients of the Rockland County Executive's Arts Awards in 1987, and she has served since then in an appointed position on the Rockland County Art in Public Places Committee.
Hopper House, at 82 North Broadway, is open Saturdays and Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is free although a donation of $1 is suggested.
 
FIGHTING STAGE FRIGHT
 It is no secret that most actors, musicians, lecturers or anyone appearing before the public experiences stage fright. And it has been observed by psychologists that the more accomplished they are, the more nervous they get.
But "nobody need be a victim of stage fright," said Lucy Joffe, a faculty member at the Westchester Conservatory of Music, who will conduct a free program on the subject Tuesday at 8 P.M. at the conservatory.
Methods for dealing with what can be a terrifying ordeal, devised in recent years by psychologists and medical doctors, can help most people, as Ms. Joffe learned after making a study of the subject in response to her own students' fears.
A graduate of Vassar College with master's degrees in music from the Manhattan School of Music and Columbia University, Ms. Joffe has been a member of the voice faculty at the Westchester Conservatory for more than 20 years. The school is at 20 Soundview Avenue in White Plains. Call 762-3715 for more information.
 
IMMIGRANTS AND ART
 These are the final weeks of a monthlong program exploring "The Contemporary American Immigrant Experience in Art," organized by the Westchester Consortium for International Studies, a joint effort of Marymount and Iona Colleges.
Joseph Brodsky, the Nobel Prize poet, Soviet exile and poet laureate of the Library of Congress, will read from his work tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. in the Library Lecture Hall at Marymount College in Tarrytown.
At Iona an exhibition of recent works by first-generation immigrant artists can be seen through Friday in the lobby gallery of the Ryan Library on the North Avenue campus in New Rochelle. Two dimensional works and crafts are included in the show, created by artists from Latin America, Asia, Europe and the Middle East. The gallery is open Mondays through Fridays from 8:30 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Saturdays from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. and Sundays from 1 to 6 P.M.
One of the final events is an artists' panel scheduled on April 14 at 7:30 P.M. in Romita Auditorium at Iona. Christine Choy, a film maker; Miguel Algarin, a playwright; Serdar Arat, a painter, and Anneliese Wagner, a poet and author, will talk about their adjustments to life in the United States on a personal and professional level. Admission to all events is free. For more information, call 694-2200, extension 521.
 
BASICS OF GARDENING
 Assuming that not all Westchester residents have green thumbs and that some might be newcomers to topsoil and trowels, the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will offer a crash course in "Gardening for Beginners" Saturday from 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.
The basics will be covered, from soils and tools to plants, vegetables and flowers and plotting the layout. Specific topics include basic plant needs, transplanting and pruning, the dynamics of dirt, outstanding tree and shrub varieties, vegetable gardening for small spaces, annuals and perennials and the end product: a cliffside garden after 40 years.
Participants will also tour the demonstration gardens. The fee is $55, including a box lunch, parking and a program book. Call (212) 220-8720 to register or obtain more information.
 
ECONOMIST'S VIEWPOINT
 Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, will discuss the recession and the prospects for recovery tomorrow from 7:30 to 9 P.M. at the Hommocks School in Mamaroneck.
Forecasting economic trends in the region and developing long-range planning strategies are part of her job, and her outlook seems optimistic, judging from her chapter titled "New York City as Global Capital in the 1990's" from "Cities in a Global Society" (Sage Publications, 1989). She has also compiled a regional forecast of population, labor force and jobs to 1995.
Admission is $15, $10 for people 65 and older. Call 698-9126 for more information.

HEADLINE: How Big Is Too Big? Township Can't Decide

BYLINE: By HELEN PIKE

DATELINE: HOLMDEL TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
WHEN John Wadington started out as clerk and treasurer of this township in 1965, he had a day job as a research chemist. He could handle his municipal duties at meetings held two nights a week and on Saturdays. It was a time when the township's population was 4,000, the State Police patrolled the roads and there was no high school.
Mr. Wadington, now 72 years old, retired last week from his township posts, and it will take two employees working full time to replace him. Holmdel's population has grown to 12,000, with its own police force and high school. New stores and office buildings and other outward signs of prosperity and progress are everywhere. 
 Yet Holmdel is a town divided. At public meetings of the Township Committee that can last until 2 A.M., the five members exchange angry arguments and personal insults. Faced with a shortage of revenue, they fight over what services to curtail, what plans to drop. The tax rate has increased almost 50 percent since 1987.
But more than anything, what they fight over is the future of their community: whether to maintain its semirural character or to approve development plans that would enlarge its base of taxable office and laboratory real estate, commonly referred to as ratables. But increased development would bring more people and traffic in its wake.
For professional planners throughout the state, the Holmdel debate has become all too familiar as corporations and their employees have increasingly moved out of the cities to the countryside.
"Rural is the next frontier," said Tom Stearn, a planner with the Hillier Group, a Princeton-based architectural company. "People want smaller-scale living. Then the tug-of-war erupts over ratables."
Too small a tax base causes municipal services to suffer, he said, while too large a base erodes the quality of life. "Towns don't always strike a balance," he added.
Holmdel has had trouble finding that balance. Last November, a slow-growth coalition of two Republicans and a Democrat, running as independents, won election and the balance of power on the Township Committee. But in this Republican bastion, where the registered Republicans outnumber the Democrats by 2,890 to 810, the struggle is mainly intramural.
A major bone of contention is a proposal from the Chase Manhattan Bank for a one-million-square-foot back-office space at the intersection of Holmdel and Roberts Roads. Chase has offered to pay an estimated $3.2 million for widening the roads. The proposal has received preliminary approval from the Planning Board, but final approval must come from the Township Committee.
Fueling the debate are additional proposals for nearly 1.5 million square feet of offices. All these plans, including that from Chase Manhattan, are for the section of the township that falls in a southerly slope away from the Garden State Parkway and into the lowlands that lead to the Swimming River Reservoir. Under the state's newest master plan, this portion of Holmdel is regarded as environmentally sensitive.
Last fall, two neighboring Monmouth County townships, Colts Neck and Marlboro, filed suits against Holmdel to block final approval of the office proposals until a regional impact study was conducted. Opponents contend that the offices would bring in thousands of workers daily, triggering high volumes of traffic along Routes 520 and 34.
Route 34 is the common boundary of the three towns. Route 520 is also West Main Street in the village of Holmdel, a one-time residential area where business signs now swing from the porches of houses that have been designated as historic.
"My crystal ball tells me we'll see Holmdel in the headlines over more lawsuits," said Peggy Lasky, a two-term Republican member of the Township Committee and the former Mayor, anticipating developers' negative reactions should Holmdel change some of its longstanding zoning for offices and laboratories.
In a nonbinding referendum in November, the township voted for change by a margin of nearly 2 to 1. "All the land was purchased years ago," Ms. Lasky said.
 
Struggling Over Budget
 As the second quarter in the calendar year gets under way, Holmdel is in the unusual circumstance of being without a formalized budget. Last year the budget was $10.4 million, and the committee has been struggling to find a way to finance a similar-sized budget -- but it has been $1 million short.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Labs provide the township with $4 million in annual taxes, and at one time Holmdel could have counted on a special tax of $2.5 million a year paid by the Prudential Property and Casualty Insurance Company, which operates a sprawling office complex in the village.
Under state law, communities receive revenue from a special franchise tax imposed on stock insurance companies whose headquarters are situated in their towns. Prudential continues to operate in Holmdel, but four years ago it moved its official headquarters to Indiana.
Under state law, Holmdel was entitled to a six-year compensatory payment from Prudential. But, Mr. Wadington said, the state wants the money for itself.
Holmdel has been fighting in court to obtain what Mr. Wadington estimates is $5 million, including interest. Two courts have ruled in the township's favor; the state has appealed both rulings, and the matter is now before the State Supreme Court.
 
'The Town Needs Revenue'
 "The town needs revenue," Mr. Wadington said. Residents can absorb a gradual increase in their taxes, he believes, but not an abrupt rise. Indeed, on $100 of assessed valuation, Holmdel's tax rate has gone from about $2 in 1987 to $2.28 in 1988, to $2.58 in 1989, to $2.87 in 1990 and to $2.85 in 1991. Real-estate prices average $340,000 for an acre of wooded land and a four-bedroom home.
The debate over Holmdel's rural and ratables future has created a split among Republicans between aggressive, city-style politics and an old-time, sedate political tradition. The Greater Holmdel Republican Club represents the township's mainline, generally pro-development Republicans; the Holmdel Republican Club, sometimes referred to as the regular Republican Club, espouses no-growth or low-growth sentiments.
"Everybody wants something different," said Adie Holmes Lubkert, whose family founded Holmdel more than 300 years ago, and whose father farmed potatoes under what is now the township's intermediate and high schools.
Jim Ackerson, who at 80 continues to till what is left of what his father called Fruit Acres, said, "They don't want to listen to each other."
 
New Mayor in 'Hot Seat'
 The new Mayor of Holmdel, named by the Township Committee's new majority, is Ernest Cote, a 14-year veteran of the committee and a budget manager with Bell Labs.
Mr. Cote relishes being Mayor. "It's my turn to be in the hot seat," he said. "I've had a lot of practice with fighting uphill battles."
Originally from Edison, Mayor Cote moved to Holmdel 19 years ago. He split with the Greater Holmdel Republican Club -- whose members he refers to as "the dinosaurs" -- over what he said was their "rich town mentality, where all we have to do is get more ratables in to pay for everything."
Ms. Lasky, who moved to Holmdel 22 years ago from Connecticut, is not one of Mr. Cote's admirers. "The kindest thing you can say about Ernie is that he's the Republican Party's black sheep," she said.
Barbs between Ms. Lasky and Mr. Cote are staples of Township Committee meetings. During one long night in February, as she tried to call for a vote, Mayor Cote responded, "Peggy, you can call a cab for all I care."
 
Allies on Committee
 Gary Aumiller, a Republican who is a physicist with Bell Labs, and Carole Balmer, a Democrat who lives on a small farm with her veterinarian husband, are Mayor Cote's allies on the committee.
Mr. Aumiller, a property owner since 1979 who hails from Pennsylvania, got his first taste of political life campaigning door to door last summer. "I have to temper my own feelings now that I'm elected," he said. "I consider myself a nonpolitician. It weighs on my mind that we can't get things done."
Ms. Balmer, who grew up in Union City and moved to Holmdel 17 years ago, is also new to political office. "I guess I'm a masochist," she said with a grin. Commenting on the failure to achieve consensus on the Township Committee, she said: "Sometimes you have to sway a little bit. It's not 'no development,' it's the 'right' development. This is all the land we've got left."
Malcolm Gropper, a Republican, is Ms. Lasky's partner on the committee. He was appointed to fill a post-election vacancy; the independents are contesting his appointment in court. He initially rose to prominence leading a successful five-year fight for public sewer hookups in his neighborhood.
 
'Too Much Politics'
 "There's too much politics and not enough business taking place at the meetings," said Mr. Gropper, a housing developer who moved here from Uniondale, L.I., 17 years ago. But he added: "I've survived corporate politics. I'll survive local politics. There's more than one way to solve a problem."
Construction is scheduled to start soon on the Holmdel Towne Center, a $40 million shopping complex owned by a division of the Sears Financial Network. The 300,000-square-foot complex is in the northern section of the township, across Route 35 from a food and garden emporium operated by Dominic Lucarelli, a second-generation farmer.
"Every few years a new ratable came in to help offset the tax base," said Mr. Lucarelli, a former committeeman. His nearest neighbor is the Harvard Electronics Company, situated in the former Lily Tulip paper cup factory.
Another neighbor in the township's light industrial zone is the former factory for Charles of the Ritz cosmetics. It is now owned by Revco, the Revlon cosmetics maker, and is used as a warehouse.
 
'We're Going to Feel It'
 "We should put aside personality and figure out how to get the economy going," Mr. Lucarelli said. Otherwise, he said, "five years from now we're going to feel it."
As Mr. Wadington, a native of Illinois, looked back on his public career, which included service with the Monmouth County Republican organization and the Holmdel Planning Board, he admitted that the long hours had taken a personal toll. A widower with three grown children, he has remarried and has a new instant family of three small children. "I didn't realize that family is the No. 1 priority one should have in life," he said.
But Mr. Wadington has not given up on politics anymore than he has given up being a Republican. In fact, he is under contract for 100 hours of work as a consultant to the township. One of his fondest hopes, he said, is that the various Republican factions in town can get together to overthrow the independents in November.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 19, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A sketch of Holmdel Township on April 5 with an article about the township omitted the artist's credit. She was Peg McEowen of Holmdel.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Two Waitresses a la Samuel Beckett

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
FOR some 40 years modern playwrights have been beholden to Samuel Beckett, who stripped the theatrical landscape of conventional structure and scenery and got to the essence of being, the void of existence, the meaning of meaninglessness, the hope beyond hopelessness and the implications of words. Like waiting.
Some playwrights apparently feel obliged to keep reminding us of that debt by invoking parallels to such Beckettian concerns as going on amid barrenness and trifling time away with seeming non sequiturs. Borrowing from old masters is confused with developing a new voice for some writers. Like Rachel Sheinkin. 
 Her play, "Loss of Virginia," at Company One Theater in Hartford, is about two waitresses in a diner. With Beckett in mind, it hardly seems necessary to remind one that what waitresses do is wait.
Which is not to say that Beckett is Ms. Sheinkin's sole influence, only the most obvious one and the most prominent in the absurdist school that has, no doubt, provoked Ms. Sheinkin to write ramblingly and repetitiously in a mixed bag of styles.
Including musical comedy. The words from "Shall We Dance?" are excerpted in the program, and two of the six other characters in the diner are formally decked out, sing lyrics rather than speak lines (to original music by Neil Ginsberg) and dance, dance, dance -- tap, tango, pirouette, Yiddish folk. After shuffling off into the kitchen, they stuff themselves with bread and throw it all over the floor. At one point or perhaps another, someone asks, "If I wasn't hungry, how would I know I wasn't happy or dead?"
The recycled banter in "Loss of Virginia" -- Virginia, one of the waitresses, is from Virginia, wants to go back there and does -- brings to mind the sort of semantic meandering that in college days was randomly indulged in by those in an existential, glib or just plain ornery mood, usually after midnight, when pauses, blank stares and parrying were mistaken for depth. Some people write all that down and call it postmodernism. Ms. Sheinkin has poignant, specific things to say about the frustrations of young people, but her vision is blurred by the overkill of the anti-establishment.
Thus, in the playwright's diner, somewhere in limboland, one hears loaded questions like, "Would you like to join me?" and "Are we alone together?" To the observation, "You're new," the retort is, "I am not used," or "I am not old." When Virginia takes the order of the other waitress, Rose, who is not from Roseland and insists that Virginia is not from Virginia either, she is called a thief. Later, Virginia on her way to Virginia, calls from the road. The exchange goes something like this: "I have a flat tire." "No, I'm not a motor vehicle."
Clearly, to the extent that clarity in any form of the word is applicable here, Ms. Sheinkin is concerned with, yes, communication. One of the denizens of the diner, who include Scratch and Sniff, wants to hear the unspoken. The playwright is also expressing the disorientation of young people who are desperately seeking sense in a society that's hiding it. And the reason Virginia has run off to Virginia with Oscar, the diner's owner, is that he has offered her love. She did not expect that Oscar would also be offering her other lovers.
Once Virginia leaves, Rose is left holding the bag -- of garbage. She has been lugging it about all along, and it has gotten bigger throughout the play. At the end, its contents -- a typewriter, a telephone, an application for employment, an application for unemployment, hair curlers, hair straighteners and "every mistake Rose ever made" -- represent the detritus, the clutter, the contradictions of her life, which is now at a standstill or, more accurately, a sit-down. She does not speak, and, in the manner of the classic Beckett stage direction, she does not move. One of the last things she says is, "I don't think I want to be here." From that big plastic bag, Ms. Sheinkin now has to sort out her own materials.
Company One, which begins its 10th year in the fall, produces new experimental works. Most recently, plays by significant new playwrights like Suzan-Lori Parks and Paula Vogel have been done. With "Loss of Virginia," the company, which has had a nomadic existence for several seasons, has taken up residence in the 284-seat Art Deco auditorium (formerly the Avery Theater) at the Wadsworth Atheneum that has been variously but inconsistently used for stage events and film programs but has an indelible claim to music-theater history. The auditorium was the site of the world premiere of the Virgil Thomson-Gertrude Stein opera, "Four Saints in Three Acts," with choreography by Frederick Ashton and direction by John Houseman, on Feb. 7, 1934.
"Loss of Virginia"  at the Aetna Theater of Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. 233-4588.  Performances through next Sunday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the cast of "Loss of Virginia," at Company One Theater in Hartford. (Phillip Fortune)

HEADLINE: Free Baby Sitting Fills Tables at Restaurant

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: BEDFORD HILLS

 BODY:
FEW businesses have escaped the pinch of the recession, and for local restaurants things are particularly dismal on the traditionally slow first three nights of the week. But one recent Tuesday evening at Rockwells, in Bedford Hills, a line of customers was backed up to the door.
What is the big draw? It's a novel concept that has struck a nerve with Westchester parents: free baby-sitting at the restaurant. On Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday nights, from 5 to and 9 o'clock, the management at Rockwells transforms an auxiliary dining room into a nursery school. Doll carts and toy cars are spread across the floor; a toy kitchen is in the corner. There are storybooks on one table and arts and crafts projects on another. 
 "This is incredible," said Elise Glier, who was visiting the restaurant for the first time. "This is heaven." Her son, Sam, almost 2 years old, had run into the baby-sitting room and grabbed a toy. "Tonight when my friend said to me we could go out to dinner at a place where they will take care of your kid, I couldn't believe it," she said. "Then I said, 'Let's go.' " 
If parents wish, their children can be served a children's meal in the baby-sitting room. Children also have the option of eating in the main dining room with their parents and playing in the baby-sitting room before and after the meal. While the baby-sitting service is free, there is a charge of $4.95 for the children's meal.
 
First-Hand Experience
 Rockwells has branches in Tuckahoe and Scarsdale, and all three restaurants offer baby-sitting. Steve Robbins, the owner, said he got the idea while trying to dine out with his own children, who are 5, 4 and 2 years old.
"I knew first-hand how hard it was to go out to a restaurant with your kids," Mr. Robbins said. "Then last year, I went to a furniture store that had a place on-site where they watched your children. It was great. We've always had a family market at the restaurants, and I thought it would probably work."
Based on the reaction of parents at the restaurant, it seems like an idea whose time had come.
"We can actually have a conversation," said Diane Renick of North Salem, who was dining with her husband, Steve, and their two children.
 
A Way to Reduce Boredom
 Eight-year-old Kristin Renick said that dining where there was a place to play "is not so boring" as eating at other places with her parents. She then announced, "I'm done. Can I go back to the room now?" She was joined by her 3-year-old brother, Stephen, who had quickly eaten a grilled-cheese sandwich while bouncing up and down in his chair.
"Kids are just so fidgety. They are on dessert and you are still on your salad," said Michal Winter, who was eating out with her husband, Warren, and their two children. "This is the only place where I can actually have coffee after dinner."
Mr. and Mrs. Winter said they come to Rockwells an average of two times a month. They rarely hire a sitter and prefer the flexibility of being able to come home from work and make a last-minute decision to go out.
"For less than the cost of going out to eat and leaving your kids at home, you can take them along and give them some entertainment, too," Mr. Winter said, adding: "Eating out is a luxury, but this way its affordable and enjoyable. We feel comfortable with them so nearby."
 
Crying Can Set Off a Chain Reaction
 Of course, all is not always rosy in the baby-sitting room. Two-year-old Sam Glier, who had first entered the room enthusiastically, had second thoughts when he realized that his mother was not going to stay with him. And in a group-care situation one crying child will often set off a chain reaction among the others, said Catherine Coughlin, the baby sitter.
"We try to get a crying child out of the room real quickly," Ms. Coughlin said. "It's better that they be with their mother than hanging around the door unhappy." Children running back and forth from the baby-sitting room to the dining room can also be disruptive to the other customers.
On balance, the concept seems to be a success. Recently, Mr. Robbins tested the service with the lunch crowd here in Bedford Hills, offering free baby-sitting from noon to 3 P.M. on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays. While the management prefers children to be at least 2 years old for evening baby-sitting, infants are accommodated at lunchtime. Earlier this month, a local play group came in to eat. The mothers enjoyed a leisurely lunch while six 14-month-old babies crawled around the playroom.
"This is a place where the grown-ups can be grown-ups and the kids can be kids," said Esmeralda Santiago of Bedford Hills, who had taken her 7-year-old daughter, Ila, in for baby-sitting. "My husband and I get to have a date, and the kids get fed and play. Then we take them home, and everybody's happy."
