HEADLINE: Nestle's Move Symbolizes A Competitive Climate

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
THE announcement that Nestle is moving its headquarters to California, coming on the heels of General Motors's decision to close its North Tarrytown assembly plant in 1995, may raise the specter of an exodus from Westchester. But corporate and government leaders say the county is resilient enough to recover from the loss of two major employers.
The Nestle Food Company, in fact, can be viewed as a window into a changing economic future. Long the beneficiary of major corporate relocations, Westchester is now experiencing the effect of corporate downsizing, mergers and restructuring. Yet it expects growth in other economic areas. 
 "We believe future growth will come from midsize and smaller companies," said Noreen Preston, an economic-development specialist at the county's Office of Commerce and Economic Development in White Plains. She said these firms "will probably focus on supplying business-support services."
 
10 Years Ago, 1,200 Employees in Purchase
 Ten years ago, Nestle had 1,200 employees at its headquarters in Purchase. In 1989, there were 925. Last month, when Nestle announced that the workers in Purchase would be leaving by the end of this year, there were only 400. About 135 of them have been offered jobs at the company's new home in Glendale, Calif.
"We don't own Nestle; it's not anchored in cement here," said S. J. Schulman, president of the Westchester County Association, a business group headquartered in White Plains. "Nestle is no different from any other big corporation today that is undergoing major restructuring to make it more competitive."
A major corporate restructuring, in which the 15 Nestle food and beverage companies in the United States were formed into six business units, has taken place since the merger of Nestle with its sibling, the former Carnation Company of Los Angeles.
The company's presence in the county dates from 1952. Nestle USA, part of the world's largest food company, Nestle S.A. in Switzerland, was established in Westchester that year when two United States subsidiaries of Nestle S.A. opened executive offices in White Plains. The company later moved to larger quarters on Bloomingdale Road in White Plains and in 1977 to a new headquarters building on Manhattanville Road in Purchase.
The move to Purchase was made possible only when the town of Harrison rezoned property owned by Manhattanville College, which it did after the state agreed to build a new exit and entrance from Manhattanville Road to Interstate 684 at a cost of $7 million. The road improvement diverted traffic from local Harrison streets and was a concession to keep Nestle in Westchester and in the state. Nestle acted in good faith, said a company spokesman, Linda Gavlick. "At that time, Nestle had no thought of moving from Purchase. No one could foresee future consolidation."
As part of the restructuring, the Nestle Chocolate and Confection Company in Purchase became a part of a merged company called the Nestle Food Company. "The move will unite the Nestle Chocolate and Confection Company in Purchase with the sales and distribution arms in Glendale," Ms. Gavlick said, "so the business will be able to draw upon the resources and support groups of Nestle Food Company and Nestle USA in Glendale."
Mr. Schulman said the move was not surprising. "What usually happens in such cases is that the new merged headquarters is close to the home of the larger sibling, which in this case was the former Carnation Company in Los Angeles," he said.
Even as it departs, Nestle is keeping real estate ties to Westchester. Last December, the company paid $11.5 million for the land on which its 260,000-square-foot headquarters building in Purchase sits, and it has just bought the building from Related Properties of Manhattan.
Ms. Gavlick said the purchase was made after Nestle examined several options. "Because we had a long-term lease on the building, it made the best sense financially for us to buy it as an investment."
 
Some Signs of Growth
 Mr. Schulman said he does not believe that corporate departures and downsizing have dealt Westchester a mortal blow. Nor, in fact, does he think they will continue.
"We recently conducted a survey of major private-sector employers in the county, and it shows that employment at the majority of them is pretty stable," Mr. Schulman said. "What is especially interesting, given the economy, is that some of them are showing a healthy increase in growth."
Citing an example, Mr. Schulman said that under the Philip Morris takeover, General Foods had become relatively stable: "In 1989, they employed 2,750 people in White Plains; this year, employment has risen to 3,050."
Even more encouraging, he added, are the employment figures from Nynex. "Six years ago, Nynex had 800 employees. This year, they have a work force of 2,180."
 
The Worst Could Be Over
 Other companies showing an increase in employment this year, Mr. Schulman said, are Texaco, Pepsico, New York Telephone, Ciba-Geigy, the Bank of New York and Liberty Lines.
"And at I.B.M., still the county's largest private employer, the work force is also relatively stable despite all the negative reports -- 11,000 in 1992 compared with 12,000 in 1989," he said.
Ms. Preston, the economic development specialist with the county, also suggested that the worst of the stagnation that has plagued the county's economy for three years could be over.
"The objective of downsizing and restructuring is to allow companies to operate more efficiently and more competitively," Ms. Preston said. "If you have a company like Nestle, which is national in scope, a proportionately larger reduction in staff makes headlines."
"But I know of many midsize companies in the county that have done the same thing and are now out of that phase and are doing very well," she added. "Of course, we realize that the time is past when Fortune 500 companies move their headquarters into the county at a fast clip."
 
A 20 Percent Vacancy Rate
 Ms. Preston said the Office of Commerce and Economic Development is active in working to attract business and retain companies.
"We not only act as a clearing house, giving out information, but we also assist companies coming into the county to find appropriate space here," Ms. Preston said. "Right now is a good time to relocate because we have a 20 percent vacancy rate for Class A office space available at $23 to $24 a square foot."
Margaret Soter, who is the director of the department, said that although the marketing efforts of the department extend beyond the state, most of the companies coming into the county have been recruited from New York City.
"Companies in New York City don't have to worry too much about relocating employees," Ms. Soter said. "They can come here with their labor force pretty intact because our bus and rail system makes it feasible for their workers to get to the job. Others also benefit from the trained labor force we have here."
 
Competition From Neighbors
 Yet Ms. Soter acknowledged that there is intense competition for every new company from neighboring Connecticut and northern New Jersey. "We're all after business," she said. "But I'm optimistic because the central location of Westchester works to our favor. We've already made the first cut for Unicef's relocation, and that organization has 800 employees. They are considering coming from Manhattan to New Rochelle."
Ms. Soter added that she is also encouraged by the recent restructuring of the Westchester Partnership, a consortium of business and private-sector organizations in the county working together to market the county as a desirable business location.
"The Partnership is now broader based, with representatives from government, business and area developers on the committee," she said. "George Delaney of Consolidated Edison has agreed to become our new president," she added.
Plans call for an aggressive marketing campaign, making use of advertising, public relations, radio and television to woo companies to the county, Ms. Soter said.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Millburn

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
MILLBURN TOWNSHIP, one of the wealthiest communities in northern New Jersey, owes much of its character to the inventor of the spring-loaded window shade.
The inventor, Stewart Hartshorn of New York City, bought a 1,550-acre tract called Short Hills in 1877 when he was 37 years old. Short Hills, which today makes up most of the northern half of the township, was named for its hills, which have a maximum elevation of 660 feet. The area offered clear streams, a chestnut forest and the contours that Hartshorn sought to develop an ideal community. 
 Rather than laying out a grid of roads and lots, he followed the terrain and often adjusted roads to avoid felling trees. He built more than 50 houses, on 2- to 5-acre lots, rented and later sold them.
Many of the original Hartshorn Houses, built of wood and blue traprock in several styles, including Greek Revival and Victorian, are still standing. But the original lots have been subdivided into half-acre to one-acre sites. Houses with six to seven bedrooms on one-acre lots are now priced from $1.2 million to $1.8 million, says Harriet Nesbitt, a broker with Burgdorff Realtors in Short Hills.
In keeping with Hartshorn's tree-preservation efforts, the town has a full-time forester. Before trees may be cut down, he must issue a permit, and he also advises residents on tree planting and care. Timothy P. Gordon, the Millburn business administrator, says the township has more than 1,000 trees that are more than 200 years old.
The Morris & Essex Railroad, built in the late 1830's to haul coal from Pennsylvania to New York City, passed through Millburn and spurred its growth. By 1872, when Hartshorn sought his town site, Millburn was already a commuter suburb of New York City with its own train station, which Hartshorn augmented with a second station in Short Hills.
The Wyoming section, on the southeastern side of town, had just been subdivided into 50-foot-wide building lots in a neat grid pattern. The homes there are a mix of styles including Tudors, colonials, historic farmhouses and Victorians. They are priced from $300,000 to $600,000. A four-bedroom neo-Georgian home on Sagamore recently sold for $525,000.
According to Mrs. Nesbitt, a starter home in Millburn would be a three-bedroom split-level for about $300,000. Such homes can be found in the southern part of the township. She said that the housing market in Millburn had suffered no more than a 10 percent price decline because of the economic slump and that sales had been brisk since December, with 27 homes closing in January alone.
Mr. Gordon said the township committee had often debated the lack of affordable housing. "The problem is that the township is all built up," he said. "There is no available land for it."
Among the newer residents are Beth Corrick, her husband, Guillermo, a financial analyst, and their three children, 15 months to 7 years old . Two years ago, they moved to a three-bedroom split-level in Short Hills from a Park Slope co-op.
"WE were concerned about crime in the Brooklyn schools," Ms. Corrick explained. "We wanted a materially successful area with a short commute to New York City, since my husband works in the city. We investigated the school system and found that it has a very low student-teacher ratio and that it was rated as one of the best in the state."
George S. Goffe, a retired executive and 14-year resident of Millburn, concedes that his children would have great difficulty buying a home in the township. However, he said, "in time, I expect that the education they received here will enable them to earn what it takes to buy a home here."
A middle-market area is the Country Club section, next to the Canoe Brook Country Club, which has an 18-hole private golf course. Four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath colonials there built just after World War II, are priced from $400,000 to $500,000.
Condominiums form the low end of the market. "We hardly notice them," Mrs. Nesbitt said. "They serve mainly young people or senior citizens."
There are 20 apartment complexes in town, some of which have been converted into condominiums. Units are offered at $100,000 to $200,000. The largest condominium complex is the 98-unit Lakeside Village on Main Street, a converted garden-apartment complex.
Vacant rental units are hard to find. The largest apartment complex in town is the 123-unit Short Hills Terrace, where one-bedroom units rent for $920 and two- bedrooms for $1,100.
There are also several blocks of small houses near the business district in the southern section. They were built about 60 years ago for immigrants who were employed at the large houses. Two- to three-bedroom homes on 36-foot-wide lots there are priced as low as $150,000.
Two downtowns, centered around the two ends of Millburn Avenue, have one supermarket each and convenience and service businesses, including ice cream parlors, beauty shops, hardware stores, restaurants and a total of 21 bank branch offices -- one for every 900 people in town.
The million-square-foot Short Hills Mall at Route 24 and JFK Parkway is anchored by Bloomingdale's and A.& S. and has such specialty shops as Gucci, Ralph Lauren and Banana Republic.
Across from the mall is the Hilton at Short Hills, a 300-room hotel that also houses one of the town's best known restaurants, the Dining Room, which has an American menu. Others are 40 Main Street, with American cooking; Sergio's, a Northern Italian restaurant at Millburn Avenue and Main Street, and Sono, a Japanese restaurant on Millburn Avenue. There also are few fast-food outlets.
The most widely used recreational spot in the township is the 36-acre Gero Park off White Oak Ridge Road. It has a par-three, nine-hole golf course, the town pool, four tennis courts and two baseball diamonds.
A POPULAR township area is the 16-acre Cora Hartshorn Arboretum and Bird Sanctuary, developed by the daughter of Stewart Hartshorn on Forest Drive. The Paper Mill Playhouse, on Brookside Drive, one of the country's best-known regional theaters, offers musicals, plays and children's events. Tickets are $24 to $38.
The Millburn Township Public School System has a reputation as one of the finest in New Jersey. It has four K-5 schools, the largest of which is the 335-student Glenwood School on Taylor Road in Short Hills. The students go on to Millburn Middle School on Old Short Hills Road and then to Millburn High School on Millburn Avenue.
Last year, the high school sent 95 percent of its graduates to higher education, according to Dr. Paul W. Rossey, superintendent of schools. The graduating class of '91 included five National Merit scholarship winners and 17 finalists, one Presidential Scholar (a national award) and two Presidential Scholar finalists.
Computer education begins in kindergarten and each of the schools has at least one computer laboratory. After-school programs are offered to gifted students from grade 3 through middle school. The high school offers 15 advanced placement courses in math, science, English, Social Studies and foreign languages.
Dr. Rossey says the quality of the school system reflects the academic and achievement levels of the parents. "It's not surprising that our students are smart," he said. "Most of the parents here have college degrees. And to live here, you have be highly competitive, work hard and be smart."
The larger private schools in town are the nursery-8 Far Brook School, the K-6 Pingry Lower School and the K-8 Roman Catholic St. Rose of Lima School.

Rush-hour commutation to midtown: 35 minutes by Lakeland Bus to Port Authority Bus Terminal, $5.25 one-way, $46.75 weekly; 35 minutes by N.J. Transit train to Hoboken, $4.10 one-way, $6.25 round trip, $35 weekly, $115 monthly, then PATH, $1.
 
Government: Five township committee members, elected to three-year terms, who annually choose one of their number as mayor (currently Frank W. Long, Republican).
 
Mill on the Burn: Millburn is a combination of the words mill and the Scottish "burn," or stream. Adopted when the area seceded from Springfield Township in 1857, the name honors Samuel Campbell, a Scot who moved there just after the Revolution and set up a paper mill on the Rahway River in what is now the 2,000-acre South Mountain Reservation recreation area, half of which is in Millburn. Campbell's Mill was followed by several others that made felt and hats. All have closed.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Silicon Egalitarians Scoff at a Private Club

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

DATELINE: LOS ALTOS, Calif.

 BODY:
A few years back, a profile by Tom Wolfe in Esquire of Silicon Valley pioneer Robert Noyce described how, in the early 60's, the employees of Fairchild Semiconductor, one of several companies he founded, gathered at the windows to gawk at a limousine and driver. Limos are no longer an oddity in Silicon Valley, but in this down-to-earth culture any symbol of social stratification still causes squeamishness. That is evident in the periodic failed attempts to establish here that bastion of East Coast urban life, the private club.
"The high-tech community doesn't have much use for things like this," said Paul Franson of the public relations firm of Hagerty & Associates in San Jose. "They don't go out to fancy lunches. You're lucky to have a sandwich at your desk." 
 Exclusive clubs in Silicon Valley have had to open their gates to the rabble to stay in business. Courtside in Los Gatos had to open its restaurant almost immediately to the public. The De Anza Racquet Club, near the Cupertino headquarters of Apple Computer Inc., went broke and is now owned by the City of Cupertino. The Decathlon Club, perhaps the most celebrated of these ventures, quietly opened its dining room to the public, too.
Now comes a new contender for the patronage of patrician-pretenders: the Silicon Valley Capital Club, part of a Dallas-based chain operating in the West. While many of its counterparts bowed to the 80's gestalt by emphasizing fitness and fine dining, the Capital Club, atop the tallest office building in the redeveloping downtown of San Jose, has forgone lockers and racquetball courts in favor of wood paneling and neoclassical furniture. The only people who break into a sweat here are the waiters.
With many of the hot little start-up companies now residing on the Fortune 500, it is betting that aging tycoons are tired of equality and ready for a private club. Since it opened in 1989, the club has grown to 850 members, despite a $2,400 individual initiation fee and dues of $79 a month. But there is not much Silicon Valley in the Silicon Valley Capital Club. Most members are lawyers, accountants and bankers from downtown San Jose. So where are all those powerful electronics tycoons? "Maybe it's the mystique about going to downtown San Jose," said Ellen G. Harris, membership director.
Such organizations are anathema to a place created to contradict the hierarchical East Coast business establishment. Here, entrepreneurship, building one's life from scratch, rules -- and the guy in the Grateful Dead T-shirt sometimes turns out to be the vice president of research and development. The industry's two most important role models, Bill Hewlett and David Packard, were unassuming engineers who ate in the company cafeteria with the rest of the staff. In their wake, even an executive dining room seems unnecessarily plutocratic. Combine this self-conscious commonness with the demands of a 90-hour work week and it is no mystery why executives might rather go for a three-mile run than to an exclusive dining room for a meal bulging with cholesterol.
High expectations may also work against the club's success. "Back East, because there are so many private clubs, many of them around for literally hundreds of years, there is a much greater tolerance of the form," said Tom Fanella, president of the local PBS affiliate, KTEH. "In Silicon Valley, the Capital Club is the first of its kind and people have very high expectations. I personally think it's a nice private club -- if you can call anything with 1,000 members private. It's a good place from which to see and not a bad place to be seen."
Norman C. Hulberg, president of Hulberg & Associates Inc. real estate appraisers, points out a subtler deterrent. "Some clients say, gee, this is a nice place; I'm glad Hulberg is successful enough to take me here," said Mr. Hulberg. "But some will resent that I can afford to belong to such a place, so I have to be careful."
Mr. Franson, a charter member, finds the place fine for press conferences, but otherwise "pretentious." "People with taste giggle about it," he said. "At dinner, there's the clicking of covers, the intrusive service, waiters calling you endlessly by name, frozen forks, giant pepper mills and all the other cliches you've ever heard of. I suppose it's not a bad place to take an out-of-town client -- if you don't mind the waiter being part of your group."
But perhaps the most telling assessment comes from another charter member, Jack Gorry, chief executive of the CXR Corporation, which makes electronic medical instruments in San Jose. "All the Capital Club is is a high-class restaurant," he said. "It wanted to be a club but nobody showed up. That's because you can't do business and socialize at the same time. It's a contradiction in terms -- and that's why most clubs here haven't worked."
Mr. Gorry belongs to the one private club in San Jose that works, the century-old Sainte Claire Club. Tucked into a modest three-story brick building just five blocks from the Capital Club, Sainte Claire is everything the upstart is not: small (120 members), anachronistic (all-male) and expensive ($35,000 initiation). It does not try to meld business and pleasure. Its one fast rule: no papers or briefcases allowed. Mr. Gorry aside, the Sainte Claire Club has not a single member even remotely connected with Silicon Valley.
Meanwhile, the Capital Club becomes less exclusive. A recent letter to members proudly announced that guests would now be allowed to pay for members' meals.

HEADLINE: All About/Acoustic Band Instruments;
The Boom in Soft-Edged Sound

BYLINE: By M. P. DUNLEAVEY

 BODY:
When the Canadian Brass, a quintet known for its spirited approach to classical music and jazz, decided about a year ago to design and make its own line of high-quality brass instruments, it faced an obstacle that instrument makers a generation ago never dreamed of: A $265 million market for acoustic band instruments, once made up of dozens of small craftsmen, now dominated by just four companies after decades of consolidation. Acoustic instruments, which include all woodwinds and brass instruments, are the fad of the moment in the $3.5 billion musical instrument market.
Three of the four largest makers of acoustic band instruments are privately held, according to Brian Majeski, editor of the Music Trade, an industry magazine in Englewood, N.J. The G. Leblanc Corporation, had about $40 million in sales last year, the Selmer Ludwig Company, had about $75 million in sales and the United Musical Instruments, had about $50 million worth of sales. The Yamaha Corporation of Japan had about $50 million in sales of acoustical instruments. About 85 percent of the 600,000 instruments sold each year are sold to students. 
 "If you look at instrument sales like a pyramid, only the very tip is professional musicians," said Stan Garber, a spokesman for Selmer Ludwig, the Elkhart, Ind. instrument maker. "The bottom is all student instruments."
Those companies sell their products through 6,000 local music stores around the country which have a virtual lock on the market. "The only way we could see a way into this was to work strictly with dealers," said Chuck Daellenbach, the tuba player for the Canadian Brass. "My father was a bandleader, and I've observed all my life the close relationship between the band and the local music store." But a new trend has emerged that is contrary to the Canadian Brass strategy: mail-order instrument sales.
Industry legend has it that during a slump the market for band instruments inexplicably picks up. "Last year was a record year in terms of sales and profits," said Michael Johnson, a spokesman for Leblanc. "So far it's holding for 1992," he added. Selmer's Mr. Garber said his company also did well during the recession.

 
 
The Fads
Wind Instruments Make a Comeback
 For a market where the products change little from year to year, there are definite consumer fads. Acoustic guitars are selling better than their electric counterparts, many retailers said. According to the Music Trade, woodwinds declined slightly in sales, to about 284,000 units in 1991 from 294,450 in 1990, while brass instruments increased to 153,000 units in 1991 from 146,115 in 1990.
"Three years ago you couldn't sell a horn," said Henry Goldrich, owner of Manny's Music World in New York. "Now people are tired of the electronic sound." Mr. Goldrich estimated that his horn sales -- industry slang for any wind instrument -- have doubled in the last two years.
 
Buying by Mail
New Competition For the Music Store
 From folk singers to heavy metal stars, the instrument-buying public is hearing more acoustic instruments -- and wants them.
Most students buy or lease their instruments from the local mom-and-pop retailer. But many in the industry now say that the aggressive marketing and low prices offered by discount mail-order companies are beginning to threaten the small dealers.
"Most students start on rental instruments," said Denny Senseny, the owner of Senseny Music in Wichita, Kan. "And most grass-roots dealers are willing to do that, but mail order has grown at the expense of full-service dealers."
A half dozen or so mail-order companies compete for a share of the acoustic instrument and market. So far their sales are still small -- about 10 to 15 percent of the market, according to Mr. Majeski. They are mostly more expensive instruments.
Giardinelli Band Instruments Inc., once a renowned New York-based discount store, is now one of two mail-order companies owned by the American Music Group in Liverpool, N.Y. that deal only in acoustic instruments. The other company, LMI of Itasca, Ill. caters to school music programs. According to David Fleming, American's vice president for sales, the two companies have combined sales of about $3 million, he said.
"Mail-order companies are only successful in areas where the local store cannot provide the right instrument or their prices are too high." Mr. Fleming said. He added that the American Music Group also owns seven local music retail stores, opened "because we saw the need, based on the fact that mail order was doing well in those areas."
Nevertheless, many retailers say mail order is beginning to hurt their business. "Customers play 'Watts line roulette,' " said Mr. Senseny, describing what many say is becoming a common phenomenon: Customers go to the local dealer to try out instruments, get information and then call 800-numbers to place an order.
"Mail-order competition is definitely one reason retail stores don't get involved in higher-end instruments," said Bernard Brauns, co-owner of Ingram and Brauns Musik Shoppe in Modesto, Calif., one of the first stores to order the Canadian Brass line. "It's too competitive." Mr. Brauns chose the line because it is not sold by mail.
 
 
VINTAGE GUITARS FOR GROWN-UPS
 Remember the kids in high school who played their guitars -- all day? They've grown up now and are still buying guitars.
"I have a lot of 40-year-olds who now can afford to buy the guitar they wanted when they were 15," said Matt Umanov, who has run Umanov Guitars in New York for the last 22 years. "So, they do."
That is welcome news for the nation's guitar makers. According to the American Music Conference, a nonprofit industry group, sales of all fretted instruments, which includes acoustic and electric guitars, hit $400 million in 1990, almost at their record 1988 levels.
Some of those sales are fueled by a renewed interest in the music of the 1960's. Sales of vintage electric guitars are also increasing, as companies like Gibson Guitar and Fender Inc. re-issue older models.
While sales of electric and acoustic guitars have been growing, "acoustics continue to outpace electrics on the sales floor" according to a survey by Musical Merchandise Review. Retailers also report that custom-built guitars -- a much smaller niche -- are selling well.
Increasingly, the guitar industry is dependent on cheap imports to lift sales. Most of the well-known guitar makers, like the Martin Guitar Company and Gibson, started out as American manufacturers, but now import at least some of their low-end models from Asia. According to the American Music Conference, most guitars sold are now imported. Washburn International Inc., a company that began making guitars around the turn of the century, is now only a distributor. All of its guitars are imported.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Small Travel Magazine Finds World of Readers

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

 BODY:
It may be published in a building that once housed a nursery, standing close to Chuck's Steak and the First Interstate Bank and across from a shopping mall, but Islands magazine takes its readers to the infinitely more alluring locales of the world's exotic and remote islands.
And the magazine's goals are no less romantic. Islands eschews service pieces that counsel readers on where to stay or what airline to fly, instead providing writers' impressions of islands that "give you the sense of being there," said Joan Tapper, the magazine's editor in chief. A recent issue carried features on Prince Edward Island, Canada's smallest province, and islands in the Russian Arctic. 
 Island's ambitions may be big, but its circulation is a mere 171,000, compared with Travel & Leisure's 1.1 million. Indeed, in an era of increasingly large media companies, the 11-year-old bimonthly is emblematic of a handful of small, independent publications that are determined to grow. They are struggling in a particularly perilous economy in which some small publishers have given up and even the Goliaths of the industry, including Hearst and Hachette, have shut down or combined publications.
 
Thriving Enterprise
 Yet Bill Kasch, who bought Islands in 1983, said the once-ailing magazine was now a thriving enterprise, with operating profits of $325,947 last year on revenue of $5.2 million.
Islands faces tough rivals. Not only does it compete against Travel & Leisure, but also Conde Nast Traveler, which has 745,000 subscribers. Publishers at both those magazines said they did not consider Islands, which carried only 504 pages of advertising in 1991, to be competition. Travel & Leisure, for example, carried 1,373 pages of advertising last year at much higher rates.
Still, John Veronis, whose company, Veronis Suhler Associates, acts as an investment banker in the publishing industry, said the magazine had a good editorial and marketing strategy. "It has high renewal rates and is very clearly targeted," he said.
And David Lehmkuhl, a media consultant, said Islands held an audience with strong demographic appeal.
Mendelsohn Media Research Inc. said the magazine's readers had an average household income exceeding $80,000 and a median age of 46 years. Islands' internal research shows that about 60 percent of those readers took a trip abroad last year.
Mr. Kasch said his goal, a difficult one, was to reach a circulation of 250,000 to 500,000 in the next five years.
Islands may never equal the circulation of some broader travel publication because "the magazine's subject matter is more focused than its rivals," Mr. Veronis said. Still, he added, small special-interest publications like Islands can still find profitable niches and can often be more aggressive in raising cover prices than larger rivals. "The person who wants to know is going to pay for the publication," he said.
 
'It Was Real Dicey'
 The story of Islands is not unlike those of other publications built by entrepreneurs. Mr. Kasch, a Wisconsin native who is now 47 years old, became disenchanted with his family's toy business in the early 1980's and moved to Santa Barbara to invest in real estate.
But a chance meeting with David Friston, then the owner of Islands, piqued his interest in the publication. "I thought it would work, but I didn't know anything about the business," Mr. Kasch recalled. "I made projections, but all my sales and circulation figures were wrong. They were much too optimistic."
The magazine ate money. Mr. Kasch took over Islands by assuming its subscription liabilities of about $600,000. (The magazine then had about 40,000 subscribers.) But he found himself investing another $1.4 million from 1983 to 1986. "It was real dicey in 1985 and 1986," he recalled. "I had borrowed more money than I meant, the advertising was not coming and times were tough."
He and Alan Rock, who has handled advertising sales for the magazine since 1983, focused on attracting ads from small car-rental agencies and hotels and sought advertisers in exotic destinations like Tahiti that few other magazines were then chasing.
"It was a typical case of ready, fire, aim," Mr. Kasch said. "I didn't know what I was doing.
Islands did not begin to attract national travel accounts like Hyatt Hotels until 1985. And the magazine has still failed to lure such large tourist-oriented advertisers as Kodak or American Airlines.
Ultimately, however, Islands began to grow, maintaining its editorial strategy of covering islands from those in the highly popular Caribbean to the Spice Islands of Indonesia. In 1987, the magazine managed to earn $3,131 on revenue of $2.5 million.
By 1990, its profits peaked at $518,824 on revenue of $4.9 million, Mr. Kasch said, although they dropped 37 percent the next year because of rising costs.
Islands has no staff writers and gets most of its articles from freelance writers. The magazine does have three editors, in addition to Ms. Tapper, the editor in chief, and each occasionally writes articles.
The magazine has been investing more heavily in writing. Recent issues included an impressionist piece by Jan Morris about travels in Wales. Adam Nicholson has written on the Shiant Islands, three tiny islands held by his father, Nigel Nicholson, author of "Portrait of a Marriage." And Francis Fitzgerald is scheduled to do a piece on the Solomon Islands.
 
What to Do Next?
 The question for Islands is where to go next. Expanding a tightly focused magazine can be difficult because the audience is often limited and many existing readers may resent changes that broaden the publication.
On the other hand, selling a publication like Islands would not necessarily be easy, although Mr. Kasch said he had been approached by potential buyers. None of them, however, were big publishing companies.
For the moment at least, Mr. Kasch seems pleased to remain a publishing island in the heart of Santa Barbara.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Much to Answer For in Iraq

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Anthony Lewis provides, in "Who Fed This Caesar?" (column, March 15), substantial evidence that the Reagan and Bush Administrations were instrumental in building Saddam Hussein's military machine since 1982, when Iraq began to show signs of defeat in its war with Iran. Almost right up to the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, 1990, Iraq had received secret intelligence, high-technology exports, weapons and economic aid from the United States, despite overwhelming evidence during the last decade of President Hussein's international aggressiveness and atrocious human rights record.
Although it is clear that United States policy toward Iraq was flawed with respect to military and economic aid, it is also important to note that the White House displayed irresponsible behavior on the diplomatic front as well, especially during the months directly preceding Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. 
 A news article last Sept. 25 about the hearings to confirm Robert Gates as Director of Central Intelligence reported that, according to Charles E. Allen, a 32-year C.I.A. veteran, the Bush Administration had been warned as early as January 1990 by the Defense Intelligence Agency, by the military's Central Command, and by the Central Intelligence Agency that Saddam Hussein was very likely considering military action against Kuwait. By July 1990, the intelligence agencies had strong evidence that an invasion was imminent. Mr. Allen stated in his Congressional testimony that these forecasts were ignored by the Bush Administration.
As these details of United States-Iraqi relations continue to surface, it is becoming clear that United States intentions in the Persian Gulf region have been completely self-serving and counterproductive to maintaining peace and promoting human rights.
Indeed, and tragically, the United States is directly or indirectly responsible for much of the recent bloodshed in the gulf region, including, yes, Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait.
 
PETER GROSS
HARJINDER SINGH
Princeton, N.J., March 18, 1992

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International A3-13
 
YELTSIN PLEDGES 'CORRECTIONS'
On the eve of an important session of the Russian Parliament, President Yeltsin demanded strong executive authority and promised measures to soften the immediate effects of his economic reforms. A1
 
BIG VOTE FOR GERMAN RIGHTISTS
Far-right parties scored surprising gains in local elections in two German states. Politicians from established parties said the results were shocking and dangerous. A1
 
IRAN BOMBS A REBEL BASE IN IRAQ
Iranian jets bombed an Iranian rebel base in Iraq in the most serious attack by Iran since a truce ended their eight-year war in 1988. A3

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Brown;
Players in Familiar Roles as Vote Nears
Brown Spreads Message That the People Must Retake the Nation

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, April 5

 BODY:
From the television studios of Manhattan to the Mall beyond the United States Capitol to a red brick public housing project here, Edmund G. Brown Jr. today spread his message of insurgency, promising voters that as President he would return the country to the people.
At every stop he repeated the theme he has sounded since announcing his candidacy last October: that the Government is in the hands of a corrupt elite that needs to be overtaken. 
 In a scene that was fitting for the former California Governor's portrayal of himself as a born-again populist, Mr. Brown was not permitted to address an abortion-rights rally on the Washington Mall. So he put together a makeshift rally on the sidelines, grabbed a bullhorn and, with the Capitol as the backdrop, implored people to join his crusade.
"The whole point in this election is about democracy," said Mr. Brown, who for the first time since his upset victory in the Connecticut primary two weeks ago, shed his coat and tie and returned to his white turtleneck. "This is a campaign to take it back. Take back our rights. People in Washington don't care."
Asked why people should vote for him in New York on Tuesday, Mr. Brown said, "To overcome the failed and decrepit political leadership that is running the country into the ground."
As he changed from his turtleneck back to his suit on the flight to Buffalo this evening, the candidate spoke of a "newly revitalized insurgent Democratic Party that is building during this campaign," and of "finally achieving a real commitment to revitalizing the national economic and social system."
In advancing his "take back America" message, Mr. Brown pressed on today with his argument that the Democratic front-runner, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, was not fit to be President. "I used to say a scandal a week," he told reporters in Manhattan. "Now, it's a surprise a day."
But Mr. Brown could not escape being confronted with his own set of fresh ethical questions in Sunday newspapers, reports that portrayed him as one of the insiders he rails against.
The Los Angeles Times said that as Governor, Mr. Brown appointed 118 judges from 1979 to 1983 after they or their family members contributed to his campaigns. Those donors made up one-fifth of his judicial nominations in that period. Forty-two of those judges made gifts of $700 or more.
 
On the Defense, He Attacks
 Mr. Brown defended his appointments today, turning reporters' questions into an opportunity to repeat his indictment against the political establishment.
"Look, the problem is the system," he said. "I made my choices based on three factors: quality as determined by the state bar, diversity in terms of philosophy and ethnicity, and third, community service. But I will say this: I really am proud of the judges I appointed. The whole system has to be changed. That is why I am running for President."
The Times said there was "a striking correlation between campaign gifts" and Mr. Brown's appointments to the bench. The newspaper cited several examples, including that of Richard F. Charvat, a lawyer who with his parents, donated $5,750 to Mr. Brown from 1978 to 1980. In 1981 Mr. Brown appointed Mr. Charvat to the Los Angeles Municipal Court.
While most of the judges interviewed said their contributions were not linked to appointments, Mr. Charvat and his father told The Times they felt the contributions were a requirement.
 
Overseas Factory Site
 Mr. Brown also disputed an article in The San Francisco Examiner that said he helped a pharmaceutical manufacturer in Costa Mesa, Calif., search for a factory site in Hong Kong and China in 1989. As a Presidential candidate Mr. Brown has denounced the practice of companies' moving factories overseas where labor is cheaper.
Mr. Brown termed the report "a bunch of baloney," and said he was in Japan seeking investment capital for a Sacramento real estate company.
At the time, Mr. Brown was on the board of the company, ICN Biomedicals Inc., a post for which he was paid $20,000 a year, The Examiner reported. The head of the company, Milan Panic, was a longtime donor to Mr. Brown.
After Mr. Brown's trip to Asia, the company announced that it would begin a joint venture with the Chinese National Medical Corporation to establish a manufacturing center in China, the newspaper said.
 
Questions About Flat Tax
 Campaigning today, Mr. Brown continued to speak in broad terms about corruption in government rather than his programs to change the system. But on television news shows today he was questioned about some of his stands, particularly his support for a 13 percent flat tax on income and a 13 percent value added tax, similar to a national sales tax.
In a debate at WNBC-TV in New York this morning, Mr. Clinton derided the tax as reminiscent of Ronald Reagan's proposals, saying it would benefit the rich at the expense of the poor. "He doesn't tell people the truth," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Brown accused Mr. Clinton of using "funny statistics" to attack his plan.
Referring to Mr. Brown's evolution as a populist, Mr. Clinton talked about "all this born-again business." All that Mr. Brown would concede was that "Bill's got flaws, I've got flaws."
In addition, Mr. Brown found himself on the defensive on the CBS News program "Face The Nation," where he was questioned about his declaration that he wanted the Rev. Jesse Jackson as his Vice President, a move that infuriated Jewish groups. Although he said Mr. Jackson was still his first choice, Mr. Brown backed down slightly, saying, "Look, nothing is written in stone, but I will tell you that I believe he would make an excellent candidate."
 
'Pro Choice All the Way'
 Mr. Brown was also questioned about a statement years ago that he opposed abortion. But at the rally in Washington today he declared himself "pro choice all the way."
From the rally Mr. Brown flew to Buffalo, where he renewed his attack on Washington before a cheering crowd at a United Automobile Worker's hall. Railing against the "failed corrupt status quo," Mr. Brown said: "Down in Washington they are so busy trying to cover up for their bouncing checks and their midnight pay raises."
In his last words to the labor rally here, Mr. Brown repeated the theme he espoused today and throughout his campaign. "There's nothing we can't do if we pull together and replace the failed leadership in Washington," he said. "Send them a message, New York, on April 7. Let's turn this country around."

HEADLINE: Sam Walton Is Dead At 74; the Founder Of Wal-Mart Stores

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Sam Walton, the founder of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the most successful merchant of his time, died yesterday at the University of Arkansas Medical Sciences Hospital in Little Rock. He was 74 years old.
A spokeswoman at the hospital, where Mr. Walton was admitted a week ago, said that the cause of death was being withheld at the request of the family. Mr. Walton had long struggled against two types of cancer, hairy-cell leukemia, which weakens the immune system by attacking white blood cells, and a bone-marrow cancer called multiple myeloma. 
 Mr. Walton opened the first Wal-Mart Discount City in 1962 in Rogers, Ark., a small city in the Ozarks. By 1991 the chain passed Sears, Roebuck & Company to become the nation's largest retailer. On April 1, it had 1,735 stores in 42 states, as well as 2 in Mexico. Mr. Walton assembled a management team that will carry on, and the company said yesterday that it foresaw no changes in corporate policy or control.
Mr. Walton created Wal-Mart with the idea, once mocked by retailers, that large discount stores could thrive in small towns and rural areas. A gifted, homespun orator, he entranced legions of low-paid loyal workers with a simple refrain -- help customers, cut costs and share profits. Wal-Mart's headquarters, in contrast to the 110-story Sears Tower on the edge of Chicago's Loop, remain a box-like warehouse and general office in Bentonville, Ark.
Wal-Mart began to sell its stock to the public in 1970. As Wall Street discovered the company's unbroken pattern of high profits and fast growth, the price of Wal-Mart's stock began to soar in the late 1970's, and the Walton family's wealth with it.
The family fortune includes $23 billion in Wal-Mart stock alone, which provides more than $90 million in annual dividends. The Waltons also own seven banks in Arkansas and Oklahoma and five newspapers in Arkansas. While the Walton name is hardly as well known as Rockefeller or Getty, the family is believed to be the nation's wealthiest.
Investors in Wal-Mart stock also enjoyed a bounty. From 1981 to 1991, the company's shares produced an astounding average yearly return of 46.8 percent, including dividends and increases in the share price. A $3,000 investment in Wal-Mart stock in January 1981 was worth $105,600 in January 1991, the company calculated. By last week, it would have been worth $170,000.
 
High Volume, Low Prices
 Wal-Mart's rapid growth, built on high sales volume and low prices, brought financial ruin to hundreds of small-town merchants on Main Streets across the South and Midwest. And as Wal-Mart's reputation grew, Mr. Walton often faced bitter resistance in communities where he planned to open stores. Yet, his promises to attract shoppers, assist charities and provide jobs almost always prevailed.
Mr. Walton always worked hard at shaping his work force, using cheers, rap songs and payment policies to urge employees to be frugal in their jobs and friendly toward customers. Bonuses were paid to all employees in stores where stealing and other inventory losses were kept below 2 percent of sales. Scholarships were established at colleges in names of employees who crafted better ways to handle merchandise.
Mr. Walton set the tone, often beginning his mornings at 4:30 and working long days from a cramped, spartan office in Bentonville, in northwestern Arkansas.
"This is a man who was at work at 4:30 in the morning, had warmth and charm throughout the day, an interest in his customers, and who treated his associates well as persons, not just as clerks and salespeople," said Walter F. Loeb, a retailing consultant who first met Mr. Walton in 1976. Mr. Walton always referred to Wal-Mart employees as his associates.
 
Born in Oklahoma, Raised in Missouri
 Samuel Moore Walton was born in Kingfisher, Okla., on March 29, 1918, the first child of a rural banker, Thomas Walton, and Nancy Lee Walton. An Eagle Scout, quarterback of the state champion football team and student council president, Mr. Walton was voted "most versatile boy" by his graduating classmates at Hickman High School in Columbia, Mo., in 1936.
Working his way through the University of Missouri at Columbia, he delivered newspapers, waited on tables and clerked at a five-and-dime store while taking classes in the Army's Reserve Officer Training Corps and serving as president of the senior class and the honor society. After graduating in 1940 with a degree in economics, he worked briefly as a management trainee in Des Moines with the J. C. Penney Company, then a small-town retailer with 1,500 stores.
During World War II, Mr. Walton served as an Army captain, working in intelligence. In 1945, he acquired his first store, a Ben Franklin franchise in Newport, Ark., with a $25,000 loan from his father-in-law, Leland Stanford Robson, a small-town Oklahoma banker. By the early 1960's, Mr. Walton and his brother, James L. (Bud) Walton, owned 15 Ben Franklin franchises.
 
Striking Out on His Own
 In 1962, when Ben Franklin executives in Chicago turned down his plan to open bigger stores in rural areas, with discount prices and smaller profit margins, he began to form what eventually became Wal-Mart Stores.
In a 1989 interview with Financial World magazine, Mr. Walton said of his disagreement with Ben Franklin, "They didn't want to give on their end to the degree that it took for the prices to be as low as I felt they should be." Operating costs at Ben Franklin were as much as 25 percent of sales, but Mr. Walton thought they could be much lower.
He said: "If they had been able to sell to me on a 12 percent range, I probably would not have put together the organization that we did. Aren't I glad they didn't accept the idea, because I was forced to build our own team and program?"
 
One Temporary Retirement
 Mr. Walton remained the chairman of Wal-Mart until his death. He relinquished the titles of president and chief executive in 1988. He retired briefly from the chief executive's post in 1974 but reclaimed it two years later.
Last month, he was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor, and hailed as "an American original" who "embodies the entrepreneurial spirit and epitomizes the American dream."
Rejecting occasional advice to sell part of his family's shares and spread his investments, Mr. Walton kept 39 percent of Wal-Mart's common stock under family control in five trusts he established in 1954. Since it became a public company, Wal-Mart has issued more than 1.1 billion shares of common stock.
The five Walton trusts hold Wal-Mart stock collectively valued at $23 billion, about $4.6 billion apiece, at current market value. Annual dividends on the family stock amount to $93.5 million.
 
Hated Distinction As Wealthiest
 In 1985, Forbes magazine declared Mr. Walton the wealthiest person in America, a distinction Mr. Walton often said he hated. "All that hullabaloo about somebody's net worth is just stupid, and it's made my life a lot more complex and difficult," he told Fortune magazine. Although he disliked doing it, he autographed dollar bills for customers and employees and smiled for their cameras.
Mr. Walton displayed scant interest in the social whirl of the fashionably rich. And on business trips that often included visits to six Wal-Mart stores in a day, he rented subcompact cars and spent nights at budget motels, or in the homes of store managers. He was notoriously absent-minded. Driving once, he was distracted by counting cars in a competing store's parking lot and rammed into the rear of a Wal-Mart tractor trailer. No one was hurt.
And Mr. Walton had his business failures. Wal-Mart's ventures into selling discount drugs, do-it-yourself building supplies and arts-and-craft supplies were all abandoned after mixed results. His huge Hypermart stores, which have sold groceries along with Wal-Mart's traditional fare since 1988 under a roof that could cover five football fields, have apparently proved too large to manage. The company is trying a similar formula in scaled-down stores called Supercenters.
On occasion, Mr. Walton sparred with labor unions that tried unsuccessfully to organize clerks in his stores or drivers in his vast trucking fleet. But he mostly avoided labor clashes by placing stores and distribution centers away from cities where unions were powerful.
He also installed profit-sharing plans that enabled hundreds of workers with low wages to retire with comfortable, and occasionally lucrative, pensions because of the rising price of Wal-Mart stock. A cashier who retired in 1989 with $262,000 in retirement benefits, Shirley Cox, earned $7.10 an hour on her last day of work after 24 years with the company, said Vance H. Trimble, author of an unauthorized biography of Mr. Walton published by Dutton in 1990.
Mr. Walton was an avid hunter, particularly of quail, and a frequent patron of local restaurants in Bentonville. He was an active worshiper at the First Presbyterian Church, where he once taught Sunday school. In recent years he drove a red 1985 Ford pickup. Bentonville, which now has a population of 10,825, named the local junior high school after him in 1983 and the local day-care center for his wife, Helen Robson Walton.
Mrs. Walton, 72, controls the trust she shared with Mr. Walton. The other four trusts are controlled by the Waltons' four children: S. Robson, 47, one of three Wal-Mart vice chairmen; John T., 45, owner of a boat-making business in San Diego; James C., 43, president of Walton Enterprises, which includes family-controlled newspapers, banks and other businesses and charitable activities, and Alice, 42, who heads a private investment firm, the Llama Company, in Fayetteville, Ark.
Mr. Walton's brother, James, 70, owns more than 20 million shares and is a senior vice president and director of Wal-Mart. Mr. Walton is also survived by 10 grandchildren.
 
Ideas That Built The No. 1 Retailer
 One of Wal-Mart's biggest strengths was the streamlined, sophisticated logistics it created for replenishing products as its universe of stores expanded, management advisers at the Boston Consulting Group said.
In the early years, Mr. Walton insisted on building stores no more than a day's drive from distribution centers. Now, Wal-Mart fills merchandise orders within two days, compared with an average of two weeks among its rivals.
The company has 19 cavernous distribution centers, with an average of six miles of rack space in each; nearly 2,000 trucks; a satellite video system for relaying sales trends to executives, buyers, store managers and clerks, and a fleet of aircraft -- purchased secondhand -- to ferry managers across the Wal-Mart system.
Eighty-five percent of the merchandise Wal-Mart sells is shipped from its distribution centers, compared with 50 percent at its biggest competitor in discounting, Kmart, which relies on suppliers to ship the rest of its merchandise.
 
Upsetting Conventional Wisdom
 In the March-April 1992 issue of The Harvard Business Review, three officers at Boston Consulting -- George Stalk, Philip Evans and Lawrence E. Shulman -- said Mr. Walton had turned on its ear the conventional retailing approach of having senior executives make purchasing and stocking decisions.
"Instead of the retailer pushing products into the system, customers 'pull' products when and where they need them," they wrote. "The job of senior management at Wal-Mart, then, is not to tell individual store managers what to do but to create an environment where they can learn from the market -- and from each other."
Some executives at the company and consultants said Mr. Walton was a fair-minded leader, but hard-driving and demanding. "He was a man who extracted and expected a great deal from others because he himself always gave 100 percent," said Kurt Barnard, an industry consultant.
 
Unauthorized Biography
 Mr. Trimble wrote that Ron Loveless, former head of the company's wholesale-club division, retired in 1986 at age 42 partly because of job stress.
"If you don't produce, you'll be gone," Mr. Loveless, who did not talk to Mr. Trimble, told The Arkansas Gazette in 1986. David D. Glass, who succeeded Mr. Walton as chief executive in 1988, suffered a heart attack a year after being promoted to president in 1984.
With the economy in recession during 1991, Wal-Mart continued to flex its muscle. Although Mr. Walton was slowed by cancer treatments, he continued piloting himself, often alone, in a twin-engine Cessna to visit dozens of stores each week as he pursued plans to push Wal-Mart's yearly sales beyond $100 billion by the turn of the century.
The company opened more than 150 new and mostly bigger stores, expanded into Northeastern states and accelerated openings of its wholesale subsidiary, known as Sam's Clubs, which in 1991 increased sales by 43 percent, to more than $9 billion. Over all, Wal-Mart's sales rose 35 percent last year, to $43.9 billion, and profits jumped by 24.8 percent, to $1.6 billion.
 
Delighted Crowds As a Showman
 Mr. Walton's enthusiasm knew few bounds. In 1983, after Wal-Mart's profits exceeded expectations, he kept a promise to employees and donned a grass skirt to dance a hula on Wall Street.
At the Wal-Mart annual stockholders' meeting each spring, the charismatic Mr. Walton played barker, preacher, cheerleader and company visionary to ever-larger crowds. On June 7, 1991, more than 10,000 people filled the basketball arena at the University of Arkansas, 30 miles south of Bentonville, for what was Mr. Walton's last performance in a role that began that day at 7 A.M. and continued until noon.
"A lot of believers are here today," he shouted to an approving roar from the crowd of stockholders, executives of Wal-Mart suppliers, and more than 2,000 employees who had traveled to Fayetteville at company expense from stores across the country. Later that day, Sam and Helen Walton held their annual barbecue for the employees on the lawn of the 5,500-square-foot house they built in Bentonville and lived in since 1959.
 
The Spirit of Prosperity
 Mr. Walton orchestrated the annual meeting to underscore his managerial doctrine that the close links among suppliers, shareholders and employees determined Wal-Mart's prosperity.
During the meeting, Mr. Walton urged each of these three constituent groups to stand separately as applause filled the arena. Then he called on employees who served in the military during the Persian Gulf conflict to stand. "Good God, let's get the lights on them," he commanded. Among Wal-Mart's 380,000 employees at the time, 582 reservists and members of the National Guard were activated for the fighting.
A Wal-Mart executive announced that 80,000 jobs had been created in the United States by Wal-Mart merchandise orders since Mr. Walton's "Buy America" campaign began in 1985. The reigning Miss U.S.A., Kelli McCarty, the daughter of a Wal-Mart manager, smiled, posed and exchanged a "high five" with Mr. Walton. Paul Harvey, the radio commentator whose sponsors included Wal-Mart, proclaimed on stage that the Wal-Mart way was "something better than capitalism: enlightened consumerism." Then the entertainer Lee Greenwood sang "God Bless the U.S.A."
 
'High Expectations Are the Key'
 "There is nothing like it in the annals of retailing," Mr. Walton shouted as the spectacle unfolded. "High expectations are the key to everything." When Mr. Glass announced that the value of all Wal-Mart shares had increased to $45 billion from $150 million in 1976, Mr. Walton interrupted him.
"And it's only just begun," he declared. "Do you believe it? Let me hear you say it!" And a chant immediately filled the hot auditorium: "And it's only just begun."
Industry analysts say Mr. Walton gained the edge in sales over other retailers by taking risks, adopting approaches that worked for competitors and getting the most from his employees. In 1988, for instance, Wal-Mart averaged $103,000 in sales for each employee, while Kmart averaged $82,000.
In the 1989 interview with Financial World, which named him chief executive of the decade, Mr. Walton said: "I probably have traveled and walked into more variety stores than anybody in America. I am just trying to get ideas, any kind of ideas that will help our company. Most of us don't invent ideas. We take the best ideas from someone else."
The family has planned a private funeral in Bentonville.

HEADLINE: Iran Strafes Rebels in Iraq; Jet Downed

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Iranian jets bombed an Iranian rebel base in Iraq today in the most serious attack by Iran since a cease-fire ended fighting between the two countries in 1988.
Iraq said that its artillery had shot down one of eight Iranian F-4 Phantom fighter-bombers and that the pilot and navigator had been captured. A senior Pentagon official monitoring intelligence reports confirmed the Iranian attack and the loss of one plane, but could not confirm any other details. 
 The official Iranian press agency said the raid was in response to an attack on Saturday by guerrillas of the People's Mujahedeen, an Iranian rebel group, on two Kurdish settlements in Iran where "several people were killed, injured and kidnapped."
 
Conflict With Hard-Liners
 Iraq's state-operated Baghdad radio immediately denounced the raid, and Iranian rebel leaders in Iraq accused President Hashemi Rafsanjani of trying to whip up public support before Iranian elections on Friday.
Mr. Rafsanjani is seeking to oust fundamentalists in Parliament who oppose his efforts to open the country to the West and institute a free-market economy.
A Pentagon spokesman, Lieut. Col. Kerry Gershaneck of the Marines, said there were no indications that Iraq had ordered aircraft to intercept the Iranian fighter jets. Under terms of the cease-fire imposed by the American-led allies after Iraq's defeat in the Persian Gulf war last year, Baghdad may not fly its fixed-wing aircraft.
Although much of its military was destroyed in the gulf war, Iraq still has surface-to-air missiles and formidable batteries of anti-aircraft guns.
 
Journalists Get a Tour
 The rebels said the attack had killed a technician and wounded several others when the jets fired rockets and showered cluster bombs on the Ashraf base, 50 miles inside Iraq and 40 miles north of Baghdad, The Associated Press reported.
Iraqi and rebel anti-aircraft gunners both said they had downed the F-4, which crashed in an irrigation channel nine miles from the base. The rebels showed foreign journalists bomb damage at Ashraf and the still-burning wreckage of the F-4 Phantom, its wings perforated by bullets, Reuters reported.
The air strike was the first significant clash involving the two countries since April 1991, when Iran's Revolutionary Guards crossed the border during the Shiite and Kurdish rebellions after the Persian Gulf war and fought Iraqi troops and Iranian rebels.
In retaliation for the air raid, exiled opponents of the Iranian Government invaded Iranian diplomatic missions in New York, Ottawa and seven nations of Western Europe today, seizing hostages and wrecking offices in apparently coordinated attacks.
Iran and Iraq have never formally ended their eight-year war, which left an estimated one million people dead, and have engaged in an increasingly strident propaganda war. Teheran has accused President Saddam Hussein of Iraq of backing the Iranian rebels, while Baghdad has criticized Iran for supporting Shiite Muslim and Kurdish insurgencies in Iraq.
Baghdad radio today warned of the "serious consequences" of the raid, and the Iraqi News Agency said Mr. Hussein met with his senior military commanders after the air strike.
But an Iranian military official who requested anonymity said Iran "had succeeded in showing its enemies" that no target was out of reach. "Baghdad is not so far," said the official. "The army may once in a while be put in a position where it has to show its teeth."
The Iranians have about 60 American-made F-4 fighter-bombers, according to the International Institute of Strategic Studies, but only about 20 are believed to be in working order. The rest have been grounded because of a lack of spare parts, which the United States cut off in 1979.
Iranian officials have frequently stated their desire to see Mr. Hussein replaced by a "democratically elected government." This policy, they say, legitimizes Iran's financial and logistical support for the Shiites and for the new Islamic Party of Kurdistan, which has an office in Teheran.

HEADLINE: March Reflects the Growing Political Clout of a Movement

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The march on Washington yesterday reflected how much the political world has changed since the Supreme Court began restricting abortion rights. It is a change that many political professionals refer to simply as, "Post-Webster."
The 1989 Supreme Court decision in Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, which gave states new latitude to restrict abortion, reopened the political struggle over the issue. The opponents of legalized abortion were organized and active in politics for many years. "Post-Webster," the supporters of abortion rights began to mobilize and join their opposition on the field, no longer counting on the courts to protect their cause.
 
A Political Message
 Yesterday's march, its organizers hoped, was a powerful show of strength for the abortion-rights movement as the nation heads into the 1992 elections. "There is a message, and it's a political one," said Kate Michelman, the head of the National Abortion Rights Action League. "We're not talking to the Court; we don't trust the Court. We're talking to George Bush and every officeholder and every office seeker." 
 The abortion rights movement scored some early electoral victories in 1989, notably in the Virginia and New Jersey gubernatorial races, but the issue was overshadowed by the crisis in the Persian Gulf and the sagging economy in 1990 and 1991. Still, candidates increasingly see support for abortion rights as a net political plus; it was noteworthy that both Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California found time to march in Washington yesterday, two days before the New York primary.
Moreover, several factors could highlight the abortion issue in the 1992 Presidential campaign. The Supreme Court is expected to rule this summer on a case from Pennsylvania that could be a vehicle for overturning or severely curtailing Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that recognized a constitutional right to abortion. At the same time, many Republicans who support abortion rights are hoping to push for a change in their party's fiercely anti-abortion platform at the party's national convention in Houston.
 
Debate Also in State Races
 President Bush remains adamantly anti-abortion, and many political professionals do not expect him to change; he already shifted his stance once on the issue in the early 1980's, when he adopted a more hard-line position. Thus, it is likely voters will be offered a clear partisan difference on the issue this fall, since the Democrats are virtually certain to produce a nominee who supports abortion rights.
Abortion-rights supporters will also be paying close attention to Congress, since they are pushing for a bill they call the Freedom of Choice Act, legislation that would codify a Federal right to choose abortion. And since the battle over abortion law is increasingly waged in the states, the issue is likely to be joined in numerous legislative and gubernatorial races as well.
In such a climate, where both sides are struggling to show that they represent the true majority on the issue, muscle-flexing counts. This explains the emphasis on marches such as yesterday's. And it explains the euphoria among abortion-rights supporters over the turnout. "This was an extraordinarily important political statement today," Ms. Michelman said, "And the politicians better be listening."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Uneasy New York -- Assessment;
Fiery Primary Could Propel Clinton Toward the Nomination, or Burn Him

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Almost no one expected this to be an ordinary election year. There was too much anger in the public opinion polls, too much cynicism toward the Government, too much discontent with the way things are. Now, on the eve of the New York primary, the Democrats are taking the full measure of the rough, conflicted and unpredictable politics of 1992.
The unrest can be heard in the voices of New Yorkers who talk in the same breath of their disgust with the politicians and their yearning for a brokered convention, in which politicians would negotiate to choose a nominee. It is there in the re-emergence of a Jesse Jackson, an Edmund G. Brown Jr. and a Patrick J. Caddell, impresarios of discontent sensing the energies of the time. 
 It is there in Paul E. Tsongas's dance on the sidelines, and in the yearnings among some Democrats for a white knight, although few can agree on just who that knight would be. And it is there, most of all, in Gov. Bill Clinton's strange political journey, which seems destined on some days for the nomination and on other days for disaster. The next phase of his journey will be decided, tomorrow, by the voters of New York.
 
Volatile Chemistry
 In a debate yesterday on WNBC-TV, Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, and Mr. Brown, the former Governor of California, squared off on a set of issues that have produced much of the volatile chemistry of this race. Mr. Clinton, reaching for the economic populism that served him well in other parts of the country, hammered Mr. Brown for his support of a flat tax to replace the progressive income tax, asserting that it would aid the rich, hurt the poor and imperil the Social Security system.
Mr. Brown pressed his attack on Mr. Clinton as a tribune of the status quo and a political system that is inherently corrupt. The animosity of the past two weeks was on full display. "How dare you call me the prince of sleaze?" Mr. Clinton demanded at one point.
The debate highlighted, as well, the racial and ethnic land mines of this primary campaign, as Mr. Brown defended his preference for the Rev. Jesse Jackson as a running mate. That position has generated considerable criticism in recent days from Jewish leaders, who recall Mr. Jackson's 1984 characterization of the city as "Hymietown."
"I was up in Harlem yesterday, and I saw the faces of despair," said Mr. Brown, who is competing vigorously with Mr. Clinton for the black voters of New York. "I see the Rev. Jackson as a powerful, inspirational leader that could bring some of these people back who are so alienated."
Mr. Clinton was also forced once again to deal with questions about his draft status during the Vietnam War following the revelation that he received a draft notice in 1969. He did not serve in the military.
 
Turning a Corner?
 Clinton campaign officials, who seemed profoundly rattled 10 days ago as they landed in New York after their loss in Connecticut, are now projecting an air of guarded optimism. "It turned a corner earlier in the week, and each poll is looking up, " said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker, who declined to furnish details of the campaign's nightly tracking. "I think we created some momentum and it's continuing."
Though New York is not the only state with a primary tomorrow -- Kansas and Wisconsin will also vote -- this state will largely determine Mr. Clinton's fate. If he wins here, he will be back on course to the nomination, which many Democratic leaders thought he had virtually wrapped up after he defeated Mr. Tsongas in Michigan and Illinois.
He will still face considerable jitters from Democratic officeholders and political professionals, so long as the polls show that much of the electorate has doubts and reservations about his character. Anxieties are particularly high on Capitol Hill, where incumbent Democrats are perennially worried about a drag from their Presidential ticket and where they now, in addition, fear the wrath of an anti-incumbent year. But the steady accretion of delegates and primary victories would make Mr. Clinton hard to stop, many Democrats agree.
Ahead lie the Virginia caucuses on April 11-13, followed by the Pennsylvania primary on April 28. The results in New York, many Democrats say, will be the biggest factor in the Pennsylvania campaign, although James Carville, the Clinton strategist, said, "I know enough about Pennsylvania to know you can't go in there and presume anything."
Mr. Carville has run three previous statewide campaigns in Pennsylvania, two for Gov. Robert P. Casey and one for Senator Harris Wofford, who scored an upset victory over former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh last year.
If Mr. Clinton loses in New York, it will almost certainly reopen the talk of other candidates entering the race and the possibility of a brokered convention. "His loss would create a vacuum," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. "It's not obvious that someone will step into the vacuum, but Clinton would lose a lot of control at that stage."
Mr. Tsongas continues to flirt with a re-entry. He said yesterday on the ABC News program "This Week" that he would make his decision on the basis of New York's results, and would have announcement on Wednesday. Still, one senior Democratic strategist, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said dryly, "He did a lot of losing, and people noticed it."
Many voters seem open to brand new candidacies; two-thirds of the likely Democratic primary voters in last week's national New York Times/CBS News Poll said they wished they had other candidates from which to choose. But the realpolitik of producing those new options, many Democrats worry, would be far less appealing.
 
Brokered Convention
 A new candidate entering the race after New York would have two days to get on the ballot in New Jersey; the filing deadline there is 4 P.M. Thursday. But the candidate would not be able to make the ballot in California, where the deadline passed last Saturday, and where by midweek counties will begin printing millions of ballots, according to the Secretary of State's office in Sacramento. The filing deadlines have passed for every other primary, according to the Democratic National Committee.
This means, Democrats say, that a new candidate would essentially have to be the creation of a brokered convention. Ordinarily, a candidate emerges from the primary season with a nominating majority, or close to it. The last time a candidate required more than one convention ballot to win the nomination was 1952, when Adlai E. Stevenson prevailed on the third ballot.
The party's 772 superdelegates -- composed of party officials, members of Congress and other elected officials -- would play a key role in this. Herein lies the concern of many Democrats about this process in a year when anger at political insiders is running high. One Democrat on Capitol Hill said, "People knew darn well that the last thing people would stand for was a bunch of Congressional superdelegates saying, 'Here's your nominee.' "
Phil Angelides, the Democratic chairman in California, said, "It would take a very compelling set of circumstances and a very compelling personality and a very compelling moment to produce a nominee out of a brokered convention" without "ever having been subjected to the voters' judgment or the level of scrutiny to which any other nominee has been subjected."
Clinton campaign officials brush aside all this talk. They cling to the hope that New York will render such questions moot, although they try not to project the front-runner's arrogance that can prove dangerous in this political climate. It has been, after all, that kind of year.
