HEADLINE: In British Campaign, Too, Many Voters Ask: Why Don't Things Get Better?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 5

 BODY:
Mired in the second severe recession in nearly 13 years of Government by Prime Minister John Major's Conservatives, British voters seem to be in a mood to teach them a lesson in the general election on Thursday.
With the opposition Labor Party two to six points ahead of the Conservatives in the latest polls, the only question seems to be how many of the 368 seats that they now hold the Conservatives are going to lose to Labor or to the smaller Liberal Democrats. 
 Both Mr. Major and Labor's leader, Neil Kinnock, pronounced themselves certain of victory in television and radio interviews today.
 
One 'Confident,' One 'Certain'
 "I am confident we will secure a majority," Mr. Kinnock said on BBC radio, promising once again that if Labor wins, "We won't spend more than we can afford," as the Conservatives charge Labor will do.
After polls earlier last week showed Labor surging into the lead, British stock prices and the value of the pound went reeling. The Times of London reported on Saturday that some senior executives were taking bonus payments and salaries in advance or in gold to avoid the higher taxes that they will face if Labor wins.
Mr. Major also tried to reassure his supporters, saying on BBC television today, "I'm absolutely certain we are going to win, and with a sure overall majority." Once again, he denied Labor's charges that the Government had starved public services to cut taxes for the better-off.
But after months of invective about the past failures of both parties, squabbles about tax figures, polls -- and even polls of polls, the electorate seems fed up, not only with the Government but with politicians in general.
"You're the best of a bad lot," Gertrude L. Wills, a shopper in Highgate, told a Conservative canvasser there last week. But watching Mr. Major gladhanding visitors at a home-furnishings exhibition in Earls Court last Thursday, Eva Adnett, a 71-year-old pensioner from Uxbridge, said, "I've voted Conservative all my life, but I'll be voting Labor this time. They're going to increase pension benefits, and I'm going to be looking after myself."
Surveys say the voters are so fragmented and unconvinced about the ability of either Labor or the Conservatives to lead the country out of its problems that no party might win the 326 seats needed for an overall majority in the new 651-member House of Commons. If this happens, there could be months of weak government and instability, with another election almost surely following by autumn, as it did the last time there was a "hung Parliament," in 1974.
As in the United States, foreign policy has hardly been an issue here.
 
Differing Only on Taxes
 Labor's past policy of unilateral nuclear disarmament does not seem to bother the people much, now that the cold war is over. Mr. Kinnock acknowledges, as he did in a television interview Thursday night, that Labor's past opposition to nuclear weapons and to British membership in the European Community may have been "an error of judgment," saying he and his party have moved on to more pragmatic attitudes.
Not even European economic and political unification has played a role, though that was the issue that brought down Mr. Major's predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, in November 1990 after she rejected the idea of a federal Europe with a single central bank and a single currency supplanting the pound.
The fact is that there is not a great deal of difference between the two main parties on most issues anymore, except on how much tax the top earners should pay.
Asked on Friday afternoon what his vision of Europe was, for example, Mr. Kinnock sounded almost Thatcherite. "The interests of Europe and of individual countries within it would not be served best by the development of any form of the United States of Europe," he said.
Rather, Mr. Major has taken a beating during this campaign mostly on popular dissatisfaction with the Conservative domestic economic policies that Mrs. Thatcher stood for so vividly.
 
Are the Rich Getting Richer?
 The "poll tax," a per-capita charge for local government services that she introduced in 1988 and 1989, aroused the most dissatisfaction, since rich and poor paid the same amount and payments soared. Mr. Major abandoned the poll tax last year for a system based partly on property values and partly on income, but it will not go into effect until next April if he wins.
"It went wrong in practice," Mr. Major acknowledged today, but he has refused to say the Tories are sorry they introduced it.
Many British voters seem to feel that the rich got richer while public services were left to deteriorate, and that it is time for a shift back from private benefit toward the common weal.
But despite reservations about the Government's performance over the past 13 years, many Conservative voters who now say they will vote for the Liberal Democrats may not do so.
 
Then, There's the 3d Party
 The Liberal Democrats' leader, Paddy Ashdown, has offered to form a coalition Government with either of the other two parties if there is no majority on April 9, but only if the coalition party agrees to support a change in the electoral system to proportional representation. This would give his party, reorganized and renamed in 1988, many more than the 22 seats it won in the last elections, when it had nearly 23 percent of the vote. The Liberal Democrats' stand to win nearly as many votes this year, according to the polls.
Mr. Major has ruled out any change. "There are no circumstances in which I will introduce proportional representation," he said Thursday. Mr. Kinnock has promised only a study of the question, but his party supports proportional voting for the Scottish Parliament that it proposes for local affairs.
The voting system and Scotland's status are both huge constitutional issues. The Scottish National Party is campaigning for secession of Scotland and separate membership in the European Community, an idea derided by both Mr. Major and Mr. Kinnock, whose party now holds most of the Scottish seats in the House of Commons.
Again and again, the 49-year-old Mr. Major and his team have warned against bringing back the chaotic era between 1974 and 1979 when Labor was last in power and strikes by militant unions paralyzed the economy. But that was so long ago that younger voters cannot even dimly remember what it was like.
The Conservatives also tried to scare voters into believing that Labor would dismantle British defenses, a fear that made the party unelectable, in Mr. Kinnock's own words, in the last national vote five years ago. But now, with the cold war over and the Soviet Union a thing of the past, few voters seem to care.
What they do care about, according to all the surveys, are education, the National Health Service and public transport: they seem to think that all three have been allowed to deteriorate because of the Tory philosophy of the less government spending the better.
Thus many voters are undeterred by the tax consequences of Labor's promise to bring about a modest redistribution of wealth, from rich to poor and from private to public hands. Labor has pledged to increase taxes on the top 15 percent of earners (over 21,060, or $36,225, a year), to a maximum marginal rate of 59 percent on incomes over 40,000 ($68,800), but Mr. Kinnock repeated today that there would be no further increases if he won.
 
The Challenger
 Asked a couple of days ago about his fitness to be Prime Minister, Mr. Kinnock, wearing an unproleterian double-breasted dark suit, was perhaps too aggressive in replying: "Apart from a slight cough," he said at a news conference, "it is damn-near perfect." Such cockiness could backfire. And, according to Robert M. Worcester, chairman of the MORI polling organization, Labor's strong showing in opinion surveys could give some voters second thoughts about switching from the Conservatives when they get to the polling booths on Thursday.
But Mr. Kinnock has lost the defensiveness that the party's leader, the son of a Welsh coal miner, showed during a visit to the United States in March 1987, just before his last try at unseating Mrs. Thatcher.
Then, he went to Washington to try to persuade President Ronald Reagan that Labor's policy of unilateral nuclear disarmament would not harm NATO. The White House answered with a blast, saying Labor's position would undermine United States negotiations with the Soviet Union.
Now, asked about his relationship with the United States, Mr. Kinnock says, simply, "It's fine."
But he makes little secret of the fact that he would be delighted if a Democrat defeated President Bush in November. The last time British and American national elections were held in the same year was 1964, when both the Democrats and Labor won.

HEADLINE: At Caterpillar, the Deadline Is Now

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 5

 BODY:
The na tion's most bitter labor dispute between Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest manufacturer of construction equipment, and the United Automobile Workers, one of the country's strongest unions -- reaches a crossroads at 7:30 A.M. Monday, the deadline the company has set for the 12,600 striking workers to either return to work or be permanently replaced.
What the workers decide, after more than five months on strike, is certain to have a profound impact on the future of the U.A.W., which has 900,000 members, and the host of companies for whom its members work. 
 Estimates here on how many Caterpillar workers will return to work run from 10 percent to 20 percent, not enough to break the strike, perhaps, but sufficient to put a noticeable dent in union solidarity. Feelings run high, and union officials have been publicly appealing to their members to abstain from violence.
Both the union and Caterpillar, which is based here and is the largest private employer in Illinois, have been taking a hard line over wages and health benefits, among other issues. While other companies in recent years have hired non-union replacements for strikers -- Greyhound, Eastern Airlines, Phelps-Dodge -- no company has ever tried to oust a union as powerful as the U.A.W.
The average age of the strikers at Caterpillar is 44 years, with an average job tenure of 22.5 years. And most of these workers have teen-age or college-age children. If they forfeit their jobs, these men and women realize there are few other places in this recession-ravaged Midwest where they can earn annual salaries that average $35,000. So the choice of walking or crossing the picket line Monday morning is deeply troublesome.
"This is the hardest decision I've had to make," said Alvin C. Oglesby, a 46-year-old quality-control tester who has worked at Caterpillar for 19 years. "I had back surgery two years ago and who else is going to have me? I have a son in the Marines and a daughter who is a senior in high school. This puts a big question mark on the issue of whether she can go to college."
For the moment, Mr. Oglesby said, he has decided not to go back to Caterpillar Monday morning. "But a month from now, I may feel differently," he said.
Richard L. Thomas, a 40-year-old laborer who has worked for Caterpillar for 19 years, said he had five children and two grandchildren but would not return to the plant because the issue was more important than money.
"They are showing us that they have no respect for the union worker," Mr. Thomas said of Caterpillar. "They talk about being the giant international company. Well, we are the ones who helped make them all of that. And we deserve to have a package that shows that they respect us."
Holding the line on wages and benefits, the company said, is critical to Caterpillar's ability to compete globally. Exports account for a full 59 percent of the company's production, making it second in that category only to the Boeing Company amongthe nation's industrial exporters.
"We had $3.7 billion in exports last year, and we have 19,500 of our jobs that are depending on our ability to export," said Gerald S. Flaherty, a group president at Caterpillar. "We are very dependent on our ability to be competitive on a worldwide basis."
Sean P. McAlinden, an automotive economist at the University of Michigan, observed: "This issue will have enormous consequences for the company, for the union and beyond. The U.A.W. cannot afford to be broken in this matter, because the auto companies are watching closely and they will take their cues from this. And the union realizes that General Motors is watching and may attempt the same thing next."
 
'Pattern Bargaining' May Fade
 A loss here by the union may also be a harbinger of the end of a practice known as pattern bargaining, in which unions use an agreement with one company as a model for other companies in the same industry. These arrangements, which were once common in several industries, including steel and tires, have begun to unravel in the last decade.
The Big Three domestic auto makers, which employ more than 400,000 U.A.W. members, are eager to tailor contracts based on their individual needs rather than in industrywide pattern. Success by Caterpillar would be likely to stiffen the auto makers' resolve.
The decision faced by the U.A.W. members at Caterpillar is made more difficult by the fact that many other workers -- unemployed and otherwise -- are waiting eagerly to seize their jobs.
The company and the state Labor Department's unemployment office say their phones have been ringing almost constantly since the company announced on Wednesday that it would hire replacement workers. The company says that it will begin hiring these new workers on Monday, and that the process of filling all the positions may take several weeks.
 
The Terms on the Table
 Caterpillar has maintained that its contract offer will raise wages by about 13 percent over three years and will cover workers' health care in full if they use specified hospitals and doctors.
But the union says that the company's proposed contract would cause union members to lose some benefits in health care and that the company can afford to be more generous in its labor payouts, which it says account for only a sixth of Caterpillar's costs. The union has also sought to gain a wage and benefits package that calls for gains similar to those reached last year by workers at Deere & Company.
The Deere contract requires the company to fill any positions vacated by attrition with laid-off union members. It also requires that the union be consulted before the company decides to buy any parts or supplies rather than manufacture them itself. The Deere contract also provides more generous health-care benefits than are being offered by Caterpillar.
 
Caterpillar's Losses
 But Caterpillar argues that its product mix and its large export business place it in a competitive position far different from Deere's. It maintains that its labor costs should be compared with those of the international giants against which it competes, principally Komatsu Ltd. of Japan.
Caterpillar is in an arduous position, hard hit by the nation's economic slump. It lost $404 million last year after earning $210 million in 1990.
What is more, it may face the threat of a drop in exports because of the rise in the United States dollar, which could make Caterpillar's tractors, trucks and excavators less attractive to foreign buyers.
 
Assessing Caterpillar's Stategy
 Some industry analysts and labor consider Caterpillar's efforts to break the union to be a foolhardy waste of time and energy, and they say that by hiring replacement workers, the company risks eroding the confidence of its customers, who have always regarded Caterpillar's products as superior.
"I can't see how this strike and breaking this union is worth it to Caterpillar," said Mark E. Erenburg, director of the Labor-Management Relations Center at Cleveland State University. "I really don't think that settling with the union is going to threaten their competitive position in the world."
On the other hand, some industry analysts say Caterpillar's posture makes perfect sense.
"Caterpillar has come up with a darn good offer, and the points of it that are at issue are points that should not matter much to an individual who is out of work and trying to take care of a family," said Alexander M. Blanton, an analyst with Ingalls & Snyder in New York.
 
The Union Perspective
 Union leaders see the matter differently. "This is of vital importance to our union," said Jerry Baker, who heads the bargaining team for Local 974 of the union, which represents about 9,000 workers at seven Caterpillar plants in the Peoria area. He said the union must remain firm in order to dissuade companies in the auto industry and elsewhere from taking a position similar to Caterpillar's.
"If we hold the line, Caterpillar will realize that they have to negotiate with us," Mr. Baker said. "They will have to come back to the table."
But not everyone thinks the Caterpillar strike will have far-reaching implications. "Every strike stands on its own," said Douglas A. Fraser, a former president of the U.A.W. who is now a professor at Wayne State University in Detroit. "Some say it will encourage union busting by the Big Three auto companies in 1993, but that's nonsense."
Nonetheless, Mr. Fraser said, the Caterpillar move follows a pattern of union breaking that goes back a decade, to President Reagan's replacement of striking air traffic controllers.
Many union members lament that they are being forced into the present quandary. "It's a shame that we're under such pressure," said Jack Emmons, a machine operator who has worked at Caterpillar for 20 years. "It's a hard decision to make, but I'm going to stick by the union. We can't back down now."

HEADLINE: Florida Expected to Ban Referrals by Doctors to Clinics They Own

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Over vigorous objections of many physicians, the Governor of Florida is expected to sign a bill this week prohibiting doctors from referring patients to clinics in which the doctors have a financial interest.
The new restrictions, intended to curb conflicts of interest and control health costs, are likely to cause upheaval in the state's health-care industry, forcing at least 40 percent of the state's doctors to sell their interests in clinics or send their patients elsewhere. 
 In Florida, as in many other states, doctors' investments in laboratories, diagnostic imaging centers and clinics have proliferated in the last few years, for a variety of economic and medical reasons. Doctors say they make such investments so new health-care technology will be readily available to their patients, and they argue that they can control the quality of care when they own the business.
Critics say doctors also have an economic incentive to refer patients to clinics in which they have a financial interest. Studies in Florida and other states have found that when doctors invest in laboratories, diagnostic imaging equipment, physical therapy centers and medical equipment supply companies, they tend to order those services more often for their patients, increasing outlays for health care. Such clinics often charge higher fees than similar businesses not owned by doctors, the studies have found.
 
Part of a National Trend
 The Florida bill is the latest in a flurry of measures aimed at putting an end to the practice. Many states, including New York, New Jersey and California, are considering or already impose similar restrictions.
For years, the American Medical Association defended such investments. But in December it adopted a new policy stating that, "in general, physicians should not refer patients" to health-care businesses in which the doctors have invested. The association did not specify penalties for violations.
But many doctors contend that such investments benefit patients by speeding access to costly new medical technology, which might otherwise be unavailable. "Physician investment in health-care facilities has a long tradition and has indisputably benefited patients in respect to access, cost and quality of care," said Dr. Robert Windom, a spokesman for the Florida Medical Association. The association opposed the bill as a form of "punitive legislation" and said the need for it had not been proved.
At least 40 percent of Florida doctors have invested in clinics and other health-care businesses, and 93 percent of the diagnostic imaging centers are owned by physicians, according to a study by a state agency, the Florida Health Care Cost Containment Board.
 
Governor Will Sign
 The Florida bill, which was approved by the Legislature last month, is to be signed in the next few days by Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat. The Governor's press secretary, Julie Anbender, said he viewed the bill as "a positive step to protect patients from paying for medical services that they may not need."
Under the Florida measure, doctors will be subject to a $15,000 fine if they send patients to a medical business in which they have invested. This ban applies to the ordering of laboratory services, X-rays, CAT scans, magnetic resonance imaging, physical therapy, rehabilitation services and radiation therapy.
The bill also sets limits on what doctors may charge patients for these services. The limits, calculated at 15 percent above rates established by Medicare for the same procedures, are often far below doctors' customary charges to patients with private health insurance. Medicare and Medicaid, the Federal programs for the elderly and the poor, regulate doctors' fees, but it is highly unusual for a state to adopt a fee schedule for doctors' services outside those programs.
Not all Florida physicians oppose the measure, primarily because the joint ventures enrich some doctors at the expense of others. For example, radiologists must depend on other doctors for referrals, and some say their business has dried up because doctors preferred to send patients to clinics where they could make a profit.
The American College of Radiology, a professional organization, contends that doctors "should not have a direct or indirect financial interest in diagnostic or therapeutic facilities to which they refer patients," and it supports legislation to ban such ownership arrangements.
 
'Good for Consumers'
 Dr. Michael B. Isikoff, a radiologist in Titusville, Fla., said the bill was "very, very good for consumers," and he predicted that the fee schedule would substantially reduce rates now charged by doctor-owned clinics.
Under the bill, doctors have until October 1995 to stop referring patients to clinics in which they have invested. But Dr. Isikoff said, "The fee schedule will decrease the profit in joint ventures, and that will drive many of them out of business before 1995."
The Florida bill was sponsored by State Representative Charlie Roberts, a Democrat, who said: "This is truly a nationwide trend. Physician joint ventures will cease to be attractive or economically feasible over the next few years. That will improve competition in the medical marketplace and will prevent the type of overutilization we have seen in every study of these investments."
 
Other States, Other Versions
 In California, doctors are resisting parts of a similar bill, which has been approved by the State Assembly and is pending before the State Senate.
In July, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey signed a bill that generally prohibits doctors from referring patients to health-care services in which the doctors have "a significant beneficial interest." But under the law, doctors may still send patients to clinics in which they invested before July 1991 if the doctors disclose their financial interest to the patient.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has also recommended legislation that would generally prohibit New York doctors from referring patients to services in which they have financial interest.
Legislators in Colorado, Hawaii, Kansas, Maryland, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee and Washington, among other states, have been working on legislation to restrict doctor referrals.
 
Federal Ban Coinsidered
 The Federal Government prohibits doctors from referring Medicare patients to laboratories in which the doctors have invested. But the Federal law, which took effect Jan. 1, does not apply to other medical services nor does it apply outside Medicare.
On Feb. 6, President Bush proposed measures to slow the growth of health costs and to assist people who have no health insurance. He endorsed the idea that Medicare should not pay when doctors send patients to get goods or services from businesses in which the doctors have invested.
Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, is trying to persuade his colleagues in Congress to impose such a ban.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans To Sell HomeFed

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 5

 BODY:
Federal regulators have decided to sell Home Fed Bank of San Diego, one of the nation's largest troubled savings and loan institutions, after determining that the company stands little chance of regaining its financial health.
Regulators said they were stopping short of formally seizing HomeFed from its parent, the HomeFed Corporation. But in a statement issued late on Friday, the company said the regulators would sell the institution, probably with Federal financial assistance, and that shareholders and bondholders would probably lose their entire investments, as they would if the institution were seized. 
 HomeFed's share price closed on Friday at 75 cents, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. The announcement of the sale came after the close of trading.
 
Potential Acquirers
 HomeFed has 201 branches in California and is particularly prominent in the San Diego area. Its branch network is likely to be highly attractive to other big savings and loan companies in the state. The company, which has assets of $13.9 billion, said it had already received expressions of interest from a number of potential acquirers, including some from outside the savings and loan industry.
Executives of HomeFed identified two potential bidders as Home Savings of America, a unit of H. F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles, and Great Western Bank, a subsidiary of the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif. The regulators could sell HomeFed as a whole or in pieces.
 
Reducing Bad Publicity
 In deciding to sell HomeFed, regulators placed the institution into what the Government calls the Accelerated Resolution Program. Under the program, the institution continues to be run by its current managers until a sale is completed. Operations will continue as normal, and Federal deposit insurance remains in place.
The program is intended to prevent troubled institutions from losing their value to possible buyers, by avoiding the stigma of a Government seizure and reducing the bad publicity that often leads to large withdrawals of deposits. HomeFed is the largest institution to be placed in the program.
The regulators' decision to sell HomeFed comes as operations of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout of the savings industry, have been slowed by a lack of financing. The House failed last week to pass legislation to continue financing for savings and loan bailouts.
The decision by the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision effectively ends a long-shot turnaround effort undertaken last year by the institution's chief executive, Thomas J. Wageman. Mr. Wageman, who was brought in to run the company at the behest of regulators, had been trying to persuade outside investors and the Government to put up more financing and let HomeFed earn its way out of its problems.
 
GlenFed and CalFed Ailing, Too
 But outside investors clearly remained wary of sinking money into HomeFed as the company's losses continued to grow on real estate loans and investments around the country. In Washington, regulators and Congress could not decide whether it would be good policy to invest taxpayer money into ailing savings institutions in the hopes of averting costly Government takeovers.
HomeFed is the most financially distressed of three large savings and loan companies in California that have been struggling to regain their financial health. The two others, GlenFed Inc. and CalFed Inc., face increasingly strict regulatory standards for financial health that could leave them short of capital this year, and they continue to be battered by weak real estate markets and the state's economic recession.
The decision to sell HomeFed came just three days after the company failed to meet a Government deadline to raise new capital on its own. On Tuesday, HomeFed reported a fourth-quarter loss of $35.6 million and a loss for all of 1991 of $807.7 million.

HEADLINE: Inquiries Are Growing on Payments to McDonnell Douglas

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
Congressional investigators and Pentagon auditors are stepping up inquiries into whether the military took actions in the last several years to bail out the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the nation's largest weapons maker, when the company faced a severe financial crisis.
The investigators said the evidence they had assembled suggested that the Pentagon was trying to provide financial aid to McDonnell Douglas without public debate or notification. The period they are studying encompasses the months immediately before the start of the war against Iraq, where McDonnell fighter planes, missiles and helicopters played an important role. 
 Investigators for two House subcomittees and the Pentagon's Inspector General are studying newly uncovered details of several cases where McDonnell Douglas, which is based in St. Louis, benefited from accelerated payments or other financial transactions that the investigators said were highly unusual.
McDonnell Douglas executives said they never requested a bailout or received any payments that were unusual or improper. They have said privately that much of the problem stems from confusion or disagreements within the Pentagon regarding the proper methods of paying contractors.
Top Pentagon officials have said repeatedly that they had no plan to bail out McDonnell Douglas and that the payments to the company fell within the bounds of complex Federal acquisition regulations.
McDonnell's financial condition has improved substantially in the last year, largely because of increased profits in its commercial aircraft business. But the Congressional investigators have been looking into the Pentagon's handling of McDonnell for the last year, and they said they see a pattern of financial concessions to the company that suggests the possibility of an effort by the military to aid the company just when it was facing a severe shortage of cash.
The conclusions of the Congressional investigators appear to be supported by a recent report from the office of the Pentagon's Inspector General. The report, which Government officials have provided to a number of news organizations in recent weeks, said payment decisions made by the Air Force in late 1990 on McDonnell Douglas's contract to develop the C-17 transport plane "appeared to be part of an overall plan to provide additional financing to McDonnell Douglas Corporation."
The Congressional investigators began studying the Pentagon's dealings with McDonnell last year, after the Pentagon decided not to demand immediate repayment from the company of $650 million the Government said it was owed from the cancellation of the Navy's A-12 bomber program. McDonnell has contended that it is owed money by the Government on the A-12 program, and that the dispute over the $650 million has not been decided.
The investigators, from subcommittees of the House Government Operations Committee, subsequently discovered that McDonnell Douglas requested expedited payment of $1 billion owed by the Pentagon early last year. McDonnell later withdrew the request as its finances improved.
The Congressional and Pentagon investigations, details of which have been reported over the last several weeks by The Los Angeles Times and other publications, are centering on the payments made on the C-17 program during the fall of 1990.
In one case, McDonnell received $148 million for work done under the development portion of the contract, even though the company had exhausted its Government budget for the work, after the Air Force agreed to finance the work out of the program's production budgets, the report and Congressional investigators said.
If the Air Force had not been willing to shift the cost of the work to the production budgets, the investigators said, McDonnell Douglas would have had to pay the costs itself, something it might have been unable to do given its shortage of cash at the time.
In a second case, the Air Force agreed to make an unusually large payment to McDonnell Douglas for work done on the C-17 immediately after being told by John F. McDonnell, its chairman and chief executive, that McDonnell Douglas had an "urgent and pressing financial need" that if not addressed could harm the company's ability to continue work on the C-17, the inspector general's report said. The payment amounted to $72.1 million more than McDonnell would otherwise have received, the report said.
 
Army Billing Dispute
 The Congressional investigators said the effect of the two actions was to give McDonnell Douglas immediate payments that it would otherwise have had to wait months or years for.
Pete Sloan, a McDonnell Douglas spokesman, said the company believed all the payments were proper and routine in both cases.
"We submitted bills in accordance with the extensive Federal regulations that cover billing, and we were paid," Mr. Sloan said.
Congressional investigators are also looking into a billing dispute over McDonnell's work on the Army's Apache helicopter that was settled in late 1990 in the company's favor. The Army had filed reimbursement claims against McDonnell for $50.3 million on the program. The claims were later cut to $20 million to $30 million, the investigators said, and subsequently settled for $2.4 million.
The settlement was made without the knowledge of the Pentagon's top auditors, the investigators said, adding that they were trying to determine whether the settlement was part of an effort to provide McDonnell with financial breaks.
Mr. Sloan said McDonnell Douglas felt the contract dispute was "settled on its merits." He said the suggestion that the Apache dispute and C-17 payments were somehow linked as part of a bailout plan was ludicrous.

HEADLINE: Fingerprints Used to Cut Welfare Fraud

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 5

 BODY:
When Matthew Dunlap walked into a Los Angeles County welfare office on Friday, he found that he had to give before he could get.
The price was an optical image of his fingerprints, which was sent to a central computer for matching against the fingerprints of everyone on the general welfare rolls. 
 Two minutes later, the word came back: Mr. Dunlap, 37 years old, had not applied for welfare at any other county office and his application could go forward. By the end of the day, he was approved to receive $341 a month until he finds work.
Los Angeles is the first county in the nation to install an automatic fingerprint-identification system for ferreting out welfare cheats. Since the program was put in place last July, officials say, the county has saved more than $5.4 million, primarily from people dropping out of the system because they refused to be fingerprinted.
"The fingerprint system prevents fraudulent duplicate claims and allows us to deliver services faster," said Eddy Tanaka, director of the Los Angeles County Department of Public Social Services.
 
Concerns Over Privacy
 But though county officials say they will not share the fingerprints with the police or any other government agency, the program has raised a host of questions about individual rights and government intrusion in an information age. And it has raised fears that honest people, particularly illegal immigrants, will be deterred from asking for welfare benefits because they are afraid they will be turned over to immigration officials or other authorities.
"I don't know if we've deterred honest people," Mr. Tanaka said. "But we do have the right to know that people are who they say they are."
Intrigued by Los Angeles County's program, the New York Legislature on Wednesday authorized an identical fingerprint-identification program, a pilot project, in Onondaga and Rockland Counties.
"We'll check for duplications on the home relief, welfare and Medicaid rolls," said Robert Penna, an aide to Senator Tarky Lombardi Jr. of Syracuse, the chairman of the State Senate Finance Committee. Mr. Penna estimated that New York taxpayers could save $72 million a year by deterring fraud if the program was expanded statewide.
 
Fraud a 'Cottage Industry'?
 He said fears about immigration authorities or other agencies were much less in New York than in California because of New York's relatively liberal welfare policies. While there are some illegal immigrants who may fear to apply, he said, in general "all you have to do is have a pulse and you qualify."
"Welfare fraud is a cottage industry in New York," Mr. Penna said. In November, police arrested 117 people in New York City for using false documents to illegally collect welfare, he said.
Fraud costs taxpayers more than $25 billion a year, said Thomas F. Wilson, vice president of Resource Management Laboratories Ltd. in Nevada City, Calif., a company that develops personal-identification systems. Passports, birth certificates, Social Security cards, drivers licenses and other documents are routinely counterfeited, he said.
The automated fingerprint system is attractive to state and county welfare officials who face a rising demand for services amid budget cuts in a severe recession. In New York City, one in six residents is on welfare, Mr. Penna said. In Los Angeles County, one in seven residents is on welfare, Mr. Tanaka said, and each month there are 18,000 new applicants for general relief.
"We've always known that some people cheat but not how many," Mr. Tanaka said. "It may be 1 to 2 percent of all applicants, or it could be higher."
 
An Immediate Change
 In 1990, he said, Los Angeles County decided to try to find out. It invited computer vendors to design a system that would take optical images of fingerprints, store them in a data base and rapidly compare a single set of prints against all those stored. The $9.6 million five-year contract was awarded to the E.D.S. Corporation of Herndon, Va., and the Cogent Matching Software Company of Sunnyvale, Calif.
The system was installed last June in three of 14 offices that dispense county money to indigent men and women, Mr. Tanaka said. "Almost immediately, the application rate at those three offices went down while the application rate at the other 11 offices went up," he said, "so we rushed to put the program into all offices quickly."
From July on, Mr. Tanaka said, each person on welfare was asked to come in and give his or her fingerprints. They put each index finger on an optical scanning device, which took an image of the print and stored it in the computer, he said. The computer then created a mathematical representation of the unique physical characteristics contained in the bifurcations, ridges and endings, called minutiae, of each fingerprint.
By October, 90,000 fingerprints were stored in the data base, Mr. Tanaka said. Inactive cases are purged daily. The system is designed to handle up to one million fingerprints, he said.
Now, when new applicants come into the welfare office, they are asked to give their fingerprints, which are sent to the main computer for analysis. If the prints do not match, the applicant proceeds through the system, Mr. Tanaka said. If a print matches, the person is confronted immediately; most withdraw their applications at once. Only one applicant pressed his case; he lost, Mr. Tanaka said.
After the system went into effect, 3,021 people refused to be fingerprinted and dropped out of the welfare system in the first four months, said Lisa Nunez, chief of computer services at the welfare department. Another 242 people were denied benefits because they had applied at more than one office, she said. This saved taxpayers $5.4 million in the first six months of the program.
In January of this year, Ms. Nunez said, 26 people were caught cheating and 59 refused to be fingerprinted, so the savings continue.
Mr. Tanaka said he hoped to extend the program to other services in his department, including Aid to Families with Dependent Children and the food stamps program. About 300,000 adults who receive such benefits would be fingerprinted, he said.
Most clients do not mind the system, said Shirley Christensen, director of the Rancho Park Social Services office, where Mr. Dunlap applied for assistance on Friday. "Anyway, honest people have nothing to worry, about so it's not an intrusion," he said.
 
Says Data Are Not Shared
 But Jennifer W., a young woman who asked that her last name not be used, thought differently. "I think it's kind of scary to be fingerprinted," she said. "Like government gets closer and closer. I'm wondering, if someone wanted to hunt me down, could they use this fingerprint? Could they get it without my permission?"
Mr. Tanaka said: "So far, we have not gotten any legal challenges. My system is to prevent duplicate services and fraud. The data are not shared."
But that is a promise that Mr. Tanaka may not be able to keep, said Janlori Goldman, director of the American Civil Liberties Union privacy and technology project in Washington. "Once a data base like this is created, the temptation to use it for other purposes is irresistible," she said. "People are right to be afraid."
Meanwhile, some welfare applicants are already looking for ways to foil the fingerprint system, Mr. Tanaka said. They put glue on their fingers to blur the prints, he said. Others come in dressed as a woman one week and as a man the next week, hoping that male and female prints are processed separately. But as far as he knows, Mr. Tanaka said, such tricks have not worked.

HEADLINE: Farmers in West May Sell Something More Valuable Than Any Crop: Water

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLYTHE, Calif.

 BODY:
Even as six years of drought turned lawns brown and forced urban Californians to take shorter showers, the farmers in the Palo Verde Valley had plenty of water to go on irrigating such thirsty crops as alfalfa and cotton. And they jealously guarded their rights to cheap Federal water from the Colorado River.
But some profound changes are about to come to this valley between the McCoy and the Dome Rock mountains along the rugged Arizona border. If all goes as planned, nearly a quarter of the valley's acreage will go fallow starting Aug. 1, and, in a two-year experiment, the water saved will be sold to people in urban areas hundreds of miles away. 
 Slowly, with some reluctance, farmers are beginning to loosen their historic grip on water in the West, transferring some of their supplies to the fast-growing cities and industries -- for a price. Such transfers are expected to be an important element of a broad long-range water plan for California to be unveiled April 6 by Gov. Pete Wilson.
The trend has been promoted by an odd twist of Reagan-era deregulation, which has made allies of environmental and urban interests in creating a partial free market in water so that it flows to where it has the most value.
 
Seeds of Unease
 If the trend builds, it could have profound implications, accelerating the already rapid urbanization of agricultural lands that in California produce half the nation's fruits and vegetables. The prospect is stirring unease among farm towns, farm laborers and sellers of seeds, insecticides, tractors and other agricultural needs.
"There's a fairly dramatic change taking place -- broad support has developed quickly for agricultural water transfers," said Duane L. Georgeson, assistant general manager of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, the powerful agency that plans to buy the water from Blythe. The Met, as it is called, sells water to utilities and communities that are home to 15 million people from Ventura to the Mexican border.
The reasons for the shift are rooted in several factors, including mounting political pressure for more urban water, rising public perception that farmers squander water it on low-value surplus crops, concern over damage to chinook salmon fisheries and other environmental harm from years of drought, and low crop prices. Farmers now use more than 80 percent of the available surface water in California that is not set aside for natural resources or does not flow to the ocean.
These are among the many signs of an emerging new water policy:
*Bills are pending in Congress and the California Legislature to permit or encourage such transfers and revise Federal allocation policy in California.
*Governor Wilson recently called on the Federal Government to cede control of the vast Central Valley Project, which provides 20 percent of the state's water, so that it could be merged with the State Water Project. Nearly everyone, including Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., agrees that this is a sensible idea, but the financial and other details of such a transfer will be difficult to negotiate.
*Top leaders of California agricultural, municipal and environmental groups have been meeting in recent months in what is widely called the "Three-Way Dialogue," trying to reach a new consensus. Participants say it has thus far produced more dialogue than consensus.
Just where all this comes out is uncertain at this point, but, Governor Wilson said in a recent interview, "Agricultural users will undoubtedly get a smaller slice of the pie." The Governor is at the focal point of a bitter political battle. He has said that he does not want a plan that will result in decades of lawsuits, but environmentalists have said that the Republican Governor has been too beholden to wealthy farm interests and has tried to derail Congressional action that would substantially reduce agricultural water rights.
 
Drought Loosens Grip
 Paradoxically, all this happens as winter and spring storms have swept the West. The once-dun countryside from Sacramento to the deserts has turned green with chapparal and grasses. The drought appears to have ended around Santa Barbara on the once-parched central coast, and Los Angeles and other cities are relaxing water-use restrictions.
But even without drought, pressures persist, both because of a fast-growing population and the demands of environmental laws governing clean water and endangered species. California's population is expected to grow from 30 million today to 41 million within 20 years. If current use patterns remain unchanged, California faces a water shortage of four to six million acre-feet a year for the next 20 years. (An acre-foot is 325,900 gallons, or roughly enough to supply two typical households for a year.)
California will have to meet this demand without additional supplies because there is little money for dams, and neighboring states fiercely resist efforts to take their water.
A result is a breakdown of the historic alliance between urban and agricultural interests in pressing for more dams and reservoirs. On the other side have been the environmentalists, who have long charged that excessive irrigation has caused environmental damage to the Sacramento Delta, San Francisco Bay and other wetlands.
 
'An Unholy Alliance'
 "Throughout history, agricultural and urban interests have been in an unholy alliance to insure everybody got what they wanted, at the expense of the environment; that alliance is starting to break down," said David Behar, executive director of the Bay Institute of San Francisco, one of 23 environmental and fishing-industry groups in Share the Water, a coalition to bring pressure to revamp the laws governing the Central Valley Project.
Though resistant, farm interests have recognized the new political realities. "Change is inevitable," said Jerald Butchert, general manager of the Westlands Water District. The largest irrigation agency in California, the district supplies Federal water to 600,000 acres of farmland on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley near Fresno.
The fight is over how far change will go. Farmers won a skirmish on March 19, when the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources reported out an omnibus water bill. It was stripped of a far-reaching overhaul of the Central Valley Project advocated by the committee chairman, Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, both Democrats. Their proposal would have set aside 1.5 million acre-feet a year to repair ecological damage and encourage irrigators to sell a certain amount of water to cities or other areas of need.
Instead, the committee adopted a bill offered by Senator John Seymour of California, a Republican. His plan, backed by farmers and Governor Wilson, allows for such transfers, subject to veto of local water districts. It also provided no special allocation for fisheries, proposing instead to address ecological problems with new diversion dams and other construction.
 
Two Houses, Two Versions
 Senator Bradley plans to try to restore his version when the bill reaches the Senate floor this month or goes to a conference to resolve differences with a House version passed last year. The House version also encourages liberal water transfers under a plan devised by Representative George Miller, a Democrat who represents the rapidly growing counties east of Oakland. The bills would not eliminate water subsidies to farmers but would permit them to sell surplus water.
Any change is difficult because it involves revamping half a century of rights rooted in an earlier rural era. A system of 20 dams and 500 miles of aqueducts that harness the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers, the 57-year-old Central Valley Project delivers about eight million acre-feet of water, 85 percent of it to nearly 25,000 farms, in normal years. Depending on their contracts, the farms pay as little as $15 an acre-foot under 40-year contracts. Urban users elsewhere in the state pay $200 to $1,900 an acre-foot.
Environmentalists say the Bureau of Reclamation, which manages the project, has caused enormous damage. For example, only 191 chinook salmon returned to spawn in the Sacramento River for the winter run in 1991, compared with 2,422 in 1986 and 118,000 in 1968, contributing to a disastrous collapse of the Pacific salmon industry.
Certain environmentalists, notably Thomas J. Graff and John Kraut kraemer of the Environmental Defense Fund, have long championed water marketing to encourage conservation to make more water available for ecological protection. "Why have a low-value crop in a state where there's an increasing premium on water?" Mr. Krautkraemer said. "It doesn't make sense to allot water to irrigated pastures, which don't contribute a lot to the overall economy. If alfalfa is really that valuable, then they should be willing to pay more for water."
Urban interests have joined the chorus. Last September, the Bay Area Economic Forum, representing such companies as the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and water-needy computer and semiconductor makers in Silicon Valley, called for a regulated, market-based water-allocation system, similar to that of utilities which distribute natural gas or electricity. A report by the forum said the area's economic growth was threatened by water policies that have "undermined reliability, availability and quality."
Senator Bradley, chairman of the subcommittee on Water and Power, agrees. "California is a giant sponge," he said in an interview on a recent visit to Los Angeles. "Every year, the equivalent of the City of San Francisco moves to California. The state has a $760 billion economy, of which agriculture contributes only $20 billion. You cannot have 85 percent of the water continue to go to agriculture."
But others argue that water marketing is fraught with dangers. "Who holds the most money potentially controls the water," Dennis B. Underwood, Commissioner of the Bureau of Reclamation, said in a telephone interview from Washington. "First you take away from farmers, then small cities. Where does it stop?"
Farm interests argue that, indirectly, farming represents a much larger proportion of the economy than Mr. Bradley says. Stephen K. Hall, executive director of the California Farm Water Coalition, agreed that all water users will pay more but said that many farmers would be put out of business, with ripple effects on local economies. "There's a misguided notion that if farmers were forced to pay more for water, they'd use it more efficiently and California's water problems would disappear," he said.
Water transfers are not entirely untried. In the winter of 1991, at the height of the drought, the California Department of Water Resources created a "water bank" that bought water from farmers and resold it to urban users. But the heavy rains and snows of March 1991 depressed demand, and the bank cost taxpayers about $30 million.
Still, such efforts are the future, argues one top water expert, Lyle N. Hoag, director of California Urban Water Agencies, a trade group of the 11 largest urban-water providers. "We've got to get rid of the constraint 'Thou shall not sell water outside of a project area,' " he said. "The progressive farmers see the winds are changing."

HEADLINE: In Politics of Water, New Pioneers in West Are Vendors

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLYTHE, Calif.

 BODY:
Dana Fisher and Virgil Jones are pioneers in the new West. The two gray-haired farmers will soon find out whether they can do better by selling some of their water to Los Angeles and other cities than by growing crops.
The Palo Verde Valley illustrates the odd economics and the law of water in the arid West. The 300 farmers in the sparsely populated valley use about 400,000 acre-feet of water a year, roughly enough to supply a city of 250,000 people. 
 The water cannot be taken away from them. Water rights here date to 1873, when an Englishman, Thomas Blythe, brought commercial farming to a region that gets only an inch or two of rain a year, by diverting water from the Colorado River. When the Federal Bureau of Reclamation created the Lake Mead reservoir upriver in Nevada in 1936, the farmers in this valley, who are served by the Palo Verde Irrigation District, were first in line for water.
For several years, the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California has coveted some of this water for the 15 million people in the 300 communities it serves. The district already gets some Colorado River water, but under law enjoys a much lower priority than the farmers. And it stands to lose about half that under a 1963 United States Supreme Court ruling that allocated more water from the Colorado River to Arizona.
When Metropolitan officials first approached farmers here about selling some of their water, they demurred, fearing that their valley would suffer the fate of the Owens Valley along the eastern slope of the Sierra to the north. The City of Los Angeles bought up nearly all the farmland there for the water 70 years ago, then pumped it south to the city, turning the valley into a dust bowl.
But starting a few year ago, the farmers here began to sense that the politics of water were shifting. "We were concerned that as the urban areas' population grew, while they could not take our water away, they might dictate crops," Mr. Fisher said. "So we felt it would be better to work with them, to take some crops out for a while while we installed water-saving drip irrigation."
Each farmer would get $620 a year for each fallowed acre, up to a quarter of his land, in a two-year experiment. "That's better than what we could get now for most any crop," Mr. Jones said. Farmland here normally rents for about $250 an acre a year.
The farmers pay $45 to $50 an acre-foot for water, actually not for the water but for the cost of moving it. Since each acre uses about 4.6 acre-feet a year, the water district's offer amounts to about $135 an acre-foot, a good profit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Virgil Jones, left, and Dana Fisher, farmers in the Palo Verde Valley of California, will soon find out whether they can do better by selling some of their water to Los Angeles and other cities than by growing crops. The farmers view the sale of their water as just a test to measure the effect on the community's economy. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Car-Insurance Reform Bill Steers Claims Out of Court

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
A campaign to revise Connecticut's auto-insurance system is provoking debate across the state, especially in this city where insurance is king and its palaces line the roads to the statehouse.
Automobile-insurance reform is difficult at best, as other states have found. In New Jersey, sweeping changes enacted in 1990 by Gov. Jim Florio have had mixed results. The Governor says he has cut rates for good drivers, but insurers complain that the state has imposed unreasonable restrictions that make it hardly worthwhile to do business. 
 In Connecticut, changes intended to rein in rising premiums have pitted two influential groups against each other: the insurance industry, which dominates Hartford's business scene, and the state's lawyers. The groups have exchanged insults, with the lawyers accusing the insurers of trying to recoup losses suffered in 1980's real-estate investments that went sour, and the insurers claiming that lawyers have an obvious interest in fanning the flames of litigation, auto-related or otherwise.
The latest attempt at reform, which some lawyers insist on calling deform, made it through one legislative committee late last month only to be gutted by another. It is scheduled for a vote in the House of Representatives later this month.
 
Revision of 1974 Code
 The bill seeks to control costs through a revision of the no-fault coverage for injury liability that the state adopted in 1974. In return for that and other changes, insurance companies would be required to reduce premiums for two and a half years, beginning in 1995. Last year, a similar bill died in committee.
Connecticut is one of 12 states with no-fault insurance, in which a person surrenders the right to sue for injury and lost wages in exchange for prompt compensation of medical costs that do not exceed a set limit. No-fault coverage applies to both personal injury and property damage, but claims for personal injury have been escalating far faster than claims for property damage. Before no-fault insurance, in disputed cases, the parties had to go to court to determine which driver was at fault and to collect on injury claims.
The primary argument is over the appropriate limit, or threshold, beyond which a personal-injury lawsuit can be filed. That limit has not changed since Connecticut's no-fault law was passed, when the limit was set at $400. That means a person must have more than $400 in medical expenses after an accident before being able to sue.
"It means that even a minor accident, with minor injury, is able to get into court," said Ross Brown, a spokeswoman for the Insurance Association of Connecticut, a trade group based in Hartford. "We think that's one reason rates are going up."
Figures provided by the association show average rates have risen by 10 to 15 percent every year since 1984. The American Insurance Association, a national trade group, says that every insured car in Connecticut costs insurers an average of $196 because of injury-liability claims, compared with a national average of $116.
The bill under consideration, which was written by the new Insurance Commissioner, Robert Googins, originally proposed raising the threshold to $5,000. That is a figure many consider far too high. The latest version of the bill proposes a $2,250 threshold, which has won support in some quarters, but the Insurance Association of Connecticut, for one, no longer favors the bill because of the smaller figure..
Jay B. Levin, a lawyer representing the Coalition for Fairness in Auto Insurance Rates, cited other problems with the legislation. "This bill has been referred to in some quarters as a consumer-choice bill," he said, "but I think it is more accurately characterized as a consumer scam.
"To tell folks they can save on something that is a required part of their daily living, and then start whispering in their ear that all you have to do is surrender some of your critical rights that you have as a matter of law, then the economic exigencies are going to compel people to save those few dollars."
Mr. Googins said his bill was "designed to be a bill in the interests of the consumer," not intended to please the insurance industry or trial lawyers. "Obviously, I've done neither," he said.
Connecticut's premiums would be lowered by raising the threshold, said David Snyder, senior counsel with the American Insurance Association in Washington. With a $5,000 threshold, the savings would be about 17 percent, he said, compared with about 8 percent if it were $2,200.
The most effective way to keep claims out of court is to specify what kinds of injuries warrant litigation, rather than setting a monetary threshold, said Renee Carter, a no-fault insurance expert with the association in Washington. "New York is one state where no-fault works well," she said, because that is how the lines are drawn. Michigan and Florida have similar laws.
John Miletti, counsel to the Insurance Association of Connecticut, said he did not think such specificity would be possible, "given the current structure of this legislature."
 
Claims on Multiple Policies
 Another issue is whether to continue the practice known as "stacking," in which insurance policies held on several automobiles can be tapped by the policyholder after an accident with an uninsured driver involving only one of those automobiles.
For instance, suppose an owner of two cars has $100,000 of uninsured-motorist coverage on each. He is involved in an accident in one of the cars, and the driver of the other vehicle has no insurance. The owner is allowed to collect from the insurance on both of his cars.
"We are potentially exposed for recoveries up to the entire stacked amount," Ms. Brown said. The Googins bill proposes an end to stacking -- a proposal that is anathema to many lawyers.

HEADLINE: 2 Big Banks Settle Suit

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 5

 BODY:
Two of the biggest Western banks, Wells Fargo & Company and the First Interstate Bancorp, have agreed to settle a credit-card price-fixing lawsuit to avoid the cost of a trial. 
 The bank holding companies said Friday that they had agreed to pay $55 million to settle the class-action suit, dating from 1986, that contended they had agreed to fix interest rates on credit cards. The suit, filed in San Francisco Superior Court, was brought on behalf of four million consumers who had credit cards from the banks between 1982 and 1986. The agreement will go to a judge for approval on Monday.
Another bank, the BankAmerica Corporation, based in San Francisco, was also charged and has decided to go to trial, a spokesman for the bank said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Banks Still Face Loan Problems

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
THE rally in bank stocks, with the share price of many companies doubling last year, has stalled in the last month, as investors wait for first-quarter earnings reports to be issued this week. They hope to see evidence that banks' losses from commercial real estate loans are abating.
But the problems of Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the giant Canadian real estate developer negotiating new terms for $12 billion it owes banks, are a reminder that the commercial real estate market remains depressed and is still claiming victims. 
 While many banks reported declines late last year in badly delinquent loans or real estate acquired through foreclosure, that improvement does not necessarily mean profits will improve.
"Bank losses from bad loans will stay high," said John D. Leonard, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers, "though not so high as the past few years when banks were still catching up" to the weakening real estate market.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported that nonperforming loans plus real estate acquired through foreclosure fell by nearly $2.9 billion for all banks in the fourth quarter of 1991, but remained higher than in any period before 1991. Despite that improvement, profits excluding gains on securities declined steadily, as loan demand remained weak and banks charged off $9.4 billion of loans as losses, a record for any quarter.
John B. McCoy, chairman of the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, and Hugh L. McColl, chairman of Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., both said recently that there were signs of a rise in loan demand. Banc One stock ended last week at $46, compared with a 52-week low of $31 and a high of $50. Nationsbank ended at $44.125, near its yearly high of $48.125 but off its low of $33.
Still, banking analysts do not expect the benefits of growth from issuing new loans to overshadow the pain of continued high loan losses.
"The bear market in commercial real estate continues," said David G. Shulman, an equity strategist at Salomon Brothers. At a meeting of banking analysts on March 26, he said it would be several years before there was an appreciable decline in vacancy rates, even if the economy strengthened and grew at a 2.5 or 3 percent rate after inflation.
Because of the danger that real estate values could continue to fall, or that developers who are now paying their loans could default, Salomon Brothers is limiting its recommended bank stocks to companies that offer prospects for earnings growth even without a drop in loan losses.
Recommended companies are typically those that avoided making bad loans in the first place, like Norwest of Minneapolis, which ended last week at $35.50 a share, near its yearly high of $38.125 and off its low of $24.875; NBD Bancorp, owner of the National Bank of Detroit, $27.875 compared with $31.625 and $22.75; Comerica, also in Detroit, $55 compared with $60.50 and $35.125; BankAmerica, San Francisco, $41 compared with $46.25 and $30.625; Republic New York, $40.625 compared with $49.25 and $37.125, and Bankers Trust, $52.625 compared with $68 and $41.50.
Although losses on commercial real estate loans have already been severe, Mr. Shulman said more losses are ahead. Charles L. Coltman, chief credit officer at Corestates Financial, owner of the Philadelphia National Bank, estimated that in many cases, commercial real estate loans were worth as little as 50 cents on the dollar if a bank wanted to sell loans or buildings quickly.
Many analysts agree that banks still have a way to go in recognizing their losses. "In almost every situation I have worked, the bank has underestimated the reserve that is required for a bad loan or the amount by which the price of the property must be reduced if it is to be sold," said Robert C. MacPhee, president of Real Estate Asset Specialists, a San Francisco bank advisory concern.
While the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency in charge of selling assets of failed savings and loans, still holds hundreds of billions of dollars in assets, and tenants will be demanding lower rents when their leases expire, Mr. MacPhee said, "The commercial real estate market remains very muddled, and it is hard for banks to have any real understanding of their losses."
The problem of additional loans turning sour as banks solve their problems is another difficulty.
At MNC Financial in Baltimore, owner of the Maryland National Bank, a 150-person department was created to handle bad real estate loans and was able to sell or reorganize an average of $200 million of loans or buildings a quarter during 1991. But almost as fast as it solved problems, others emerged, so that by the end of 1991, the company had reduced its holdings of badly delinquent loans or real estate acquired by foreclosure by only $110 million from a year earlier, to $1.77 billion.
The new problems "are cropping up at a slower rate," said Daniel G. Finney, senior vice president at MNC, which ended last week at $7 a share, compared with a yearly high of $9.125 and a low of $3. "But we are not confident enough about the market to say the slowdown will continue."

HEADLINE: Brown and Clinton And Their Pursuit Of the Arts World

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The manner in which Edmund G. Brown Jr. and Gov. Bill Clinton courted New York's arts world is hardly likely to be the deciding issue in tomorrow's turbulent and vitriolic Democratic Presidential primary here, but it does provide an illuminating contrast between the two major candidates and their views of the arts.
Last Tuesday night, Mr. Brown, whose impromptu campaign has itself become an issue, visited a group of artists at a Brooklyn loft. The meeting might as well have been clandestine. No one at Brown headquarters, in New York or in California, seemed to know who the artists were or what had been discussed. No "Artists for Brown" committee was announced, and no one connected with him seemed to know whether anything so formal was even contemplated. 
Asked about the nonevent, Susan Bunn, Mr. Brown's New York press secretary, said: "If something's already integrated and in place, why do you need a committee to organize it? This is a visionary campaign."
 
Gathering at the Harvard Club
 In contrast, back in January, well before Governor Clinton's campaign became an exercise in damage control, several of his top aides launched a conventional and well-planned drive to capture New York's intellectuals and artists. They held an all-day seminar at the Harvard Club, where prominent local Democrats were formed into panels and asked to enlighten the Clinton staff on issues ranging from the economy and health care to the arts.
Afterward, Bruce Reed, who holds the title of deputy campaign manager for policy for the Clinton campaign, asked Donald Blinken, a former chairman of the State University of New York who had participated in the arts panel, to help the campaign formulate an arts policy.
Mr. Blinken, an investment banker who helped develop an arts policy for the Dukakis campaign four years ago, immediately began a confidential survey of arts leaders around the East Coast, and on the basis of the returns made his recommendations to Governor Clinton. Whatever comes of his report, a host of cultural leaders were flattered by having had their opinions respectfully solicited.
As the campaign has grown more clamorous, Governor Clinton has often seemed like a camel caught in tent ropes, and Mr. Brown like a rider on a runaway horse. But the basic character of their campaigns, like their attitude toward the arts, has remained unchanged. Governor Clinton has been measured in his approach, while Mr. Brown has gone all-out.
 
Differ Over the Endowment
 They differ, for instance, in their support for the National Endowment for the Arts, which has become a political flashpoint since February, when President Bush dismissed its chairman, John E. Frohnmayer.
Mr. Brown believes in giving the arts endowment "full support independent of the content of the art it supports," said Tom Pier, Mr. Brown's national press secretary.
Governor Clinton said in a statement released by his campaign headquarters, "While I believe that publicly funded projects should strive to reflect the values that most Americans share, I strongly support and will defend freedom of speech and artistic expression."
Mr. Reed explained that while Governor Clinton "would never allow outside pressure to infringe the basic freedom of artists," he conceded that finding a way to protect both the rights of artists and of the public is "one of the toughest issues we face today."
 
The Brown Record
 Governor Brown's reputation as both a miracle worker and an eccentric arose in large part because of his involvement with the arts during his two terms as Governor of California. Shortly after his election in 1974, Governor Brown persuaded the State Legislature to abolish the California Arts Commission, which had been created in 1963 when his father was Governor. In its place, they created the California Arts Council with a broad legislative mandate and a $3.7 million budget, nearly four times that of its predecessor.
Governor Brown shaped the agency by appointing artists, many of them black, Asian or Hispanic, to the council's grants-making body. A result, said Peter Coyote, an actor who served as a member of the council and later its chairman, was the awarding of many pioneering grants, and "the activation of the whole state so that each county worked out a plan for its own cultural development."
But the arts council drew criticism, both for its public image and specific grants. "I had six rings in my ear and lived in a truck when Jerry Brown picked me," said Mr. Coyote. "We created a lot of divisiveness."
 
The Whale-Whistle Episode
 One of the grants widely criticized as frivolous, especially as the Proposition 13 tax revolt gathered steam in the spring of 1978, subsidized the "whale whistle," a device thought to be capable of warning porpoises to steer clear of tuna nets. For a time, a prototype was displayed in the Governor's office.
Such targets of ridicule, together with mockery of Governor Brown's interest in such matters as the possibility of communication with dolphins, prompted the State Legislature in 1978 to slash the art council's budget to $2 million from $4 million.
Only months after suffering the backlash of Proposition 13, however, he asked the Legislature to sextuple the appropriation for the arts council, to $12 million. Surprisingly, he got $8.7 million, and by 1981 nearly $13 million, which made California second only to New York in the amount it spent on the arts.
Then and now, Mr. Brown's friends say, he is more interested in the ideas than the objects or occasions of art. "He's not the kind who buys paintings or goes to a ballet opening," said William B. Cook, who became director of the California Arts Council in 1979. "You're more likely to find Jerry at a North Beach coffee house in San Francisco talking to a poet."
Other admirers point to his efforts to secure passage of the Resale Royalties Act, which provides that artists receive a 5 percent royalty on the re-sale of their work, and the Art in Public Buildings Act, which requires builders to dedicate 1 percent of the capital cost of a state project to art.
If Mr. Brown emphasizes the arts as a source of ideas for government and society, to Governor Clinton they have economic utility. Both he and his wife, Hillary, have sought to promote Arkansas crafts such as the making of quilts, split-oak baskets and dulcimers as a means of economic development for the state.
Joan W. Baldridge, a Clinton appointee who is director of the Department of Arkansas Heritage, credits Governor Clinton with having been the driving force behind the successful expansion of an annual blues festival in Helena into a multi-disciplinary arts festival based at the Delta Cultural Center in a restored Union Pacific railroad depot.
 
Increase Amid the Decreases
 Governor Clinton, also, has pressed his State Legislature to increase the arts budget. William Puppione, the present director of the council, said: "He gave us an increase of $9,000 this year specifically for grants to artists. That doesn't sound like much, but when 30 to 40 percent decreases were common for other agencies, it shows you where his heart is."
Other supporters applaud Governor Clinton's insistence that his revision of the state's school system include making the study of the arts a graduation requirement. Since 1983, the budget for music and arts teachers in the public school system has increased 35 percent.
His personal taste in the arts is decidedly middle-of-the-road. His friends say he enjoys dropping in on a high school band concert and playing along on the saxophone, and curling up with a murder mystery by P. D. James. His favorite book, friends say, is Gabriel Garcia Marquez's "One Hundred Years of Solitude."
Before the campaign, the Clintons were frequently seen at performances of Ballet Arkansas in Little Rock. Hillary Clinton serves on the company's advisory board, and their daughter, Chelsea, is a member of the junior company. "They're very supportive," said Phillip Quick, the executive director of Ballet Arkansas. "Like all of our parents, they want the best for their kid."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
