HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Union Cuts Demand on Contract

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
On the fifth day of a potentially destructive strike, the National Hockey League's civil war of words changed battlegrounds yesterday, from Toronto to New York, as team owners gathered for today's critical board of governors meeting at the Plaza Hotel and the union offered another proposal for settlement of a deadlock that threatens the Stanley Cup playoffs.
The N.H.L.'s president, John A. Ziegler Jr., and the executive director of the Players Association, Bob Goodenow, met into the evening. Goodenow said afterward that he had offered the owners a contract that would meet one of their major demands. 
 The new offer, Goodenow said, would cover the current season, plus the next two, with the possibility for a "re-opener clause based on economic conditions" after next season.
 
Owners Want 1-Year Deal
 The owners have been demanding only a one-year deal, for the season of 1992-93, because, they say, they are losing money and must form a closer economic partnership with the players.
"We need to form a study group to look at the business of hockey in great detail," Goodenow said, without being specific about what circumstances would trigger a re-opening of the contract after one more season. "The re-opener is based on a review of what the study group from either side might find. We've made a proposal in a key area."
Another key area is that of licensing for revenue from trading cards. The players now get about $10 million per season for this and they use it to finance the union. Although such revenue has gone to the players for more than 20 years, the owners now want the players to negotiate for it. Some players have said they view this as an attempt to break the union. Goodenow said yesterday that the owners "have been unresponsive to our positioning on licensing."
Mike Gartner of the Rangers, a member of the union's bargaining committee, said the revenue from the hockey cards "is probably the single most important issue."
 
'Not Weakening
 The players have also made concessions on the issue of free-agent mobility and equalization between teams that sign them. For months, the players have said this was their top issue. Asked if the union seems to backing off, Goodenow replied: "Our position isn't weakening. We're trying to be responsible to the areas of concern for the owners."
In a statement released by his office, Ziegler said, "I am duty-bound to take whatever new ideas" -- to the board -- "and will do so in this case but I will do so without endorsement."
The strike began last Wednesday, when the players voted by 560-4 to begin the first walkout in the 75-year history of the league.
The regular season was to have ended yesterday and the playoffs were to have begun on Wednesday. If no settlement is reached soon, both sides agree that it will be difficult to salvage the full two months of the post-season playoffs, which begin with 16 teams and generate gross revenues of between $50 million and $100 million.
The owners say they will lose $9 million this season after making a $125 million profit in the previous three. The players say the owners will make $24 million this season.
Barry Shenkarow, the owner of the Winnipeg Jets, who also is a member of the negotiating committee, said Goodenow "took a calculated gamble" by leading a strike when he did.
"Well, you play roulette, that's what happens," Shenkarow said. "You put your coin down on number 24 and, well, your number didn't come up, but you spent your wife's last dollar.
"Whoever fed the players this thing of leverage has led them astray. If they had the leverage, why isn't it working? We're in a big dilemma. It's a really sad situation."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Why No One Fixes What Doesn't Seem Broken

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

The Culture of Contentment
By John Kenneth Galbraith
 195 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $22.95. 
 At the opening of his elliptically acerbic critique of America's current economic state, "The Culture of Contentment," John Kenneth Galbraith observes that one of the most enduring lessons of history "is that individuals and communities that are favored in their economic, social and political condition attribute social virtue and political durability to that which they themselves enjoy."
For the past decade or so, Mr. Galbraith argues, the majority of voting Americans have enjoyed a prosperity based on government nonintervention in the form of diminished regulation and reduced income taxes, particularly for the wealthy. We have attributed virtue to that nonintervention and idealized it as a turning away from the welfare state and a return to a purer form of laissez-faire capitalism.
But in fact, says Mr. Galbraith, the state's nonintervention has been highly selective. Washington may have cut back on rebuilding the nation's public works and decreased its investment in the poor and unemployed, but it has continued to create jobs for those connected with the military sector, and it has happily seen to the welfare of the scandal-ridden savings-and-loan associations.
Moreover, Mr. Galbraith insists, to the extent that we have unleashed capitalism we have also set free its inherently self-destructive tendencies, as demonstrated by the frenzy of wasteful corporate takeover activity in the 1980's and by what he sees as the catastrophic deregulation of the airline industry. In the short run, a community of contented grasshoppers continues to frolic. In the long run, winter is likely to set in.
It is difficult to capture in this space the scope of Mr. Galbraith's deadpan wit. One tiny sample: on why high interest rates favor the rich, he writes: "It is an indubitably inescapable fact that those who have money to lend are likely to have more money than those who do not have money to lend -- an economic truth that stands on a par with the unimpeachable observation attributed to Calvin Coolidge that when many people are out of work, unemployment results."
Yet his highly oblique prose, which rolls by like the thunder of a distant storm, makes everything seem of a piece. Part of what enables him to fit it all together so compactly is his compression of ideas he developed at length in such previous books of his as "The Great Crash, 1929," "The Affluent Society" and "The New Industrial State." In "The Culture of Contentment," he has summed up a lifetime's ballet in a single soft-shoe dance.
Indeed so streamlined is his analysis here that it rounds the edges off such jagged controversies as the true menace of Communism during the past half-century, which he appears to dismiss as inconsequential (though paradoxically he celebrates the collapse of the Soviet bloc as "the greatest transformation on the world scene in the last half century and more"), or the role of the New Deal in terminating the Great Depression, which he unquestioningly affirms (though in general he believes that complex forces of history, not single figures like Franklin D. Roosevelt, are what intervene to alter the destinies of nations).
And then having set the reader up for an apocalyptic bang, his book ends with something of a whimper. What does he see as likely to bring to an end this country's present debilitating state of contentment, and to make it possible once again to regulate the economy through Keynesian fiscal policy in general and in particular higher taxes?
"The present age of contentment will come to an end only when and if the adverse developments that it fosters challenge the sense of comfortable well-being." As well as a strong and successful political appeal to the discontented who now don't bother to vote in national elections, Mr. Galbraith sees three plausible possibilities for change to happen. "They are: widespread economic disaster, adverse military action that is associated with international misadventure, and eruption of an angry underclass."
He continues: "All could, in fact, come together. A deep recession could cause stronger discontent in the areas of urban disaster in the aftermath of some military misadventure in which, in the nature of the modern armed forces, the unfortunate were disproportionately engaged. This could, indeed, be at grave cost to contentment."
Yet having pointed out such dangers, he seems to throw up his hands in weariness: "But, as sufficiently established, it is not in the nature of contentment that such eventualities, however persuasively described, be other than ignored. Contentment sets aside that which, in the longer view, disturbs contentment; it holds firmly to the thought that the long run may never come."
As for the future of the American economy: the probability "is more gradual but more definitive stasis. This is already well under way as American manufacturing industry and the economy generally concede to the superior economic performance of other nations, principally Japan, Germany and the countries of the Pacific Rim."
So Mr. Galbraith concludes that it is most unlikely that from the power of his prose "must proceed the remedial action." That may well be the case. But the pessimistic vision of "The Culture of Contentment" must certainly give its readers pause. And if gloom can ever be mitigated by the exercise of wit, then Mr. Galbraith has us smile at the dismalness of our prospects.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
It Isn't Dollars, the Players Maintain

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
Top-ranking members of the striking Players Association, gathered in New York to monitor today's pivotal meeting of the National Hockey League board of governors, told reporters yesterday that they felt their strike was no longer about dollars, but about dignity.
"All the economic issues have been agreed to," was the assessment of Mike Gartner, the Ranger forward and a member of the union's negotiating committee. "We want to have a wedding. We just don't want it to be a shotgun wedding." 
 Five players appeared for a small news conference yesterday at a midtown hotel, at the urging of Ranger star Mark Messier, who said there had been too much "player-bashing" by the public since the strike began last Wednesday. The players insisted that they had been more than reasonable with their latest compromise proposal, which will be discussed by the owners today at the Plaza Hotel.
If this deal fails, they said, there is not much more they can do.
"If it's not decided now, then will it be never?" said Mike Liut of the Capitals. "Everybody's a little afraid. We are close enough to either do it or not do it. That's why we haven't considered a mediator. A mediator isn't going to volley any new issues around."
 
Two Issues
 At this stage of the negotiations, there appear to be only two issues remaining as obstacles between the two sides: percentage of licensing fees and length of the new collective bargaining agreement. But the players wondered aloud yesterday whether the owners weren't trying to invent new issues to replace those that already had been settled, in order to weaken or break the union.
"At times it has felt like the c.b.a. wasn't the issue," Bruin Andy Moog said of the collective bargaining agreement. "It felt like something else was up not related at all to the c.b.a. There was always another stumbling block, but maybe that was just the nature of the agreement."
The issue of free agency appears to have been all but settled in discussions between the N.H.L.'s president, John A. Ziegler Jr., and the executive director of the Players Association, Bob Goodenow. The only changes between the players' proposed free-agency rules and the ones in effect under the old agreement involve relatively minor compensation technicalities.
 
Concern About Rank and File
 Liut said there was a question as to whether the rank-and-file players would approve the free-agency proposal as submitted by the union's leadership.
"They weren't thrilled with the package to start with," Liut said, "and we haven't made any improvements."
The players remained steadfast on the issue of licensing and trading-card revenues, which Liut called "the lifeblood of the Players Association."
"It shouldn't even be an issue," said Bryan Trottier, the president of the Players Association. "The players understand the money is ours."
Any new collective bargaining agreement would be retroactive to the start of this season, when the old agreement expired. The players are seeking a three-year deal instead of the two-year deal offered by the owners.
"The owners say they're looking to revamp the business of hockey, but that's vague," Liut said. "Twelve months is not long enough to come up with a new model."
Goodenow, and the union's negotiating committee, will be available today in New York if the owners at the board of governors meeting invite them to discuss the proposals. If talks fall through, the players said, it could possibly mark the beginning of the end of hope for a settlement.
"We're not trying to destroy the owners," Trottier said. "But something has to give."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mark Messier of the Rangers at news conference called by Players Association leaders yesterday at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Clinton: Challenges on Taxes

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ


GRAPHIC: Television script: "You have to wonder about Jerry Brown. First, he didn't tell the truth about his tax plan. It will triple taxes on the poor and raise taxes on the middle class. Senator Moynihan said it would put a silver bullet through the heart of Social Security.
Chart: "Clinton: Challenges on Taxes"
"Now Brown's not telling the truth about his own record. CNN found his ad claim is just plain wrong. He raised taxes in California and left the state with a huge deficit.
"And he's not telling the truth about Bill Clinton's civil rights record. An outstanding record of fighting against bigotry and hatred of any kind.
"Now you know the truth, and the truth is, we just can't believe Jerry Brown." (Producer: Great American Media Inc., Washington.)
On the screen: Photo of Edmund G. Brown Jr., then words repeating and emphasizing passages from the script, including, "left the state with a $1.5 billion deficit." Images of Gov. Bill Clinton shaking hands with people, talking with mothers and children.
Accuracy: The claim of a tripling taxes on the poor and increased taxes for the middle class under Mr. Brown's plan is based on a study by Citizens for Tax Justice. Analyses by the Brown campaign and by some other economists dispute the conclusion. It is true that California had a budget deficit exceeding $1 billion by the time Mr. Brown left office.
Whether Mr. Clinton has an "outstanding" civil rights record is arguable. He has made strides on civil rights, but by most measures his achievements are no better than those of many other governors. More blacks and women have been appointed to boards, commissions and departments than under any other Arkansas governor. But Arkansas is one of only nine states with no law against discrimination in the sale and rental of housing, and one of only two states with no civil rights bill. Mr. Clinton supported such a bill in last year's Legislature, but it lost despite his backing.
 Scorecard: The victim of character issues himself throughout the campaign, Mr. Clinton in this advertisement is trying to counter that by raising a character question against Mr. Brown, in effect accusing him of deceit. At the same time, he is attempting to plant doubts about Mr. Brown's economic stewardship.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Clinton's Promise

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
New Yorkers have the power to destroy one of the most promising Presidential candidates in decades. Or they can give Bill Clinton a chance to be heard fully and clearly for the remainder of this campaign.
More than anyone now on the national scene, the Governor from Arkansas could be what we most need: a Great Experimenter in foreign and domestic policy. 
 No one has good answers for the kind of world descending on us, nor for the complexities of health and education in post-industrial societies.
A leader through this haze and maze must be committed to solutions, as are Democrats, and possessed of a practical skepticism about means, as are Republicans. Such a leader has to be a bleeding-heart conservative, a bold experimenter like Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman and John Kennedy.
To get a sense of these qualities in Mr. Clinton, just compare the world he talked about in his foreign policy speech last week with the worlds of Jerry Brown and George Bush.
The world sketched, stingily, by Mr. Brown seems to be a very simple place inhabited by destructive environmental Martians -- and little else.
Mr. Bush's world seems still peopled by dictators like the Chinese whom he wants to protect and tyrants like President Assad of Syria whom he seeks to befriend. It is an old, crumbling chessboard where kings play with each other and are indifferent to their subjects.
Mr. Clinton does not pretend to understand or describe the world of the 21st century. Instead, he concentrates on what he does know and on what really matters -- on people, their problems and aspirations.
Unlike Mr. Bush, he is committed to doing something dramatic to combat global warming. But he is not bound to particular actions regardless of cost and before clearer remedies are at hand, unlike Mr. Brown.
Unlike Mr. Bush, Mr. Clinton still worries about U.S. energy security and dependence on Persian Gulf oil. But he is still searching for politically palatable solutions like increased gas taxes, unlike Mr. Brown, who never seems troubled by political realities.
Unlike Mr. Bush, who would keep U.S. military spending near current levels and have Americans police the world alone, Mr. Clinton would make significant cuts in the Pentagon budget and stress the need for collective military action against aggression. Unlike Mr. Brown, he would do so with a scalpel, not with a meat cleaver.
Above all, Mr. Clinton's pronouncements center on the new and profound connections between foreign and domestic affairs. This connection is at the heart of modern diplomacy, and Mr. Clinton understands this. No nation, even one as mighty as the U.S., will be able to exercise sustained influence abroad unless it is economically strong at home, and Mr. Clinton understands this, too.
So Mr. Clinton speaks of America first, but never of America only.
In his treatment of domestic issues, he also brings commitment to ends and flexibility about means.
He accepts the necessity of a new national health care plan. But given the massive disagreements about means and costs, he talks about trying different approaches, about experimenting. He presses for reform in education. And while he highlights the idea of giving parents a choice of schools as a way to generate quality, he is open to other ideas as well.
Jerry Brown talks as if he really had all the answers -- and they are all simple. But mostly it seems that he has returned from his latest deep space probe as Jack D. Ripper, full of anger and nastiness. Mr. Bush, by contrast, seems to have no ideas and offers gimmicky slogans like "family values" and "Congressional reform." His new "change thing" is every bit as convincing as his "vision thing."
Bill Clinton may not have vision either. We do not yet know. But he does have energy, drive, ideas and an incredible fund of knowledge about domestic policy issues, second only to Senator Pat Moynihan of New York.
Yes, we all have questions and doubts about somebody labeled Slick Willie. And we should have lots of questions and doubts about Turnstile Jerry, No New Taxes Bush and a Paul Tsongas who so abruptly quit the campaign.
But Bill Clinton could be special, a bold experimenter in a world searching for answers. New Yorkers could defeat him or they could work through the tabloid garbage to glimpse that promise -- and put it to a further test.

HEADLINE: Don't Let the Campaign Stop You From Voting;
Clinton and Race

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The problem of racism in this country, and solutions to it, is more complicated than "Bill Clinton, in Black and White" (editorial, March 11) suggests. In my view, Gov. Bill Clinton's ability to win 75 percent of the black vote in Florida reflects massive outreach by him and his supporters through networks of black churches and community organizations -- shrewd traditional organizing, more than innovative approaches.
I agree with Mr. Clinton's observation that, in harsh times, the reactionary right wing preys on the fears of "the most economically insecure white people." I also agree that Americans "want to be part of a nation that's coming together, not coming apart." This untapped yearning for a leader who will make racial unity a priority has existed for a long time. But to state that dream is not to achieve it. A leader does more. 
 I urge Mr. Clinton to identify publicly the obstacles that keep us from unity -- lack of cultural understanding, the departure of major industries from our central cities, stereotype portrayals of people of color by the mass media and de facto segregation of most residential communities.
Mr. Clinton, having grown up in the South through the crucible of the civil rights era, and having toured the country during this campaign, could address us as no President has about the linkage between race and class, the distinction between institutional and personal racism, and about what his youth and later travels have taught him about race relations.
Frank talk brings political risk. Mr. Clinton will be urged to play it safe, to repeat the harmony cliches that have left us in conflict. But failure to speak the truth and support it with policies and programs would make him a timid nominee unable to win in November or a President unable to govern a polarized nation.
Governor Clinton has the potential to achieve much more. This voter awaits words of courage and commitment.
 
MICHAEL McQUILLAN
Brooklyn, March 11, 1992
